He was assigned to the First Motorcycle Pre cinct, Unionport Road and Bronx River Parkway, in the Bronx.

title: Murphy Defeats Brewer In Playoff and Wins Horse
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 1 (AP)Bob Murphy sank a six foot birdie putt on the first ex tra hole today to defeat Gay Brewer in a suddendeath play off and win the Kentucky thor oughbred procelebrity golf tournament.

title: F.C.C. AIDE RENDERS ORLANDO TV DECISION
description: WASHINGTON, June 1A Federal Communications Com mission hearing examiner ruled today that an Orlando, Fla., TV station tainted by scandal in the late 1950's and in dispute ever sincebe returned to its original license holder.

title: Pnompenh Stages an Alert
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 1  The new Cambodian Gov ernment, in an effort to infuse a sense of war emergency into this languid capital, put martial law into effect today and staged its first general alert. It lasted about an hour.

title: Martin H. Meaney Dead at 81; ExDeoutv Police Commissioner
description: Martin H. Meaney, a former deputy police commissioner and a retired Army brigadier gen eral, died at Kings County Hos pital on Sunday following a stroke. He was 81 years old and lived at 1224 East 32d Street in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: View From Mount Vernon
description: As the United States prepares to observe the two hundredth anniversary of its founding, there is cause for alarm over the present status and future pros pect of some of the great homes and sites of the Revolutionary era.

title: Advertising: Black Enterprise Sets Debut
description: Last December when plans were first announced for Black Enterprise, a monthly magazine to be directed to existing and potential Negro businessmen, the first issue was set for April.

title: Theater: The Nuns of Cherry Lane
DANCE RECITAL GIVEN BY ALICE CONDODINA
description: Alice Condodina, a member of the Jos Limon company who has turned to choreogra phy in the last two years, pre sented a concert with her own dance company last night at Kaufmann Concert Hall.

title: Mrs. Smith Warns of Repression
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 Senator Margaret Chase Smith spoke today of a national sickness pervading the land, and she denounced protesting student militants. She also attacked their critics in the Administration.

title: Jones Beach Opener July 1
description: Guy Lombardo and the Long Island State Park Commission announced yesterday that The Sound of Music, the Richard Rodgers  Oscar Hammerstein musical, will open July 1 at the Jones Beach Theater. Mr. Lom bardo said that the show al ready had an advance sale of $200,000, the largest in the 17 years he has been pro ducing at the outdoor theater.

title: Profit Mark Is Set By Seatrain Lines
Bridge:
description: The Goldman Pair Cham pionship, one of the two top rated events in the Eastern Regionals this week at the New York Hilton, was won Sunday by a littleknown Virginia partnership.

title: ALCOA WILL BUILD OKINAWA SMELTER
description: The Foreign Investment Board of the Ryukyu Islands announced yesterday in Naha, Okinawa, that it would permit the Aluminum Company of America to build a smelter in the islands, to be wholly owned by Alcoa.

title: Judge Issues an Injunction To Bar a Rock Festival
description: PLATTSBURGH, N. Y., June 1 (UPI)Justice Norman L. Har vey of the State Supreme Court today granted, by default, permanent injunction to pre vent FestIRama, Inc., from holding a rock music festival in Clinton County.

title: ADVANCES SHOWN IN AMEX TRADING
description: Stocks on the American Stock Exchange advanced along a broad front in active trading yesterday to close with good gains. Stocks showing advances totaled 715, out numbering by far the 198 de clines and the 186 issues that remained unchanged from Fri day's levels.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Coast Guard Chief Sworn
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe today swore in Adm. Chester R. Bender as the 14th commandant of the United States Coast Guard in ceremo nies aboard the cutter Gallatin.

title: Union for J. & L. Deal
description: PITTSBURGH, June 1The United Steelworkers Union withdrew its opposition to a proposed takeover of Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation by LingTemcoVought, Inc., fol lowing a secret meeting here with James J. Ling, Texas in dustrialist, yesterday, it was disclosed today.

title: Teamsters Break Custom and Back Rockefeller
description: Governor Kockefeller yester day picked up the support of a big segment of organized labor when New York Team sters Joint Council 16 endorsed bim for reelection.

title: U.S. Supports Thai Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (Reu ters)The United States sup ports in principle an offer by Thailand to send volun teer troops to Cambodia, the State Department said today. The department spokesman, Carl E. Bartch said that the offer, announced by Premier Thanom today, had been dis cussed with United States offi cials in Bangkok.

title: Nickel Gives the Final Word: He's Not in Governor's Race
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) Walter J. Hickel, the Secre tary of the Interior, confirmed today that he would not run again this year for Governor of Alaska, thereby ending ru mors that have persisted for weeks.

title: Douglas Backs Right Of a Judge to Live Own Life Off Bench
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)  Supreme Court Justice Wil liam O. Douglas, facing an im peachment threat for his non judicial activities, defended to day a judge's right to live his own life off the bench.

title: President Returns to Capital
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) President Nixon returned to Washington at 10:43 tonight.

title: Johnson, Bruins' Aide, Elevated to Coach
description: BOSTON, June 1 (UPI)The Boston Bruins named Torn Johnson, an assistant general manager, to succeed Harry Sinden today as coach of the Stanley Cup Champions.

title: State Clears Contractors of Mt. Vernon School
description: A report by the State Com mission of Investigation made public here yesterday clears the contractors who built the Traphagen Elementary School in Mount Vernon of charges that their work was danger ously deficient and that they charged excessive prices.

title: Yanks and Mets Renew Chases Against Royals, Braves Tonight
description: The Yankees returned to New York from the West yes terday to open an eightgame home stand tonight while the Mets headed South for a nine game trip  both in second place.

title: Feeney Says Baseball Clubs And Players Need Each Other
description: Charles S. (Chub) Feeney, president of the National Lea gue, was the only witness heard yesterday in Curt Flood's anti trust suit against baseball's re serve system. His testimony generally supported the views expressed last week by Com missioner Bowie Kuhn that the present system was necessary for baseball's health and fai?? to the players.

title: $50 Towaway Touch Brings an Ouch!
description: Fifty dollars left in the sav ing account, now it's gone and I still have to get up $25 for the summons, Barbara Kepple said yesterday.

title: Hong Kong Land Brings $800 a Sq. Ft.
description: HONG KONG, June 1A record price of more than $800 a square foot is being paid for a piece of land in an area that was a harbor anchorage when this British crown colony was founded in 1841.

title: 9 PUT ON PROBATION IN S.D.S. MOB CASE
description: CHICAGO, June 1 (AP)  Nine members of the Students for a Democratic Society pleaded guilty today to charges of aggravated battery and mob action stemming from a demon stration last September protest ing the start of the Conspiracy 7 trial.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 2. 1970

title: Zoe Caldwell Enjoying Colette and East 3d St.
description: When Zoe Caldwell was in rehearsal with her new hit, Colette, Lynn Fontanne asked her: Where are you playing?

title: Voting Rights in Danger
description: The House Rules Committee Is expected to take action today on extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965, one of the most effective civil rights laws ever passed. If the committee reports out the expected resolution, allowing the chamber simply to vote for or against the bill as amended by the Senate, there is a good chance that this crucially needed legislation will quickly be passed and sent on to the White House.

title: RICHARD B. JONES
description: Richard Brown Jones, founder and president of Economic Analyst, Inc., brokers, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 71 East 77th Street. He was 71 years old.

title: Suspect in 20 Bank Robberies Seized
description: An alleged bank robber, dubbed Dashing Dan by the Federal Bureau of Investigation fog his mannerly method of dealing with tellers, was ar rested outside his Queens home yesterday, less than an hour after he reportedly held up an other bank  his 20th job in three months.

title: Campaign Worker for Lindsay To Head Bureau of Standards
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday ap pointed Thomas F. Galvin, a Manhattan architect and an early Lindsay campaign work er, to head the city's Board of Standards and Appeals.

title: War Casualties
Chairman for General Host
description: Harris J. Ashton, president of the General Host Corpora tion since December, 1967, has been elected chairman and will continue as chief executive of ficer, the company announced yesterday. As chairman, he suc ceeds Richard C. Pistell, who re signed last week. Edward H. Hoornstra, vice president in charge of operations, was named president and chief op erating officer as well as a director.

title: Miss Hepburn Extends Rae of Coco to Aug. 1
description: Katharine Hepburn will re main in the title role of Coco, through Aug. 1, marking the second time she has extended her engagement in the musical.

title: Blair to Undergo Surgery For Damage to Nose, Eyes
description: ORANGE, Calif., June 1 (UPI) Paul Blair, Baltimore center fielder who was hit in the face by a pitched ball yesterday was scheduled to undergo sur gery for repair of multiple fractures of the nose and eye socket.

title: BENJAMIN J. HYMAN, SURGERY PROFESSOR
description: Dr. Benjamin J. Hyman, at tending surgeon and professor of surgery at the New York Polyclinic Hospital Division of French and Polyclinic Medical School and Health Center, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 480 Park Avenue. He was 65 years old.

title: Tanker Goes Down Off the Seychelles; Oil Threatens Isles
description: VICTORIA, Seychelles Is lands, June 1 (Reuters)A British Navy tanker sank nine miles off this British colony in the Indian Ocean today. Oil; seeping from the ship, the Ennerdale, threatened the fish ing industry in these islands as well as government plans for increased tourist trade.

title: ENGLISHMAN ROUTS MURRAY BY 7 AND 6
description: NEWCASTLE, Northern Ire land, June 1 (AP)Michael Bonallack of England, seeking a third consecutive title, ap peared to be the man to beat after an easy firstround vic tory today in the British Ama teur golf tournament.

title: Israelis Soberly Optimistic But Don't Feel Peace Is Near
description: The chances for peace in the Middle East appear more re mote than ever three years after the sixday ArabIsraeli war.

title: Police Link Sawchuk's Death to an Altercation, Plan to Question Stewart
2 GUNMEN STAGE $200,000 ROBBERY
description: Two gunmen took 200,000 in cash from an armored car making a delivery to a check cashing store in Brooklyn yes terday while 75 people looked on. The owner of the store was shot in the stomach.

title: Utilities Are Criticized on Research Funds
description: BOSTON, June 1The Chair man of the Federal Power Com mission told leaders of the na tion's electric utilities here to day that a National Energy Resources Council had to be created to develop a national plan to meet energy needs.

title: Pollikoff's Music Gallery Ends Season
description: There is something corn forting about the format of Max Pollikoff's Gallery of Musk in Our Time series, which ended Sunday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A.

title: Northwest Says Engine Trouble May Delay Start of 747 Service
description: Northwest Airlines said yes terday that engine trouble might force it to postpone the start of 747 service, which had been scheduled to begin June 15.

title: CIVIC GROUP HONORS CATLEDGE, CRONKITE
description: Walter Cronkite, news cor respondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, and Tur ner Catledge, retired vice presi dent of The New York Times have been named recipients of the Citizens Budget Commis sion Distinguished Service Award.

title: MODEL CITIES HELP IS DUE IN BROOKLYN
description: Brooklyn College and Cen tral Brooklyn Model Cities have agreed to use television and other media to meet the educa tional and community needs of Central Brooklyn residents.

title: Fanny May Results Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Federal National Mortgage Association will return to biweekly mortgage auctions, presi dent Oakley Hunter announced today.

title: Epithets Said to Slow Keino
description: According to one of the meet directors of the Dr. Martin Lu ther King International Free dom games, repeated racial epi thets from the field caused Kipchoge Keino of Kenya to slow down in his 1,500meterl race against Marty Liguori of Villanova last month.

title: INJURY SIDELINES WORLD CUP GOALIE
description: GUADALAJARA, Mexico June 1 (AP)  Rumania will take the field in its opening World Cup matc against Eng. land tomorrow without thei?? star goalkeeper, Necula Radu canu, one of the tallest men in the sport.

title: Vietcong Aide Accuses U.S.
description: PARIS, June 1 (Reuters)A spokesman for the Vietcong delegation to the peace talks here said today the announce ment that Thai troops would go to Cambodia confirmed his movement's accusations that the Americans were trying to form a puppet axis of Asian mercenary forces.

title: A Tour to Benefit 5 Towns Fund
description: WOODMERE, L. I., June 1 The special events and service division of the Five Towns United Fund will hold its annual house and garden tour on Wednesday from noon to 5 P.M.

title: John Norwood Will Marry Mrs. Ruth Havemeyer July 11
description: Mrs. Ruth Hill Havemeyer, daughter of Mrs. Frederick C. Havemeyer of New York and the late Mr. Havemeyer of Tuxedo Park, N. Y., and John Norwood, vice presi dent of Sport Magazine and a former amateur sports car driver, plan to be married in Southampton, L. L, on July 11. Mr. Norwood is the son of Mrs. Ford Park of Sonibel Island, Fla., and the late 0. Guy Norwood.

title: A Look at Monthly Magazines
description: For the first six months of this year, monthly magazines seem up or down in advertising pages depending on the category, according to figures in the May 27 issue of Magazine industry Newsletter.

title: Mrs. John Dewey's Estate Valued Up to $2Million
description: The widow of John Dewey the educator, left an estate valued between $1million and $2million, according to a four page, handwritten will filed in Surrogates' Court yesterday.

title: EGYPTIANS REDUCE TROOPS AT CANAL
description: CAIRO, June 1Gen. Moham, med Fawzi the Minister of War, has disclosed that Egyptian troops along the Suez Canal have been reduced to a minimum to protect them from heavy Israeli bombing while they train for the war of liberation.

title: Justices Rule U.S. Courts Can Enforce Strike Bans
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Supreme Court ruled 5 to 2 to day that Federal judges may bar workers from striking in violation of nostrike clauses of collective bargaining contracts.

title: STOREN, 34, NAMED HEAD OF COLONELS
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 1 (UPI)Mike Storen, American Basketball Association execu tive became the president and general manager of the Ken tucky Colonels today.

title: Books of The Times; Sociology (1): Up Against the Wall, Functionalists
description: Most Americans don't think much about theory, and about sociological theory, they think not at all: those who can, do; those who can't, theorize. One measure of Alvin W. Gouldner's enormous achievement in this book is that he proves that what we do depends to a large extent on our will ingness to accept the prevailing theoretical notion of the way things should be done. Another is that he demonstrates that pre vailing American social theory is full of holes. A third is that he makes the history of ideas read like a detective story: from the Utilitarianism of the 18th century to the Positivism (and Marxism) of the 19th to the Functionalism (and Stalinism) of the 20th; from SaintSimon to Comte to Durk heim to Weber to Pareto to Talcott Par sons, along one line of development; and from Marx to Lenin to Lukacs to Marcuse to Roger Garaudy and Adam Schaff, along the East European socialist express.

title: Nixon Aide Forecasts an Upturn
description: Federal Budget Director Robert P. Mayo came to Wall Street yesterday to reassure the investment community that the Nixon Administration was con fident of a business upturn in the second half of 1970.

title: Young Gonzales Helps the Old Pro Tune Up at Garden
description: The two tennis players stood on the same side of the net at Madison Square Garden yesterday hitting balls as a doubles team and separated only by the gray of time.

title: More Policemen to Be Assigned to Corruption
description: The number of policemen working to suppress corruption in the New York Police. De partment will be increased during the next few months, a high police official reported yesterday.

title: Auto Maker Confirms Its Discussions With German Concern
description: The General Motors Corpora tion confirmed yesterday that it was holding discussions with Wankel, G.m.b.H., of West Germany.

title: Libya and Foreign Oil Concerns In Test of Wills Over Payments
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, June 1 The revolutionary government of Libya has engaged the oil industry in a test of wills for enormous stakes.

title: Margaret Mead Gets Post
description: KINGSTON, R. L, June 1 (AP)  Margaret Mead, the anthro poligist, has been named first Alumni Association Distin guished Professor at the Uni versity of Rhode Island, the col lege announced yesterday. She will continue teaching at Co lumbia and Fordham.

title: GROMYKO IN FRANCE FOR A FIVEDAY VISIT
description: PARIS, June 1The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, began a fiveday visit to France today in the atmosphere of uneasy cordial ity that characterizes French Soviet relations.

title: TAMPA CUP IS WON BY MISS BUDWEISER
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 1 (AP) The national champion, Missl Budweiser, with Dean Cheno weth of Toledo, Ohio, driving, won the Tampa Sun Coast Cup unlimited hydroplane cham pionship today.

title: COURT AGAIN RULES WALINSKY ELIGIBLE
description: ALBANY, June 1 (AP)An appeals court unanimously up held today the right of Demo crat Adam Walinsky to run for New York State Attorney General.

title: SUN OIL INCREASES PRICES FOR CRUDE
description: The Sun Oil Company an nounced a price increase yes terday of 5 cents a barrel to $3.35 a barrel on its East Texas crude oil, effective immediately. Sunoco said the change was made to meet competitive con ditions in the East Texas field, and would affect production of about 12,000 barrels a day.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Anniversaries

title: They're Off (Slowly) at Monmouth as Computer Fails
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 1  A computer that developed a sudden case of amnesia con tributed to a bizarre opening today as Monmouth Park began its memoryfilled Centennial Anniversary meeting.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS STATE ON WELFARE
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Supreme Court overturned to day a lower court's holding that the New York Legislature violated the Constitution in 1969 by passing a welfare law that set higher benefits for welfare clients in New York City than in the rest of the state.

title: Bus Strike in California.
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 1 (UPI) A bus drivers strike jammed the San FranciscoOakland Bay Bridge with crawling traffic to day as 200,000 commuters lost their public transit.

title: NIXON ANSWERS BOY, BROTHER OF A HERO
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)  President Nixon has reas sured a 10yearold Maryland boy that the youth's brother, soldier killed in Vietnam, is in heaven.

title: A.C.L.U. WOULD HELP MADDOX TO PICKET
description: ATLANTA, June 1 (AP)The American Civil Liberties Union has offered Gov. Lester G. Maddox assistance in his de cision to picket two Atlanta newspapers this week.

title: Imperiale Bars Direct Support For Either Addonizio or Gibson
description: NEWARK, June 1  An thony Imperiale, the white mili tant councilman who ran third in the May 12 Mayoral election here, declined tonight to sup port either of the two candi dates who will compete in a runoff on June 16, but left ??o doubt that he thought his supporters should vote for in ??umbent Mayor Hugh J. Ad donizio.

title: Art Group Disrupts Museum Parley
description: Flourishing protest banners as they invaded the speak ers' rostrum, a group of more than 30 dissident artists broke up the staid business meeting of the American Association of Museums at the WaldorfAstoria yester day morning, and turned it into their own thing.

title: 12,000 IN 7 STATES STRIKE RCA PLANTS
description: PHILADELPHIA, Tuesday, June 2 (AP)  Picket lines formed outside RCA plants in Camden, N.J., and Lewiston, Me., shortly after midnight to day, as 12,000 members of the International Union of Electri cal, Radio and Machine Work ers struck 13 plants in seven states.

title: I.O.S. Declines to Comment
description: GENEVA, June 1An I.O.S. spokesman declined today to comment on reports of renewed interest by European banks and financial institutions in acquir ing a participation in the com pany.

title: Poverty Program Causing Dissent in Crown Heights
description: Officials from City Hall and the city's antipoverty agency are gingerly trying to settle complaints froM mem bers of the black community of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, that the Jewish community there is dominating the area's antipoverty program.

title: STUDY INDICATES STAR COLLISIONS
description: Observations with a giant, balloonborne telescope have shown the nucleus of a distant galaxy to be so compact that if, as many believe, it is a dense assembly of stars, they must be circling one another wildly, like a swarm of angry bees.

title: LINDSAY RENEWS CONTROLS PLEA
description: Mayor Lindsay urged Presi dent Nixon yesterday to impose immediate acrosstheboard mandatory controls on wages and prices for six to 12 months to halt inflation.

title: Policeman Is Shot to Death; Friend Accused of Murder
description: NEWARK, June 1 (UPI)  A woman was charged today with shooting her policeman boyfriend to death with five shots from his service revolver as he lay in bed in her apart ment.

title: Brewers Call Up Pitcher
description: MILWAUKEE, June 1 (UPI) The Milwaukee Brewers ac quired today the contract of Ray Peters, a righthanded pitcher from their Portland farm dub of the Pacific Coast League. Peters is the third pitcher called up from Portland in recent days. His acquisition puts the Brewers at the 25. player limit.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON SHOW AN ADVANCE
Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Shultz Orders a Washington Plan for Minorities
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz ordered into effect to day a Washington Plan that would require all contractors with Federal jobs in the na tion's capital to make good faith attempts to increase mi nority hiring on all their proj ects.

title: Lindsay Plans to Skip Annual G.O.P. Dinner
description: For the first time since he was elected Mayor in 1965, John V. Lindsay is going to pass up the annual dinner of the Republican State Com mittee, scheduled for Thurs day in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Ottawa's Decision
description: PRINCE ALBERT, Saskatchewan, June 1Ottawa's deci sion for the second time since World War II to let the Canadian dollar find its own level in foreigncurrency dealings may prove to have important implications for the interna tional monetary system.

title: Abernathy, in Jackson, Bids Young Blacks Shun Violence
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 1  The Rev. Ralph David Aber nathy called on youg blacks tonight to avoid violence even in the face of provocation by the white authorities.

title: Authenticity of Painting Here Doubted
description: LONDON, June 1 (UPI) A British art historian said today that a 17thcentury French masterpiece at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York might be a fake. The comment, about Georges de la Tour's Fortune Teller, came from Benedict Nicolson, editor of The Burlington Magazine and former deputy surveyor of the Royal Collec tion. It appeared in the magazine's new issue.

title: Medicaid CostSharing Is Begun By State, but City Defers Plan
description: The State Social Services De partment put into effect a con troversial, longdelayed pro gram yesterday calling on the state's nonwelfare Medicaid eligibles  808,352 persons as of last March 31to pay 20 per cent of their bills for outpatient medical services.

title: U.S. Fliers Dispatched To Learn Peru Needs
description: QUARRY HEIGHTS, Pan ama Canal Zone, June 1A United States Southern Com mand spokesman said to night that a request for assistance for the earth quakehit areas of Peru had been received from the De fense Department.

title: Palafox Defeats Rivkind, 64, 62, At Long Island Net
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 1 Topseeded Tony Palafox, a former Mexican Davis Cup play er now teaching in Port Wash ington, L. I., defeated Daniel Rivkind of New York, 64, 62, in the first round of the Long Island tennis champioship to day at the Great Neck Country Club.

title: Fair Access to TV
description: The President of the United States can rightly call upon the television networks whenever he wishes to speak about the Vietnam war or any other major mat ter. Tomorrow evening he will make an interim report on the Cambodian operation; another one is promised at the end of the month when all American troops are scheduled to have returned to South Vietnam.

title: TRUSTEE OF N.Y.U. QUITS IN PROTEST
description: An 18year trustee of New York University submitted his resignation yesterday to pro test what he described as the university's political activist role in connection with recent protests against United States military involvement in South east Asia.

title: MRS. ROMNEY URGES U.S. PULLOUT BY '71
description: DETROIT, June 1Lenore Romney, a candidate for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate from Michigan and wife of George Romney. Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, called today for the withdraw al of all American troops from Vietnam next year.

title: MRS. KING PICKED FOR CUP TENNIS
description: Mrs. Billie Jean King, who recently became eligible again, was named with four other players yesterday to the United States Wightman Cup tennis team that will meet Britain June 12 and 13 at Wimbledon in the annual fourofseven match series.

title: CANADIAN DOLLAR SOARS BY 3 CENTS
description: OTTAWA, June 1Canada's new floating dollar soared be tween 3 and 4 cents in most money markets today.

title: Jordan Reports a Child Killed
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 1 (Reuters)A military spokes man said today that the Jor danian town of Irbid had been shelled by the Israelis and that one child had been killed and 12 other civilians, including children and 2 women, wounded.

title: Adoption Group Plans Rose Ball At Bedford Club
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 1 The Adoption Service of Westchester at 19 Green ridge Avenue here will hold its Northern Rose Ball on June 13 at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club. Mrs. E. Albert Berol of Bedford is general chairman of the eve ning, which has been ar ranged as an Austrian wine festival.

title: Jersey Candidates End Senate Primary Races
description: JERSEY CITY, June 1 Harrison A. Williams Jr., the Democratic United States Senator from New Jersey, ended his campaign for re nomination in tomorrow's primary in an impromptu hand shaking display that saw his opponent stalk away from Journal Square.

title: Plan for Capital Representation in Congress Backed
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)Strong bipartisan sup port was expressed today for a constitutional amendment to give residents of the District of Columbia representation in Congressa lost cause for many years.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 2, 1970

title: PAST QUAKE TOLLS OFTEN ENORMOUS
description: The largest number of fatali ties from one earthquake in re corded history has been esti mated at more than 800,000 people killed in Shensi province of China on Jan. 24, 1556.

title: Finns Face Summer of Caretaker Rule
description: HELSINKI, Finland, May 30 Finland, beset by politica confusion since the unexpectec swing toward the right in the March general election, has settled down for the summer with a nonpolitical caretake?? Government headed by the Mayor of Helsinki.

title: MANUEL ORTIZ DEAD; EXBOXING CHAMPION
description: SAN DIEGO, June 1 (AP) Manuel Ortiz, former world bantamweight boxing champion, died yesterday of cirrhosis of the liver at San Diego Naval Hospital. He was 53 years old.

title: COURT ASKED TO LET NEWTON OUT ON BAIL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 1 An attorney for Huey P. New ton asked the California Court of Appeal today to free the imprisoned Black Panther leader on bail.

title: Quarry's Future Hinges on Foster Bout
description: Mac Foster served two tours of combat duty in Vietnam with the Marines. In one of 14 battles, the 27yearold ser geant knocked out a 50caliber machine gun with a grenade. He has been recommended for the Silver Star, as a result of that action near Chu Lai.

title: PERU ESTIMATES 30,000 DIED IN QUAKE THAT WIPED OUT SCORES OF TOWNS IN NORTH
description: LIMA, Peru, June 1  The Peruvian Government believes that more than 30,000 people were killed in the earthquake that devastated large areas of northern Peru yesterday.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES SHOW AN ADVANCE
description: Soybean futures, together with soybean meal and oil, rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. The most attractive commodity on the floor was soybean oil.

title: F.T.C. Accuses 4 Publishers Of Deceit in Magazine Sales
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI)  Federal officials ac cused 14 major publishers and magazine agencies today of using deceptive means to sign up longterm subscribers and proposed stringent controls over their salesmen.

title: Entertainment Events
description: TONIGHT

title: Lucy Lynn Fiancee Of James Follayttar
description: MANHASSET, L. L, June 1 Miss Lucy Lynn and James Follayttar, members of this year's graduating classes at Trinity College and George town University, respectively, plan to be married in Sep tember

title: Airplane Uneconomics
description: The mammoth Lockheed C5A cargo plane seems to be lining up alongside the illstarred F111 fighter bomber as a disastrous military investment. Air Force confirmation that a technical study of the costly new transport is under way lends substance to a report by The Armed Forces Journal that the huge plane's fatigue strength is far below contract specifi cations.

title: Construction Activity Drifted Down in April
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 New construction activity drifted lower in April to the lowest point since last No vember and well below April a year ago, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Tories Are Cheered by Polls as British Election Campaign Opens
description: LONDON, June 1  The British election campaign got under way officially today with the outlook rather less sunny for the Labor Government than expected.

title: Margaret in Belgrade
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 1 (Reuters)  Princess Margaret arrived here today with her husband, Lord Snow don, on a sevenday visit to Yugoslavia, the first member of the British royal family to visit a Communist country.

title: G.O.P. CHIEF VIEWS CAMBODIA AS BOON
description: WASHINGTON, June 1The Republican National Chairman, Representative Rogers C. B. Morton, said today that United States involvement in the Viet nam war no longer served the national interest, and he pre dicted that the Cambodian foray would help make it pos sibe to get the hell out of there.

title: Thieu Is Reported Acting to Block Move By Ky to Exploit His Role in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1President Nguyen Van Thieu was reliably reported today to be moving swiftly to block Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky from making political capital out of his active role in South Vietnamese military operations in Cambodia.

title: CITY AIDES ATTEND POLICEMAN'S RITES
description: ELMONT, L. 1., June 1 Mayor Lindsay, Police Commis sioner Howard R. Leary and nearly 2,000 policemen, fire man and friends attended the funeral here today of Patrol man Lawrence Stefane, who was stabbed to death Thursday.

title: SO. AFRICA DEFENDS POLICY OF APARTHEID
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, June 1 (AP)South Africa will not give up its apartheid Policy of racial searegation as the price for narticipating in world snort, Prime Minister John Vorster said today.

title: U.S.Foreign Gold Deals Limited in First Quarter
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  Gold transactions with foreign countries continued limited in both number and volume in the first quarter of this year, the Treasury disclosed today. The largest transaction was a pur chase of $25million from Kuwait and, the next largest, a sale of $5million to Argen tina. All other transactions in volved less than $3million. largest transaction was a pur chase of $25million from Kuwait and, the next largest, a sale of $5million to Argen tina. All other transactions in volved less than $3million.

title: Expo Lists Record Crowd
description: OSAKA, Japan, June 1 (UPI) Expo '70 recorded its largest attendance yesterday when 528,294 people visited the fair grounds. Officials said the larg est previous crowd was 510,147 on May 3, Constitution Day. Attendance since the March 15 opening has been 22.5 million.

title: Explorer Will Resume Hunt for Santa Maria
description: WASHINGTON June 1 (AP) An ocean explorer says he will return to a reef off north ern Haiti on June 15 to begin excavation of what he be lieves is the wreckage of the Santa Maria, Christopher Co lumbus's flagship in 1492.

title: Cleveland Parsons Bank Lists Potential Conflicts of Interest
description: The Union Commerce Bank in Cleveland, which was taken over last year by the Parsons Groupowner of an extensive chain of banks in Michigan, Colorado, Washington, D. C., and Switzerlandpub lished the details yesterday on a long list of transactions with other Parsons banks that it said involved potential conflicts of interest.

title: Dr. Oscar James Campbell Jr., Shakespeare Scholar, Is Dead
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 1  Dr. Oscar James Campbell Jr., a Shakespearean scholar and professor emeritus of English at Columbia University, died at his daughter's home here this afternoon after a long illness. He was 90 years old.

title: U.S. BANKS INVITED TO JOIN IN I.O.S. AID
description: PARIS, June 1Paul Vin cent, director general of the, Banque Rothschild, said today that American banks were being invited to join an inter national consortium to rescue Investors Overseas Services, the troubled mutualfund giant.

title: Tutors and Pupils: Worlds Apart, Yet So Close
description: Once or twice a week they leave the towers of upper park Avenue and descend to the dreariness of the Lower East Side. There, they have discovered stores for herbs, tiedyeing, bookbinding and Wonderful breads.

title: Mayor Asks Engineers to Ease Subway Tunnel Impact in Park
description: Mayor Lindsay has asked city engineers to see if there is a way to build the new Queens  to  Manhattan subway without ripping up Central Park playgrounds, rock out crops and sylvan pond areas.

title: City to Install Fume Killers On Own Cars
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced a major experi mental program to test techniques for controlling air pollution from automobiles.

title: Judge Clears Psychiatrist Of Refusing to Testify
description: REDWOOD CITY, Calif., June 1 (AP)An Orinda psychiatrist has purged himself of a con tempt citation for refusing to testify about a patient, Judge Melvin Cohn of the San Mateo County Superior Court ruled today.

title: James Stewart Series On TV Reported Due
description: James Stewart is reported to be ready to join the long list of Hollywood stars who have made weekly television series.

title: TV: A Frightening Look at the Problems in 1985
description: Taking a note from Orson Welles's celebrated 1938 War of the Worlds radio scare, Metromedia television and WNEWTV took a brave look into the future last night and discoveredthe Apoca lypse.

title: Lutherans Modify Brazil Plan
description: GENEVA, June 1 (Reuters)  The World Lutheran Fed eration said today that it had decided to go ahead with its plans to hold its fifth assembly next month in Brazil, despite strong criticism from a number of leading Lutherans. However, President Emilio G. Mdici of Brazil will not be invited to attend.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: Alan Claude Weds Jacqueline Knowlton
description: COLUMBIA, Mo., June 1 Miss Jacqueline Ann Knowl ton and Alan Michael Claude were married here this eve ning in the chapel of Stephen College by the Rev. Kenneth L. Frerking, a Lutheran min ister.

title: 2 Performers Get Derwent Awards
description: Two Off Broadway per formers were chosen yester day as winners of the 26th annual Clarence Derwent Awards, given to the actor and actress for best individ ual supporting performances.

title: Executive Changes
description: David J. Mahoney has been elected chairman of Norton Simon, Inc., continuing as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds Harold M. Wil liams, who has resigned to become dean of the University of California Los Angeles' graduate School of Business Administration.

title: Market Place.
description: Let's say you run a corpo ration on the march and you are accustomed to, making acquisitions, using your stock as the quid pro quo.

title: Dodgers Beat Cubs, 54, on Grabarkewitz's TwoRun Homer in Sixth Inning
Wood, Field and Stream
description: Joan and Lee Wulff, two of the country's most experi enced flyrod anglers, will be the head instructors at the Garcia Corporation's flyfish ing school June 19 through 21 at the Eldred, N. Y., Trout Fishing Preserve.

title: Egyptians, More Confident, Prepare for a New Conflict
description: CAIRO, June 1Three years after suffering one of the most humiliating battlefield defeats in the history of warfare, the Egyptians are girding for an other battle with Israel, sobered by the 1967 rout but regaining confidencesomewhat pleased and surprised by their endur ance under attack but increas ingly impatient to end the sacrifices of war. The mood in the United Arab Republic differs strikingly from the euphoric sloganeering and illu sions of invincibility that swept the country preceding the dis aster of June 5, 1967, when the Israelis destroyed the armed forces of the United Arab Republic, Jordan and Syria in six days.

title: Injured ExRedskin Sues Club, N.F.L. for $4.2Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI  Jim (Yazoo) Smith, a formes top draft choice from the Uni versity of Oregon, has filed a $4.2million law suit against the Washington Redskins and the National Football League.

title: BAPTISTS' PARLEY HEARS UNITY PLEA
description: DENVER, June 1  The Rev. W. A. Criswell, fundamentalist president of the Southern Bap tist Convention who has on oc casion invited liberals to leave the church, opened the denomi nation's 125th anniversary con vention tonight with a plea for cool tempers and an end to feudin'. fussin' and fightin'.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 1  The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Airports Here to Get Wheeled Passenger Lounges
description: A mammoth new wheeled passenger lounge that is part bus and part elevator will be introduced next year at Ken nedy and La Guardia Airports by American Airlines and Pan American World Airways.

title: Goldberg Asks Ban on Some Engines
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, who is seeking the Democratic nomi nation for Governor, said yes terday that if at least 90 per cent of the air pollution caused by automobiles was not elimi nated by 1975, the state should ban the internal combustion engine.

title: Columbia Fetes McMillian, Dotsun
description: Jim McMillian and Hey ward Dotson, stars of the Lions' basketball team, were among the seniors honored at Class Day ceremonies at Co lumbia University yesterday.

title: BIG BOARD PRICES CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Stock prices continued to climb yesterday As the market posted its fourth consecutive large gain in active trading.

title: Wimbledon Finals on TV
description: The National Broadcasting Company said yesterday it would televise via satellite the finals of Britain's Wimbledon tennis tournament on July 4.

title: GHANA ENJOYING POLITICAL REVIVAL
description: ACCRA, Ghana, May 30 Ghana's eight million people are happily accustoming them selves to a greater measure of genuine democracy than they have known in years.

title: MISSISSIPPI BOMBER LOSES COURT APPEAL
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 1  The Mississippi Supreme Court rejected today an appeal by Thomas A. Tarrants 3d, who was caught in a police trap after placing a bomb at the home of a Jewish businessman in Meridian. Miss., in 1968.

title: Post Is Filled by UAL
description: UAL, Inc., a holding com pany, and its wholly owned subsidiary, United Air Lines, have named Irving Roth as vice president of both organizations. Mr. Roth is a former director of the bureau of economics of the Civil Aeronautics Board.

title: Mrs. Charles Haskins, 91, Widow of Harvard Dean
description: CAZENOVIA, N. Y., June 1 Mrs. Clare Allen Haskins, wid ow of Charles Homer Haskins, professor of history and dean of the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences at Harvard Uni versity, died in Lexington, Mass., on May 22 at the age of 91.

title: ALABAMA EXPECTS A BIG VOTE TODAY
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 1 A blossoming black electo rate and a sturdy white back lash meet headon here tomor row in a gubernatorial primary that could decide George C. Wallace's political future and influence this nation's next Presidential election.

title: U.S. Troops Find Big Hospital in Enemy Base Complex in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 (AP)  United States troops found today an under ground hospital in a North Viet namese base complex in Cam bodia that already had yielded tons of enemy munitions and supplies.

title: Israelis Report Death of Girl
description: JERUSALEM, June 1An Is raeli Army spokesman reported that a 9yearold Israeli girl was killed this moiming and eight other persons, including five children, were wounded when half a dozen rockets launched from Jordan landed in a schoolyard in Beisan, in the Jordan Valley.

title: Iona Netmen Triumph, 41, To Keep C.H.S.A.A. Crown
description: NEW ROCHELLE, June 1 lona Prep of New Rochelle re tained the Catholic High School Athletic Association tennis championship today by down ing previously undefeated Mon signor McClancy High School of Queens, 41. It marked the third consecutive year that Iona has captured the title.

title: Senators and Circuses
description: The high cost of campaigning on commercial tele vision has produced some ingenious touches in the race for United States Senator from New York. To get a headline in the papers or a free show on the evening news, it is no longer enough to eat pizza on Mulberry Street, soul food in Harlem or wage a blintzkrieg in the Bronx.

title: PLAN TO CUT NOISE AT AIRPORT BEGINS
description: A fourmonth experimental program designed to give re lief from jet noise to some com munities near Kennedy Interna tional Airport was begun yes terday.

title: STEEL MEN FAVOR NIXON TRADE BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 (UPI) The Nixon Administration's trade bill was supported by the steel industry today, but only as a stopgap measure that treats the symptoms and not, the causes of American trade problems.

title: Stanford Scans LowIncome Housing
description: PALO ALTO, Calif., June 1 Stanford University, to the sur prise of some of its neighbors and to the irritation of others, has announced that it is con sidering construction of lowin come housing on its plush sub urban camous.

title: 73 Senators Urge U.S. To Sell Jets to Israel
description: WASHINGTON, June 1A total of 73 Senators urged Secretary of State William P Rogers today to authorize promptly Israel's request to purchase more jet aircraft.

title: MRS. ROBERT E. GARST
description: Mrs. Iris Kollmorgen Garst, the wife of Robert E. Garst, a former assistant managing editor of The New York Times, died at her home, 61 West Ninth Street, yesterday even ing after a long illness. She was 70 years old.

title: Sports of The Times
description: When the New York Football Giants traded the frequently spectacular Homer Jones to the Cleveland Browns, they re ceived an inordinately high price in re turn. They got three men, each of whom is likely to win a regular berth. But they also found themselves virtually stripped of experienced pass catchers, and that could be a fatal flaw for a team whose offense revolves around the passthrowing manipulations of Fran Tarkenton.

title: PRICES RISE AGAIN IN CREDIT MARKET
description: The move toward higher bond prices and lower interest rates that began last Wednes day morning gathered more strength yesterday.

title: Bouton Is Warned by Kuhn On Content of His Writings
description: Bowie Kuhn, the Commis sioner of Baseball, and Jim Bouton, the author, met yes terday to discuss Bouton's book, Ball Four, a revealing diary about his baseball career.

title: Fromin Rides $30, $31 Winners On Liberty Bell's Opening Day
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 1  Marty Fromin and Liberty Bell race track got off to successful starts today.

title: U.S. OUTLINESPLAN FOR OIL CLEANUPS
description: WASHINGTON, June 1 The White House announced today a national contingency plan for a Federal cleanup of oil spills from ships and on shore and offshore installations when their owners fail to do the job.

title: A TROTTING BABY EARNS HIS KEEP
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 1  June and a lot of 2yearold horses were bustin' out all over at Roosevelt Raceway this morning. The occasion was a series of baby races, each for a gross purse of $1,000, with $500 going to the owner of each winner.

title: Cambodian Battalion Searching for 8 Newsmen Is Driven Back
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 2 (Reuters)  A battalion of Cambodian troops attempted to day to reach the cars of eight missing television newsmen but pulled back under heavy fire.

title: A Woman of Many Titles Joins Goldberg's Campaign
description: At noon today, a trim dark haired woman with an ani mated voice, a thoughtful turn of mind and strong opinions will make her official debut as an independent campaigner for Arthur J. Goldberg, candi date for the Democratic nom ination for Governor.

title: Japan Opens Auto Center
description: The Japanese automotive in dustry, which has become a major exporter to the United States, has opened a new head quarters here. It is operated by the Japan Automobile Manufac turers Association at 30 East 42d Street, Kenkichi Konichi has been named director of the office, which will be a clear ing house for trade information and data on Japanese automo bile safety and pollution control.

title: U.S. HEALTH AIDE IS OUT IN DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, June 2Rob ert H. Finch, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced today that he had dismissed Dr. Stanley F. Yolles, the Government's chief mental health official.

title: SILVER FUTURES EDGE UP IN PRICE
description: Metal futures prices increased yesterday in moderate trading.

title: Belmont Jockeys
Chimbote: A City Half in Ruins Already Has Begun Rebuilding
description: CHIMBOTE, Peru, June 2 Most of this coastal city, which was built by the Peruvian fish meal boom, has been reduced to the level of the sand dunes.

title: Crew of Apollo 13 Due In a Motorcade Today
description: The Apollo 13 astronauts Capt. James A. Lovell Jr., Fred W. Haise Jr. and John L. Swigert Jr. will ride through midtown in an open car just before noon today on the way to a Lincoln Center luncheon.

title: Manny Shinwell, 85, Made Life Peer
description: LONDON, June 2  Emanuel Shinwell, who resigned from the House or Commons last week after a career spanning 48 years, was made a life peer today.

title: Italian Printers to Strike Dailies Again
description: ROME, June 2The printers unions called today for another walkout that would shut down most Italian daily newspapers for 24 hours on Thursday. It would be the third printers strike in three weeks. The two others lasted four days and two days In a nation where only one out of every 10 persons ever buys a daily newspaper, the reaction to the projected press blackout was one of apathy.

title: New Cambodian Envoy
description: PARIS, June 2  In hap pier times the cream of Cambodian society used to pack its sons off to the Lyce Chasseloup Laubat, an elite French secondary school in Saigon.

title: LONDON STOCK DIP ENDS 4DAY RALLY
Modern Art Museum to Show Series of 6 Vintage Fox Films
description: In an agreement with 20th CenturyFox, the Museum of Modern Art will present a series of six vintage Fox films, both silent and sound, which have not been avail able to the public for many years, starting next Tues day. The opening offering is City Girl, a 1928 silent drama directed by F. W. Murnau with Charles Farrell, Mary Duncan and David Tor rence in lead roles. It will be shown at 2 P.M. and 5:30 P.M.

title: Memorial Services
description: WANGLERAlbert McCleery, in his eighty third year, at Woudstock, N.Y. Memorial service, Princeton University Chapel, 4 P.M., Friday, June 5. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Princeton University Li brary suggested.

title: Burnham to Add Partner
description: Mark N. Kaplan, senior part ner of the law firm of Marshall, Bratter, Greene, Allison & Tucker, will be admitted as senior partner of Burnham & Co., a member of the New York Stock Exchange, on July 31.

title: PANTHER HEARING EXAMINES MEDIA
description: NEW HAVEN, June 2De fense lawyers called 16 em ployes of various area news media and the city's police chief to the witness stand to day in an attempt to show that Lonnie McLucas, a Black Pan ther, cannot get a fair trial on murder and kidnap charges be cause of massive adverse pub licity.

title: Advertising: Radio Group Holds Workshop
description: The crowd in the Baroque Suite of the Plaza was al ready heavy at 8:45 A.M. yesterday and Miles David, president of the Radio Bu reau of Advertising, while quite happy to see everyone was wondering Where to seat them all at lunch time.

title: Architects' Own Brownstones: Ideas Tempered by Finances
description: Does the architect who designs his own home have a fool for a client? Four architects who renovated three rooming houses in the West 90's admit to making mis takes. But they still think it's wonderful, as Peter Samton put it to create your own life. Among the mistakes they admit to having made are:

title: Laird Expresses Concern
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP)  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird expressed concern to day over the capture of Ameri can newsmen in Cambodia and urged the enemy to provide in formation about them.

title: Only 9% Turned Out for Manhattan School Election
description: The community school board elections in Manhattan last Thursday attracted a far lighter turnout of voters than the elec tions held previously in the other boroughs, the Board of Elections reported yesterday.

title: Chief Pennsylvania Attorney
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) Gov. Raymond P. Shafer ap pointed Fred Speaker, a 40 yearold Harrisburg lawyer, as Pennsylvania's Attorney Gen eral today, succeeding William C. Sennett, who resigned to manage the reelection cam paign of Senator Hugh Scott, Republican of Pennsylvania.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Where Cheese Is. Still King
description: There was a time when one block in Manhattan between Second and Third Avenues on 59th Street boasted one of the greatest concentrations of fine food shops in America.

title: Conservative Defeats Gov. Cargo in New Mexico
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 2New Mexico Republicans re jected today Gov. David F. Car go's moderate approach to gov ernment, defeating his bid for nomination to the Senate.

title: Hatfield Absolved by Senate of Franking Misuse
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI)  Members of the Senate  Republicans and Democrats, hawks and dovesralied today around Senator Mark O. Hat field, Republican of Oregon, in a rare display of unity.

title: Williams and Gross Win Jersey Senate Primaries
description: United States Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. won a decisive victory yesterday in New Jersey's Democratic pri mary, defeating a Senate candidate backed by the powerful oldline Hudson County Dem ocratic organization to win the party's nomination for a third term.

title: The Moonlighter
description: Charlie Metro would never dream for an instant of intruding on the predawn time of his. Kansas City Royals. But many years ago, when he was a young minor league manager, he was not quite that circumspect. The Royals dropped into town yesterday for a series with the Yankees and Charlie got to talking about one of baseball's stranger episodes.

title: Funds for Park Sought
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) State Senator James Denor mandie of Massachusetts asked a House Interior subcommittee today to authorize $5.9million in additional funds for ac quiring land for the Minute Man National Historical Park in Massachusetts.

title: Five Political Prisoners Reported Killed in Taiwan
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 2 Five political prisoners were executed last Saturday for kill ing two guards during an at tempted escape four months ago, informed sources said to day.

title: New Cyanamid Resin Plant
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 2 (UPI)  American Cyanamid Company announced today plans to build a multimillion dollar plant near here to pro duce resins and specialty chem icals for the Southern textile industry. The plant, which will have a capacity of about 90,000 tons a year, is scheduled to be in operation by late next year. It will occupy a 175acre tract and will take the place of Cy anamid's present manufactur ing facility, which shares a 20 acre site with the company's Southern distribution center.

title: Market Place
description: It's obvious that investor confidence was up last week. The stock market tells us so. But there was no sign of an uptick in consumer confi dence. That stayed at a re cession level, says Sindlinger & Co., an opinion and re search organization.

title: Spokesman Says Nixon Won't Meet With Palme
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (Reuters)  President Nixon will not meet Sweden's Prem ier, Olaf Palme, during his visit to Washington this week, the White House said today.

title: Roundup: McDowell's Mental Curves
description: Sam McDowell's fastball is good enough to stop op posing batters, but he has to use some mental curves on himself.

title: Cheerful and Confident
description: Bruce McLaren had a soft voice and a loud laugh and he smiled in a way that sug gested he was relishing a little private joke.

title: Gov. Farrar Wins Renomination in South Dakota
description: SIOUX FALLS, S.D., June 2 (AP) Gov. Frank L. Farrar won renomination in the South Dakota primary tonight over his Republican opponent, Frank Henderson.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
JOHN JACOBS
description: John Jacobs, a lawyer for merly on the staff of the Con solidated Edison Company and the Hydrotechnic Corporation, engineering consultants, died of leukemia Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 305 East 70th Street.

title: Big 6 Mayors Plan a Campaign To Cut Back Albany Strictures
description: GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 2 The state's Big Six mayors will wage a major campaign this fall for greater independence through a very substantial restructuring of homerule provisions at the next session of the State Legis lature.

title: Bliss Becomes Chairman Of Foundation for Dance
description: Anthony A. Bliss has been elected chairman of the board of directors of the Foundation for American Dance, the parent organization of the City Center Joffrey Ballet.

title: Arthur L. Wadsworth, 59, Dies; A Vice President of Dillon, Read
description: Arthur L. Wadsworth, execu tive vice president and a direc tor of the investment banking firm of Dillon, Read & Co., died, apparently of a heart attack, at his home, 7 The Dogwoods, Roslyn, L. I., yester day. He was 59 years old.

title: Reaping the Whirlwind
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 2 (UPI)  A 19yearold college stu dent from Kings Point appeared in Nassau County District court today because a policeman said that the plants he was water ing in front of his home were marijuana. The youth, Robert Kogel, was released in $1,000 bail on a charge of possession of a dangerous drug.

title: Transit Police Award Medals for Bravery
description: The Transit Police Depart ment's highest award for valor, the Medal of Honor, was given posthumously yes terday to a young patrolman who was slain in the Times Square area last February.

title: New Detour Is Planned To Ease Bronx Car Jam
description: Motorists who have been exasperated for some time by the annoying detour in the Bronx in the vicinity of the Bruckner Traffic Circle received some encouraging news yesterday from the State Department of Trans portation. A new detour with fewer bends and turns is expected to be opened in about two weeks.

title: Clover Blossom, $9.60, Wins By a Nose at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (AP) Thomas F. Lutz's Clover Blos som, making her second start of the year, took the lead in mid stretch today then held off the late bid of Lady Jester to win the Juniata Purse at Liberty Bell Race Track by a neck.

title: CITY U. EXPECTS 30,000 FRESHMEN
description: More than 30,000 freshmen are expected to register at the City University this September, Chancellor Albert H. Bowker reported yesterday.

title: Bridge:
Boston Hospital Lab Strike
description: BOSTON, June 2 (AP)Tech nicians at the Boston City Hos pital's biochemistry laboratory continued their sickness ab sences for a second day today to protest what they called in adequate wages. The hospital continued to contract outside agencies for laboratory work, a spokesman said.

title: SERVICE DELAYED ON PENN CENTRAL
description: A fire under the rear car of a New Yorkbound Penn Central train caused delays up to 50 minutes on the line's New Haven and Harlem divi sions yesterday morning.

title: Unveilings
description: LEVYLya (nee Weiss). A monument will be unveiled in loving memory of the de voted wife of Dr. Norman Levy, mother of Karen, Susan and Joanne Levy, daugh ter of Abe and Esther Weiss and sister of Mrs. Beatrice Drayer, on Sunday, June 7, 1970, at 11 A.M., New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Queens, N. Y. No postponement.

title: Officer in Germany Denies U.S. Base Has Klan Unit
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 2 (AP)Col. Martin D. Howell, commander of the Unit ed States 14th Armored Cav alry Regiment, denied as un substantiated today charges that a Klu Klux Klan klavern existed at his unit.

title: Lockheed Officials Cleared by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 2The Securities and Exchange Com mission announced today that a staff investigation into the Lockheed C5A matter had not disclosed evidence of un lawful insider trading.

title: NATIONAL LEAD SET TO LIFT OXIDE PRICE
description: The National Lead Company announced yesterday that it will increase the price of its antimony oxide by 30.5 cents to $1.38 a pound, effective immediately. The company said that move reflected higher raw material costs.

title: Straw Hat Awards Devised for Summer Actors
description: The Council of Stock Thea ters, comprising some of the major summer theaters in the country, has created the Straw Hat Awards for excel lece In the American sum mer theater.

title: TARIFF UNIT SPLIT ON SHOE IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 The Tariff Commission an nounced today it had split 33 on the question of whether one company and five groups of workers in the shoe industry were eligible for Government adjustment assistance.

title: PRINTERS RESUMING TALKS AT L. I. PRESS
description: Negotiators for Typographi cal Union No. 6 and The Long Island Press are scheduled to resume talks today in an effort to reach agreement on a new contract.

title: Fordham Acclaims Moses
description: A plaza at Fordham Uni versity's Lincoln Center campus was dedicated to Robert Moses yesterday.

title: Honduras and El Salvador Hold Talks on a DMZ
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Conversations here on the creation of a demilitarized zone between Honduras and El Salvador have entered an in tensive phase.

title: INVESTOR QUESTIONS HONG KONG. AUCTION
description: HONG KONG, June 2An American investor today ques tioned the validity of an auc tion sale yesterday of 53,000 square feet of reclaimed Crown land for $43million, equiv alent to more than $800 a square foot.

title: Gromyko in Paris
description: PARIS, June 2President Pompidou pledged continued French amity toward the So viet Union today after France's leaders discussed the Arab Israeli conflict and other world problems with the Soviet For eign Minister, Andrei A. Gro myko.

title: Lindsay Aids Indian Cause
description: Mayor Lindsay attended a $100aticket cocktail reception for the benefit of the Ameri cans for Indian Opportunity last night at the Plaza Hotel.

title: Powell, Unworried, Opens A Campaign Headquarters
description: Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., Democrat of Man hattan, took the unusual step of opening a campaign head quarters last night, but insisted that he was not worried about his chances for reelection.

title: Lawrene Mae Nixon, a Niece Of President, to Marry June 27
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif., June 2Miss Lawrene Mae Nixon, a niece of President Nixon, will be married here on June 27 to Thomas Elmer Anfinson. A White House spokesman said yesterday that there was a possibility that Mr. and Mrs. Nixon would attend the wedding, which will take place in St. Andrew's Presbyterian Church.

title: 400 ATTEND SERVICE FOR JOHN GUNTHER
description: About 400 people attended a funeral service yesterday for John Gunther, the bestselling author of Inside U. S. A., In side Europe, and other books. Mr. Gunther died of cancer Fri day at the age of 68.

title: Orders for Nondurables Down in April; Auto Makers Show a Decline in Sales
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Manufacturers' new orders de clined and inventories rose sub stantially in April, the Com merce Department reported to day.

title: Francis Law Dies
description: HOUSTON, June 2Francis Marion Law, president of the American Bankers Association during the Depression, died today. He was 93 years old.

title: ROMNEY ASKS BAN ON RULES CURBING HOUSING FOR POOR
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 The Nixon Administration pro posed today enactment of a Federal law that would bar local governments from using zoning, building codes and other powers to prevent con struction of lowincome hous ing in areas undergoing devel opment.

title: Doubts an Ambush
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (AP)  Accounts of peasants in the area where group of television reporters disappeared Sunday raised a question today whether the men had been ambushed.

title: Canada Floats Its Dollar
description: Canada has cut its dollar loose from the United States peg of 92 cents and is letting it float upward in value. The move was a wise one for a country troubled both by inflation and unemployment.

title: ADDONIZIO'S TRIM OPENS IN TRENTON
description: TRENTON, June 2Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark went on trial here today in Federal District Court with seven other defendants on 66 counts of conspiracy to extort $253,000 from Constrad, Inc., a company that builds sewers for Newark. Severances were granted to four other defend ants.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Kansas City at New York (8 P.M.) Drago (33) vs. Kekich (11).

title: Rochester Peace Drive Spreads Across Nation
description: ROCHESTER, N. Y.When the four students were killed by National Guardsmen at Kent State University on May 4, nearly 1,000 of the University of Rochester's 3,300 undergraduates met in a dining hall to seek a way to vent their anger and frus tration.

title: GHANAIANS PLEAD: DROP SOME DEBTS
description: ACCRA, Ghana, May 30The new Government of Ghana has begun a fresh struggle to ease the burden of its huge foreign debt.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Ruling on Abortions

title: An Independent Woman
description: Sculptor, traveler, writer and feminist, Clare Consuelo Frewen Sheridan managed to shock her proper family and many proper Britons in the nineteentwenties and thirties by her indiscretions in print and in deed.

title: NIXON AIDE BACKS 'INCOMES POLICY
description: WASHINGTON, June 2A high Treasury official told Congress today that in his per sonal opinion the time had come to give serious consideration to some form of voluntary restraint on wages and prices.

title: Damage to Apollo 13 Prior to Launching Blamed in Explosion
description: HOUSTON, June 2 (UPI) Apollo 13's nearly disastrous oxygen tank explosion on the way to the moon apparently resulted from a human error during attempts to empty the tank before launching, the head of the explosion review board said today.

title: Fans in Millions to Lose Sleep Viewing World Cup Soccer TV
description: Millions of soccer fans will be losing a lot of sleep this month, and Swedish sociologists fear families may be split up.

title: Manet's Nuns Closes
description: The Nuns, a play by Ed uardo Manet, adapted from the French by Don Parker and Paul Verdier, closed after one per formance at the Cherry Lane Theater. It was presented by Mr. Parker in association with Stanley J. Hatoff.

title: Police Chief's Home Robbed
description: LONDON (UPI)  Burglars broke into the home of Lon don's police commissioner, Sir John Waldron, while he was away on leave.

title: Jokes by Garagiola Brighten Flood Antitrust Suit Testimony
description: A few jokes by Joe Gara giola brightened the plodding testimony in Curt Flood's antitrust suit against base ball's reserve clause system yesterday, as three high base ball officials restated the position that the present sys tem was necessary and fair.

title: N.Y.U. Names Krause Top Athlete
description: Walter Krause, whose ath letic goal has been to exit as a winner, fulfilled his ambi tion last night when the Na tional Collegiate Athletic As sociation foil champion was named New York University's outstanding athlete for the 196970 season.

title: House War Foes Plan Attack On Debt Ceiling Increase Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) Antiwar Representatives said today they would try to amend a proposed debt ceiling increase in order to cure United States involvement in Southeast Asia.

title: Venezuelan Appeals to Nixon on Oil
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 President Rafael Caldera of Venezuela, here on a state visit, urged President Nixon today to produce tangible deeds in support of his pub lic promises of changed at titude toward Latin America and he insisted on a new pol icy toward imports of Vene zuelan petroleum.

title: M'COY CONSIDERED AS HEAD OF COLLEGE
description: NEWARK, June 2  Rhody A. McCoy, administrator of Brooklyn's Ocean HillBrowns ville Experimental School Dis trict, is being considered for the job of president of strife torri Essex County College here.

title: Evelyn lunge Plans Bridal
description: Mr. and Mrs. August Junge of Brooklyn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Evelyn Jo Ann Junge, to Wayne Wei An Chou, son of Dr. and Mrs. TzuPei Chou of New York and Stamford, Conn.

title: Museum Group Weighs Artists' Plea
description: Conferees at a general ses sion of the American Asso ciation of Museums at the Waldorf  Astoria Hotel weighed and found wanting yesterday a resolution for mulated by the New York Artists Strike Against Rac ism, Sexism and War.

title: U.S. Completes an Inquiry Into G.I.Looting Charges
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam (AP), June 2The United States command has completed an in vestigation into charges of looting lodged against American troops who captured the Cam bodian town of Snoul last month. Any disciplinary action that may be taken will be car ried out by the units involved, a spokesman said today

title: New Monsanto Plant Set
description: The Monsanto Company an nounced yesterday it planned to build a multimilliondollar sty rene monomer plant at Texas City, Tex. The facility will have a capacity of 1.3 million pounds a year and will be the largest of its kind in the world. When the plant is completed in late 1971, a smaller facility at the same site will be phased out.

title: TV RATE CUT ASKED FOR POLITICAL ADS
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  The Federal Communications Commission challenged Con gress today to broaden its drives for cutrate political ad vertising on television and for modification of the equal time rule that now frustrates campaign debates.

title: MRS. JOHN A. PAPPS
description: Mrs. John A. Papps, for many years active in charitable af fairs in Glen Cove, L. I., died Sunday at Hambledon, in Sur rey, England, after a shore ill ness. Mrs. Papps, the former Edith Powell, was the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Powell of Glen Cove.

title: ENGLAND AND PERU ADVANCE IN SOCCER
description: MEXICO CITY, June 2 (UPI) England, which is defending the title, Peru and Uruguay all won today in the 1970 world soccer championship.

title: Welfare Dissidents Seized After Pennsylvania Clash
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 2 (UPI)  Six persons were ar rested today following a clash between welfare recipients and state officials over a proposed 75 per cent cutback in public assistance.

title: Grenade on Philippine Airliner Goes Off, Killing 1, Hurting 12
description: MANILA, June 2 (UPI)A hand grenade ripped a gaping hole in the fuselage of a Philip pine Air Lines passenger plane with 44 persons aboard today, killing one person and injuring 12 others.

title: G.I.'s Still Go to the War, And Many Are Skeptical
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 2 Above the coffee shop in the shiny new Oakland In ternational Airport is a row of 24 clocks telling the time at 24 points around the globe, including the Azores, Dakar and Bombay.

title: MONDAY NIGHT FIGHTS
description: New YorkDavid (Toro) Me lendez, 148 pounds, New York, knocked out Curtis (Youngblood) Phillips, 147 New York, 7 rounds.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 3, 1970

title: BARGAINING RESUMES WITH SCHOOL AIDES
description: Negotiations on a contract for the school system's para professional employes resumed last night against a background of mounting strike preparations by the United Federation of Teachers.

title: Bendix Sets Up New Posts To Direct Its Operations
description: The Bendix Corporation has established two new top man agement posts to direct its domestic and foreign opera tions, A. P. Fontaine, board chairman, president and chief executive officer, announced yesterday.

title: City Begins Move to End Bias Against Jews on Sabbath Jobs
description: The city Commission on Hu man Rights and Mayor Lindsay moved yesterday in separate actions to fight discrimination against Orthodox Jews who are denied employment because they observe their Sabbath.

title: New England Hit by a Brownout As Utility Heads Talk in Boston
description: BOSTON, June 2  The six state New England area was forced to reduce its electric voltage by 5 per cent as some 2,500 leaders of the electric utility industry sat down to the second day of the 38th annu al Edison Electric Institute con vention here. The chief topic of the day's speakers was a de tailed analysis of the industry's efforts for environmental im provement.

title: Boy, 14, Is Killed by Fall
description: A 14yearold boy identified as James G. Whalen of 57 East 95th Street fell to his death Monday night while playing with his brother on the skeleton of a school under construction near Madison Avenue, the police reported.

title: WCBSTV Backs Samuels
description: Station WCBSTV announced last night it was endorsing Howard J. Samuels for the Democratic nomination for Governor because he was a thoughtful student of the state's problems and a vigorous advocate of reform. The sta tion said that it found the campaign of Arthur J. Goldberg disappointing . . . particularly in his grasp of state issues and his uncertain approach of those issues.

title: CHANGES WEIGHED IN MONEY SYSTEM
description: PARIS, June 2  Currency markets continued restive to day as foreign exchange trad ers and government officials weighed the prospects of great er flexibility in the monetary system following the provision al float of the Canadian dollar announced Sunday.

title: Abraham. Kraditor, a Lawyer, Jewish Veterans' Leader, Dies
description: Abraham Kraditor, a lawyer and certified public accountant who was a former national commander of the Jewish War Veterans, died of a heart at tack Monday after being strick en at his office, 38 Park Row. He lived at 183 Girard Street in Brooklyn, and was 74 years old.

title: Thailand Joins the Fray
description: Thailand's decision to send volunteer ground forces as well as gunboats and other military aid to Pnom penh may in the short run bolster the shaky Lon Nol regime and help to speed the promised withdrawal of American forces from Cambodia this month. In the long run, however, this latest extension of the Indo china conflict is more likely to add to the problems of the Cambodiansand the Thaisand to complicate the task of extricating American forces from South east Asia.

title: FOOD PROGRAMS CALLED DECEPTIVE
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Federal food assistance pro grams create a cruel illusion that effective action is being taken against hunger, two former White House investiga tors told a Senate committee today.

title: SOPRANO DISOWNS TAX RETURN ITEM
description: Renata Tebaldi, the opera singer, denied that she had paid $2,400 to a claque in 1964, as in dicated on her tax return of that year, which was introduced as evidence yesterday in Federal District Court in the trial of Norman H. Egenberg, a tax ac countant, who is charged with bribing Internal Revenue agents and falsifying tax returns of more than a dozen theatrical clients.

title: Stage: Mira, La Mama's Indian Play
description: You never know what is going to turn up at La Mama, but at the very least it will be interesting, and at the most it will be truly exciting. It is fascinating that right now in London a La Mama troupe is getting extremely respectful reviews in the West End. What hope would it have on Broadway? Well, perhaps they will have to wait.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: 5 New York G.O.P.Men At Buckley Reception
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 Five Republican House mem bers from New York attend ed a reception here this evening for James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the United States Senate.

title: THAI VOLUNTEERS TO GET U.S. ARMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 The State Department said to day that the United States would provide arms and equip ment to ethnic Cambodians liv ing in Thailand who go to Cam bodia for military duty.

title: Changes Urged
description: Howard J. Samuels outlined yesterday a program for party political reform that he said he would work for if elected Governor.

title: BRITAIN REPORTS RISE IN RESERVES
description: LONDON, June 2 (Reuters)  Britain's gold and dollar reservers rose by 32 million ($7.2million) to reach 1.153 billion ($2.767billion) in May, the Government announced to day.

title: ISRAELIS REPORT NEW SUEZ STRIKES
description: TEL AVIV, June 2 (AP) Israeli warplanes stepped up strikes against Egyptian tar gets at the Suez Canal again today with four separate at tacks lasting seven hours, the Israeli military command said. The planes encountered no re sistance, a spokesman said, de nying a report by Cairo that Egyptian planes had intercept ed the Israelis.

title: Miss Dena Finn Bride Of Arnold E. Merriam
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 2Miss Dena Finn and Arnold E. Merriam were mar ried here at noon today in the home of the bride's par ents, Mr. and Mrs. David Finn. The ceremony was per formed by the bride's grand uncle, the Rev. Dr. Louis Finkelstein, chancellor of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America. He was assisted by his son, Rabbi Ezra Finkel stein.

title: Fire Ruins 3 Alcatraz Buildings; Indians Put the Blame on Whites
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 2 The dispute between the In dians encamped on Alcatraz and the Federal Government intensified today after a series of fires destroyed a number of the old prison buildings on the island last night.

title: TV: Britten's Peter Grime  Tonight
description: The adaptability of opera to the exigencies of televi sion has long since been demonstrated, and although we do not see many operas on the TV screen nowadays it is not because the art form and the medium are incom patible.

title: JERUSALEM PLAN BACKED BY FULLER
description: R. Buckminster Fuller, the builder of the geodesic dome, called yesterday for, the resto ration of Biblical dwellings in Jerusalem to bridge the past to the present.

title: A Crisis Seen
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 21 Arthur J. Goldberg began a threeday upstate campaign to day in his quest for the Demo cratic nomination for Governor by chiding Governor Rockefel ler for unsound and unfair budget practices and by pledging to consolidate or abol ish state agencies grown fat with patronage.

title: U.N. Youth Parley Getting Aid From Britain and U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 2The financial troubles of the world youth assembly have been eased by a $28,200 gift from Britain and a promise of free air travel given by the United States, probably for as many as 100 participants.

title: CONSOLIDATION SET BY HAMILTON WATCH
description: Directors of Bush Universal, Inc., and the Hamilton Watch Company agreed yesterday to a plan to consolidate the busi nesses and assets of the two companies.

title: 5 Charged With Picnicking On U.S. Flag in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UPI)Five young men, one identifying himself as a son of a junior college president, were held today in $1,000 bail each after they allegedly picnicked on an American flag near the Walnut Lane Golf Course.

title: HOUSTON SCORED ON JOB POLICIES
description: HOUSTON, Tex., June 2 Houston, America's space head quarters, was described today by the chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Corn mission, William H. Brown 3d as a very sick city for not providing jobs for blacks, Mex icanAmericans and women.

title: Israel's Coalition Government Is Showing Its Internal Strains
description: TEL AVIV, June 2Premier Golda Meir's coalition govern ment has been showing signs of internal tension.

title: Mrs. Clare Sheridan, Sculptor, Dies in England
