title: Bergman On His Own Terms
description: SEEING almost any new film by Ingmar Bergman these days is a little like coming into an exotic country late at night, alone, with a handy pocket dictionary filled with phrases you'll never use, and a guidebook that is probably already out of date. The country is not entirely strange. You've been there before, on short visits, but each time you arrive, the port of entry has changed. You can read some of the signs, recognize a lot of faces, but you can never feel exactly at home because it isn't your homeand no matter how long you remain, and no mat ter how much argot you pick up, it never will be. It is very much of the modern world with highways and automobiles and telephones and television, and there is always the awareness of a shared heritage of things that matter. Still, it is a unique land, with its own history, languages and laws, some of which seem unreasonably obscure and perplexing, and some of which seem archaically humanistic in a world where almost everyone is bent on defining meaninglessness and chaos through mean inglessness and chaos. There is an austere order in Bergman's land, and you travel there on Bergman's termsit's rather like being in an esthetic police state. One anticipates the experience with excitement (because Bergman is a genius), and a cer tain amount of dread. I mean, can one ever really measure up to the work of an artist who is so uncompromising with him self? Genius sometimes carries itself with arrogant humility.

title: Getting Getting Straight Straight
description: GETTING STRAIGHT is a bad movie and my problem as a film critic is that I can't stand bad movies. Physically. They make me nervouslike being in a car with a careless driver; my feet press down on imaginary brake pedals, my stomach flutters, I squirm restlessly in my seat, closing my eyes at the mo ments when disaster, automotive or cinematic, seems inevitable. (I've had better luck with poor drivers than with poor directors else I shouldn't be here to write this.)

title: Barbara Bisco Bride in Ithaca
description: ITHACA, N. Y., June 6 Miss Barbara Bisco and Roger Montgomery, doctoral candi dates in economics at Cor nell University, were mar ried here today. The Rev. Michael Jupin performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Annabel Taylor Chapel on the Cornell campus.

title: No LetUp In Sight In Israeli Arab Conflict
description: JERUSALEM  Israel's six day war with the Arab states on her borders is three years old now and there is no end in sight. More blood is being spilled, especially on the Suez Canal. Yet the Israelis feel rea sonably secure, more so than they did before the great out burst of violence in 1967.

title: Mrs. Gandhi Seeking Ban on Extremists In Wake of Violence
description: NEW DELHI, June 6 Alarmed by the recent spread of violence in India, Prime Min ister Indira Gandhi has pro posed a nationwide ban on extremist activity.

title: Orchestra Plays Role For a Port
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 6 By attuning itself to culture, the Delaware River Port Authority hopes to take some business away from New York., its chief rival.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Sunday, June 7, 1970

title: Officials in Normandy Mark 26th Anniversary of DDay
description: BAYEUX, France, June 6 (UPI)French and American officials made a pilgrimage to the battlesites of World War II today on the 26th anniversary of DDay, the allied landing in Normandy.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON To most ob servers of Nixonian Washing ton, the mention of Attorney General John N. Mitchell's name brings to mind two images: the sternvisaged prosecutor and the highlevel political operator.

title: Park Talks of Provocations
description: SEOUL, June 6 (AP)Presi dent Chung Hee Park said to day during ceremonies mark ing South Korea's Memorial Day that North Korea had in tensified provocations in a search for an opportunity to renew hostilities against the South.

title: Miss Mary Jean McKee Is Married
description: IRVINGTON, N. Y., June 6 At the Irvington Presbyter ian Church this afternoon Miss Mary Jean McKee, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudyard Charles McKee of ArdsleyonHudson, became the bride of Norman Spencer Carmichael, son of Comdr. Horace Carmichael, U.S.C.G., retired, and Mrs. Carmichael, of Charlottesville Va.

title: The Court Acts to Block Wildcat Strikes
description: A twomonth wildcat strike by Los Angeles truck drivers against a national contract ne gotiated by their parent union ended last week, the first fruit of a change in Federal labor policy decreed by the Supreme Court.

title: Katharine Lindsay Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Katharine Hawes Lindsay, the quiet, introspec tive 19yearold daughter of Mayor and Mrs. John V. Lind say, was married on the lawn of Gracie Mansion yesterday afternoon to Richard Lance Schaffer, a 23yearold grad uate student she had met at the University of Pennsylvan ia.

title: 35 Years Later, It Still Sings
description: WE KNOW what hap piness is, the songs and the cartoon books have told us. But what about unhappiness? In Aviake and Sing un happiness is hats. Whenever the tiny apartment with the Motorola radio and the spare cot in the living room gets too crowded for anyone to endure, everyone puts on a hat, maybe to go to the movies. When Sam Fein schreiber, fallguy forever, finds out that his Hennie has married him only to dump a bastard child on him, he bolts into the dining room, sits down rigidly at the table without removing his coat or his hat, locking and unlock ing his legs at the ankles as though he might be able to keep himself from kicking the world apart. When Uncle Morty, the money  maker, gets mad enough at his inept relatives to wash his hands of them and call off the whole advantageous insur ance deal, he whips up his black fedora and slaps it onto his head as though that act alone passed sentence. When an old man, a grand father who cuts hair on the premises when he is not pre occupied with Caruso or Karl Marx, goes to the roof, the snow, to die, he puts on his ancient fur cap more quietly. But always hats end things, or threaten to end them.

title: Sights, Sounds And Scents
description: A VISIT to the Oriental Stroll Garden of the Hammond Museum in North Salem, N. Y., sharpens the senses. There is the gurgling of a small waterfall, the crunch of gravel under feet, and a faint odor of thyme. There is a tiny splash and a golden carp flicks through dark water in the main pool it seems more beautiful than any fish ever seen.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALTHOUGH various, types of anchors for fasten ing to brick, concrete, plaster and tile have been available for many years, some people still feel a sense of hopelessness when faced with the task of fasten ing to surfaces of this kind.

title: NEW COURSE SET AT L.B.J. SCHOOL
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 6An idea for producing govern mental problemsolvers with peripheral vision has been evolved for the new Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Af fairs that will open Sept 3 at the University of Texas here.

title: LONG ISLAND CLUB WINS IN LACROSSE
description: BALTIMORE, June 6The Long Island Athletic Club won its third straight national club lacrosse championship tonight by beating Maryland, 115, at Norris Field before more than 3,000 fans.

title: LONGSHOREMEN JEER PALME AT COLLEGE
description: GAMBIER, Ohio, June 6 (AP)  Premier Olof Paime of Sweden refused to he shouted down by demonstrating long shoremen today during a speech at Kenyon College.

title: Goa: Cte d'Azur IndianStylete
description: PANGIM, GoaMost visitors to In dia meet their first Goan un knowinglywhen they sit down in a Bombay restaurant and give their order to the bowing, smiling maitre d'. He is probably from the tiny coastal enclave of Goa, a man trained in European civility by the Portuguese and who has reluctantly emigrated to Bombay because bigcity money is available there.

title: Robert Kennedy's Words Sung In Mass Marking Assassination
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) The words of Senator Robert F. Kennedy were heard at Ar lington National Cemetery to night. They were read by his sons and sung by a youthful chorus to joyful folk rhythms in a mass commemorating the second anniversary of his as sassination.

title: Concerns Adding Their Own Stock
description: The Chemical New York Corporation, a $10billion bank holding company, has spotted what it thinks is a good buy in the stock mar ket: Its own stock.

title: Forgotten White House Is Back in Business
description: WASHINGTON  The pencilled sign under the edge of the door mat says, Please Ring Bell for Admission. This in formal touch welcomes visitors to Octa gon House, a dignified Federal mansion at 1799 New York Avenue, just two blocks southwest of the White House.

title: Magazine Reports Standard Changes For 5 Dog Breeds
description: The June issue of Dog World, a monthly magazine published in Westchester, Ill., a Chicago suburb is devoted to breed standards. The last time such an issue was pub lished was two years ago. In the interval the standards for five breeds have been changed. They are the Dober man pinscher, Skye, Dandie Din and Nor wich terrier, and the Norwegian elkhound. Helen Nowicki, Dog World's editor, told of the changes. She said that the Doberman standard had been altered substan tially and those of the other breeds slightly. She said that the magazine's biennial special issue was useful to judges, exhibitors, breeders, and newcomers who wanted to know more about their breeds.

title: THOMPSON LEADS IN KIWANIS GOLF
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va., June 6 (UPI)  Rocky Thompson fought off bogey trouble today and finished with a par 72 for a total of 210 and a onestroke lead in the $250,000 Kiwanis Peninsula open golf.

title: The Culinary Travels of a Gourmet
description: Some one hundred cookbooks will have been published in the 1970 springsummer season more than that were published between last September and December.

title: BRIAR COURT WINS FIRST JUMP TITLE
description: READINGTON, N. J., June 6  Briar Court, a former race horse with a sulky disposition and no speed, won the open jumper championship at the Four Seasons Farm Horse Show today in a sea of mud and rain.

title: Marcos Says He Favors Asian Parley on Cambodia
description: MANILA, June 6President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he was in favor of an all Asian meeting on Cambodia, which the 12 Asian nations that met last month in Jakarta had proposed to Secretary Gen eral Thant of the United Na tions.

title: New and Recommended
description: FICTION

title: Advertising:
description: One of the big marketing stories of last week was that the new coasttocoast Atlantic Richfield Company represented by 24,000 serv ice stations in 46 states  was about to start a $60 million program that would link all those stations to gether with a common brand of gasolineARCO.

title: Marriages
description: CHANDLERSOMMERSMr. and Mrs. Jo seph A. Chandler of Woodmere, L.I., are pleased to announce the marriage of their daughter Cindy Jo to Mr. Jeffrey Lee Sommers. The groom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Sommers of Woodmere, L. I., Thursday, June 4, 1970.

title: Soviet Committee Presses For Meeting on Olympics
description: MOSCOW, June 6 (AP)The Soviet Olympic Committee, smarting from rejection of Moscow's bid to stage the 1976 Olympics, indicated today it would press for reform of the International Olympic Com mittee.

title: Patriots Sign Wirgowski
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)The Boston Patriots of the National Football League today signed Dennis Wirgowski, a 6foot5 inch 254pound defensive end from Purdue.

title: More Money for V.A.
description: To attempt to rectify the de teriorating and in some places tragic conditions in Veterans Administration hospitals, the House has just passed an ap propriation for the V.A. for the fiscal year 1971 of about $122 million more than has been, or will be, appropriated for the fiscal year 1970.

title: Mrs. Jensen Is Remarried
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 6Mrs. Jane Gillespie Jensen and Charles William Bonner 3d, both of New York, were married here today at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. C. Waring Gillespie. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Lee Fairchild, a Presbyterian min ister from Mount Kisco. N. Y.

title: Teamsters and Professors Unite in Wisconsin College Dispute
description: WHITEWATER, Wis., June 2A man alone hasn't got a chance, said the shop stew ard of Teamsters' Local 579 (Whitewater Shop).

title: Letters: In on the Kill in Kenya
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Survival of a Free Society
description: The issues that have aroused and shaken the na tion are far too serious to be settled in the gutter. Revolutionary posturing by the extremist fringe onthe left and Vice President Agnew's ugly truculence on the right give aid and comfort only to those who seek political conquest in divisiveness. The brick throwers and the brawlers only discredit dissent; the toughs and the flag wavers only radicalize those who ought to play the indispensable role of loyal oppo sition.

title: Bridal at Home For Kyle Ford
description: NEW BRITAIN, Conn., June 6Miss Kyle Ford and John Lee Bunce Schutz were mar ried here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents. The ceremony was performed by Judge William Ford of the Connecticut Pro bate Court, an uncle of the bride.

title: Canadian Shipments Of Meat Top Forecast
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP)Canada shipped 25.2 million pounds of meat to the United States during the first four months of this year, or more than half of the amount Agriculture Department ex perts had expected for all of 1970.

title: James Cook to Wed Alison Buck
description: NEW HAVEN, June 6 Miss Alison Buck, a candi date for a master's degree in theater at Mount Holyoke College, and James Scott Cook, an architect, plan to be married in early Septem ber in the Russell Sage Chapel of the Northfield (Mass.) School.

title: Children Offer Their Contributions as a New Community School Opens in Greenwich Village
description: The Village Community School, a new private elemen tary school in Greenwich Vil lage, opened its doors to the public for the first time last week. It will begin its first semester in September.

title: New England Muscle Keeps The Firemen's Muster Alive
description: NEWBURY, Mass.The firemen's muster, one of the oldest organ ized sports in the United States, has thrilled spectators across the country for generations, but these days it seems that New England is doing the most to keep this fairgoers' spectacle alive.

title: PICTURE CREDITS
description: 1HARRY BENSON

title: Daubed R.O.T.C.Cenfer Restored at Connecticut
description: STORRS, Conn., June 6 The University of Connecti cut's Reserve Officer Training Corps building, which re ceived a psychedelic paint job during last month's stu dent strike, was restored to its original muted red today by a score of student and faculty volunteers wielding paint brushes and rollers

title: TITLE SOCCER SERIES OPENS HERE TODAY
description: The GermanHungarians and the New York GreekAmeri cans, winners of the German American Soccer League's South and North Groups, respectively, will meet at 3 P.M. today in the first of two playoff games for the league title at Metropol itan Oval in Maspeth, Queens.

title: Kodes Vanquishes Franulovic In French Final, 62, 64, 60
description: PARIS, June 6Jan Kodes, who said the way he was play ing he could have beaten Tony Roche in straight sets on clay, won the men's singles cham pionship of the $100,000 French open tennis tournament today.

title: Wide Power Brownouts Likely in East in Summer
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 Much of the Eastern half of the nation is almost certain to have some dislocation of elec trical service this summer.

title: Nixon and Congress : Test of Will on Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON  After three weeks of perhaps historic but slowmoving debate, the Senate last week got around to the first crucial vote on the Cambodian issue. The test of strength went against the Nixon Administra on and indicated that a majori ty in the Senate was determined to impose legislative limitations on future military activities in Cambodia.

title: Hannover Ties Stockholm In Intertoto Soccer, 11
description: HANNOVER, West Germany, June 6 (UPI)Hannover 96 played its third scoreless tie in the Intertoto soccer round today11 against Djurgaar den Stockholm.

title: Israeli Generals Soviet Missiles
ASTRONAUTS SAID TO ADAPT TO SPACE
description: A medical study of the first five manned Apollo flights has found that the 15 astronauts involved generally adapted well to the weightless environ ment during their 3,105 hours in space, but that all these men lost weight and some had minor medical problems.

title: SCHOOL SLAPPING TO BRING PROTEST
description: Three students of the Lyce Frangaise de New York said yesterday that they would com plain to the French Consul Gen eral about being slapped by Hugues Homo, a member of the French consulate here, because they sat down while The Star Spangled Banner was being played at a commencement ex ercise.

title: Red Sox Game Rained Out
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)Rain forced a postponement today of the game between the Boston Red Sox and Kansas City Roy als. Officials scheduled a double header for tomorrow to make up the postponed game.

title: Jungle Cove, 1110, Wins As Chompion Runs Second
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP) James Cox Brady's Jungle Cove led all the way and held on for a head victory over fastclosing Chompion in the $39,000 Cus ter Memorial Handicap today. A rainy day crowd of 17,329 turned out at Suffolk Downs.

title: Jews to Celebrate Start of Shabuoth Sundown Tuesday
description: Shabuoth, the Jewish com memoration of the time Moses gave the Ten Commandments to the Jewish people, will start at sundown on Tuesday with observances in temples and syn agogues.

title: A Tourist's Calendar Of Eastern Events
description: MAINE

title: ADMIRAL'S SHIELD DELAWARE VICTOR
description: STANTON, Del., June 6 (AP) Red Tree Farm's Easily Best and William C. Robinson Jr.'s Admiral's Shield captured the two divisions of the Kent Stakes today at Delaware Park on a turf softened by rain.

title: D.S.Ely Weds Diana Fricke
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 6 Miss Diane Louise Fricke and David Stanley Ely were married here today in the First Congregational Church by the Rev. Samuel Fogal.

title: Personality:
description: When Aubrey C. Lewis reached the F. W. Woolworth Company in 1967 as an exec utiveoffice recruiter by way of Montclair High School, the University of Notre Dame, Paterson Central High School and the Federal Bu reau of Investigation, his F.B.I. training came in handy.

title: NAVY SETS BACK WISCONSIN CREW
description: MADISON, Wis., June 6 (AP) Navy defeated Wisconsin to day in a crew race on Lake Mendota that was halted for several minutes because of an injury to a Wisconsin oarsman.

title: Mary Marshall Attended by Five At Jersey Bridal
description: CHATHAM, N. J., June Miss Mary Beth Marshall and William Edward O'Con nell were married here this afternoon in the Chatham United Methodist Church by the Rev. Robert Drew Simp son. He was assisted by the Rev. John P. O'Connell of the Holy Family Roman Catholic Church in Florham Park.

title: U.S. ENDS FREEZE ON ILLINOIS FUNDS
description: EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., June 6 A 23month freeze of Feder al highway construction funds for St. Clair and Madison coun ties ended this week, seeming ly short of its goal of stopping discrimination against blacks in hiring for highway work.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: ATLANTIC CITY

title: HEALTH UNIT PLAN GAINS IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 6A National Council on Health Pol icies, which would be the first group set up to advise the Pres ident on medical affairs, would be created under a plan that may reach the Senate floor next week.

title: MISS ENGLEHORN SETS MARK ON 67
description: LUTHERVILLE, Md., June 6 (UPI)Shirley Englehorn of Palm Desert, Calif., moved into a firstplace tie with Carol Mann after two rounds in the $22,500 Lady Carling open golf tournament today with a 67 for 139.

title: Anniversaries
description: FELDMANDorothy and Manuel. Congratula tions on your 35th wedding anniversary on June 9. All our love, Steve, Linda, Carole, Howie, Michael and Jill. SCHOENHarry and Frances Schoen happily celebrated their 50th wedding anniversary June 4, 1970.

title: 2 ANTIWAR OFFICERS LOSE BRIEFING JOBS
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) Two members of the first known antiwar organization op erating at the officer level have been removed from their intel ligence jobs in the office of the Chief of Naval Operations.

title: PENTAGON MOVIING TO REDUCE FORCES.
description: WASHINGTON, June 6The Defense Department is moving cautiously to reduce the size of the armed services, but Pen tagon planners doubt that the force can be cut to 2.5 million menthe preVietnam level in the immediate future.

title: SHRIVER BACKS OFF FROM PARTY FIGHT
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 6 (UPI)Sargent Shriver, for mer Ambassador to France, said today he did not want to become entangled in an argu ment between party officials in Congress and the National Democratic Committee chair man, Lawrence O'Brien, over a proposed national council for Congressional leadership.

title: A Third Party May Be A Real Force in '72
description: WASHINGTON. IT is not unlikely or unreasonable to believe that there will be a lib eral third  party movement by 1972. Dissatisfaction with the two major parties is widespread. This dissatisfaction is not regional or sec tional. It is not restricted to one economic or cultural group, but is based upon frustration and disap pointment which has a historical base.

title: Saigon Army's Field Rations Sell Briskly in a Cambodian Town
description: NEAK LUONG, Cambodia, June 2As the United States landing craft Showboat 89 unloaded food, ammunition and other supplies at this Mekong river town in Cam bodia today, shopkeepers and free agents on a once sleepy street just above the landing area were doing a brisk busi ness in items from the Show boat's earlier deliveries.

title: My Texas Dandy, $53.20, Triumphs in Omaha Sprint
description: OMAHA, June 6 (AP)A pair of long shots finished onetwo in the $20,000 added AkSar Ben Handicap today.

title: Space
description: Neil Armstrong was in Moscow on a visit last week when the Soviet Union launched its latest manned space mission  Soyuz 9. There was no particular con nection between the two events, but they illustrated the continuing performance gap between the manned flight programs of the two space powers.

title: Gibson Assails Addonizio as Divisive
description: NEWARK, June 6Kenneth A. Gibson, a candidate for Mayor, told an audience of blacks and whites today that their meeting together was an answer to the fear and divi siveness injected into the cam paign by Mayor Hugh J. Addo nizio, who is running for re election.

title: Contract Awarded
description: LOS ANGELES, May 30 (UPI)  Sargent Industries, Inc., has obtained a $6mil lion contract from the Mc Donnell Douglas Corporation to make passenger evacua tion systems for DCI0 air craft. The work will be done at San Francisco and Hunt ington Park, Calif.

title: Residence at Harvard Dedicated to Kennedy
description: CAMBRIDGE. Mass., June 6 (AP)  John Winthrop House at Harvard Univer sity, where President Ken nedy resided as a student, has been dedicated to his memory and converted into a guest suite, the university disclosed.

title: Heavy July Rains Will Affect War
description: SAIGONThe war in South Vietnam has always been a se ries of regional and local affairs, but it has become even more fractionalized since the allies en tered. Cambodia. Last week it looked more like a dozen wars than a single struggle.

title: Two Giants Battle Over Schumann
description: SCHUMANN's Kreisleri ana is a strikingly ro mantic work, in turns gentle, furious, myste rious and loving. It runs the whole gamut of heightened emotions Schumann was so fond of. It is monumental in size, extremely difficult to play and all but defies shape liness.

title: Chess
description: A FOURMAN student team from Brookline, Mass., won first place in the recent 1970 U. S. High School championship at the Hotel McAlpin, New York. Scoring 22 game points during the eightround event, Brookline topped its nearest rivals, Bayside, Queens, N. Y., and Roosevelt, Des Moines Iowa by a halfpoint.

title: SegregationOr Else
description: George Wallace's primary election once more raises sharply the question of that fabulously outmoded de vice of American politics, the Electoral College. Logi cally, a single party's choice for the governorship Alabama should not be a matter of greats national con cern; but it is just that in the case of Mr. Wallace's victory, narrow as it was. For he is now in an ideal position to turn the Electoral College to his purposes.

title: Dance
description: THE Royal Ballet left us last week, and quite frankly it may have left us for the last time.

title: Book Carnival at the Capital
description: At this moment, while most Americans are honoring their Day of Rest, 3,500 brethren in the bookpublishing industry from all parts of the nation are converging on the Shore ham Hotel in steamy Washing ton, D. C. For today marks the start of the annual fourday convention of the American Booksellers Association. Four days of exhibits, by approxi mately 300 publishers, of their key fall and Christnias wares, panel discussions on topics like The Role of the Wholesaler in Successful Bookselling and Children's BooksWhere and How to Sell Them, luncheons where worldrenowned authors and dignitaries provide glam our and apreschicken delight.

title: As Inflation Rises and Hems Fall, Retailers Worry
description: Inflation, the murky out look of the economy and the mood of the consumer on domestic and foreign affairs will have a more profound effect on fall retail business than will the currently hot issue of how long a hem the average American wo man prefers on her clothes.

title: New Chief of P.O.D. Philately
description: WILLIAM D. DUNLAP, who collected stamps as a boy while growing up in Austin, Minn., and whose in terest in the hobby has not faded although he hasn't been active as a collector for many years, is going to have a powerful effect on the United States stampissuing program. Last week, Post master General Winton M. Blount announced that Mr. Dunlap had been appointed Deputy Special Assistant for Philatelic Affairs and Special Projects. Since the spring of 1969, Mr. Dunlap has been a public information advisor for the Post Office Depart ment, having joined the de partment after years at Proc tor and Gamble, Cincinnati, where he was brand mar keting manager. master General Winton M. Blount announced that Mr. Dunlap had been appointed Deputy Special Assistant for Philatelic Affairs and Special Projects. Since the spring of 1969, Mr. Dunlap has been a public information advisor for the Post Office Depart ment, having joined the de partment after years at Proc tor and Gamble, Cincinnati, where he was brand mar keting manager.

title: Point of View
description: The industrial economy of the United States has not been prepared for peace. In 1969, 3.4 million Americans worked in industry on Penta gon orders, 1.1 million civil ians were on the Pentagon payroll and 3.4 million Amer icans served in the uniformed armed forces. Adding those

title: GOLDMANN FEELS PEACE IS POSSIBLE
description: Dr. Nahum Goldmann, Zion ist leader and president of the World Jewish Congress, be lieves that fear of world war by both the Soviet Union and the United States is a major factor working for the restora tion of peace in the Middle East.

title: F.D.A. Gives Cautious Approval To Ldopa
description: The Food and Drug Ad ministration gave cautious ??pproval last week to the marketing of the drug Ldopa for the treatment of Parkin son's disease, an affliction of the nervous system. Dr. Charles C. Edwards, Com missioner of Food and Drugs, said in making the an nouncement: As a treat ment for Parkinson's disease, [the drug] is important to possibly as many as a mil lion Americans suffering from this affliction.

title: Romney Seeks to Clear Path For Housing For Poor
description: WASHINGTON  While the policy makers in the White House have been pursuing the allegiance of the silent majority and the technicians in the Budg et Bureau have been trying to keep the lid on Government spending, George Romney at the Department of Housing and Urban Development, in an orbit all his own, has been worrying and fretting about what is hap pening in the cities.

title: Rome's Roaming Prices
description: ROMEThe custom whereby some downtown shops quote prices in American dollars as well as in Italian lire is calculated to help tourists. But this calculating visitor re cently figured that the bilingual price system can multiply problems, instead of adding up to a convenience.

title: War Critic in House Race
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., June 6 (AP)Dennis J. Morrisseau, a former Army lieutenant who joined an antiwar demonstra tion in front of the White House two years ago while in uniform, has announced his candidacy for the United States House seat held by Robert T. Staf ford, a Republican. I consider myself a Democrat, and I will be filing for that primary in just a few weeks, Mr. Morris seau said Thursday.

title: Boating Through Florida
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla.Nearly 15, 000 miles of navigable inland waterways bring an almost end less flow of boatmen to Florida. There are 1,700 rivers of varying lengths and 7,700 named lakes, and they com bine to offer excellent fishing, celebrated scenery and waterside stopoffs at a number of famous historical sites.

title: KNAPP SAYS LAWS SPUR POLICE GRAFT
description: The chairman of the new commission investigating cor ruption within the New York Police Department said last week that the state laws regu lating gambling, business on the Sabbath and the private sexual acts of consenting adults were an important cause of police corruption.

title: Fredericka Anne Savage Is Wed
description: GARRISON, Md., June 6 Miss Fredericka Anne Sav age, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Adams Savage of Owings Mills, was married here this afternoon to John Knox Shaw 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shaw Jr. of Glyn don. The Rev. George Sin kinson Jr. performed the ceremony in St. Tomas Epis copal Church.

title: Don't Sell Out Stands as a Motto for Many College Students in the Class of '70
description: PALO ALTO, Calif.In the next five, or 10 years, I want to maintain my political aware ness and keep working in poli tics, said Rick Stewart, as he sipped a cup of coffee in the student union. I don't want to sell out, I don't want to take a 9to5 job and escape with the kids to the mountains on the weekend.

title: That Subscription Crowd Must Go!
description: WE may well look back upon this season as the one in which the first moves were made to exor cise from our musical life that inescapable poltergeist, the habitual sub scriber. Hisor, more likely, herrap ping, rattling and clattering turn most performances at Lincoln Center into an ordeal for those of us who go to hear music only. Our one hope is that ap proaching Federal aid, changing admis sion policies and escalating audience militancy will combine, as they started to do this season, to free the opera, ballet and concerts from the curse of subscription performances.

title: Hudson's Republican Chief Will Not Seek ReElection
description: JERSEY CITY, June 6 (UPI) John Beier Theurer, Republican party chairman of Hudson County for 17 years, says he will not seek reelection.

title: U.S. Business:
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 6 Philadelphia employers in search of manpower are now doing sonic of their recruit ing through a job bank.

title: Swiss Voting Today on a Plan To Cut ForeignWorker Level
description: GENEVA, June 6I have nothing against individual Ital ians. But there are now so many foreign workers in Switzerland that the Swiss people no longer feel at home in their own country. How, would the Italians feel if there were 10 million Germans living in Italy?

title: Annual Reports Draw Criticism
description: This year's spate of annual reports drew some criticism in a nationwide poll of pro fessional opinion on compa nies' ??early statements.

title: A multiple picture of some powerful personalities
description: Catherine Drinker Bowen, possibly the foremost living American writer of biography, has at long last written a book about her own remarkable family. She calls it Family Portrait. It is autobiographical only in periph ery; it is an intricate multiple picture of many men and women, powerful personalities, admirable if not always likable; written with wis dom, depth, truthfulness and an art less freshness like the unsullied air of the early century when Mrs. Bowen was young. This is a book to be read and savored in layers, a book within book.

title: Utility Leader Foresees Critical Summer in 1970
description: BOSTON. Mass.  This will be the critical summer for the electric utilities. Al though reserve margins are somewhat better than last year, if it really gets hot, we could have brownouts or even blackouts in New Eng land, New York, the Pennsyl vaniaNew JerseyMaryland Power Pool region and per haps the entire Midwest.

title: In The Camera World
description: VOLUNTEER Service Photographers, Inc., an organization de voted to helping hos pital patients and children through photography, is hold ing a Camera Coach Cruise of Long Island on Saturday to benefit the organization's programs. A chartered air conditioned bus will leave Pennsylvania station at 8:30 A.M. and return at 6 P.M.

title: NIXON POPULARITY INCREASES IN POLL
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 6 President Nixon has registered steady gains in popularity over the last two months, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: The Lone Granger
description: The Cincinnati Reds played 162 games last season, the normal quota. Wayne Granger performed in 90 of them and that's a positively abnormal quota. If he had been a fillin operative at any of eight other positions, not an eyebrow would have been raised. But the tall and lean righthander is a pitcher and no pitcher in the history of the game ever made as many appear ances as he did in his record contributions to the cause.

title: Flower Shows and Tours
description: NEXT Sunday, Dr. Cyn thia Westcott, noted plant patholgist, rose authority and author, will hold her 30th annual Rose Day at Springvale, Croton onHudson, N.Y. The public is invited from 2 to 6 P.M. Honor guests will be Frank Benardella, trustee of the American Rose Society, and rose hybridist, Jack Lisse more. Members of the West chester Rose Society and the Springvale Garden Club will serve punch and cookies. Springvale is located on Route 9A between Croton and Peekskill.

title: Sandler, Forced to Play LeftHanded, Loses A.A.U. Handball Final
description: Mark Levine, an 18year old Brooklyn College fresh man majoring in political science, won the Amateur Athletic Union national one wall handball championship yesterday by upsetting Steve Sandler of the 92d Street Y.M.H.A., 215, 2111, at the Municipal Courts in Coney Island. Sandler, topseeded and the defending champion, had also won the title in 1966 and 1967.

title: Letters
description: JUDGE KAUFMAN'S DECISION

title: Sendak Raises The Shade On Childhood
description: AT the age of 3 or 4, Maurice Sendak recalls, I was con valescing after a long, serious illness. I was sitting on my grand mother's lap, and I remember the feeling of pleasant drowsiness. It was winter. We sat in front of a window, and my grandmother pulled the shade up and down to amuse me. Every time the shade went up, I was thrilled by the sudden reap pearance of the backyard, the falling snow and my brother and sister busy constructing a sooty snowman.

title: Lynn Walchli, Alumna of Ithaca, Wed to James Idell, Cornell '71
description: WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass June 6  Miss Lynn Walchli, who was graduated magna cum laude last month from Ithaca College, was married this afternoon to James Beatty Idell, a member of the class of '71 at Cornell University. The Rev. Arthur Melanson performed the ceremony in the First Congregational Church.

title: A strange and melancholy setting, almost a character in itself
description: . . . In the Highlands Since Time Immemorial, as its very title indi cates, is a story in which the physical setting plays as powerful a part as any of the more mobile characters. The Highlands in question lie in the northeastern corner of Scotland, in Invernessshire, an area which some times even today seems as far from the Scottish capital Edinburgh as Edinburgh does from London. The climate is hard, with an arduous winter, and spring hardly coming before May. Husbandry is difficult and wind and space, as Miss Ostrow puts it, often seem in more abundant supply to the inhabitants than other more fertile symbols.

title: Bells Are Ringing for Firemen
description: A number of firemen's musters will be held in New Eng land this summer. Among them will be those in Acton, Mass., next Saturday; Richmond, Me., June 20; Mystic, Conn., June 27; Peabody, Mass., July 4; Topsham, Me., July 11; Newburyport, Mass., July 25 and Aug. 2; East Greenwich, R. I., Aug. 8; Essex, Mass., Aug. 22, and Mar blehead, Mass., Sept. 5.

title: Spy Ship Incident
description: At first it looked like another Pueblo incident, only worse. North Korea's radio announced priday that a heavilyarmed spy ship of the United States imperialist aggressor army had entered North Korean waters and been promptly sunk. But with in an hour of the broadcast, a Pentagon spokesman denied that any American ship had been sunk or was even in the area in question, off the west coast of Korea, adjacent to the Yellow sea. He added, We understand that there has been an encounter between some North and South Korean vessels.

title: A Word Or Two To Agnew
description: Vice President Spiro Agnew has been making good on his promise earlier this year to keep calling the shots as he sees them no matter how much the liberals may disapprove. He has leveled attacks on the press, Senate doves, youthful dissenters, peace demonstrators and liberal critics in general. Last week his choicer epithets were criminal misfits and charlatans of peace.

title: DR. A. M. ROSS DIES; LABOR EXPERT, 54
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 6 Dr. Arthur M. Ross, vice president of the University of Michigan and former United States Commissioner of Labor Statistics, was found dead to day in a motel in Allen Park near Detroit. His age was 54. Dr. Ross had been on a busi ness trip for the university. The death was apparently from natural causes, the state police said.

title: Woman, 80, Gets Diploma
description: YORK, Pa., June 6 (AP) About 400 teenagers and an 80yearold woman were grad uated this week from William Penn Senior High School. The woman, Mrs. B. Hay Gilbert, who began attending night classes in the nineteenforties, said she would advise today's students to continue their edu cation as long as possible.

title: Greece Said to Weigh Cutting Required Schooling to 5 Years
description: ATHENS, May 31Propos als to reduce Greece's require ment of six years of schooling by one year or even two are receiving serious consideration from the country's military Government, according to re liable but unofficial sources.

title: Niarchos Dedicates Drydock In Greece to His Late Wife
description: ATHENS, June 6  The Stavros Niarchos Hellenic Ship yards today inaugurated a new 240,000ton drydock, and Mr, Niarchos named it after his wife, Eugenia, who died five weeks ago of an overdose of barbiturates.

title: The Right Place To Write
description: Historians are prisoners, but like all prisoners they dream of flight. My friend Angus Wilson goes off to the desert near Marrakesh or to the teathreaded hills behind Colombo and so dodges the vile English winter, allows his fertile and highly creative imagination to simmer and boil as sun  drenched day follows sun drenched day in peace and quiet and work, and returns with another splendid book finished. As one plods grimly through the slush and snow to the University Library at Cam bridge, facing the piercing northwest er that drives month after month across the huge college lawns, how can one fail to bemoan one's lot?

title: Article 5  No Title
description: More News Of Sports On Page 27

title: Voices of Harvard '70
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. THE party, in the Cambridge Boat Club on the Charles, on the second warm night of spring, honors Nicholas Gagarin, Harvard '70. His novel, Windsong, is published today.

title: U.S. AUTO CLUB LISTS $350,000 IN PRIZES
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 6 The United States Auto Club announced this week that its 1970 and 1971 championship races would have a $350,000 sponsorship from Philip Morris, Inc., on behalf of the com pany's Marlboro cigarettes.

title: Try a Little Taoism
description: ORIGINALITYthe oldfashioned idea of genius now strikes me as absurd. The idea of try ing to be different is completely idiotic.

title: Fertilizer Producers See Recovery
description: After several lean years that played havoc with prof its, producers of fertilizer materials are showing faint smiles.

title: Monmouth Lockeys
At Dawn
description: They sing now before 5:00 in the morning, and you don't have to be up and out of doors to hear them. You can lie in bed and listen. You can't very well fail to listen if you are awake, for the dawn chorus of the songbirds is very special now. In another two or three weeks it will taper off to a few voices and there will be virtually no singing between dawn and dusk. But the sunrise hallelujah is still with us.

title: TRAVEL
Savage Wins Mile in 4:05.2 In N.A.I.A. Championships
description: BILLINGS, Mont., June 6 AP)Texas Southern won the 140yard relay in a disappoint ??ng 40 seconds today and Dennis Savage of Westmont (Calif.) College retained his ??itle in the mile run in they National Association of Inter collegiate Athletics champion ships.

title: Ribicoff Says His Choice For Senate Is Joe Duffey
description: HARTFORD, June 6Sen ator Abraham A. Ribicoff to day endorsed the Rev. Joseph D. Duffey for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from Connecticut.

title: Ottinger's Three Rivals Say He Exceeds Limit
description: The need to limit campaign expenditures has become one of the major issues in the four way race for the Democratic nomination for the United States Senate in this state.

title: HIGH ECHELON TAKES BELMONT STAKES FOR JACOBSES; YANKEES DEFEAT WHITE SOX, 31
description: Don't look now, but the Yankees won their fifth game in a row yesterday when they defeated the Chicago White Sox, 31, on a sixhitter by John Cumberland.

title: Architecture Mailbag
description: East 53d Going, Going...

title: Record in Delinquent Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (AP) Delinquent and uncollected taxes reached an alltime high in 1969, the Internal Revenue Service advised Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Dela ware. The service said delin quent Federal taxes were over $2billion, an increase of 27 per cent from the preceding year. Taxes rated uncollectable to taled $228.7million.

title: A MaskedArt Party on L. I. Will Benefit Hampton Day School
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., June 6The scholarship fund of the Hampton Day School in Bridgehampton will benefit from a MaskedArt Party at the Parrish Art Museum here on June 30.

title: Up Against the Wall? Or Floored?
description: EXTREME cases? On first appearance, the sculpture of John Mc Cracken, now on view at the Sonnabend Gallery, 924 Madison Avenue, and the sculpture of Michael Steiner, currently being shown at the Marlborough Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, give the impres sion of being so. In McCrack en's case, the sculpture is quite literally  and deco rouslyup against the wall; in Steiner's, it has been com pletely floored.

title: The Week in Finance:
description: Whether the United States now needs an incomes policy of some sort to aid in the prolonged battle against inflation has become one of the hottest questions in the economic realm.

title: New Orleans Skipper Wins British Soling Class Sail
description: POOLE, England, June 6 (AP) John Dane 3d of New Orleans won the Soling Class of the British national sailing cham pionships today.

title: Lording It in London, Bertie Wooster Fashion
description: LONDONI had asked My Man to call for me at 10:30 A.M. At 10:29, the doorbell rang  and there he stood at my doorstep in his neat brown uniform, a small smile on his discreet pink face.

title: Unveilings
description: BERMANRubin. Unveiling in loving memory on Sunday June 14, 1 PM. New Mount Carmel Cemetery, Cypress Hills Street at Cooper Avenue. Brooklyn.

title: Barrientos Out points Kadota
description: MANILA, June 6 (AP)Rene Barrientos, a former World Box ing Council junior lightweight champion, defeated Shinichi Ka lota of Japan in a 10round bout tonight. Barrientos weighed 134 pounds, Kadota 134.

title: Black Art and Expedient Politics
description: BOSTON. WRITING last Sunday about the exhibition called AfroAmeri can Artists: New York. and Boston, currently on view at the Museum of Fine Arts, I suggested that the concept of black art put forth by Edmund B. Gaither, the black organizer of the exhibition, was funda mentally a political concep tion. Implicit in the distinctions Mr. Gaither has drawn in his Introduction to the cat alogue of this show, I wrote, is an assumption that black art is to be exempted from the customary application of critical discriminations based on purely artistic values.

title: F. and M. Names Keating Outstanding Senior Athlete
description: E. Michael Keating of Wayne, Pa., for three years the leading member of the Franklin and Marshall College swimming team, was recently given the outstanding senior athlete award at the college's spring sports dinner.

title: Scoutmaster Spots Pot
description: CLEVELAND, June 6 (UPI) The police said Leslie Pochedly, 26 years old, who cleared a plot of land in a city park here and planted 20,000 seedlings, was arrested because a scout master knew the difference be tween pot and poplar. The scoutmaster and his troop were checking tree seedlings they had planted in the Rocky River Reservation when they disc?? er?? the 20,000 ??inchtall m??uana seedlings.

title: A bizarre triangle playing out a paranoid tragedy
description: Truly unconventional writing has nothing to do with hallucinatory prose adventures, or tricks of style, or selfconscious appearances by the writer in his own work; it is only a matter of discovery or rediscovery, a revelation of surprising and there fore unconventional emotions with in a framework that may appear absolutely ordinary. What point is there to experimental writing when it reveals to us familiar ideas, familiar faces? Much of what passes today for experimental writing is simply derivative, taken over from Sartre, Ionesco, Beckett and others; it is certainly not experimental in the sense in which it tries out new visions of the world.

title: Veeck to Testify This Week In Flood's Antitrust Action
description: Curt Flood's antitrust suit contesting baseball's reserve clause resumes tomorrow in Federal court here with the for mer major league club owner, Bill Veeck, among those sched uled to testify during the week.

title: House Panel Urged to Curb Soaring Campaign Costs
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 (UP) The National Committee for an Effective Congress says that if limits are not placed on tele vision campaign spending pub lic office will become the pre serve of the rich and the cor rupt.

title: Car Rams Police Cruiser
description: CINCINNATI, June 6 (UPI) Joseph Rahn, 21 years old, was charged with reckless driving this week after the police said he deliberately ran his car into a parked police cruiser. I just felt like ramming a police car, he told the police.

title: Deputy Police Commissioner For Trials Named by Leary
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary has appointed Benja min Ward as the new Deputy Police Commissioner in charge of police disciplinary trials.

title: Hooks, Saia to CoCaptain Connecticut Wrestling Team
description: Randolph Hooks and John Saia have been named cocap tains of next winter's Univer sity of Connecticut wrestling team.

title: OHIO STATE AREA QUIET BUT TENSE
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 6 The shops lining the other side of North High Street no longer reflect the verdant Ohio State University campus in their dis play windows.

title: Test Tube Gene
description: A spirited scientific controversy was set off last fall when a group of Harvard researchers expressed grave misgivings over the possible consequences of their own work at the same time that they were reporting the first isolation of a gene, the basic unit of heredity. The researchers were worried about what would happen when men possessed the godlike pow ers of genetic engineering, when individualsand governmentscould manipulate the shapes and prop erties of living organisms as easily as General Motors decides the shapes and properties of its 1971 auto mobiles. These expressions of concern were promptly countered by skepticism of other scientists who argued that the time when genetic engineering would be pos sible is still far in the future.

title: STEWART ON POLE FOR BELGIAN RACE
description: FRANCORCHAMPS, Belgium, June 6 (Reuters)Jackie Stew art of Scotland gained the pole position in tomorrow's Belgian Grand Prixa race that is overshadowed by the death of Bruce McLaren and a bitter controversy over the safety of the international race circuit here.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Threat to Survival

title: Correction
description: Because of a typographical duplication, the legend of the review of Roger Kahn's The Battle for Morningside Heights stated that the book, besides being written by Mr. Kahn and published by William Morrow, was also edited by Robert A. Rosenbaum and published by Doubleday. In fact, Mr. Rosen baum and Doubleday accounted for another book reviewed on the same page and were so credited. Mr. Kahn informs us that he is a professional writer and capable of doing his own editing.

title: Paper Urges U.S. Pullout
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6 (UPI)  The Los Angeles Times, which in the past has support ed President Nixon's Vietnami zation program, called on him in an editorial prepared for to morrow's editions to withdraw all American forces from Viet nam in 18 months at the latest.

title: Facts on America's Cup
description: Q. What is the America' Cup?

title: London's Chelsea Losing Ground To Hippies and Highway Planners
description: LONDON  I was In the Chelsea Library, drinking coffee with those of the borough's residents who had gathered to fret over the fate of their embankment. They fear that a superhighway may be built to sever Chelsea from the Thames forever. The highway would cut off their view of the river, a view made famous in the paintings of Whistler and Turner. It would also ruin the sites of houses where Whistler painted the portrait of his mother and where Swinburne, Rossetti and Wilde did some writing.

title: ROTZ SAYS VICTOR NEEDED NO URGING
description: Maybe this is good for High Echelon, Patrice Jacobs was saying in the paddock before the 102d Belmont Stakes yes terday. Maybe it'll be his day, the only way he'll be able to get the glory.

title: The Unemployed Executive
description: Behind the statistics that detail the rising rate of whitecollar unemploy ment are the individuals involvedand their problems.

title: Economy Preoccupies East Germany
description: BERLIN, June 2Kurt Zir zow, a member of the Burow collective farm in East Ger many, told a Communist re porter that he and his colleagues had been unable to plant any summer wheat this year be cause of the cold and wet spring and that by the end of May only half of their potatoes were in the ground.

title: KY, IN PITOMPENH, GIVES ASSURANCE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 6Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky of South Vietnam said today that his country had no terri torial ambitions in Cambodia and that Saigon would send military forces to help Cam bodia whenever and wherever Pnompenh asked.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass.  Spotting the surf rods on the roof of my car, Al Doyle, a Martha's Vineyard painting contractor and ardent striped bass fisherman, said: You'd better get down to Wasque. They're catching blues and stripers right now.

title: Miss Gluck Is Bride of Joseph Treaster
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 6 A tiny island in the east branch of the Saugatuck River here was the setting this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Barbara Adele Gluck to Joseph B. Treaster. The ceremony was per formed by Rabbi A. Bruce Goldman and the Rev. Richard Mann, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: BONALLACK TAKES BRITISH AMATEUR
description: NEWCASTLE, Northern Ire land, June 6Mike Bonallack, the British Walker Cup captain became the first man to win three British Amateur golf championships in a row today when he beat aging Bill Hynd man of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. 8 and 7, in the final.

title: Dispute Is Spurred By Kicker
description: One of the most controver sialand bitterly criticized practices of lenders today is a fairly common method of financing large realestate ventures known as the kicker.

title: A Boon For Weekend Sailor: Winds When You Want Them
description: WE are weekend sailors who de pend upon Long Island Sound, with its calms, its gusts and its choppy, oftpolluted waters, for our weekend cruises. The simple motions of wind and water and the euphoric detachment that comes from the act of getting one's feet off solid ground spell adventure of the highest order.

title: Squashed Bust of an Emperor Restored by 2 Young Britons
description: LONDON, June 5A bronze head of the Roman Emperor Lucius Aurelius Verus, squash ed flat in an earthquake and discovered in the course of an excavation, has been restored into the round in six months' work by two young British re storers.

title: NONBLACKS FEEL KENYAN PRESSURE
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 3A Kenya official closed the busi nesses of several whites and many Asians yesterday in the town of Eldoret because they had failed to attend a rally celebrating an important na tional holiday.

title: KLECATSKY VICTOR IN SINGLES REGATTA
description: FRANKFURT, West Ger many, June 6 (UPI)  Larry Klecatsky, an American light weight sculling champion, rowed a borrowed boat to an easy threelength victory to day in the elite singles race at the annual Frankfurt in ternational regatta.

title: Harlem Holdup Victim Kills Suspect in Supermarket
description: While a holdup man held a gun at his back, a Harlem super market owner took a pistol out of his safe and opened fire, kill ing him, the police said yester day.

title: Visiting Nome Via Jetliner And Dog Team
description: NOME, AlaskaPeople are queue ing up outside the post office. Mail should arrive any minute. That is, if the dog team made it from Unalakleet and over the Yukon Trail from Fairbanks. But forget that scene  it occurred 70 years ago.

title: YUGOSLAVIA STUDIES ALBANIAN OVERTURE
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 6Enver Hoxha, the Albanian leader, is reported to have said that Albania desires the de velopment of good relations with Yugoslavia as well as feelings of friendship with the Peoples of Yugoslavia.

title: Observer: Let a Thousand Etceteras Bloom
description: WASHINGTON, June 6Notes for a commencement speech: I. Opening: (A) Joke. Funny thing hap pened to me on the way over here this morning etcetera. (Call Raymond; ask if he has any new campus jokes, gas mask laughs, etcetera boffos.)

title: Bich Views His Father's Cup Challenge as Just That
description: Scribbling notes while the young Frenchman talked the interviewer wondered what might happen if the youth's father's 12  Meter yacht worked as well as his ball point pens.

title: Two Share Hydro Race Lead
description: WASHINGTON, June 6 After a oneyear absence, pow erboating's glamour class, the unlimited hydroplanes, returned today to the Potomac River to compete in the 39th President's Cup regatta.

title: Article 1  No Title
CHINA'S ECONOMY GAINING UNEVENLY
description: HONG KONG, June 6Com munist China's economic devel opment appears to be moving ahead steadily if unevenly under a policy that aims at the best possible output from big defenserelated industries but puts primary emphasis on agri culture and small rural manu factures.

title: ANOTHER DISPUTE HITS OCEAN HILL
description: A new controversy involving charges of violation of due pro cess of law to protect the rights of teachers has flared in the Ocean HillBrownsville Demonstration School District in Brooklyn.

title: LIQUORI IS THIRD IN COMPTON MILE
description: LOS ANGELES, June 6 Arizona State's Chuck Labenz upset Martin Liquori of Vil lanova to win the Compton Mile in 3 minutes 59.5.seconds at the Compton invitation meet tonight.

title: LEADERS HOPEFUL AFTER PERU QUAKE
description: LIMA, Peru, June 6Despite the loss of at least 50,000 dead, and incalculable material dam age in last Sunday's earthquake, Peru's military leaders feel that their revolutionary programs will advance faster than ever.

title: The Merchant's View:
description: Department store volume continues to hold a slight edge over the level of sales last year as retailers strug gle with the problems of in flation and the general lag in the economy. In the week ended an Memorial Day, sales were fractionally below those of the year before, but for the month of May, they managed to hold a dollar gain of about 3 per cent.

title: Affluent Children Attend Pilot Camp Of Fresh Air Fund
description: During the twomonth sum mer vacation period beginning in July, about 2,500 needy boys and girls from economically blighted areas of the city will have a chance to live, learn and play together at the Fresh Air Fund's Sharpe Reservation camping center in Dutchess County.

title: Miss Allaire Married to R. E. Cacchione
description: Miss Judith Ann Allaire, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Raymond Allaire of Union City, N. J., was mar ried at the main altar of St. Patrick's Cathedral here yes terday afternoon to Robert Edward Cacchione, son of Mr. and Mrs. Mario Cacchione of Rye and Larchmont Manor, N. Y. Msgr. Eugene Clark performed the ceremony.

title: South's Voter Education Project Becomes an Independent Force
description: ATLANTA, June 6  The Voter Education Project, which helped more than a million Ne groes register to vote in the South when it was aligned with the Southern Regional Council, is now functioning as a sepa rate, independent organization.

title: Cornell Meeting Suggests Ways To Aid Black Graduate Students
description: ITHACA, N.Y., June 6A conference on graduate educa tion for black students ended a threeday session at Cornell University today with proposals for injecting some rationality into attempts to get blacks into Postgraduate work at predomi Inantly white universities.

title: SOVIET CRITICIZES U.S. ON MIDEAST
description: MOSCOW, June 6The So viet Union expressed anger to day at efforts in Washington to use the resumption of So vietAmerican talks on the Mid dle East as a means of bring ing pressure on Moscow to withdraw personnel from the United Arab Republic.

title: Wace Victory by 2 Lengths In Finger Lakes Feature
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., June 6 (AP)  Wace, a 5yearold gelding, came within onefifth of a second of tying a Finger Lakes track record today in winning the $2,300 feature race.

title: Business Index Rises in Week
description: The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Ac tivity rose to 364.8 from 352.7 a week earlier. A year ago it was 358.3.

title: THOMAS LAMONT, 63, AGRICULTURIST, DIES
description: ALBION, N. Y., June 6 (AP) Thomas E. LaMont, a former leader of agricultural organiza tions and retired professor, died in Batavia yesterday. He was stricken while returning to his home here from a meeting of farm leaders in Albany. He was 63 years old.

title: OTTINGER SEEKS CHANGE IN SETUP
description: Congress is operating in the horse and buggy age, Repre sentative Richard L. Ottinger said yesterday, suggesting a series of reforms in a white paper issued as part of his campaign for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York.

title: Summer Diary
description: I'm not sure I should be reviewing this book. Maybe it isn't even a book. First of all it hasn't been written yet. The young vacationer or stayat homer is supposed to do that, fill in the blank pages as well as complete occasional sentences that read My idea of a good time is to,

title: TWO IN CONGRESS SEEK OTHER SEATS
description: HARTFORD, June 6  The odds are strong that the Re publican nominees for Governor and United States Senator in Connecticut will be United States Representatives Thomas Meskill and Lowell P. Weicker.

title: The Horrors Of Hiroshima
description: OVER the past century, photography has taught us much about our selves. Through this medium we have learned the mechanics of human loco motion, the complexities of our skeletal structure, the physiognomic subtleties of our personaeand the depth of our depravity.

title: WILSON CAMPAIGN: NOVEL TECHNIQUE
description: LONDON, June 6Through the deserted streets of working class South London drove four modest sedans. An amplified voice went out from the first to the occasional stray citizen:

title: Miss Lindsey Is Wed
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 6Miss Margaret Elise Lind sey and Craig Harrison Wood were married here this after noon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the Rev. S. Hughes Carvin.

title: Cornfeld Rival Quits as Head of Investors Group
description: GENEVA, June 6  Richard M. Hammerman has resigned ?? president and chief execu tive officer of Investors Over ??eas Services in a move seen as strengthening the hand of Bernard Cornfeld in the ailing mutual fund giant.

title: Science
description: Each of us is such an odd and original mixture of traits inherited from our par ents, our grandparents and ancestors long forgotten that it was natural to assume that heredity is like mixing painteach individual repre sents a different combina tion of amorphous, inherited characteristics.

title: 40Car Field Completed For Motor State 400 Today
description: CAMBRIDGE JUNCTION, Mich., June 6 (AP)A 40car field that includes all of the top names in stockcar racing: was completed today for the Motor State 400, a $72,000 highspeed chase that is the first stop on a western swing for the drivers from Dixie.

title: G. J. Winters Weds Miss Miller
description: GREENWICH, Conn.. June 6Miss ShirleyJane Larkin Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Weber Miller, was married here this after noon to Geoffery James Win ters, son of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Winters. The Rev. J. Clifford Greise performed the ceremony in the St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church.

title: Seattle Honors Dr. King
description: SEATTLE June 6 (AP)The Seattle School Board has de clared an official school holi day on Jan. 15, birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., assassinated civil rights leader. The new holiday becomes effec tive in 1971.

title: A Study Finds World's Jews Have Low Population Growth
description: LONDON, June 6While the world is experiencing a popu lation explosion, the number of Jews is declining in some coun tries and falling behind other groups elsewhere, according to a study published here this week.

title: Athens Denies Offers to King; Royalist Influences Are Curbed
description: ATHENS, June 6King Con stantine of Greece celebrated his 30th birthday in exile this week, just after the latest flurry of rumors that his coun try's armybacked regime had invited him to return to Athens.

title: Goodyear and Union Reach 3Year Pact To Settle a Strike
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 6 (AP) Tentative settlement on a new threeyear contract calling for wage increases and im provements in fringe benefits was announced last night by the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company, the nation's largest rubber producer, and the United Rubber Workers.

title: Guardsmen Defended by Chief Over Stabbings in New Mexico
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 5Maj. Gen. John P. Jolly, the state's adjutant general, says that National Guardsmen who stabbed students and newsmen during a disturbance May 15 on the campus of the Univer sity of New Mexico had fol lowed an Army training man ual exactly as it was written.

title: News of the Realty Trade
description: A subsidiary of the Chrys ler Corporation has joined the Del E. Webb Corporation in a joint venture to develop an 800acre tract of land in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., near Detroit.

title: C.U.N.Y. Revamps Format Of Basketball Tournament
description: A change in the format for the City University basketball tournament has been an nounced by the athletic di rectors of the five member col leges.

title: Education
description: Free enterprise and competi tion are symbols of the con sumer's right to pay his money and make his choice. Last week, an educational theorist and the Federal Government proposed a test of the market economy con cept in the business of educa tion.

title: Trainer at Lamar Tech To Head National Group
description: ST. LOUIS, Mo., June 6 (UPI) Robert L. Gunn of. Beaumont, Tex., has been elected president of the National Athletic Train ers Association.

title: Soviet Dissidents : Grim Game Of Cat And Mouse
description: MOSCOW  Political dissent in the Soviet Union today is a grim game of cat and mouse. The predator is the ubiquitous State Security Committee  the K.G.B.  and the prey are men and women who, for widely differing reasons, oppose what they consider Soviet authoritar ianism. The opposition is usual ly expressed in writing. There are few public demonstrators.

title: Professor Galbraith reluctantly recommends WagePrice Controls The Cure for Runaway Inflation
description: THESE last few months have, just possibly, been decisive in the modern history of econo ics. Ideas in which economists have reposed the greatest confidence have been proved wrong and therewith, not surprisingly, the responding policy. And this has happened under circumstances which admit of no really plausible explanation, rationali zation, or alibithings in which we economists are more than minimally accomplished. There was, to be sure, more than a suspicion of error be fore; the evidence was highly adverse to the reputable ideas. But the heretics were a minority and the adverse evidence could be attributed to a lag. In economics, any incon venient disassociation of effect from cause is always attributed to a lag. But not forever.

title: Doubts About Oral Diabetes Drugs
description: WASHINGTON  Diabetes has always been a complex and difficult disease. For many patients, however, it seemed mercifully much less complicated after the first of the oral diabetes drugs came into use in 1957.

title: Hotel in Boston Closes
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)The once elegant Hotel Vendome, whose guests included Presi dent Martin Van Buren, Thorn as Edison, Sarah Bernhardt and Gen. U. S. Grant, has closed its doors after 100 years.

title: L.I. Teacher's Body Found in Queens
description: The body of a woman school teacher from Long Island was found yesterday in a vacant lot, in East Elmhurst, Queens.

title: Seasoned Amateurs Will Run Ox Ridge Show Like Old Pros
description: The fourday Ox Ridge Hunt Club horse show gets under way Thursday with some of the top hunters and jumpers in the country on hand.

title: Gannon Names Markey Coach
description: Gannon College has an ??ounced the appointment of Dave Markey as head basket ??all coach and Jim Lewis as freshman basketball coach. For the last 11 seasons Markey has served as assistant coach at Canisius College in Buffalo.

title: PAKISTAN OUSTS 191 AFTER TRIALS
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 6  One hundred ninetyone Government officials, among them the civil servant most closely identified with the au thoritarian regime of former President Mohammad Ayub Khan, have been dismissed fol lowing trials by special mili tary courts. Sixtynine others have been retired.

title: Again the Hot Issue Of Those Files on Dissenters
description: TRENTON, N. J.  A New Jersey test case that could have farreaching effects on the whole controversial issue of amassing secret police dossiers on civil rights activists and other pro testors reached another mile stone last week when the State Supreme Court unanimously up held police in this activity.

title: It Wasn't the Best of Seasons, But It Could Have Been Worse
description: BY all odds the most significant event of a generally desultory television season was the advent of Sesame Street. Produced by the Children's Television Workshop, headed by Mrs. Joan Ganz Cooney, Se same Street has become almost a video religion in some quarters and has gen erated extensive discussion among soci ologists and educators. But more prag matically the program adds up to one thing: After heaven knows how many years, public broadcasting has finally with hit all its own.

title: Miss Patricia Yu Becomes Bride
description: Miss Patricia Yingnin Yu, a systems analyst with Trans World Airlines, and Michael Chenching Tsien, a systems analyst with Francis I. du Pont & Co., were married here yesterday in St. James' Episcopal Church. The Rev. Claude Pickens, a former missionary in China, per formed the bilingual cere monv.

title: Feud on 33d Floor Drives a Family Into Suburban Life
description: IT Is now a year, almost to the day, that Sanford Socolow, a lifelong resi dent of the city, his wife and children, moved to the sub urbs.

title: Where Do Movies Come From, Dad?
description: WHERE do movies come from, Daddy? asked 5yearold Cecil. Dad blushed and put down his newspaper. Holy smoke, don't they teach you those things at school?

title: Hollywood PlayboyClub Fire
description: HOLLYWOOD, June 6 (AP) The 10story building that is home to Hollywood's Playboy Club was damaged early today by a fire that also briefly threatened neighboring struc tures on the Sunset Strip. The $10million, 86,900squarefoot building suffered relatively lit tle structural damage, fire of ficials said. The damage esti mate was $400,000, mostly toi interior furnishings, including those at the club.

title: Newsmen Lead Perilous Existence In Cambodia
description: SAIGON  In shallow graves off Route 3 about 40 miles south of Pnompenh, the capital of Cam bodia, the bodies of the first known victims of covering the war news in Cambodia were found last week. They were three members of a Columbia Broad casting System television crew and their Cambodian driver.

title: Engagements
description: MEREDITHEKSTROM. Mr. and Mrs. Fred erick Ekstrom of Brooklyn, New York, an nounce the engagement of their daughter, Marsha Jean to Samuel Meredith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clark Meredith of Yellow Springs, Ohio. An August wedding planned.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: TO ADVERTISE announcements of anniversaries, births, engagements and marriages call The New York Times Classified Advertising Dept. (212) OXford 53311. Closing time for Sunday issue is 6 P.M. Thursday.

title: JOLTS FIGHT JUNE 19 FOR LEAGUE CROWN
description: The International Boxing League will crown its first team champion and seven individual titleholders when it holds its first tournament of champions in Denver. June 19 and 20.

title: News of the Rialto
description: INCREASINGLY and insis tently the young corn mand attention. But, in our throwaway society, what about the old, the senior citizens, who have been and are being tossed upon the scrap heap through no wish or disability of their own?

title: NELSON TAKES FIRST IN LIGHTNING CLASS
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 6 Bruce Nelson of the Manhas set Bay, L. I., fleet, sailing Flame, won the first race of the Riverside Yacht Club's Lightning Class regatta today, the second of the new Northern Circuit summer series for the class on Long Island Sound.

title: Open to sun and spray
description: At the top of the hill all you can see is a little bit of silversided house, with a waisthigh bridge running from the driveway to the top level. Then as one starts to explore this geo metric labyrinth of a house on the beach at Montauk, it unfolds dramatically in decks and bridges, terraced gardens and stairways like an Italian hill town marching down to the sea. Faced with a narrow site that pitches sharply down to the beach, architect Richard D. Kaplan built two tall boxes, one set diagonally below the other on the slope. Decks and balconies were built out at odd angles and a multitude of windows were set in the walls, so that every where there is brilliant light and framed vistas of the endlessly changing Atlantic. To the angled drama, the ownerWilliam Lee Curry, a professor of English literature at Ade1phi Uni versityhas added the serenity of books, the poetry of careless bouquets in old vases, the comfort of wicker and bentwood furniture, the richness of Oriental rugs and Renaissance angels soaring on walls, all of which can be seen in the twostoryhigh living room below. The focal point of the living room is a cast iron fireplace hung in front of a window so that the flames are visible from the beach at night. In the wellequipped kitchen, owner Curry in dulges his hobby of cooking. He serves meals on the large deck, shown below right, where sunwarmed guests can contemplate the rolling sea and the wheeling flights of gulls overhead.

title: Lawrence Picked to Drive
description: EDMONTON, Alberta, June 6 (Canadian Press)  Graham Lawrence of New Zealand was named driver today of the Edmontonowned racing car, Spirit of Edmonton. The Mc Larenbuilt Mark 12 car is scheduled to compete in this year's CanAm race series. The first race will be held at Mos port nekr Toronto June 14.

title: Jolie Madame Captures Class S Sailing Laurels
description: BAY SHORE, L. I., June 6 Gene Whisenhunt, in his Cor vette sloop Jolie Madame, was first home today and also saved enough of her handicap to cap ture Class S correctedtime honors in the Bay Shore Yacht Club's invitation regatta for the South Bay Cruising Club's auxiliary fleet.

title: YANKEE CONFERENCE SELECTS ALLSTARS
description: Ray Ellerbrook of Massachu setts and Jim Cameron and Bill West of Maine were repeat se lections to the AllYankee Con ference baseball team chosen by vote of the coaches and an nounced by the office of Com missioner J. O. Christian.

title: Field Of Travel
description: TWO new Passport Offi ces have been opened in New York in an fort to help relieve the burden of processing 350,000 passports a year in the main passport office in Rockefeller Center. One of the new offi ces Is in the State Supreme Court building on Foley Square; the other is in State Supreme Court building on the Grand Concourse in the Bronx

title: Insurance Policy Loans Crimping Investments
description: One of the best money bargains aroundthe right that most holders of ordi nary life insurance have to borrow against he cash value of their policies at 5 per centis making matters dif ficult for the investment of ficers of some of the nation's largest life insurance com panies.

title: School Ferment Roils Phi Beta Kappa
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 6Phi Beta Kappa, which bestows the country's oldest and most coveted academic honor, is striving to cope with two trendsan egalitar ian spirit among students and a widespread tendency to abandon gradesthat are un dermining its traditional se lection system.

title: Bay State Judge to Retire
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)Judge Kenneth L. Nash, 82 years old, presiding judge of the state Dis trict Court system and a judge for 52 years, has announced that he is retiring effective Sept. 1.

title: Week's Disorders End in Alexandria
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 6 The store where Robin Gibson died has been closed, and this city was quiet today after rash of fires and vandalism that plagued the Negro districts this week.

title: Barbara Sprowls a Bride
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 6  Miss Barbara Jean Sprowls was married here this afternoon to Alan Deloss Jenkins. The Rev. Bradford Hastings performed the cere mony in Christ Episcopal Church. Mr. and Mrs. John S. Sprowls are the bride's par ents, and the bridegroom is the son of Col. Robert Deloss Jenkins, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Jenkins of Carlsbad, N. M. Mr. Sprawls is a vice president with Kamen & Co., New York investment bank ers.

title: Tennis Grand Prix Totals $150,000
description: PARIS, June 6 (Reuters) Prize money in the new tennis Grand Prix will total at least $150,000 this year. Internation al Lawn Tennis Federation offi cials said here today.

title: Koosman Leaves Club To Get Cortisone Shot
description: CINCINNATI, June 6Al though the Mets had been optimistic about Jerry Koos man's tender left elbow, the situation took a turn for the worse today when he had to get a cortisone shot.

title: Aswan Dam Alters Marine Ecology
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 6 The salt content and tem perature of the eastern Medi terranean are being raised as a result of the building of the Aswan High Dam, according to scientists at the American University of Beirut.

title: Botswana Offers a Promising Contrast in Africa
description: GABORONE, Botswana, May 28  Botswana  independent less than four yearsoffers a pleasant and hopeful contrast to many of the most common trends on the African conti nent and is fast becoming an encouraeine success story.

title: Supply Ship Commissioned
description: BOSTON, June 6 (AP)  The U.S.S. Kansas City, the third of a new class of multipurpose supply ships, went into commis sion today in the United States Navy in ceremonies at the Charlestown Yard.

title: Andretti Wins Pole Position
description: MILWAUKEE, June 6 (AP) Mario Andretti pushed his Mc Namaraturbocharged Ford to 119.359 miles an hour to win the pole position today in qual ifying for tomorrow's 150mile Rex Mays Classic at State Fair Park.

title: U.S. TEAM TRIALS LED BY RICHARDS
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 6 (AP)Lieut. Charles Richards of Tacoma, Wash., has scored an overwhelming victory in trials for the United States military pentathlon team that will compete in the world meet in Sweden.

title: DONOHUE PACES OHIO QUALIFIERS
description: MANSFIELD, Ohio, June 6 Round four of the TransAmer ican championship for small sedans comes to this southern Ohio agricultural area tomor row, with extremely tight com petition presaged by today's qualifying times.

title: BLACK CHURCH UNIT TO GET $1MILLION
description: AMHERST, Mass., June 6 (AP)The Massachusetts Con ference of the United Church of Christ voted 611 to 194 today to pay the remainder of a con troversial $1million grant to an allblack group.
