title: Gilbert Is Striving to Repel Invasion of His District by Scheuer
description: Representative Jacob H. Gil bert, who has survived almost continual sniping from Bronx Reform Democrats in his 10 years in Congress, is facing his most vigorous primary challenge yet with the invasion of his district by Representa tive James H. Scheuer.

title: Washington: Finch and the Postwar Economy
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Al most everybody around here seems to be sympathizing with Robert Finch these days for be ing bounced out of his job as Secretary of Health, Educa tion and Welfare, but the truth is that he has bounced into the most interesting and maybe the most influential staff job in the White House

title: New Jersey Water Project In Peril as City Withdraws
description: The Jersey Central Power & Light Company announced yes terday that the future of its Longwood Valley pumped stor age project is in doubt now that Jersey City has decided to with draw from the project.

title: Supplies Pile Up in Peru but Are Slow to Reach Quake Victims
description: CHIMBOTE, Peru, June 8  At the side of a road near here is a neatly painted sign saying Huambacha village destroyed we need help.

title: New Books
description: Mr. Crook Lifts the Mask, by An thony Gilbert (Random House, $4.95). Detective story.

title: NEGRO MAY FORCE A CAROLINA RUNOFF
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., Wednes day, June 10 (AP)A surge of late votes from heavily Negro precincts may have forced Rep resentative L. McMillan into a runoff June 23 against a Negro physician in the Sixth District.

title: Another Tonkin Resolution?
description: The effort to curb the further spread of the Vietnam war into Cambodia and to reassert the constitutional authority of Congress in the warmaking process faces a second crucial test tomorrow when the Senate is scheduled to vote on a proposal by Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, to alter the proposed CooperChurch amendment to the Military Sales Act.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Astronauts. The President nominated Comdrs. John W. Young and Eugene A. Cernan, two of the Apollo 10 astro nauts, for permanent promo tion to the grade of captain in the Navy.

title: New Pentagon Contract Policy Seeks to Avert Cost Overruns
description: WASHINGTON, June 9In an effort to save money on de fense, contracts and to avoid cost overruns, the Defense De partment has issued a broad policy directive that may have widespread impact on the mul tibilliondollar aerospace indus try.

title: Army Identifies 7 Soldiers Killed in Fort Bragg Blast
description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., June 9 (UPI)The Army identified to day the seven Green Berets who were killed yesterday in the premature explosion of TNT on a demolition training range here.

title: Restaurants Face New Tax
description: Restaurant owners con fronted by the possibility of a variety of new and increased city taxes, learned yesterday htat they face another extra expense  a $10 increase in their $25 Health Department permits. The current $25 charge

title: 3 Foundations Each Give $5,000 To Assist the. Fresh Air Appeal
description: The New York Yankees Foundation, the Frank and Marie Louise Bailey Founda tion and the Vanneck Founda tion have each contributed $5,000 toward the Fresh Air Fund's 1970 goal of $800,000, the fund said this week.

title: Ship Seizure Protested
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 9 The United Nations Com mand asserted here today that the South Korean Navy ship that North Korea said it had sunk in the Yellow Sea last Fri day was not sunk but was ac tually seized and towed to North Korea.

title: Rangers Unscathed by First Phase of Draft in Montreal
description: MONTREAL, June 9With all the care and catlike cunning of a jewel thief, the Rangers today left Ron Stewart, Tim Horton and Don Marshall un protected in the National Hock ey League's intraleague draft and got away with it.

title: Independent Rumanians' Spines Stiffened by Disasters and Soviet Pressure
description: BUCHAREST, June 5Ru mania continues to proclaim a policy of purposeful independ ence despite disastrous floods that have weakened her eco nomically and new pressure from Moscow.

title: Goodell, at Finch, Urges a Halt To Mistake of Indochina War
description: Senator Charles E. Goodell told the graduating class of Finch College yesterday that American participation in the war in Indochina was an aw ful mistake from which we should withdraw.

title: FAST FEDERAL TRIAL URGED IN ERVIN BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)  Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., charging that citizens are be ing deprived of their constitu tional right to a speedy trial, introduced a bill today that would require Federal criminal trials to start within 60 days of indictment.

title: JERRY RUBIN'S WIFE IN MOSCOW PROTEST
description: MOSCOW, June 9Three American women wearing black pajama  like suits and conical straw hats demonstrated today in front of the United States Embassy against the American military action in Southeast Asia.

title: Buchman State Net Victor
description: Jon Buchman, the topseeded player, led the way into the third round of the New York State tennis championship at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club yesterday. Steve Ross, Bob Barker, Tony Vin cent, Bob Kahn and King Van Nostrand also scored victories.

title: PUSEY DENOUNCES RADICALS ON LEFT
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 9 Seventeen years after he stood up against Joseph R. Mc Carthy, Nathan M. Pusey, presi dent of Harvard University, charged today that the late Senator's hateful technique was now being used by radi cals of the left to destroy the universities for their own gain.

title: DR. P. R. GOLDSTEIN OF WELFARE BOARD
description: Dr. Philip R. Goldstein, a member of the staff of the National Jewish Welfare Board from 1920 to 1961, died at Beth Israel Hospital here on Sunday. He was 79 years old and lived at 200 Cabrini Boulevard.

title: Politics: Samuels Charges Fiscal Irresponsibility
description: Howard J. Samuels yesterday accused both Arthur J. Gold berg, his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Governor, and Governor Rocke feller of fiscal irresponsibility.

title: Japan's Color TV Exports To U.S. Declined in April
description: TOKYO, June 9 (AP)Japan exported 42,914 color televi sion sets to the United States in April, down 34 per cent from the previous month and down 41.2 per cent from April, 1969, the Electronic Industry Asso ciation and the Finance Minis try's customs bureau reported today.

title: Eisenbud at Queens borough, Decries Despair of Today
description: More than 1,000 students were awarded degrees yester day at Queenshorough Com munity College's ninth com mencement. The exercises were held in Robert F. Kennedy Hall on the college's Bayside cam pus.

title: Seeks to Reassure U.S.
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 9The six nations of the European Economic Community decided today to reassure the outside world about their international trade policies, which are caus ing increasing concern to non member countries, mainly the United States.

title: Blacks Press Reparations Demands
description: Why did you single out the church? someone recent ly asked the Rev. Calvin B. Marshall 3??, chairman of the Black Economic Develop ment Conference that has de manded $3billion in repara tions from religious groups.

title: Governor Says Goldberg Lagged Over War Issue
description: Governor Rockefeller gibed yesterday at the current oppo sition to the war in Vietnam by his wouldbe Democratic rival, Arthur J. Goldberg, im plying it came late. He said he had himself opposed the war and offered a 1968 plan to end it.

title: Seniors at Princeton Shun Traditions
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 9 Traditions that had persisted since Aaron Burr's college days were toppled today as Prince ton University held its 223d commencement.

title: McCall's Is Cutting Its Rate Base
description: Faced by probable postal increases and advertiser re sistance to high page rates, McCall's magazine will cut its rate base by a million, to 7.5 million, with the Septem ber issue. It is also planning to cut the page size to that of its sister publication, Redbook, but no date has been set for that change.

title: A Policeman's First Reaction Was I Hope Nobody Got Hurt
description: I disbelieved it at first, said a sergeant at the desk in the 18th Precinct station, at 306 West 54th Street.

title: Big 4 Aides Meet in West Berlin and. Then Pay Visit to the Eastern Sector
description: BERLIN, June. 9The Soviet Ambassador to East Germany, Pyotr A. Abrasimov, was host to envoys of the United States, Britain and France in East Ber lin today in the first major dis play of fourpower responsibil ity for Berlin since 1954.

title: WALKOUT IN BRITAIN CLOSES BIG PAPERS
description: LONDON, June 9A walk out by newspaper workers halted production tonight of all British national newspapers except The Morning Star, a Communist paper.

title: Post Offices to Process Requests for Passports
description: WASHINGTON, June 9In a sixmonth test program, post offices in several cities around the countryinclud ing eight in Connecticut will begin to accept passport applications.

title: Reentry Vehicle Launched
description: VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 9 (UPI)An experimental reentry vehicle in the advanced ballistic reentry, system was launched at 5:23 A.M. today down the Air Force Western Test Range. The shot was part of a program aimed at developing more effective, vehicles for the intercontinental ballistic missile deterrent force.

title: A Wright House Public and Private
description: MOUNT VERNON, Va. There's the story about the owner of a Frank Lloyd Wright house who called the architect to complain that the ceiling was leaking onto his table while he dined. Move the table, Wright told him.

title: LAIRD WARNS NAT?? ON SOVIET'S ARMS
description: VENICE, Italy, June 9 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird has warned that, unless there is progress in the stra tegicarms limitation talks with the Soviet Union in the next 12 to 18 months, the Nixon Ad ministration will have to recon sider whether to expand and accelerate its nuclear arms pro gram.

title: KEY LAOTIAN TOWN SEIZED BY ENEMY
description: VIENTIANE, Laos. June 9 Premier Souvanna Phouma an nounced today the fall of the major southeast Laotian town of Saravane to Communistled Pathet Lao and North Vietnam ese troops.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert W. Hendrickson, vice president of cus tomer planning, the Western Electric Company, effective July 1. He replaces Darius M. Gallagher, who is retiring.

title: Puerto Rican Indicted Here In a G.E. Bombing Attempt
description: A man who has described himself as a member of a rev olutionary Puerto Rican group called MIRA was indicted yes terday for attempted arson and other charges growing out of an alleged attempt to bomb the General Electric Building, at 51st Street and Lexington Avenue.

title: ERCOLE TAMBURELLI, JERSEY BUILDER, 70
description: LEONIA, N. J., June 9 Ercole Tamburelli, a Bergen County builder, died here Sun day at his home at 353 Oak dene Avenue. He was 70 years old.

title: Excerpts From Speech by Pusey of Harvard Attacking Extremists of the New Left
description: I want to speak today not about the baffling problems of the world outside but of what I take to be a declina tion in the quality of our life here which I find disturbing. I have chosen to introduce what I have to say by call ing attention to a point of similarity between the pres ent situation of Harvard and that which obtained when returned to Cambridge 17 year ago to become the uni versity's 24th president.

title: EXAMINATION URGED OF BOARDS OF BANKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) An exhaustive examination of interlocking directorships among commercial banks was urged today by Wright Patman, Democrat of Texas and chair man of the House Banking Committee.

title: WATER RATE RISES PROPOSED BY CITY
description: A list of waterrate increases that would raise $80million to help balance Mayor Lindsay'S $7.8billion expense budget was published yesterday by the En vironmental Protection Admin istration. The new charges, published in The City Record, are subject to approval by the Board of Estimate.

title: Sperry Rand Sets Accord
description: The Systems and Library Bureau of the Sperry Rand Cor poration announced yesterday an agreement to market the optical scanning and retrival equipment produced by the Su preme Equipment and Systems Corporation.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Foreign Affairs: The Limits of Superpower
description: SOCHI, U.S.S.R.  Despite blatant contrasts in ideology, tradition, living standards, po litical aspirations and the commitments each has as sumed in the contemporary world, underlying resemblances between the U.S.A. and the U.S.S.R. strike a returning visitor to the Soviet Union more than the evident and wellknown differences.

title: Better Than Expected in Italy
description: Italy's hardpressed centerleft governing coalition emerged from the regional elections in a stronger position than generally predicted. The coalition made a modest advance over its showing in the 1968 parlia mentary election. The Communists, almost for the first time since the last war, failed to gain and a leftwing Socialist splinter party allied with them lost ground.

title: FITCH IIPPRESSIVE IN LIEDER RECITAL
description: Bernard Fitch, tenor, who sang Monday night at Carnegie Hall, is a pleasant enough vocal ist and a fine artist. His de livery is smooth and easy, his manner assured, and he has plenty of musical knowhow. Though his voice is shallow in quality and mostly in one color, what equipment he has he uses intelligently.

title: HERMAN W. BLOCK, TEXTILE PARTNER
description: Herman W. Block, a former textile executive and a promi nent figure in child care, died yesterday in his home at 12 East 86th Street. He was 98 years old.

title: City Takes First Step In AirPollution Alert
description: The Environmental Pro tection Administration an nounced late yesterday that the city was in a high pol lution forecast stage.

title: Mississippi Weapons Held
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 9 Gov. John Bell Williams said today that the state highway patrol would not give the F.B.I. the weapons used at Jackson State College campus where two youths were slain because Mr. Leonard had pro posed to use them for a fish exvedition.

title: Chicago Masons Win Raise
description: CHICAGO, June 9 (AP)One hundred sixty independent cement contractors agreed to day to meet wage demands of striking cement masons until an official settlement of the strike was worked out. Herman Ecklund, president of cement masons Local 502, said the con tractors agreed in letters of understanding to give masons an immediate $2anhour in crease in wages and benefits. They now earn $5.46 an hour.

title: Thar She BlowsHow Long?
description: If the Federal Whale Research Program, which em ploys only two biologists and costs the United States no more than $65,000 a year, is eliminated as threat ened, the country would be abandoning all systematic effort to study the decline of a magnificent creature in the hope of preventing its total extinction.

title: Rival Gravity Theorists Test How Fast an Apple Falls
description: Does an apple today fall faster or slower than it did in the days of Galileo and New ton? Or has the force of gravi ty remained constant?

title: MOTOR WHEEL LIFTS AUTO PARTS PRICES
description: The Motor Wheel Corpora tion, a subsidiary of the Good year Tire and Rubber Com pany, announced yesterday that it would increase prices across the board on car and truck ??arts, effective June 15.

title: Hampton Estate Files Suit For $3.75Million in Chicago,
description: CHICAGO, June 9 (Reuters) A $3.75million law suit was filed in Federal District Court today seeking damages on be half of the estate of Fred Hamp ton. The Black Panther leader was slain in a predawn police raid on his Chicago apartment six months ago.

title: Firm Enjoined by S.E.C.
description: The New York Stock Ex change and the Securities and Exchange Commission simul taneously announced discipli nary actions against Meyerson & Co., a brokerage house with headquarters in San Francisco, and two of its to officers.

title: FIDELITY WEIGHS PLAN FOR MERGER
description: Executives of the Fidelity Corporation of Virginia met here yesterday to consider their next move following a deter mination of New Jersey's In surance Commissioner, Robert L. Clifford, that a merger with the Bankers National Life In surance Company of Montclair, N. J., would be prejudicial to Bankers policyholders.

title: Allen Aide Urges Education Agency in Cabinet
description: Dr. James Gallagher, who is resigning this week as chief of research and planning for the United States Office of Educa tion, has called in a highly critical memorandum for the creation of a separate, Cabinet level Department of Education.

title: New Hand on Throttle
description: Shortly after Paul Albert Gorman joined the Penn Central Company last Dec. 1 as president, one of his new associates remarked to group of senior corporate of ficials that Gorman's a pretty nice guy. One of these officials turned quickly and answered: That's one thing we don't need around hereany more nice guys. On Monday, the nice guy from. Carrollton, Mo., finished first, not last, when he was named chairman and chief executive officer of the Penn Central Transportation Company, the nation's largest transporta tion system and principal subsidiary of the Penn Cen tral Company. He is also ex pected to be elected soon to the same positions at the parent company.

title: PICKETS AT F.B.I. VISITED BY JUDGE
description: State Supreme Court Justice gorge Starke visited a picket line in front of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's head quarters here last night to see whether it was as noisy as resi dents of the area say it ts.

title: Gunfire in Jordan Wounds U.S. Aide and Wife Slightly
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) The State Department re ported today that a military attache at the United States Embassy in Amman, Jordan, and his wife were wounded slightly by gunfire Sunday night.

title: Chief Executive Is Elected By Westcoast Transmission
description: The board of directors of the Westcoast Transmission Com pany, Ltd., elected Kelly H. Gibson as chairman and chief executive officer at a meeting yesterday at Calgary. Alberta.

title: GORDON IS HIRED TO COACH STARS
description: MONTREAL, June 9Jackie Gordon, the former assistant general manager of the Rangers and one of the American Hock ey League's most successful executives, signed a threeyear contract today to coach the Minnesota North Stars.

title: No Upturn Is Expected Before End of '70 for the Mild Downturn
description: DETROIT, June 9A con sumer recession is under way and according to current indi cations, the 1970 recession will be the longest postwar reces sion, a University of Michigan consumer survey reported to day.

title: Dan Sikes Shoots 135 to Pace Open Qualifiers in Southeast
description: ATLANTA, June 9 (AP)Dan Sikes of Jacksonville, Fla., shot a nineunderpar 135 over 36 holes today and led the Southeast sectional qualifying for the United States Open golf championship.

title: MISS HOGAN GAINS 60 64 TRIUMPH
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 9 (AP)  Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., advanced to the third round of the Kent tennis tournament today and Valerie Ziegenfuss of San Diego won her firstround match.

title: Dr. Abraham Maslow, Founder Of Humanistic Psychology, Dies
description: MENLO PARK Calif., June 9Dr. Abraham Maslow, pro fessor of psychology at Bran deis University in Waltham, Mass., and founder of what has come to he known as human istic psychology, died here yesterday of a heart attack. He was 62 years old.

title: EGYPT REPORTS RAID BY 36 ISRAELI JETS
description: CAIRO, June 9 (AP)Forma tions of Israeli warplanes at tacked Egyptian positions on the Suez Canal for more than three hours today, killing one soldier and wounding another, the military command an nounced here.

title: E. M. Forster
description: So long as a need exists to identify and impale racial and social prejudice, the novels and essays of Edward Morgan Forster will be read. For in such books as A Passage to India and A Room With View he exposed, in a quintessential way, the human flaws of hypocrisy and repression.

title: U.S. Troops Clash With Foe In the Fishhook of Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 9 (Reuters)  Fighting in creased in the Fishhook region of Cambodia yesterday, a, United States military spokes man said today. Four American soldiers were reported killed and 36 wounded. Vietcong and North Vietnamese losses were not known, the spokesman said.

title: Out on the MiniMidi Limb and Listening for Sound of Sawing
description: Most women, even decisive ones, are still wondering whether they should switch to midis and risk looking older or stick with minis and perhaps look pass.

title: Competition Booming in CanAm
description: The 1970 CanadianAmeri can Challenge Cup series may he the most competitive ever. This development has been a long time coming, but it was Inevitable in view of the enor mous lootthis year more than $1million in purses and accessory awards. For the first time it is likely that the

title: I.O.S. STOCK PRICE NEAR RECORD LOW
description: GENEVA, June 9Stock of Investors Overseas Services traded today near its record low of $2 as reports circulated that bank's interested in ac quiring the distressed mutual fund company were offering little, if anything, for the shares.

title: U.N. Cyprus Force Extended
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9The Security Council voted unanimously today to ex tend the United Nations Peace keeping Force in Cyprus until Dec. 15. its present mandate expires June 15.

title: President to Disclose Revisions In Welfare Reform Plan Today
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) President Nixon will an nounce tomorrow relatively modest revisions of the welfare reform proposal that ran aground in the Senate Finance Committee last month, Admin istration officials indicated today.

title: PRIEST IS ARRESTED ON FRAUD CHARGES
description: A Maronite Catholic clergy man, in Brooklyn was arrested yesterday on a Philadelphia warrant charging that he fraudulently converted $200,000 in church funds to his own use when he was pastor of a South Philadelphia church.

title: Various Solutions Offered
description: Varying views on ways of coping with the dislocations in securities markets caused by largeblock trades were offered yesterday by representatives of different parts of the securities industry.

title: Orioles Enroll 2 Draftees
description: BALTIMORE, June 9 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles signed two draft choices, Mike Sat terle, a catcher from Portland, Ore., and Eddie Blake Jr., a righthanded pitcher from East St. Louis, Ill.

title: Campaign Here Old Hat To a Japanese Newsman
description: Keiichiro Yashira, a politi cal commentator on NHK, the Japanese television net work, traveled around Man hattan yesterday with Arthur J. Goldberg and observed that campaigning in Japan was not much different than that in New York except for the balloons and televi sion advertising.

title: M'DERMOTT & CO. SHOWS PROFIT DIP
description: J. Ray McDermott & Co., Inc., engineers and builders of pipelines, offshore drilling platforms and other work for the petroleum industry, showed a sharp drop in earnings for the quarter and fiscal year ended March 31, the New Orleansbased company report ed yesterday.

title: U.S. HEALTH BUDGET CRITICIZED IN REPORT
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 Only about onefifth of the Fed eral Government's total health budget of $20.6billion for next year will actually he spent on programs designed to improve and maintain the health of the public, according to an anal ysis prepared by Dr. James A. Shannon, former director of the National Institutes of Health and now a professor and as sistant to the president of Rockefeller University.

title: 35 on Parking Lots At Kennedy lndicted In $250,000 Fraud
description: Thirtyfive of the 120 park ing lot employes at Kennedy International Airport were in dicted yesterday in connection with what Queens District At torney Thomas J. Mackell called a $250,000 parking ticket racket.

title: Argentine Junta Pledges A Return to Civilian Rule
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 9 The three commanders of the Argentine armed forces who deposed President Juan Carlos Ongania, pledged today that they would give Argentina a civilian Government through elections. But they gave no date.

title: A Copter Beats the Traffic From City to Washington
description: WASHINGTON, June 9Si korsky. Aircraft and Pan American World Airways dem onstrated today one way to beat traffic jams in the air and on the ground between Man hattan and Washingtona heli copter, which made the trip in one hour and 17 minutes.

title: MARTIN J. WIMAN
description: Martin J. Wiman, director of the Edgecomb Rehabilitation Center for narcotics addicts at 163d Street and Edgecomb Avenue, died Monday of a heart attack in St. John's Hos pital, Smithtown, L. I. He was 48 years old and lived at 56 Grandview Lane, Smithtown.

title: CUP SOCCER FANS WORRY OFFICIALS
description: MEXICO CITY, June 9 (AP) International soccer officials are beginning to express serious concern about the destructive behavior of fans during the cur rent world championship.

title: NICHOLAS PARKER OF HENRI BENDEL
description: Nicholas Parker, former pres ident and coowner of Henri Bendel, Inc., the specialty store, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home at 301 East 78th Street. He was 64 years old.

title: N.Y.U. SURGEONS GET A $2MILLION GRANT
description: The New York University Medical Center announced yes terday that it expected to re ceive $2million over the next five years from the Billy Rose Foundation for research and patient  care studies in two areas of surgery.

title: Whitney Displaying Year's Acquisitions
description: Seven Calders. Ten Johnses. Six Ossorios. Six MarcaRellis. Two Motherwells. The count may sound like inventory day at Sa??tini's Fine Arts warehouse, but those and more than 100 other works are part of the giant haul ac quired or purchased by the Whitney Museum last year, and now on view in a show entitled Recent Acquisi tions.

title: Magazine Plant Struck
description: KOKOMO, Ind., June 9 (AP) A strike by the 325 members of Bookbinders Union Local 165 today stopped the printing of several national magazines at the Cuneo Press plant in Kokomo. The union's contract expired at midnight Sunday. A company spokesman said that strike of any duration would delay delivery of Good House keeping, Sports Afield, Boy's Life and Popular Mechanics magazines to newsstands.

title: 2 Kennedy Cargo Handlers Indicted in $200,000 Theft
description: A Federal grand jury in Brooklyn indicted two cargo handlers yesterday on charges of theft and possession of $200, 000 from mail sacks at Ken nedy International Airport.

title: 291 APPLICANTS PASS BAR TESTS
description: ALBANY, June 9The State Board of Law Examiners an nounced today that 291 of 496 applicants had passed the writ ten examination for admission to the bar. The examination was given April 7 and 8.

title: Advertising: Business Called a Cure for Ills
description: Despite a rising wave of hostility to business around the world, it will be busi ness and not governments that cures some of the major problems of mankind.

title: MOSCOW SAYS U.S. IS TORN BY CRISIS
description: MOSCOW, June 9The So viet Union, in an analysis of the world revolutionary movement, described the United States to day as torn by internal crises and rapidly losing influence in Western Europe and Latin America.

title: Bridge:
description: A basic guide to bridge, intended for someone who knows nothing about the game, is difficult to write. Such books are often pro duced by bridge teachers who lack expertise and writ ing ability.

title: Bell & Howell to Buy Stock
description: The Bell & Howell Company announced yesterday that it plans to make openmarket purchases of up to 100,000 shares of its own stock over the next several quarters. The company, which has about 5.2 million shares outstanding, said it would use the shares for corporate purposes.

title: KOREAN REDS SAY U.S. MUST GET OUT
description: TOKYO, June 9North Ko rea has published a long docu ment asserting that reunifica tion of the country cannot be accompished until the United States imperialist aggressor army has been forced off the peninsula and the traitorous South Korean regime of Presi dent Chung Hee Park has been overthrown.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Events for Debutantes Pick Up in the Suburbs
description: Annual activities on the suburban debutante circuit move into high gear this week with three parties scheduled for Friday. A fourth party will be held on Monday and a fifth on June 27. But the total number of young wom en to be honored at the five parties, 59, is lower than in past years.

title: Western Governors See Economy as Vital Issue
description: PARK CITY, Utah, June 9 Voter resentments over the double crunch of inflation and rising unemployment may prove decisive in elections this fall, state political leaders said in interviews here today.

title: City Plans to Auction Old Police Academy
description: The former Police Acad emy, a fivestory brick build ing at 5 Hubert Street, is among 122 parcels of surplus properties to be sold at pub lic auction by the city's De partment of Real Estate on June 24.

title: Fire Burns Police Station In Suburban Jersey Town
description: CAMDEN, N. J., June 9A fire, attributed to arsonists, de stroyed the suburban Stratford police station early today.

title: Negro Backing Addonizio Target of Shotgun Blast
description: NEWARK, June 9A shot gun blast early today ripped through the living room window of the home of the Rev. Levin P. West, a Negro minister who is supporting Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio's bid for reelection.

title: Brazilian Aide Says Drought Puts 200,000 Out of Work
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 9 The drought in Brazil's north east has destroyed even the meager livelihood of a million people, the Minister of Plan ning, Joo Reis Veloso, esti mated today.

title: MSGR. J. J. M'GRATH, COLLEGE PRESIDENT
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 9 Msgr. John J. McGrath, presi dent of St. Mary's College, a women's liberal arts school, died here today in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 47 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: Is Patsy Carpenter worth 794 pages? Patsy is young, pretty, recently married, financially secure and psychologically adrift on a sea of qualms in the American Southwest, circa now. She reads a lot, she cries a lot, she worries a lot about her sex life. But the several years we spend with Patsy seem like just that . . . several years. Even in the capable hands of Larry McMurtry whose first novel, Horseman, Pass By, was a better book than the Paul Newman movie it inspired; how weary Mr. Mc Murtry must be of hearing about Hud  Patsy seems elephanti astic. If there were anything meretri cious about Mov ing On, any mechanized grind ing out of narra tive quick  mix, any hard eye scouring the landscape for the main commercial chance, it wouldn't be worth reviewing. It is, however, a novel of monumental honesty, about people as real as your sister, consisting of in sights as undeniable as this morning's weather. Attention must be paid.

title: Heckled at N. Y. U. Rites, Wald Recites the Pledge
description: Dr. George Wald, the anti war Nobel laureate, responded to a smattering of heckling from parents and students at the New York University com mencement yesterday by re citing the Pledge of Allegiance with emphasis.

title: New Chairman Elected By United Fund Here
description: The election of J. Kenneth Jamieson, chairman and chief executive officer of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), as chairman of the United Fund of Greater New York was announced yester day.

title: Justice Named in Jersey
description: TRENTON, June 9 (AP) Evan W. Jahos, a former assist ant state attorney general, was named today to head the newly created Division of Criminal Justice. He will in effect be come a head prosecutor under the new law giving the state more control over county prosecutors.

title: New State Program to Train And Find Jobs for Inmates
description: ALBANY, June 9Governor Rockefeller today announced a new state program for train ing and finding jobs for New York City residents who are inmates of state correctional institutions.

title: 18 MORE CHOSEN IN SCHOOL RACES
description: Additional winners in the community school board elec tions held May 28 in Manhat tan were announced yesterday by Dr. George H. Hallett Jr., director of the special election unit established by the Board of Elections.

title: CHARLES E. R. CLUKIES
description: Charles E. Robert Clukies, a vice president of the Chemical Bank, died of cancer Sunday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived at 6009 75th Avenue, Glendale, Queens.

title: Army Temporarily Barred From Transferring Doctor
description: A Federal judge yesterday temporarily barred the assign ment to Vietnam of a 28year old New York psychiatrist who contended he would be re quired to commit war crimes on a massive scale.

title: Award to Rockwell Corp. of B1 Contract May Provide 15,000 Jobs
description: EL SEGUNDO, Calif., June 9 The North American Rock well Corporation has taken ap plications from more than 1,000 unemployed aerospace workers since last Friday.

title: Peacemakers Fail to Calm Isla Vista
description: ISLA VISTA, Calif., June 9 Attempts by faculty and stu dents to maintain order in this battlescarred college town have broken down.

title: New Housing Down 42% In State in First Quarter
description: Authorizations for building new housing have been run ning 42 per cent below last year's already low rate through out the state, with the rate in New York City off as much as 72 per cent, state figures showed yesterday.

title: MINNESOTA HELD TO FOUR SAFETIES
description: The hottest team in town, the New York Yankees, took on the tough Minnesota Twins without flinching last night and scored a 52 victory behind the fourhit pitching of Stan Bahn sen.

title: J. RUSSELL PARSONS
description: WEST ORANGE, N. 3., June 9  J. Russell Parsons, a for mer partner and director of Chubb & Son, an insurance management firm, died yester day at his home in Llewellyn Park. He was 73 years old.

title: Laver Defeats Mukerjea, 64, 62, in Wimbledon Tune Up Tourney
description: BRISTOL, England, June (AP)  Rod Laver, preparing to make his bid for a third straight Wimbledon title, de feated Ja??dip Mukerjea, of In dia, 64, 62, and Marty Riessen of Evanston, Ill., ousted Paul Huchins of Britain, 62, 63, in the $25,000 Willis open tennis tournament today.

title: Official Says Million Get Pill Illegally
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 The head of the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Charles C. Edwards, estimated today that one million American women were obtaining birth control pills illegally.

title: Bill Easing Antitrust Curb On Newspapers Advances
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The House Judiciary Committee ap proved today, 13 to 8, legisla tion that would immunize from antitrust prosecution existing agreements for joint publication of separately owned newspa pers and would permit addi tional agreements under looser standards than apply to other businesses.

title: Mansfield Warns Senate Against Byrd's Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Senate Democratic leader, Nike Mansfield of Montana, led an attack today against an Administrationsupported pro posal on Cambodia. He con tended that the effect of the Administration proposal would be to produce another Gulf of Tonkin resolution, giving the White House a blank check.

title: Thai Patrols Increase
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 9  Police patrols along Thai land's border on northwestern Cambodia have been increased to a roundtheclock operation, and a marine battalion has been sent to help the police.

title: Harney Leads Field With a 136 as 13 Qualify for U.S. Open in Area Trials
description: WOODMERE, L. L. June 9 Paul Harney, winner of the Massachusetts Open the last three years, said today he was not the least superstitious about qualifying for the 13th time for the United States Open Champ ionship.

title: For Lovers of Wildlife, There Is Still a Haven in Botswana
description: MAUN, Botswana  Much of the old Africa is gone, and what is left is disappear ing fast under the wheels of touristfilled microbuses and the plows of landhungry populations.

title: Article 1  No Title
STARS' VOICES LIFT ROUTINE MET AIDA
description: To some extent, the first Aida of the Metropolitan Opera's June Festival fell into a familiar, wellroutined pat tern on Monday night, but some extraordinary singing by Martina Arroyo in the title part and Carlo Bergonzi as Radames set enough fires to keep any chill off the evening.

title: Or. Rafael Calderon, 72, Dies Former Costa Rican President
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 9 (Reuters)Former President Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia died today after a twomonth illness. He was 72 years old.

title: I.C.C. AIDE FAVORS RAILROAD MERGER
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  A merger of the Illinois Central and the Gulf, Mobile & Ohio Railroads was recommended to day to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

title: I.R.S. STOPGAP RULE ISSUED ON INTEREST
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Internal Revenue Service an nounced today a stopgap pol icy dealing with the deductibil ity of interest that banks pay on loans, the proceeds of which are used to buy taxex empt securities.

title: Dodd Considers Running For Senate Independentiy
description: HARTFORD, June 9Sena tor Thomas J. Dodd confirmed reports today that he is con sidering running for reelection this fall on an independent ticket. He said he had been approached by many people who are asking me to run as an independent and I am giv ing it consideration.

title: McLain, $400,000 in Debt, Files Bankruptcy Plans
description: DETROIT, June 9 (AP) Citing unsecured claims of about $400,000, Denny McLain, the suspended Detroit Tiger pitcher, filed today for bank ruptcy.

title: Far Rockaway Beats Canarsie In P.S.A.L. Baseball Final, 72
description: Sometime after the start of yesterday's Public Schools Ath letic League championship game between Far Rockaway and Canarsie in Yankee Sta dium, Jack Ogden, a right handed ace for the Seahorses, found that his fast ball wasn't working.

title: F.B.I., in Slaying Inquiry at Kent, Checks Political Beliefs of the Faculty
description: KENT, Ohio, June 9  Fed eral Bureau of Investigation agents, sent here after the slaying of four Kent State Uni versity students in a volley of National Guard gunfire, have been questioning students and faculty about the political be liefs and teaching of some pro fessors, according to several members of the campus com munity.

title: Pollution's Tie to Prosperity Disputed
description: CHICAGO, June 9Environ mentalists disputed today eco nomists who depict both boom ing population and pollution as integral parts of American pros perity.

title: STATE'S COURT VOIDS WEAPONS CONVICTION
description: ALBANY, June 9The Court of Appeals today reversed the conviction of a man who had served two years of a maxi mum sevenyear sentence. The court agreed with the prosecu tor that the defendant had been illegally arrested.

title: Soyuz 9 Crewmen Mix Science and Exercises
description: MOSCOW, June 9 (AP) Col. Andrian Nikolayev and Vitaly Sevastyanov, the Soviet astronauts in Soyuz, mixed sci entific observations and phy sicial exercise again today in the eighth day of their space flight.

title: LINDSAY ASSAILS NIXON ON HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 Mayor Lindsay assailed the Nixon Administration's pro posed Housing Act of 1970 to day, provoking a sharp counter attack from George W. Rom ney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development.

title: METRO DISMISSED AS ROYALS' PILOT
description: KANSAS CITY, June 9 (AP) Charlie Metro was dismissed today as manager of the Kansas City Royals and the team's pitching coach, Bob Lemon, a former star hurler with the Cleveland Indians, was named to succeed him.

title: Rumanians Welcomed With Warmth in Peking
description: HONG KONG, June 9The Chinese Communists empha sized their differences with the Soviet Union today by giving an especially warm welcome to an official good will delegation from Rumania and lauding Rumania's resist ance to foreign interference.

title: Catholics Petition Congress To Halt Fighting in Asia
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 Nearly 200 Roman Catholic priests, nuns and seminarians called upon members of Con gress today to end the fighting in Southeast Asia, end repres sion of political dissent and act to restore confidence in the American form of government.

title: SENIOR EVENT LED BY CURTIS PERSON
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 9Curtis Person, still just youngster by senior golf stand ards, was up to his old tricks of playing like a man of 25 as he shot par today to take the firstround lead in the an nual Eastern Senior Golf As sociation tournament.

title: Market Place:
Theater: Another Look at Merchant
L.I.U.SENIORS HOLD QUIET PROTESTS
description: Scattered symbolic protests in the name of peace, the en vironment, human rights and the embattled history of Long Island University marked its 40th annual commencement ex ercises, held yesterday after noon at the university's Brook lyn Center.

title: KARTHYANI OFFERS 10 INDIAN DANCES
description: One had respect and a some what restrained enthusiasm for the program of 10 Indian dances Karthyani presented last night at the Cubiculo. The pieces were meticulously costumed and presented, but were strangely unexciting.

title: GUERRILLAS FIGHT JORDAN'S TROOPS IN AMMAN REGION
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 9 Palestinian guerrillas battled with Jordanian forces today in and outside Amman, the capi tal. At one point, according to a Jordanian broadcast heard here, King Hussein escaped an attempt on his life.

title: MOUND ACE SNAPS HIS 4GAME SLUMP
description: HOUSTON, June 9  The Mets, who became baseball's outdoor champions last year, took another major step tonight toward winning the indoor championship this season.

title: 3 ExPoverty Aides Held as Embezzlers
description: Three former neighborhood antipoverty program directors were arrested yesterday on charges of having embezzled more than $34,000. A fourth man is being sought on similar charges.

title: Mrs. Hart Leads by Two Strokes With 74 in Eastern 54Hole Golf
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 9 Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of the Essex County Country Club, West Orange, N. J., took a two stroke lead in the 60th annual Women's Eastern Golf Associa tion's 54hole medalplay cham pionship today.

title: BOND SALES SLOW DESPITE RATE RISE
description: The credit markets, faced yesterday with an extraordi narily heavy volume of new fixedincome securities for sale, handled their burden much as a tired old man might have done. Interest rates were raisedsome to peak levels and yet many of the offerings failed to move.

title: QUEENS SPEAKER ANGERS PARENTS
description: Dr. Howard Zinn, a longtime activist in the civil rights and peace movements, speaking yes terday at the 46th commence ment of Queens College, was heard with mixed feelings when he made a bitter attack on the war in Vietnam and the para phernalia and rigamorole of the democratic process in the United States.

title: Traffic Takes Toll of 100YearOld Trees in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 9 Saigon's residents do not mourn the loss of the tall leafy trees that once made Saigon a city with charm, for there is too much else that is gone from their lives.

title: HYDROGEN MOLECULE IS FOUND IN SPACE
description: A rocket observation from above the atmosphere has re vealed for the first time the presence in space of the stuff from which it is believed stars are chiefly mademolecular hydrogen.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The poetic feeling came to Steve Tannen five years ago, as a senior in high school. He had this close friend, who quit school, in junior high and joined the Marines. The friend had less than four months of active duty left in Vietnam, but never made it home.

title: Olivier to Take Gamble In Nathan Detroit Role
description: LONDON, June 9  Sir Laurence Olivier is to play Nathan Detroit in Guys and Dolls, the first musical to be presented by the National Theater.

title: MUSKIE QUESTIONS SEWAGE AID PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 Senator Edmund S. Muskie took issue today with the Nixon Ad ministration's plan for reim bursing the states for their pre financing of the Federal share of the cost of sewage treat ment projects already com pleted or approved.

title: Senators Ask Integration Safeguards
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  Skeptical Senate liberals chal lenged the Nixon Administra tion today to guarantee that its proposed $1.5billion fund to assist desegregating schools does not end up reinforcing veiled segregation in schools where the only thing deseg regated is the front door.

title: Sentence Cut in Flag Case
description: YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, June 9 (UPI)William Short, 18 years old, sentenced to 10 days in jail for removing two American Flags from a park, has won a reduction to two days of con finement by following the judge's orders to write the Pledge of Allegiance 500 times. He presented the finished as signment, 51 handwritten pages, to Judge Leo Morley along with a letter of apology.

title: Thai Aide in Saigon As Rumors of Shift In Forces Increase
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam, June 9 (AP)Thailand's Chief of Staff flew here from Bangkok today amid mounting specula lation that part of Thailand's 12,000man Black Panther Divi sion would be withdrawn from South Vietnam to fight in northwest Cambodia.

title: H. C. Wright Jr. to Wed Miss Robbin L. Ridder
description: ST. PAUL, June 9Miss Robbin Lee Ridder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard H. Ridder Jr., plans to be wed to Howard Candler Wright Jr., a fellow student she met at the University of Califor nia in Santa Barbara.

title: Shell Oil Planning to Invest In Houston Office Complex
description: HOUSTON, June 9 (Reuters) The Shell Oil Company is making its first big venture into American real estate with an officehotelapartment com plex in Houston that could ul timately represent investment of more than $1billion.

title: PRICES ADVANCE ON LONDON BOARD
description: The London stock market closed slightly firmer yesterday in continued light trading.

title: GORMAN OUTLINES COMMUTER GOALS
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 9 Paul A. Gorman, new chairman and chief executive officer of the Penn Central Transporta tion Company, said today that he would seek to improve the railroad's commuter and Metro liner service but would press hard to eliminate all its long distance passenger trains.

title: Baruch Graduates Warned by Weaver On Violent Protest
description: Dr. Robert C. Weaver, presi dent of Bernard M. Baruch Col lege, told the graduating class yesterday that questioning values and institutions was commendable, but he warned that those who attack the status quo must be prepared to face the consequences of their actions.

title: Arab News Agencies Merge
description: CAIRO, June 9 (Reuters) The press agencies of Egypt, Sudan and Libya will merge into one central news agency, information ministers from the three countries agreed today.

title: Many U. S. Civilian Roles In Asia May Go to Military
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Nixon Administration is drawing up plans to shift numerous American economic and social programs in South Vietnam and Laos from civilian to military control.

title: Two Peace Democrats Supported by Lindsay
description: Mayor Lindsay has written letters of endorsement to two antiwar insurgent candidates seeking Democratic nomina tions for the House of Rep resentatives in the June 23 primary election.

title: World Cup Soccer
description: GROUP I

title: Wallace Is Official Winner
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 9 (AP)George C. Wallace was officially certified as the Demo cratic nominee for Governor today. The official canvass of returns from the June 2 pri mary runoff by a subcommit tee of the State Democratic Executive Committee gave Mr. Wallace a record 559,832 votes, or 51.56 per cent, and Gov. Al bert P. Brewer, 525,951, or 48.44 per cent.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Cost of Campaigning

title: POLICE ARE ADVISED ON USE OF FIREARMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI)  The Nixon Administration has advised the nation's police authorities that in dealing with protest demonstrations the first objective should be to keep the situation cool enough so firearms will not have to be used.

title: FEDERAL BACKING FOR PENN CENTRAL ON LOANS PLEDGED
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Nixon Administration has de cided to put the Government's credit behind the Penn Central Company and that holding com pany's financially troubled rail road subsidiary, the Penn Cen tral Transportation Company.

title: Cutback Imperils Park Shakespeare
description: The uses of adversity may be sweet for some, but for the New York Shakespeare Festival they may prove to be otherwise.

title: Veeck Will Testify for Flood As Antitrust Trial Ends Today
description: The Curt Flood trial is scheduled to end today with Bill Veeck as the final rebut tal witness for Flood's side in Federal Court here.

title: In Memoriam
description: ALTEREllas. Birthday. In memory we will always be together as in life. Loved, longed for, ANNA.

title: Musical Antipasto Is Served Up At Concert by Apostolic Family
description: An unusual mixture of musi cal elements was brewed at the Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street, on Monday night  blues, church music, country music, children's songs, pop parody, delivered with a hill country twang and with electronic instrumentation.

title: Sloan Fund Group Will Study Cable TV
description: The Alfred P. Sloan Founda tion announced yesterday a grant of $500,000 to establish a Commission on Cable Televi sion to conduct a 15month study on the impact and pros ??ects for the medium.

title: Harold Phelps Stokes Is Dead; Times Editorial Writer '2637
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  Harold Phelps Stokes, a member of the editorial board of The New York Times from 1926 un til 1937, died Monday at his home after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Schacht Is Buried in Munich; 150 Attend Rites for Financier
description: MUNICH, West Germany, June 9 Hjalmar Schacht, the man who was often credited with planning the financial foundation of Hitler's Germany in the nineteen thirty's. was buried here today. The former Economics Minister died last Thursday at the age of 93.

title: Addonizio Trial Witness Testifies From Ho spital on Dummy Company to Aid Extortion
description: EAST ORANGE, N. J., June 9  A paralyzed witness, who mumbled replies from his hos pital bed in the trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and seven other defendants on extortion charges, identified $240,828 worth of checks today as kickbacks from contractors who had worked for the city.

title: C.E. Introduces New Radios
description: The General Electric Com pany introduced at a press showing yesterday its 1971 line of radios that includes 14 new products. Included in the new items is an AMFM clock radio that is said to be the first to use largescale integrated elec tronic circuitry.

title: BOMB EXPLOSIONS RISE IN FREQUENCY
description: The explosion last night at Police Headquarters was the latest in a series of blasts that have taken place with increas ing frequency across the coun try.

title: Training Program Is Urged to Put More Nurses in City Hospitals
description: A demand for largescale training programs to alleviate the critical shortage of nurses and technicians in municipal hospitals has been made to the city' new Health and Hospitals Corporation.

title: Blackmun Is Sworn as 98th Justice
description: WASHINGTON. June 9  Harry A. Blackmun took the oath today as an Associate Justice and quickly plunged into judicial work that has accumulated during the 13 months in which the Supreme Court has been without a ninth Justice.

title: John McAuliffe, Mary Sperling Plan to Marry
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., June 9Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey Sperling Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Sperling, to Ens. John Herbert Mc Auliffe, a reserve officer on active duty with the Coast Guard at its Washington headquarters.

title: Negro Police Chief Named
description: KANSAS CITY, Kansas., June 9 (AP)Maj Boston Daniels was named chief of police to day, the first Negro to hold that position in this city. Kan sas City has an estimated pop ulation of 170,000, of approxi mately 35 per cent, or 31,000, are Negroes. The Police De partment has 88 Negroes on the force and 282 white mem bers.

title: 10 Get Jail Terms in Raid on Chicago Draft Office
description: CHICAGO, June 9 (UPI) Ten persons, including four who claimed innocence on the ground of cultural insanity, were sentenced today to terms ranging from five to 10 years for ransacking a Chicago draft board office and burning its records.

title: Heinemann in Denmark
description: COPENHAGEN, June 9 (Reu ters)President Gustav Heine mann of West Germany arrived for an official visit to Denmark today.

title: Bomb at Police Headquarters Injures 7 and Damages Offices
description: A tremendous explosion rocked Police Headquarters at 240 Centre Street last night, heavily damaging offices on the second story of the fivestory building.

title: Study of Two Million Checks Barred in Tax Unit Inquiry
description: HOUSTON, June 9Federal District Judge John V. Single ton has refused to allow the Internal Revenue Service to examine two million cashier's checks and drafts to gather evidence against a Houston physician suspected of having bank accounts in four foreign countries.

title: Peru Asks Survey Mission
description: GENEVA, June 9Peru asked the governing council of the United Nations Development Program today to send a special mission to Peru to appraise the amount of damage from the recent earthquake.

title: U.S. Lakeshore Opposed
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Establishment of Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore in western Michigan was op posed today by a property owner in the affected area. Margaret Thomas of Birming ham, Mich., told a House In terior subcommittee it would make better sense, if the Fed eral Government helped the Michigan Natural Resources Department develop land now under state ownership.

title: Lefkowitz Issues Warning On Violence by Dissenters
description: Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that the right to peaceful dissent had to be protected but that dis senters who resorted to violence and lawlessness must be pre pared to accept the conse quences.

title: Miss Berry Has Nuptials
description: BLOWING ROCK, N. C., June 9Miss J. Madeleine Berry, whose great  great grandfather, Stephen A. Douglas, was defeated for the Presidency by Abraham Lincoln, was married here this afternoon to E. Thomas Nash. The Rev. Zack Ralston performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany.

title: Tarkenton Gets Tittle's Vote to Keep Scrambling During 1970 Giants' Campaign
description: No, Fran Tarkenton said, he will not run in 1970. This statement had nothing to do with the baldish gentle man sitting next to him, a a fellow named Y. A. Tittle, who never used to run, either.

title: ARKANSAS GOVERNOR SEEKS THIRD TERM
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 9 (UPI)Gov. Winthrop Rockefel ler, Arkansas's first Republican Governor since Reconstruction, announced today that he would seek a third twoyear term.

title: New President Named By Drexel Harriman
description: Drexel Harriman Ripley, Inc., announced yesterday the election of James W. Strat ton, 34 years old, as presi dent and chief executive offi cer of the large investment banking and brokerage con cern.

title: PepsiCola a Casualty of the Cambodian Conflict
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 9 (AP)  PepsiCola's bubbling business has fizzled in Cambodia. The Cambodian Army seized its trucks for supply wagons and the boys at the bottling plant have gone to war.

title: STUDY YOUR MARKET, BOOKSELLERS URGED
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 Lillian Friedman, vice president of Brentano's Bookstores, took her profession to task today for talking to itself rather than listening to customers.

title: 3 Rivals Allege Ottinger SideSteps a TV Debate
description: Three of the candidates for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York ac cused the fourth yesterday of avoiding a television debate.

title: For That Next Trip, Timbuktu?
description: This summer, if you are bored with Paris, Rome, or Rio, you can fish your way around the world in 33 weeks for $33,763.

title: Students in Commencement Speeches Urge Understanding Between Generations
description: The rhetoric of dissent and defiance once again resounds from the commencement plat form as spokesmen for the col lege Class of 1970 cry out against war in Indochina and exploitation and repression at home.

title: Jersey Hospital to Gain
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 9St. Peter's General Hospital here will receive the proceeds of a ball and two horse shows. The Grand Prix Ball will be held Friday at the Plainfield Country Club. The threeday Johnson Park International Driving Show starts June 19 and the four day Middlesex County Horse Show and Country Fair starts June 25.

title: Subversion by C.I.A.
description: The disclosure that the American economic aid mis sion in Laos is being used a a cover for intelligence operations in Laos is nothing less than a body blow to the credibility of the peaceful presence of the United States in neutral and friendly nations. The decision to allow the Central Intelligence Agency to subvert an important foreign mission was made during the Kennedy Administration in 1962. The fact that it has thus persisted under three Presidents dramatizes the extent to which the debasement of national and diplomatic ethics has become a nonpartisan evil.

title: BIG BOARD MIXED ON LOW TURNOVER
description: Business is very dull, a stockbroker remarked yester day on Wall Street and the statistics bore out his words when the closing gong sounded on the New York Stock Ex change. Prices showed a mixed pattern.

title: NEGRO WILL HEAD TUSKEGEE SCHOOLS
description: ATLANTA, June 9A Negro has been named superintendent of schools in Tuskegee, Ala., and Southern educators say it is the first time in this century that a black man has been placed in permanent charge of a racially mixed school district in the South.

title: PACE IS LISTLESS IN AMEX TRADING
description: At least the market didn't go down. This comment by a broker summarized the activity on the American Stock Exchange yes terday. Prices on the exchange just managed to finish slightly higher in very quiet trading.

title: Labor Party Pleased
description: LONDON, June 9  The Treasury provided the Labor Party with campaign ammuni tion today with a report that Britain ran a strong surplus of $345.6million in her first quarter trade in goods and services.

title: Roundup: Phils Activate A Coach Who Delivers
description: They're called the tools of ignorance the mask, chest protector and shinguards worn by baseball catchers. But some of the game's soundest strategists have worked behind the plate.

title: Carol Lynne Carriuolo Betrothed
description: AVON, Conn., June 9Mr. and Mrs. Christopher W. Carriuolo have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Lynne Carriuolo, to Albert Burdette Stirrup 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sturrup Jr. of Middle Haddam.

title: Cambodian Drive Hailed by Mission On Return to U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) Members of a group of 11 Congressmen, governors and White House assistants who toured parts of South Vietnam and Cambodia at President Nixon's request reported to night they were enthusiastic over the military success of the United States intervention in Cambodia.

title: Heyerdahl Near Islands
description: COLL MICHERI, Italy, June 9 (AP)The Ra II, a papyrus boat of the Norwegian naviga tor, Thor Heyerdahl, is near the Cape Verde Islands and sailing westword fast, his wife re ported today. Mrs. Heyerdahl had her weekly radio conver sation with her husband today.

title: Newberry Plans Family Centers To Spur Volume
description: Since millions of cautious people refused to buy many items this year, there is now a builtin consumer money reservoir, greater than we can possibly imagine, Walter C. Straus, chairman and president of the J. J. Newberry Com pany, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

title: City School Robbed 5th Time
description: For the fifth time in the last 10 days, thieves ransacked and robbed Public School 99, at Stebbins Avenue and 167th Street, the Bronx, early yester day morning, causing the total in damage and stolen property to rise to about $40,000. Wil liam Poppel, principal of the school, reported that the thieves smashed a number of windows and stole television receivers, typewriters, duplicating ma chine and tape recorders.

title: Monmouth Jockeys
Tighter Rules on Job Prejudice Against Women Issued by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Labor Department issued de tailed guidelines today that are designed to eliminate discrim ination against women in jobs paid for with Federal funds.

title: OFFICER IS FREED IN SONGMY DEATHS
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Army dismissed today for lack of evidence all charges against an officer accused in the alleged massacre of civilians in the Songmy area of South Vietnam.

title: News Summary and Index
description: International

title: Baeza Scores a Double Despite Injury
description: A consecutive double with Wheatley thoroughbreds by Braulio Baeza, after the star jockey had suffered a possible nose fracture, and a riding vic tory in the jump by a Johns Hopkins sophomore featured yesterday's program at Bel mont Park.

title: London Free Market Price Of Gold Off 19c an Ounce
description: LONDON, June 9 (Reuters) The London free market price of gold came down today by 19 cents an ounce, to $35.51, after having soared by 49 cents dur ing the previous 24 hours.

title: Valiant Twice Outsails Intrepid, Ties Cup Trial
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 9 Once again the race committee called out Valiant's name first in announcing the official times today in the preliminary Amer ica's Cup defense trials. This time the committee had the right order.

title: Floating Canada Dollar
description: The dust has settled a bit since the Canadian Govern ment surprised the financial world last week by allowing its dollar to float, thus abandoning the fixed par value of 92.5 cents that had pre vailed for the Canadian dollar since 1962. Analysts are start ing to look at the longrange implications of the move, both within Canada and on the larger canvas of the world money markets. The snap reaction of many commentators to Ottawa's decision was that the floating dollar could well be an entering wedge for a general reform of the rules of international finance that would allow for far greater flexibility in foreign currency pricesa step that in the view of most academic economists at least is long overdue.

title: Guelker, Southern Illinois, Named U.S. Soccer Coach
description: EDWARDSVILLE, III., June (AP)Bob Guelker, the soccer coach at Southern Illinois Uni versity in Edwardsville, was named today to coach the United States Olympic soccer team for the 1972 games in Ger many.

title: Offices Here Tighten Security Measures After a Sharp Rise in Bomb Alarms
Speedier Repairing Of Phones Ordered
description: The state Public Service Com mission charged yesterday that too many pay telephones had been out of repair for too long a period and ordered the New York Telephone Company to achieve the goal of fixing breakdowns within four hours of detection.

title: New Books
description: FICTION

title: Manager Says Samuels Is Closing the Gap Fast
description: Howard J. Samuels' cam paign manager contended yes terday that Mr. Samuels would carry upstate areas over whelmingly in his June 23 primary fight for the Democrat ic nomination for Governor.

title: 2 BAR UNITS SCORE NIXON CRIME BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Opposition to the Nixon Admin istration's proposals for fighting organized crime has developed within the legal profession, only three weeks after President Nixon called upon bar organiza tions to help him pass his anti crime program.

title: Phone Rate Rise Is Reduced
description: BOSTON, June 10 (AP)The state Department of Public Utilities denied today a re quested rate increase totaling $55million annually to the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company, but it agreed to allow increases of $7.7million. William I. Cowin, commission chairman, said that the new rates, effective in July or August, would result in about 14 cents in additional charges to monthly phone bills for home service.

title: PALESTINIAN WARNS OF JORDAN CIVIL WAR
description: PARIS, June 10 (Reuters) George Habash, leader of the Popular Front for the Libera tion of Palestine, said in an interview published here today that the guerrillas would start a civil war in Jordan if there was an attempt to suppress them.

title: Gallup Poll Finds 48% Back WagePrice Controls
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 10 Fortyeight per cent of the American public is in favor of freezing prices and wages at their present level as long as the Vietnam war lasts, accord ing to the latest Gallup Poll. Fortyone per cent are opposed and 11 per cent are undecided, the Gallup organization said to day.

title: Saigon Army Likely to Get Bigger Combat Role Soon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10South Vietnamese and American military planners are expected to give the South Vietnamese Army a greatly expanded role in fighting the North Vietnamese main force in the next few months.

title: Deceit Victor by Three Lengths In Colleen Stakes at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 10 (AP)Deceit, a Kentuckybred filly owned by the Windfields Farm of E. P. Taylor of Can ada, scored an easy victory, as expected, in the $24,400 Col leen Stakes at Monmouth Park today, winning by three lengths.

title: NEUTRALIST OFFERS TO GOVERN VIETNAM
description: PARIS, June 10A promi nent South Vietnamese neu tralist offered here today to form a government of the silent majority, with no ties to either side, to lead his coun try out of the war.

title: A Moderate Decline in Coming Months Cited by Kennedy
description: Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy predicted yesterday that interest rates which in some sectors of the market posted record highs yes terdaywould decline moder ately in the months ahead.

title: Ossie Davis' 'Cotton Comes to Harlem'
description: "Balloons, fans, feathersthey're all out of style," says the racially aware exotic dancer preparing her act for Harlem's Apollo Theater. "They don't say a thing about my people!"In addition to the exotic dancer, who talks like an earnest Radcliffe girl (and who finally decides to do a strip tease atop a bale of cotton), there are a number of funny things in "Cotton Comes to Harlem," including a back-to-Africa swindle that has the approval of such astute agencies as the State Department, the New York Attorney General's office and the Securities and Exchange Commission.There is also a marvelous chase that, in keeping with the film's relentless system of reversals ("there's a honky in the woodpile" is a sample gag) comes near the beginning, rather than at the end, of the story. There is, throughout it all, a sense of liberation, for here is a film by a new black director (Ossie Davis, otherwise the actor and author), based on the work of a black novelist (Chester Himes), shot in Harlem with a large and talented black cast.However, like the dancer's balloons, fans and feathers, the movie's stick-ups, shootouts, chases, murders and wisecracks say little about the Black Experience except that Ossie Davis, when given the opportunity, can turn out a ghetto comedy-melodrama that is almost as cold and witless as Gordon Douglas's Gold Coast fables, "Tony Rome" and "Lady in Cement." It's strictly for people who don't care much about moviesor who persist in regarding movies as sociology."Cotton Comes to Harlem" is faithful, sometimes to the point of utter confusion of plot, to the Himes novel, one of a series about Coffin Ed Johnson and Grave Digger Jones, two black New York City detectives whom French literary critics have compared (somewhat too extravagantly, I feel) to Inspector Maigret and Sam Spade. In the book, their dialogue and actions are completely interchangeable. In the movie they can be distinguished by the fact that Godfrey Cambridge, whose eyebrows aspire to meet up in the center of his forehead when he is puzzled, plays Jones, and Raymond St. Jacques, who almost always looks angry, plays Johnson.The story, which seems to have been made unnecessarily ambiguous by the film's editor, has to do with $87,000 hidden (for reasons more convenient to the title than comprehensible in the plot) in a bale of cotton, and with the detectives' efforts to unmask the bogus preacher (Calvin Lockhart) who conceived the back-to-Africa plan as one way of getting himself back to someplace like Las Vegas.There are constant intimations throughout the film that Davis had in mind a contemporary fairy tale, a kind of cops-and-robbers "Purlie Victorious," with stereotypes (Redd Foxx, for example) used in a conscious way to satirize the society that gave them birth. Reality and truth, however, keep intruding to break the desired spell. The car chase that helps to open the film is hilarious until you learn, later on, that the pedestrian, who was winged by a bumper and went sailing into the air for a large laugh, is quite seriously dead.This occasionally works as black black humor, but there is no consistent style, and about half-way through the film I had the feeling that all Davis was able to do was to try to keep up with the seemingly endless plot revelations as outlined in the script.At their best, Cambridge and St. Jacques, throwing away not terribly comic lines, reminded me most of Sammy Davis Jr. and Peter Lawford on a slumming vacation from their British-based "Salt and Pepper" series. I was also reminded of Oscar Micheaux, who in the 1920's and 1930's, made black films for black theaters modeled on white movie stereotypes. Aside from its honest black idioms and actors, "Cotton Comes to Harlem" is a conventional white movie that employs some terrible white stereotypes of black life. Its soul looks very much like rhythm.The film opened yesterday at the De Mille and the 86th Street East Theaters. When I saw it at the first showing at the DeMille, it was apparent that the largely black audience was often as confused as I, not only by the plot but also by the point of view. Throughout most of the film, their sympathies were with the movie's villain, played with lovely, stylish cool by Lockhart, even to the extent that they snickered when St. Jacques upbraided the preacher for conning his own people. "You could have been a Marcus Garvey or a Malcolm," says the cop, but the audience, as far as I could tell, was simply disappointed that crime did not pay.

title: Time Inc. Announces PreRecorded TV Venture
description: Time Inc. announced yester day formation of TimeLife Video, a new venture in the prerecorded television field. Richard M. Clurman, an edi torial vice president of Time Inc. was chosen to head the new operation which will cre ate and market programs to be recorded on cartridges for home use. Emphasis will be on jour nalism, home information and education, according to Andrew Heiskell, chairman.

title: BERNSTEIN CONDUCTS AT VIENNA CONGRESS
description: VIENNA, June 10Leonard Bernstein opened the Victory Party Congress of Bruno Krei sky's Austrian Socialists to night, playing Beethoven with the Vienna Philharmonic.

title: PROFESSIONS JOIN LOBBY FOR PEACE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The doctors in the auditorium of the New Senate Office Build ing wore peace buttons and smoked their pipes reflectively. Senator Harold E. Hughes, in a bright blue suit, looked down on them and said happily:

title: Petit Quits Paris Opera Ballet In Dispute Over Job Contracts
description: PARIS, June 10 Roland Petit last night resigned from the directorship of the Paris Opera's Ballet. As the story goes, he did so by letter from his home rather than from his office because he had no phone in the office.

description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 10 (UPI)Space agency offi cials are thinking about cancel ing next year's Apollo 15 moon mission, and possibly a second flight, to free more Saturn 5 rockets for the space station program.

title: Homes Cleared After Fire
description: ELYRTA. Ohio, June 10 (AP) Some 200 families were evac uated from their homes today after possible cyanide fumes were found at the site of an ??

title: 85 Degrees in London
description: LONDON, June 10 (Reuters) The temperature soared to 85.3 degrees today on the hot test June day for nine years.

description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Last Thursday, quiet, reflec tive George Pratt Shultz thumped his fist on a confer ence room desk at the Labor Department and told a group of contractors who had come to see him about a lottery plan for selecting apprentices that the meeting was over.

title: Farm Workers Sign Largest Pact to Date
description: DELANO, Calif., June 10 (UPI)The signing of the largest contract to date be tween the United Farm Workers Organizing Commit tee was announced today by Cesar Chavez, farm union leader.

description: The New York Yankees, who seem to be nourishing an im possible dream of their own this season, made it two straight over the Minnesota Twins last night on a fourhitter by Mel Stottlemyre.

description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)  A compromise $2.76 billion, threeyear extension of the HillBurton hospital aid program cleared Congress to day.

description: The president or the Patrol men's Benevolent Association yesterday denounced the bomb ing of Police Headquarters on Tuesday night as the work of anarchists and warned that the city was close to an explosion that will destroy us all.

description: TOPEKA, Kan. Burnett's Mound is a bulbous lump on the smooth surface of eastern Kansas, named after a Pota watomie chief whose real name  Kahhegawatiangh was so unpronouncable that some white name dubbed him him Abram Burnett. In fron tier Topeka, Abram was an imposing figure.

description: The tax increases proposed by Mayor Lindsay to balance the city's expense budget are, paradoxically, both economically risky and fiscally essential.

title: In The Nation: The CrimeFighters' Folly
description: WASHINGTON, June 10In the absence of any formal posi tion by the American Bar Asso ciation, a committee of the bar of New York City has partially filled a conspicuous gap by testifying strongly against ma jor portions of the proposed organized crime control act.

title: Process Shot Takes Stakes
Nasa Plans to Send 2 Unmanned Craft On Trips to Jupiter
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) The space agency, said today it would launch two unmanned spacecraft toward Jupiter in 1972 and 1973 on missions of two years or longer.

title: Scientists Draw a Map Showing How Floor of the Pacific Varies in Age
description: A map showing how the Pacific grew has been pub lished by a team of American and Soviet scientists who took part last year in drilling into the floor of that ocean.

title: E. F. HUTTON ADDING 2 BRANCHES OF ORVIS
description: E F. Hutton & Co. announced yesterday that it had acquired the offices of Orvis Brothers & Co. in Norfolk, Va., and Mem phis, Tenn. Earlier in the week Hutton had reported the ac quisition of the Orvis branches in Chicago and Washington, D. C.

description: Zandra Rhodes describes herself as an unnatural person and few people catch ing sight of her for the first time would be inclined to disagree.

description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 (AP)  Robert Pelletreau, a member of the United States Embassy staff in Jordan, was among the 14 Americans and other foreigners held hostage in the Intercontinental Hotel in Amman.

description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10 (UPI)Gen. Bartolome Blanche, Provisional President of Chile for two weeks in September, 1932 died today at the age of 91.

title: The Pretrial Hearing
description: Ten years ago, things were simpler for judges and lawyers and district attorneys: A man was arrested, arraigned, in dicted if a felony was involved and sent to trial.

title: Judith Thomas, A. E. Naughton Plan to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Thomas of New York and Truro, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Ellen Thomas, to Alexander Ed ward Naughton, son of Mrs. Helen Naughton of Palo Alto, Calif., and the late Alexander Edward Naughton, professor of French and Italian at Stanford University. Mrs. Naughton heads the depart ment of foreign languages at the College of Notre Dame in Belmont, Calif.

title: SCHOOLS DEVELOPING A TEACHING PH.D.
description: The Carnegie Corporation yesterday announced grants totaling $935,000 to 10 univer sities to plan new graduate programs leading to a Doctor ate of Arts degree with the aim of improving the quality of college teaching.
