description: The bus is called the Fresh Meadows Express, and it leaves 34th Street and The Avenue of the Americas every 10 minutes during the rushhour period. It makes three stops in midtown Man hattan and then rolls nonstop until it reaches the winding roads and garden apartments of eastern Oueens.

title: POLICE TAKE LOOK AT OWN SECURITY
description: The Police Department, busy at all times guarding other people, took a look at its own security problem yesterday, not only at headquarters, but also in local stations.

title: Publishing Aide Named By Institute of Physics
description: The American Institute of Physics has named Robert H. Marks as its associate di rector for publishing and in formation activities.

title: Richard Max McCarthy
description: ELMIRA, N. Y., June 10 This city and Binghamton, in the state's Southern tier, were visited by Representative Rich ard Max McCarthy today, while in Washington his staff sub mitted a bill that would give Federal compensation to the widows and wives of police men and firemen killed or in jured in the line of duty.

title: Low Speed at Penn Central
description: The convulsion that cost the jobs of Penn Central's board chairman Stuart T. Saunders and two key associates throws a harsh spotlight on some of the problems now plaguing American business and threat ening the health of other corporations as well.

title: DR. Y. H. FOERDER, 69, ISRAELI BANK HEAD
description: Dr. Yeshayahu H. Foerder, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank Leumi of Israel since 1957 and chairman of the First Israel Bank and Trust Company of New York since January, 1969, died Tues day in Tel Aviv after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Reservist Makes Mistake and Is in the Army Now
description: Specialist 4 James E. Hamer stone has been on active duty in the Army since March 24, but according to the 27yearold reservist, no one told him about it until last Thursday.

title: AFTER THE RAIN FROZE
description: Ice cellophaned branches.

title: College Student, 18, Held In Slaying of His Mother
description: SYRACUSE. June 10  A college student who had just returned home for summer re cess was charged today with killing his mother and wound ing his father in Baldwinsville, a small hamlet northwest of here. Investigators said they had been unable to discover a motive.

title: Diana Davenport A Bride in Athens
description: Miss Diana Davenport, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Braxton Bragg Davenport of Lancaster, Pa., was married on June 3 in Athens to E. Haring Chandor, a stock broker with Shearson, Ham mill & Co. The ceremony in the American Protestant Church was performed by the Rev. Dr. Otto Meinardus.

title: National Genetics Study Urged As Step to New Era in Medicine
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Dr. Joshua Lederberg, a Nobel Prize winner in genetics, asked today for the establishment of a national study group on ge netics research to help bring to realization a new era in medicine.

title: NARCOTICS SUSPECT TRAPPED IN BRONX
description: A man described by the police as a major distributor of heroin in the Fordham section of the Bronx was arrested last night after he allegedly sold an under cover agent 15 decks of the drug.

title: Eric Till's Drama of 'The Walking Stick' Opens Here
description: "Who wants a girl with a withered leg? Imagine in bed: one good leg, and the other just hanging there like the tail of a lizard." However, Deborah soon succumbs to Leigh's seductive gentleness, and eventually they make it and they begin living together. A polio victim in childhood, Deborah has based a powerful habit of self-protection on her one lame leg. But under Leigh's tutelage, she embraces life, sets aside her stern black walking stick, and begins limping around in miniskirts.The artistic daughter in a family of London doctors (by profession she is the porcelain expert in a fashionable auction house), she is really an easy mark for the handsome young painter, an unfashionably realistic poetic realist, who woos and wins her and then begins the series of betrayals that constitute the dramatic substance of Eric Till's "The Walking Stick," an uneven movie of unspectacular virtueswhich, by grace of careful if quite conventional plotting improves as it goes along.Essentially a Jamesian subject  a maimed girl made whole by the love of a man who proves false and who in turn owes his own undoing to the strength he has given herthe story of "The Walking Stick" might as well have been set in the London of Henry James.For despite the miniskirts, the pants suits, the cars, the crowded underground, a bit of burglary, and a mite of mod violence, "The Walking Stick" really strives for a sense of untimeliness (with its heroine in figurines, as it were, and its hero in figurative art) so that the involutions of its rather moving story may remain untainted by any suspicion of that curse upon so many recent movies: relevancy.George Bluestone's screenplay, though embarrassing in detail (especially the detail of dialogue), is intelligent enough in over-all strategy. And Mr. Till's direction, by its comparative simplicity, usually redeems the ritual clichsthe idiot flashbacks, the glamour dissolves, the glossy moodsthat beset psychological story movies of a certain commercial ambition."The Walking Stick" begins as a women's picture, becomes crime melodrama, and ends as a much superior kind of women's picture. By its changes it grows slightly richer and tougher, and thus shares with its heroine a few of the stoic satisfactions (for example, development through adversity) that are the rewards of traditional fiction.As the heroine, Samantha Eggar gives a beautifully restrained and evocative performance. Utterly unsensual, vulnerable, ultimately strongshe creates a character that is quite simply more interesting and cohesive than I am used to seeing in movies (even in better movies than this one). In this she is helped both by the visual concentration of Mr. Till's direction, and by the screenplay, which makes of Deborah a genuine point-of-view character.But almost as a corollary, David Hemmings has too little to do as Leigh to create a viable characterization. Immensely attractive at the beginning, he becomes indistinct toward the middle, and positively murky by the endwhen he has grown younger, vaguer, and little more than the enabling influence in one woman's moral self-determination.

title: JOHN J. GEOGHAN
description: John J. Geoghan, controller of the Power Authority of the State of New York, died Tues day of a heart attack here. He was 55 years old and lived at 19 Stuyvesant Oval.

title: DAVID R. CUNNISON, PUBLISHING OFFICER
description: David Reid Cunnison, former vice president, director of cir culation and director of the CrowellCollier Publishing Com pany, died Friday in Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 5 Pennsylvania Boulevard. Bellerose. L. I.

title: Specialty Plastics Revised Upward
description: Prices for several chemical and other products were given higher mice tags yesterday.

title: Ambro Decries Racism in Campaign
description: Jerome A. Ambro, a white man running against a Negro for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, said yesterday that it was very dif ficult for him to campaign be cause everything he says is in terpreted as racism or bigotry.

title: Columbia Wins Team Title In Eastern College Tennis
description: ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 10 Columbia clinched the team title today in the Eastern Inter collegiate tennis championships as two Lion doubles pairs quali fied for the final tomorrow at the University of Rochester courts.

title: Federal Court Here Runs Out of Jurors In Criminal Cases
description: Judges ready to try criminal cases before juries in Federal Court here this week have had a problemnot enough furors.

title: Palestinian Peril
description: The latest bloody clash between Palestinian guer rillas and the Jordanian Army adds urgency to the fresh diplomatic initiatives that Secretary of State Rogers has promised in connection with any new arms aid to Israel.

title: Optimism in Washington By WILLIAM BEECHER
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Senior military planners here, surprised and elated by the per formance of South Vietnamese military units in Cambodia, say that it may bring about a shift in the strategy for conducting the war once most American soldiers leave Vietnam.

title: PRICES ARE LOWER ON LONDON BOARD
Maddox Surgery Successful
description: ATLANTA, June 10 (AP) Gov. Lester G. Maddox was re ported to be resting comfort ably today after surgeons re moved a kidney stone in a halfhour operation. Dr. Thomas Florence, who performed the operation at Georgia Baptist Hospital here, said there were no complications and the Gov ernor could be out of the hos pital by June 20.

title: American Issues Trade Plea to Japan
description: TOKYO, June 10 (Reuters) An American business leader made a strong plea today for prompt liberalization of Ja pan's trade and capital transac tions at the seventh Japan United States business confer pnre here.

title: SOL 0. LIPSET
description: Sol 0. Lipset, vice president and account supervisor of Diener & Dorskind, Inc., an advertising agency at 1501 Broadway, died Tuesday at his home, 4 Hull Street, Oceanside, L. I. He was 61 years old.

title: Argentina Is Tranquil After Coup
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 10 A. period of cautious maneuver ing began today as the three military commanders who seized power Monday sought the means to govern Argentina, nation that has often seemed ungovernable.

title: New Mexico Land Elects
description: Richard C. Grayson, presi dent of the St. LouisSan Fran cisco Railway Company, was elected chairman of the New Mexico and Arizona Land Com pany, succeeding J. E. Gilliland, it was announced yesterday following the annual meeting in St. Louis. The Frisco owns slightly more than 50 per cent of the land company's stock.

title: Marquette Picks Captain
description: MILWAUKEE, June 10 (AP) Dean Meminger, a 6foot1 inch senior guard from New York, was picked by Coach Al McGuire today to captain the 197071 Marquette University basketball team.

title: Samuels and Goldberg To Hold 2 TV Debates
description: Howard J. Samuels and Arthur J. Goldberg, the two candidates for Governor in the Democratic primary on June 23, will hold the first of two scheduled debates on Sunday.

title: Rumor, Intrigue and Criticism Beset City's Brooklyn Methadone Center
description: The city's experimental methadone program in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn, which started last October, is under attack.

title: Cynthia Kroll To Be a Bride
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 10Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Kroll have announced the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Cynthia Knox Kroll, to Andrew Thompson Dwyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Dwyer Jr. of Syosset. L. I.

title: Benoit Defeats Removsky On Benefit Boxing Card
description: A capacity crowd of 2,500 paid almost $15,000 to watch a boxing program staged last night at Sunnyside Garden, Queens, to raise funds for a clubhouse for Ring 8, the Vet eran Boxers Association.

title: Evers Charges Bias
description: FAYETTE, Miss., June 10 (UPI)Mayor Charles Evers accused the State Highway De partment today of discriminat ing against this southwest Mis sissippi town by removing welcome signs showing a black hand shaking a white hand. The Highway Commission director, Bruce McCaa, in re sponse to the charge, said the signs... were illegally placed on rights of way on state high ways.

title: Winton M. Blount 3d Marries Miss Lucy D. Dunn in Alabama
description: Miss Lucy Durr Dunn, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Ransom Johnson Dunn Jr., was married at her parents' home in Birming ham, Ala., on Saturday to Winton Malcolm Blount 3d, son of Postmaster General and Mrs. Blount of Mont gomery and Washington.

title: U.S. AIDE IS SLAIN IN AMMAN BATTLE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10A United States military attach was killed by Palestinian guer rillas at his home in Amman today and the United States Embassy came under sniper fire several times in the second day of heavy fighting between the Jordanian Army and the com mandos, the State Department announced today.

title: The Midi Won't Darken Their Door
description: MILWAUKEE, June 10 (AP)I am not responsible for any midilength skirts purchased by my wife, Marvin Glasspiegel declared Monday in a newspaper advertisement that he later described as a protest to lowered skirt lengths.

title: Millionaire Is Shot To Death on Coast; Wife Is in Custody
description: FRESNO, Calif., June 10 (UPI)William E. Thoresen 3d, a shadowy millionaire once con victed for assembling a vast ar senal of military arms and am munition, was shot to death to day in a quarrel with his wife.

title: News Summary and Index
description: THURSDAY, JUNE 11, 1970

title: CARMEN RETURNS WITH NEW VOICES
description: Bizet's Carmen returned to the Metropolitan Opera reper tory on Tuesday night for the first time in the 196970 sea son, bringing some singers new to their roles with the company and returning Jean Morel to the Met podium after an absence of seven years.

title: KEOGH SETS MARK OF 4:10.1 IN MILE
description: Fred Dwyer, the Manhattan College coach, had a smile al most wide enough to span the nearby East River at Downing Stadium yesterday as the mile run finished in the Eastern States schoolboy track and field championships.

title: Rescue Plane Lost in Peru
description: LIMA, Peru (UPI)A twin engine Argentine rescue plane on a mission from Lima to the earthquakeravaged town of Anta was reported five hours overdue and was presumed to, have crashed.

title: PRICES SHOW DIP IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange drifted lower yesterday in very light trading.

title: Plea by Clay Rebuffed
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) Assistant Justice Hugo L., Black of the Supreme Court denied an application by Cas sius Clay's lawyer to allow the former heavyweight champion to go to Canada for a boxing match. Special permission for foreign travel is ??ssary be cause of Clay's 1967 conv??ion for fa?? ??

title: Thieu Sets Tie to Pnompenh
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 (AP)  President Ngu yen Van thieu signed a decree today establishing a permanent South Vietnamese Embassy in the Cambodian capital, Pnom penh, the Government radio re ported.

title: Paterson Advocates Sale Of Jet Planes to Israel
description: State Senator Basil A. Pater son, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Lieutenant Governor, called on the Nixon Administration yes terday to sell jets to Israel in order to maintain the balance of power in the Middle East.

title: MULLER'S 3 GOALS DEFEAT PERU. 31
description: MEXICO CITY, June 10 (AP) Gerhard Muller, a center for ward, scored three goals for the second time in the World Soccer Cup championship and leg over team to a 31 victory over Peru today to assure the West Germans of top place in Group IV. Peru finished second in that groupand also goes into the quarterfinals.

title: INTREPID BEATEN HANDILY ON SOUND
U.S. Grants Funds to Aid Medical Service for Poor
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)The Office of Economic Opportunity announced a $1.95 million grant today to encour age and train more doctors, dentists and other medical personnel to serve in poor neighborhoods.

title: Russian Astronauts Orbit 9th Day in Good Condition
description: MOSCOW June 10 (UPI)  Andrian Nikolayev and Vitaly Sevastianov flew today through their ninth day in orbit conduct ing research necessary for giant orbital observatories of the fu ture.

title: AirPollution Caution Continues Till 1 P.M.
description: Robert N. Rickles, the Commissioner of Air Re sources, announced yesterday that the high pollution fore cast stage that was an nounced Tuesday would con tinue until 1 P.M. today.

title: Paul O'Dwyer
description: Paul O'Dwyer visited a muni cipal children's shelter yester day and then denounced both the city and Federal govern ments for what he called their childwelfare policies.

title: Thefts of Furs Have Risen In Germany in Recent Years
description: BONN (UPI)Thefts of furs by organized gangs who steal them by the carload and smug gle them across national bor ders for resale have increased in recent years in West Ger many, as well as in neighbor ing countries.

title: PETER H. DEITSCH, DEALER IN PRINTS
description: Peter H. Deitsch, a leading dealer in contemporary prints, died yesterday at the Contin ental Hotel in Munich, West Germany, apparently of a heart attack. He was 45 years old.

title: HERMAN LEBOW
description: Herman Lebow, vice presi dent of Regalia Furs, 345 Sev enth Avenue, died in Roosevelt Hospital Tuesday after a heart attack. He was 64 years old and lived at 390 West End Avenue.

title: DAVIDSON DOWNS RALSTON, 61, 86
description: BRISTOL, England, June 10 (AP)  There was an upset in the $24,000 Wills open tennis tournament today, a Wimble don tuneup, as Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., was toppled by Owen Davidson, the Australian southpaw, 61, 86, in the second round.

title: Everybody Seems to Have Fun At Greenwich Club's Coursing
description: Representatives of seven gazehound breeds (only the Irish wolfhound of the eligi bles was missing) raced with undimmed vigor at the Greenwich Kennel Club show last Saturday, even though every now and then the rain poured down. The exhibition lasted an hour. When it was over, Mrs. J. Wal lace Cross of Cos Cob, Conn., the show chairman, told how her fa vorite breed, the dachshund, had got involved.

title: 200 IN JERSEY CITY HURL ROCKS AT POLICE
description: JERSEY CITY, June 10  About 200 members of the Young Puerto Rican Society staged a rockthrowing melee at City Hall here at about 10 o'clock tonight, overturned a police car and damaged two, others in a disorder that grew out of a protest against alleged police brutality.

description: ROZETTAugusta, June 11, 1966. In mem ory of a loving wife, mother and grand mother. THE FAMILY.

title: Fair Will Help Princeton Hospital
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 10 The Women's Auxiliary of Princeton Hospital will hold its 17th annual benefit fair all day Saturday.

title: Reform Democratic Leaders Back Cintron for Assembly
description: Eighteen Manhattan Reforml Democratic District Leaders an nounced yesterday their en dorsement of Humberto Cintron for the Democratic nomination in the 68th Assembly District, which includes East Harlem.

title: U.S. Court Backs Muslims, Voids Registry in Alabama
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 10 (UPI)A Federal court ruled in favor of the Black Muslims to day, striking down as uncon stitutional an Alabama law re quiring Communists, Nazis and Muslims to register if they are in the state as long as a day.

title: U.S. Ambassador Cheered On Visit to Swedish City
description: SUNDSVALL, Sweden, June 10 (UPI)Several hundred per sons cheered and applauded Ambassador Jerome Holland to day at the end of a fourday Visit to this industrial city in northeastern Sweden.

title: STATE GUARD DUTY IS CUT FOR 13,000

description: ATLANTA, June 10  Hosea Williams, a longtime civil rights activist, qualified today to run for Secretary of State of Georgia as a Republican. His wife qualified to run for Con troller General as a Democrat.

title: F. C. C. Urged to Punish Deals for TV Ads
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The Justice Departmennt said today that any broadcasting Company that systematically solicits commercials from com panies it does business with should be denied a renewal of its broadcasting license.

title: Advertising: Varying Views of Pollution
description: A variation on a tavorite themethe social responsi bility of advertising  was played yesterday morning as the World Congress of Ad vertising reached the mid point of its weeklong meet ing.

title: BONN AND WARSAW PLAN FULL PARLEY
description: BONN, June 10West Ger many and Poland agreed today after four rounds of exploratory talks that they were close enough on essential political is ?es to start negotiating a gen eral treaty on diplomatic re lations.

description: The city filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday against four major manufacturers of master key systems, charging them with conspiracy to fix prices.

He was 81 years old and lived at 529 Wychwood Road.

description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Mrs. Sakie Prout Buel, widow of Walker S. Buel, the former chief of The Cleveland Plain Dealer bureau here, died yes terday at Doctor's Hospital after a brief illness. She was 78 years old and resided here.

Tuttle, a small Vermont publisher, received the John Barnes Publisherof, theYear Awards tonight at the, closing session of the annual convention of the American Booksellers Association. The awards  named for the late founder of Barnes & Noble, Inc. are made each year by secret ballot among the association's, membership, which now totals 2,800 bookstores and wholesale dealers.

description: FORT BRAGG, N. C., June 9The newly reorganized John F. Kennedy Center for Military Assistance has just graduated its first class of new ugly Americans39 officers who received a concerted sixweek smattering of knowledge in the Political and social sciences.

Edgar Hoover, director, an nounced today. Mr. Sullivan succeeds Cartha D. DeLoach, who last week announced his retirement as one of two spe cial assistants to Mr. Hoover.

description: LYME, Conn., June 10 Douglas J. Bennet of Lyme, who was an unsuccessful candidate for the House of Representa tives in 1956, announced his candidacy today for the Second District seat vacated by the death May 1 of Representative William L. St. Onge. Mr. Ben net is the fourth candidate to announce for the Democratic nomination. The other three candidates are State Senators William B. Stanley of Norwich and John F. Pickett of Middle town, and former State Senator Alfred Bineham of Salem.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
NINE DEFENSEMEN PICKED BY SABRES
Savings Banks in State Reversed Drain in May
description: New York State savings banks had a net deposit inflow of $6782million last month, in contrast to a deposit drain of $194.16million in April, the Savings Bank Association of New York State announced yes terday.

title: Shoes and Salesgirls From France
description: The biggest name in French shoes comes to Fifth Avenue today. The Charles Jourdan shop, designed by a French architect with most of its Plexiglas, steel and leather interior made in France and assembled here, opens at 700 Fifth Avenue (55th Street). It is the first of a projected chain of retail shops that the manufacturer plans to establish in the United States. There are 14 other Charles Jourdan shops, in Paris, other European cities and Hong Kong. New York women have been buying shoes with the Jourdan label at Blooming dale's, Lord & Taylor, Altman's and I. Miller. Christian Dior and Pierre Cardin shoes, which are also made in the Jourdan factories, have been available, respectively, at Delman and Bonwit Teller. All of these associations will continue but now the three high fashion brands of shoes will all be sold in the new Jourdan shop, along with handbags, stockings, scarves and men's tics.

title: Chess:
description: Zwischenzug, an intermedi ary move or inbetween sur prise one, instead of say, a re taliatory capture, is a fascinat ing tactical play. It may have various facets. It may, for ex ample, have an ugly look. It is usually a shock to the play er on the receiving end, in any event.

title: CLASH WITH ISRAELIS REPORTED BY BEIRUT
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 (UPI)A Beirut spokesman said today that Lebanese troops had attacked one of the regular patrols Israel has been sending into Lebanon's frontier zone since an Arab guerrilla bazooka attack May 22 on an Israeli school bus that killed and wounded 32 children and adults.

title: Many Bodies Seen on Airfield At Laotian Town Taken by Foe
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 10 A reconnaissance pilot who flew over Saravane yesterday after the important southern Laotian town fell to Communist forces said he saw many bodies on the airfield.

title: F.D.A. Concedes Lag on Cyclomate Ban
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Dr. Charles C. Edwards, the head of the Food and Drug Ad ministration, conceded under, Congressional questioning to day that the artificial sweetener cyclamate should have been taken off the market sooner than it had been.

title: Screen: 'One More Time':Davis-Lawford Movie Should End Series
description: Let's fervently hope that "One More Time" wraps it up forever for the team of Sammy Davis Jr. and Peter Lawford, who yesterday unveiled this deadly little sequel to their "Salt and Pepper" a while back. This time, continuing their roles as co-owners of a London bistro, the two star-producers are prancing and scampering through the great halls of a British castle with virtually nothing to do in a picture that goes nowhere except back and forth between them, the color camera hovering in rapt fascination.This feeble little jape is so rickety and parched for humor that its amusing highlights are simply two loud sneezes emitted by Davis that make shambles of a costume ball. At this point, toward the end, there was a faint hope that the director  a chap named Jerry Lewis  yes, the same  would jazz things up with a custard-pie or two. But no. The picture proceeds to die on its feet, even with Davis hysterically imitating his director. Lawford, in the double role of twins, roguishly lets us know that he's quite at home in that castle, y'know.The real waste here is the excellent color bestowed on on the beautiful, ancient place and a smattering of London street scenes. The fade-out finds the boys peering into the camera and joking about their next picture together. "This one's finished," Davis reminds us. Man, it was finished even before it started.

title: Gil Hanover, 52 Pick, Draws 2dTier Post for Dexter Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 10 Gil Hanover, a $95,000 pur chase as a yearling who failed in the first race of his career but since then has been un beaten, did not fare well this morning in the post position draw for Saturday night's $111,514.24 Dexter Cup trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

description: Bob Moose, Pittsburgh's righthanded pitcher, got a bad case of the Willies in San Francisco's Candlestick Park yesterday.

description: Israel Goichberg, a Yiddish poet and teacher, died Tuesday in the New York Infirmary after a short illness. He was 76 years old and lived at 60 West 68th Street.

description: The New York Yankees are not moving to London. They are not even being sold to anybody in London. They are not even being sold.

description: WASHINGTON, June 10  President Nixon made public today the outline of a revised, expanded welfare program that he hopes may prove more ac ceptable to Congress than the bill that stalled in the Senate six weeks ago.

Addoni zio of Newark and seven other defendants identified checks to day amounting to $687,901 as contractors' kickbacks that he had cashed for the collection branch of the alleged munici pal extortion conspiracy.

description: George Balanchine's cele brated dictum that there are no mothersinlaw in ballet seems hardly supported by his own A Midsummer Night's Dream, so clearly does the master of plotless ballet tell a tangled tale.

J., June 10 A midnighttodawn curfew was imposed for the second night in this small town eight miles southeast of Camden fol lowing a night of violence in which 20 persons were arrested, three policemen were injured and a police sergeant's garage apparently was fire bombed.

He was immediately challenged by supporters of the trust fund on the House Public Works Com mittee.

description: Barry Farber was ruled off the Liberal party line yester day in the November election for Representative in the 19th Congressional District.

title: Transfer of Air Rights Is Key to Downtown Skyscraper Deal
description: The City Planning Commis sion has been asked to permit a developer to put up a 50 story office tower downtown in exchange for giving up control of an ancient block of buildings to he preserved as part of the South Street Seaport.

title: U.S. Check for Housing Mellows City
description: Two top city housing offi cials, upon receiving a check yesterday for more than $53 million In Federal urbanre newal funds, took pains to stress how cordial their rela tions were with the Federal De partment of Housing and Urban Developmenta day after the department's Secretary, George W. Romney, called Mayor Lind say's attack on a Nixon Ad ministration housing bill irre snonsible and inaccurate.

title: INQUIRY IS STARTED BY U.S AND STATE
description: NEWARK, June 10Kenneth A. Gibson, the black candidate in next Tuesday's runoff may oral election here, has requested Federal and state investigations of an alleged campaign plot involving a possible assassina tion attempt and the provoca tion of a racial incident this weekend. Both inquiries have already been started.

title: Central and South West Sees a Rise in Earnings
description: Given normal weather and no serious busines downturn, earnings of the Central and South West Corporation could approximate $2.85 a share this year, S. B. Phillips Jr., presi dent, told yesterday's luncheon meeting of the New York So ciety of Security Analysts. The concern is a public utility holding company in the South west.

title: Earl Grant, a Popular Organist And Record Star, Dies in Crash
description: LORDSBURG, N.M., June 10 (UPI)Earl Grant, entertainer and organist who was best known for his instrumental version of Ebb Tide, died with a companion in an auto mobile crash today in the New Mexico desert. Mr. Grant was 39 years old.

title: City Pays a Down Payment On Brooklyn Navy Yard
description: The city turned over a $2.6 million check to the Federal Government yesterday and for mally took possession of the Brooklyn Navy Yard.

title: UTILITY OFFERING LAGS IN SELLING
description: Interest rates continued to move higher yesterday, again reaching new historic peaks. A highquality bond issue sold by an electric utility was priced to yield a record 9 per cent, but investors showed relatively little interest in it.

title: Civilian Service Proposed As Alternative to Draft
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) A bipartisan House group to day introduced a bill that would replace the current draft law with a system allowing young men to choose between military and civilian service.

title: NIXON UNIT BACKS DRIVE IN CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, June 10On the eve of a crucial Senate vote on the Nixon Administration's Indochina policy, the White House received from a Presi dential commission an optimis tic report on the push into Cambodia.

title: MISS SMITH GAINS TWOSTROKE LEAD
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 10  Delancy Smith of Snyder, N. Y., added a oneoverpar 75 today to her firstround 78 for a 153 and a twostroke lead in the Women's Eastern Golf Association's 54hole medal play championship.

title: Lesotho Asks Famine Relief
description: MASERU, Lesotho, June 10 (AP)The Prime Minister, Chief Leabua Jonathan, declared to day that all of Lesotho was hunger stricken and, in a radio appeal, requested famine relief from international organiza tions. Lesotho has been hit by drought and this year's corn crop is only a third the size of last year's. Lesotho, completely surrounded by South Africa, was formerly the British terri tory of Basutoland.

title: Hodgson, ExBusinessman, Popular With Unions
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  James D. Hodgson, the Under Secretary of Labor, who was nominated by President Nixon today to head the department, is only the second former busi ness executive to be named La bor Secretary since 1933.

title: South Korea Refuses Plea For Cambodian Military Aid
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 10President Chung Hee Park has refused a Cambodian re quest for direct military assist ance from South Korea but has promised nonmilitary support, a presidential spokesman said yesterday.

title: Tear Gas Used to Scatter SitIns at Santa Barbara
description: SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 10 (UPI)Tear gas was shot into a crowd gathered in the student community of Isla Vista tonight after the police were unable to break up a sit in with mass arrests.

title: Treasury Chief Sees Rate Cuts
Fuji Photo Plans to Offer Its Color Film Line in U.S.
description: The Fuji Photo Film Compa ny, Ltd., Japan's largest maker of quality color film and a lead ing producer of photographic materials, said yesterday it would introduce its color film products in the United States.

title: Dick Gregory Hones Humor at Village Gate
description: A force of about regimen tal strength named Dick Gregory moved into the Village Gate on Bleecker Street Tuesday night, direct from counter commencement at Fordham University.

title: LUFTHANSA PLANS ITS FIRST DIVIDEND
description: BONN, June 10Lufthansa, the West German airline, an nounced today that it would propose its first dividend, a 4 per cent cash payout. Last year saw the company's best profit in its 15 years of operations.

title: Changes Due in Administration of Public TV Here
description: Delicate negotiations in pub lic broadcasting appear des tined to make New York's Channel 13 one of the more unusual noncommercial TV op erations in the country. If no hitches develop, James Day, president of National Educa tional Television, will become president later this month of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, licensee of Chan nel 13.

title: Spain Lifts Opposition Leader's Passport
description: MADRID, June 10  The Span ish Government seized the pass port today of the Count of Motrico, a leading figure of the opposition.

title: Books of The Times
description: One picked up Bech: A Book, or Bech: A Buch, or Bekabook, or however it's pronouncedand one groaned. One had never been a particular fan of Mr. Updike's. One had never quite been able to stomach the precociousness of his descriptive powers; the message, Look, Ma, I'm writing, that wafted off his pages; the ultrafine sensi bility that seemed to rob twigs and leaves and even pubic hairs of their rights to an unap prehended exist ence. The sensibil ity seemed so inquisitive and ob jectifying that it had had the ironic effect of casting an Updikean pall over everything it touched with its verbal necroman cy. And now, in Bech: A Book it was invading the kingdom of the Jews, inventing, in the writer Henry Bech, a fictional composite of N. Mailer, S. Bellow, A. Port noy, I. B. Singer, H. Roth, D. Fuchs, and J. Salinger. Bad show, J. Updike, poor sport, one thought. You, among the few who stand outside the renaissance of Jewish letters, you have the least right to schmoo zle your way in, to climb aboard the cara van. Bech? Fech!

title: JOHN P. HAGGERTY
description: John P. Haggerty, president of the Haggerty Supply Com pany of Forest Hills, Queens, electrotype supplies, and for merly with the engraving de partments of Cond Nast and the Hearst publications in New York, died yesterday in St. John's Queens Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 98.25 34th Road, Forest Hills.

title: Harlem Prep Graduates 83 In a Festive Street Ceremony
description: Harlem Preparatory School graduated its third and largest class  83 collegehound stu dentsin a sprawling, festive commencement yesterday in the middle of a main street in the black community that gave the school its name.

title: McMurray Resigns as Queens College President
description: Dr. Joseph P. McMurray has resigned the presidency of Queens College to become head of the College of New Rochelle, a Roman Catholic institution for women. He will be its first nonclerical president.

title: L. I. Man Dies in Collision
description: MANALAPAN, N. J., June 10 (AP)William Rivera, 29 years old of Freehold, was killed today in a twocar headon collision on a straight stretch of County Route 522 between Freehold and Englishtown.

title: Girl Found in Refrigerator Believed to Be Murder Victim
description: NEW LONDON, Conn., June 10A 7yearold girl was found dead here in an unused refrig erator last night, and officials said they suspected she had been murdered.

title: Reserve Board Approves Move by Holding Company
description: The Security New York State Corporation, an upstate bank holding company based in Rochester, announced yesterday that the Federal Reserve Board had approved, without dissent, its proposed acquisition of the National Bank of Auburn, N. Y.

title: Rustin Calls for a Coalition To Oppose Nixon Policies
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 10 (AP)  Bayard Rustin, the civil rights leader, said today that only a coalition of labor union ??sts, minority groups and stu dents could turn the country away from President Nixon's coalition of the rich.

title: KROEHLER COMPANY DROPS BEDROOM LINE
description: The Kroehler Manufacturing Company, Naperville, Ill., one of the country's largest pro ducers of furniture, announced yesterday that it was discon tinuing its production of bed room furniture in the United States due to conntinuing un profitability. Bedroom furni ture represented less than 10 per cent of Kroehler's 1969 sales of $117.5million.

title: Motor Vehicles Post Filled
description: The appointment of Max I. Basner as supervising referee for the State Department of Motor Vehicles, new Adminis trative Adjudication Bureau here was announced yesterday by Commissioner Vincent L. To fany. The bureau's five local offices will open on July 1 and will handle adjudication of most moving violations taking place within city limits.

title: SHULTZ HEADS NEW AGENCY REPLACING BUDGET BUREAU; FINCH DISMISSES DR. ALLEN
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon today named George P. Shultz, the Secretary of Labor, as director of the new and powerful Office of Manage ment and Budget. It was the second major Cabinet change in less than a week.

title: Personal Finance
description: With rising salaries pinched by increasing costs of living, proper tax planning for life insurance policies becomes more important each year.

title: 2 FORD GRANTS AND ART RESTORATION
description: Two grants for programs that would develop technical resources in art conservation were announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation.

title: Mafiosi Freed by Italian Law Reform
description: PALERMO, Sicily, June 6 Scores of notorious underworld figures have been freed under a new Italian decree to protect the rights of accused persons.

title: COURT ORDERS BAIL FOR WOMAN PANTHER
description: HARTFORD, June 10 Fed eral District Judge M. Joseph Blumenfeld today ordered bail for a Black Panther jailed by state judge for refusing to tes tify.

title: Hruska Backs Meat Quota
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Weakening of the present meat import quota system would harm the United States cattle industry and the con sumer, Senator Roman L. Hruska, Republican of Nebraska, said today in a Senate speech.

title: ANITA W. MERRIAM, U.S. TAX AUTHORITY
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Anita Wells Merriam, Treasury tax adviser, died Sunday at her home here, apparently of a heart attack.

title: Shift to Salt Lake City Official for A.B.A. Stars
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 10 (UPI)The Los Angeles Stars of the American Basketball Association officially became the Utah Stars today.

title: ELECTIONS BOARD BACKS VOTE AT 18
description: The city's Board of Elections yesterday came out in support of giving th right to voter to 18yearolds in city and state elections.

title: BUDDHIST MONK, 74, IS SUICIDE IN SAIGON
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday. June 11 (AP)A 74 yearold Buddhist monk burned himself to death in Saigon early today to protest against alleged Government persecution and to appeal for peace in Vietnam.

title: Short Skirts Still Available (at $400)
description: The printed explanations that accompany designers' fashion collections are not noted for their brevity, but George Halley managed to get his message across in two sentences.

title: Linda Thoman to Be the Bride Of Robert Fritz in September
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 10 The engagement of Miss Lin da Marie Thoman to Robert Anthony Fritz of New York has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Thoman. The bridegroomtobe is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Fritz of Cranston, R. I.

title: Nasser and Libyan Leader Urge End of Amman Fighting
description: CAIRO, June 10 (Reuters) President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic and Muammar elQaddafi, the Libyan leader, today called on king Hussein of Jordan to do everything in his power to end the crisis between his Govern bent and Palestinan guerrillas.

title: U.S. Helps Soviet Doctor In 2 Operations at Sea
description: RUISLIP, England, June 10 (AP)A Soviet doctor and United States Air Force rescue crews worked together at sea to save the life of a Greek cabin boy and to pro vide emergency surgery for a British seaman, the Air Force here reported today.

title: An $88.5Million Deal By ALEXANDER R. HAMMER
description: The American Enka Corpora tion has agreed in principle to acquire the International Salt Company as well as 100 per cent of the stock of Organon, Inc., in a transaction value at about $88.5million, it was announced yesterday.

title: Many Negro Candidates Elected In Virginia Municipal Contests
description: RICHMOND, June 10  Ne groes took seats on city and town councils throughout Vir ginia in yesterday's balloting.

title: LOAN IS SEEN SOON FOR PENN CENTRAL
description: Paul A. Gorman, head of the Penn Central Company, ex pressed the hope yesterday that the troubled transportation system within the next few days would have the money in hand that a group of banks has agreed to loan it with the Government's guarantee.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Bill Veeck, a peglegged man who never wears a tie, says he had $11 when he arrived in Milwaukee 30 years ago to operate the minorleague Brewers. Twenty years later, when he sold his interest in the Chicago White Sox, he was worth in the vinicity of $1million. Along the way, he introduced black ballplayers to the American League, mova ble fences to Milwaukee and Cleveland, a major league midget to St. Louis and the promotion called Bat Day, which a grateful nation has made baseball's most popular attraction. With these cre dentials, Veeck, now 56 years old, appeared in Fed earl Court yesterday as an expert witness for Curt Flood on the last day of the antitrust suit against baseball. At the center of this case is baseball's con tention that the network of contractual agreements that bind a player to his original club until trade or death part themthe so called reserve clauseis necessary to the stability, even the survival, of the game. Veeck, clear and sen sible, said that a modified reserve clause would en hance the game. In testi mony, Veeck said that sud den termination of the re serve clause could lead to chaotic conditions, but an orderly termination would not. He cited the du Pont antitrust case in which the Government ordered the cor poration to divest itself of General Motors stock but gave it time so as not to dislocate the market.

title: HUGHES TOOL TOLD TO POST SECURITY
description: The Hughes Tool Company, which lost a major antitrust suit last year to Trans World Airlines, was ordered here yes terday to post security of $75 million before June 22.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT

title: CROSSWORD PUZZLE
description: ACROSS

title: WORDS OF NIXON CHANGED BY AIDES
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The official transcript of President Nixon's latest news conference quotes Mr. Nixon as having as serted that United States forces in Cambodia had captured rockets by the thousands and small arms ammunition by the millions.

title: NEGROES CHALLENGE DESEGREGATION PLAN
description: RICHMOND, Va., June 10  Attorneys for Negro plaintiffs contended in Federal District Court here today that the city's proposed school desegregation plan was unacceptable.

title: AMERICANS ADVANCE IN MUSIC CONTESTS
description: Tass, the Soviet Government press agency, reported last night from Moscow that 16 of 27 performers had qualified for the second round of the inter national Tchaikovsky violin competition.

title: LONG PRESS STRIKE FEARED IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON, June 10In the middle of the campaign for the June 18 election the British to day found themselves without their national newspapers.

title: Collins Cards 64 and Sets Record for Century Course
description: PURCHASE, N. Y., June 10 Bill Collins of Brae Burn Country Club set a course record for the Century C. C. golf course today carding 34, 3064, seven under ?ar.

title: AT LEAST 100 DIE IN AMMAN CLASHES WITH GUERRILLAS
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 10 Arab guerrillas battled Jor danian soldiers today for the fourth consecutive day and held about 40 foreigners as hostages in an Amman hotel.

title: PEPITONE CLOUTS FOURRUN HOMER
description: HOUSTON, June 10 With eager anticipation, about 200 residents of the Texas town of Alvin made the 30minute drive to the Astrodome tonight to watch their hometown hero, Nolan Ryan, pitch in person for the first time in two seasons.

title: Priest Seeks Pastore's Senate Seat
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 10 (AP)The Rev. John J. Mc Laughlin, associate editor of the Jesuit magazine America, formally announced today that he would seek the Re publican nomination for the United States Senate seat held by John O. Pastore, a Democrat.

title: Turkish Program Curbing Opium Poppy
description: ANKARA, Turkey, June 3 The Turkish Government is making slow but so far en couraging progress with a pro grain of political and agricul tural alchemy  turning fields of opium poppies into stands of wheat, hops and alfalfa and turning off the source of 80 per cent of the heroin used in the United States.

title: 2,000 on L. I. Pay $100 To Attend Rockefeller Party
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., June 10 Governor Rockefeller brought his reelection campaign to Suffolk County tonight at a $100aticket reception at tended by more than 2,000 people.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C.Dr. R Wharton Gaul is an appar ently mildmannered ortho pedic surgeon, but turn the conversation to North Caro lina's trash fish industry and the good doctor's restraint falls away.

title: School Board Is Planning to Drop 2,000 FullTime Substitutes
description: As many as 2,000 fulltime substitute teaching positions, virtually all the substitute posi tions remaining in the city school system, may be elimi nated this fall, Board of Educa tion sources said yesterday.

title: Ruling Clears the Way
description: PITTSBURGH, June 10 (AP) A Federal judge issued a rul ing today clearing the way for LingTemcoVought, Inc., to take over the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation.

title: Harvard Ph. D. Will Become Agnew's New Speech Writer
description: WASHINGTON, June 10A Harvard student who has been severely critical of the liberal way student radicals have been treated by colleges will become Vice President Agnew's only fulltime speech writer.

title: Fund Founder Seen Opposed to Bid by Outsiders
description: GENEVA, June 10Bernard Cornfeld is reported to be op posed to efforts of an outside banking group to acquire con trol of Investors Overseas Serv ices and has been talking of a proxy fight to regain control of the troubled mutualfund company he founded 14 years ago.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ANSWER TO PREVIOUS PUZZLE

title: F.T.C Seeks Curbs on Fabrics Violating Inflammability Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The Federal Trade Commission ??oposed stiffened penalties to day for the manufacture and sale of clothing and household fabrics that fail to meet Federal flammability standards.

title: Bridge:
description: The United States interna tional team has a mystery to ponder as it heads out of New York today en route to Stockholm and a possible world championship title. The mystery has a crucial bearing on the team's pros pects of bringing the Ber muda Bowl, the emblem of world superiority, back to these shores for the first time since 1954.

title: $40 to $50Million Reported to Have Been Concealed
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Robert M. Morgenthau, former United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York, said today that Investors Over seas Services had concealed $40million to $50million in loans to directors and other close associates that materially affected the stock of the shaky international financial empire.

title: Owner of Caribia Sees Vindication In Court's Ruling
description: The future of the Pana manianflag cruise liner Caribia, now anchored off the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn, ap peared decidedly brighter yes terday to its owner, Andrew Kostantinidis.

title: Saudi King Visits Indonesia
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 10 (Reuters)King Faisal of Saudi Arabia arrived in Jakarta today for a threeday state visit to Indonesia, the world's most populous Moslem nation. Presi lent Suharto welcomed the Saudi monarch at the airport.

title: Vaughn Quits Colombia Post; Dispute on Policy Is Reported
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Authoritative sources said to night that the United States Ambassador to Colombia, Jack Hood Vaughn, had resigned amid reports that he was dis satisfied with the Nixon Ad ministration's attitude toward Latin America.

title: Observer: Nothing but Baling Wire and Chewing Gum
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Usually it is the night planes that bring the men back. You see their wives at National Air port, waiting, waiting, while the clock hands crawl towards midnight, and the exhausted children doze.

title: ESTIMATED CROP OF WHEAT DROPS
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today a 1970 winter wheat crop of 1,076,445,000 bushels, a drop of 2 per cent from May and 6 per cent less than last year's production.

title: Goodell Appoints Sweet As Campaign Manager
description: After a sixmonth search, Senator Charles E. Goodell an nounced the establishment yes terday of an election campaign organization that has close ties with Mayor Lindsay and Sena tor Jacob K. Javits.

title: Emergency in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 10 ninesquaremile section of Philadelphia has been placed under a limited state of emer gency as a result of several nights of racial confrontations over the use of a neighborhood playground. The proclamation, declared by Mayor James H. J. Tate, bars outdoor gatherings of 12 or more people except for persons who are awaiting transportation, engaging in recreational activities in a usual and customary place or peaceably entering or leaving buildings.

title: Richard L. Ottinger
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y. June 10Greeted by television cam eras at every stop, Representa tive Richard L. Ottinger carried his campaign upstate today.

title: Elaine N. Butcher To Marry Aug. 22
description: Miss Elaine Noel Butcher and William Joseph Garrett of Philadelphia will be mar ried Aug. 22 in Jamaica Es tates, Queens.

title: Buffalo News Strike Goes On
description: BUFFALO, June 11 (AP) A strike by helpers on delivery trucks halted publication of The Buffalo Evening News today for the second day in a row. Negotiators for the paper and the strikers met for several hours with a state mediator, but there was no report of progress. The 20 fulltime and 30 parttime helpers are mem bers of a newly formed union, the Independent Hoppers Asso ciation of Western New York, which is seeking a first con tract with the newspaper.

title: Cambodian Thanks Nixon for Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP)  Cambodia's new ambassador told President Nixon today that United States assistance had saved us from the hands of the Communists. In reply, Mr. Nixon pledged We shall do our best to aid Cambodia to defend its neutrality.

title: THANT SAYS BIG TWO HOLD KEY IN MIDEAST
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y.. June 11 Secretary General Thant said today that only agreement between the two biggest pow ersthe United States and the Soviet Union could end the rising level of war going on in the Middle East.

title: Help for Stricken Peru
description: Even for this turbulent and violent century the dimensions of Peru's natural disaster strain credi bility. The Peruvian Government now believes at least 50,000 persons were killed in the earthquake that struck the lovely Callejon de Huaylas and by the Andean avalanches and floods that came after.

title: TV: Play Finds Right Medium on N.E.T. Tonight
description: The fitting of a play to its right medium is illustrated at 8:30 this evening in National Education Television's pro duction of Ronald Ribman's drama, The Ceremony of Innocence. Two years ago the presentation received a stage production by the American Place Theater; to night Bob Markell's produc tion demonstrates the greater artistic mobility to be gained through imaginative use of cameras not tied to the per spective of the proscenium arch.

title: Ohio Republicans Shaken by Scandals
description: COLUMBUS. Ohio  For 30 years, the Ohio Republican party has been one of the na tion's most potent political organizations, with skilled lead ership, ample financing and de voted workers at the precinct level.

title: Zicarelli Indicted in Failure To Pay Taxes on $960,000
description: NEWARK, June 11Joseph (Joe Bayonne) Zicarelli, reputed boss of Hudson County racke teering and a leading Mafia figure, was indicted today on charges that he evaded paying income taxes on a total of $960,000 in 1967 and 1968.

title: Tradition Falls at Harvard as Women Join Men at Graduation Rites
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 11 Three hundred nineteen years of tradition at Harvard Univer sity fell today as 265 women from Radcliffe College received their degrees for the first time at the same ceremony as Har vard men.

title: Card of Thanks
description: MARKHOFFMrs. Ruth Markhoff and famify, of 255 Pennsylvania Ave., Mt. Vernon, N. Y., sincerely thank their friends ??ad relatives for their kind expression of sym pathy during their recent bereavement.

title: Kennedy Announces Senate Candidacy; To Serve Full Term
description: BOSTON, June 11Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, announced to day his candidacy for reelec tion to a second term in the United States Senate.

title: Labor and the State Race
description: ALBANY, June 11  New York State labor unions have forsaken Democrats to endorse Governor Rockefeller for re election this year with a fre quency that is embarrassing to Democrats who are supporting former Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg.

title: Chicken Dish for Weekend
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: EDUCATORS DEFEND PUPIL VOUCHER IDEA
description: Adam Yarmolinsky and Na than Glazer, two prominent Harvard University professors associated with the American Jewish Congress, took issue yesterday with the group's for mal opposition to a federally sponsored plan to establish an education voucher system in one or two cities next year.

title: U.S. Methadone Plan Proposed To Guide Wider Use and Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The Federal Government took major steps today toward regu lating the use of methadone and gathering proof of its value in rehabilitating nar cotics addicts.

title: 70 CIVILIANS DEAD IN A VIETCONG RAID
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11  Vietcong guerrillas shot their way through a South Vietnamese hamlet early today, killing 70 civilians in their homes, a United States military spokesman said.

title: NATO COSTSHARING ENDORSED BY LAIRD
description: BRUSSELS, June 11Secre tary of Defense Melvin. R. Laird endorsed today a pro posal for budget sharing under consideration by 11 of the Eu ropean members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: ... but a Blow to Education
description: The abrupt dismissal of Dr. James E. Allen Jr. from the key post of United States Commissioner of Education is a reflection not on his leadership ca pacity but on disorderly governing procedures of this Administration.

title: Museum Names Chairman
description: Covington Hardee, a partner in the law firm of Kelley Drye Warren Clark Carr & Ellis, was appointed yesterday as chair man of the hoard of governors of the Brooklyn Museum. He succeeds Robert M. Burke, vice president for marketing of the New York Telephone Company, who became hoard chairman of the museum a year ago.

title: Screen: Take One, 3 Programs of Student Works
description: Take One Is the name the distributor, Universal, has given a group of student films now showing in three separate programs at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle. All the films were made within the last two years or so, and all were made by graduate or undergraduate students or (in a few cases) by non students closely associated with schools.

title: POLICE ERROR SEEN IN F.B.I. PICKETING
description: Justice George Starke said yesterday in State Supreme Court that the police had no right to permit the use of bullhorns or other sound equip ment by ItalianAmericans who nightly picketed the headquar ters of the Federal Bureau of Investigation here.

title: Screen: Joyless 'Jovita':Polish Tale of Passion at the Fifth Avenue
description: "Jovita," which opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, is an earnest, joyless little Polish film that traffics in the kind of romantic passions, revelations and sensibilities most often found in a writer's first notebook.A young man goes to a masquerade ball where he meets a lady wearing the costume of a houri and something that looks like a black surgical mask. For him, it's instant love and he calls her Juliet, though she says her name is Jovita. When he tries to kiss her, she points out that they've just met. "Well," he says in what, for me, was the film's high point, "maybe later we won't want to."When the lady fails to keep a subsequent rendezvous, the young man searches the city for her, letting his careers as both a professional long-distance runner and an architect (for all its romanticism, the movie never separates its characters from their practical environment) go to hell.There are affairs with other girls, including one who talks about Peter Pan in bed, some guilt about a friend's suicide, and ultimately, according to the conventions of the movie-of-self-discovery, he finds himself although I never once was convinced he had been misplaced.The movie was directed by a Polish director new to me, Janusz Morgenstern, a graduate of the Lodz Film Institute. His work is very proper and unexciting. Early in the film he defines the dissolute love life of his hero via an afternoon tryst and images of a seltzer bottle, a ringing telephone that goes unanswered and a single, shared cigarette. The film's technique isn't as restrained as it is inhibited.The performers include Daniel Olbrychski, as the young man, Barbara Lass, as the girl and Zbigniew Cybulski, the fine star of "Ashes and Diamonds" and "Innocent Sorcerers," who was killed in an automobile accident in 1967 at the age of 40. Here, he plays a supporting role, that of a track coach. He looks dissipated and well en route to middle-aged flab, which is sad indeed.

title: Doubts Aramburu Was Slain Are Dwindling in Argentina
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 11 Nearly add doubt disappeared today that Pedro E. Aramburu, provisional President of Argen tina from 1955 to 1958, had been murdered by the terrorist group that kidnapped him 13 days ago.

title: Irving A. Manacher, President Of Coal Concerns, Dies at 74
description: Irving A. Manacher, who, al though sightless for 50 years, ran two of the nation's largest independent coal and fueloil distributing concerns, died Tuesday in his sleep at his home, 55 East End Avenue. His age was 74.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Outside it was noisy with shouts from the people and canisters of tear gas clat tering in the street, but Carbarn had heard it all before.

title: U.N. Picks Chief of Peru Quake Study
description: GENEVA, June 11  Toni Hagen, a Himalayan explorer, was appointed today to head a group of United Nations en gineers and aid experts who will survey the earthquake damage in northern Peru. Their report is intended to be the basis for allocation of hundreds of millions of dollars in assist ance from the United Nations and other international agen cies.

title: Temple Ruins at Angkor Reported in Foe's Hands
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 11Communist troops were reported today to have seized control of the area of the renowned temple ruins at Angkor in northwest Cambodia. Communist forces reportedly, also opened a new attack on Siemreap, a pro vincial capital only four miles from the edge of the huge temple complex.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION CLIMBS IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, June 11 (AP) Scheduled United States auto mobile production surged to yearly peak of 185,461 this week, nearly even with the out put of 185,660 for the compar able week last year. The previ ous weekly high for 1970 was 183,353.

title: With British Election a Week Off, Young Voters Are Apathetic
description: LONDON, June 11  In a groundfloor Labor party office overlooking Argyle Square, 26 yearold Joe Jacob picked up the telephone the other eve ning and dialed quickly.

title: O'Dwyer Scores Policy Of Port Authority Here
description: Strolling along the remodeled but deserted piers that sup planted the teeming wharves where he worked as a young longshoreman, Paul O'Dwyer berated the Port of New York Authority yesterday.

title: Bump Elliott Is Named Iowa Athletic Director
description: CEDAR FALLS, Iowa, June 11 (AP)Chalmers B. (Bump) Elliott, former head football coach at the University of Michigan and a standout player for the Wolverines in the 1940's, today was named athletic director at the Uni versity of Iowa.

title: TAXFREE BONDS URGED AS A SPUR
description: While housewives on the up per floors of a tenement casual ly dropped garbage past his head, Howard J. Samuels ex plored the refusestrewn alleys of a South Bronx slum yester day, then proposed a way to solve the housing crisis.

title: CLARENCE R. MEASE, Y.M.C.A. DIRECTOR
description: Clarence R. Mease, associate executive director of the Na tional Council of Young Men's Christian Associations of the United States, died of a heart attack yesterday at Beekman Downtown Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 54 Rose Terrace, Chatham, N. J.

title: Frank Silvera, ActorDirector, Electrocuted in Coast Mishap
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 11 (AP)Frank Silvera, the actor, director and producer who played the role of a Mexican ranch owner on television's High Chaparral series, was accidentally electrocuted today in his home here.

title: Bridge:
description: The team headed by Jeff Rubens, and including Mi chael Becker, Steve Altman, Peter Weichsel and Joel Stuart, all of New York, and Monroe Ingberman of New Peitz, N.Y., virtually clinched the Von Zedtwitz Knockout Team Championship title in play at the Baronet Club on Wednesday night.

title: Lonborg on Disabled List
description: BOSTON, June 11 (UPI)The Boston Red Sox placed Jim Lon Borg, a righthanded pitcher, on the disabled list today. Lonhorg, the 1967 Cy Young award win ner, aggravated an injury to his right shoulder in an exhibition game against the Montreal Expos.

title: British Guards to Tour in Fall
description: The Coldstream Guards and the Black Watch regiments of Britain will join forces for a threemonth tour of the United States and Canada next fall. The program will include music, marching ceremonies and High land dancing. The American tour will begin with five per formances at Madison Square Garden from Sept. 16 through Sept. 20.

title: Advertising: Hopeful Look at Society's Ills
description: The World Congress of Advertising ended yesterday on the subject of society's illsits dominant theme for four days.

title: Israelis Report Raiders Kill 20 Egyptian Soldiers
description: JERUSALEM, Friday, June 12 Israeli commandos struck across the Suez Canal and at the west bank of the Gulf of Suez this morning; destroying bunkers and fortifications, an Israeli Army spokesman said this morning.

title: White House Reception
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) Mrs. Richard M. Nixon will be hostess at a White House reception tomorrow for 800 delegates to the 50th anniver sary conference of the Women's Bureau of the Labor Depart ment. Mrs. Nixon also will be hostess next Thursday at an afternoon party for 1,000 Dis trict of Columbia children in vited to a preview of the Summer in the Parks Program.

title: A New Vice President Announced by Gimbels
description: Clarence Giffen has been named vice president and controller and executive board member of Gimbels New York and its nine stores, ef fective Monday.

title: Pennsylvania Police Clash With 250 White Protesters
description: ALIQUIPPA, Pa., June 11 (AP) The police clashed tonight with 250 whites who had massed in front of the police station to demand the release of four white youths seized in racial disorders today.

title: Nonsmoking Day Proclaimed
description: Mayor Lindsay, a nonsmoker, yesterday proclaimed Wednes day as Kick the Smoking Habit Day. At a City Hall ceremony, Mr. Lindsay named Michael Lazar, a Queens Democratic Councilman, as honorary city wide chairman of the observ ance.

title: Music Survey Studies Amateurs' Instruments
description: About one out of every six Americans plays a musical instrument, and more than one of every three American households has an amateur musician, according to a sur vey released yesterday by the American Music Conference.

title: SAIGON WILL RELEASE 62 DISABLED P.O.W.'S
description: PARIS, June 11The Saigon Government announced today that it would release next month 62 disabled war prison ers and 24 fishermen captured at sea off North Vietnam. A spokesman for Hanoi indicated that his Government would raise no obstacle to the transfer.

title: Foote, Cone Elects Top Executive
description: A year ago Jahn E. O'Toole and Arthur W. Schultz were named president and chairman, repsectively, of the newlycreated Foote, Cone & Belding Advertising, the sub sidiary of Foote, Cone & Belding Communications, that was charged with all domestic advertising.

title: SOVIET WIDENS AID TO NORTH VIETNAM
description: MOSCOW, June 11The So viet Union announced today that it was increasing its mili tary and economic aid to North Vietnam as a result of intensi fied fighting in Indochina.

title: CornellPenn Trackmen Rout OxfordCambridge
description: LONDON, June 11 (AP)A combined track and field team from Cornell and Pennsylvania universities won 12 of 16 events today and crushed Oxford and Cambridge at the Crystal Palace Sports Center.

title: Securities Industry and S. E. C. Seek InvestorInsurance Accord
description: WASHINGTON, June 11The securities industry and the Securities and Exchange Commission are racing against a Congressional deadline in an attempt to agree on an insur ance system to protect investors from losses when brokerage firms go bankrupt. Persons close to the negotiations said today the odds were 5050 that an agreement would be reached by Monday, when hearings on the issue begin in a House Commerce sub committee.

title: LEARY FLIES BACK FOR BOMB INQUIRY
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary returned from West Berlin last night and said the only way to make Police Head quarters secure from future bombing attacks was to shut it in with a Berlin wall something he would not do.

title: Joseph Noble Leaving Met Museum to Head City's
description: Joseph V. Noble, vice direc tor for administration at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has resigned his post to be come the director of the Mu seum of the City of New York. He will start his new job Sept. 1.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Cambodian Evaluation

title: FOUR GRAHAM WORKS DUE IN FALL REVIVAL
description: Four major works by Martha Graham that have not been seen here for about 20 years, will be revived by the Martha Graham Dance Company in an engagement at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Oct. 2 through Oct. 8.

title: HUSSEIN ACCEPTS GUERRILLA TERMS; OUSTS 2 GENERALS
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 11 After five days of the bloodi est fighting ever between Arab guerrillas and the Jordanian Army, King Hussein yielded to night to the two principal com mando demands by removing his uncle as Commander in Chief and dismissing the com mander of the Third Armored Division, which surrounds the capital.

title: Dancer Entry Drivers a Secret For $111,514 Dexter Cup Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 11 No one around Stanley Dancer's barn at Roosevelt Raceway to day was able or willing to talk about which drivers would handle the Dancer Stable entry in Saturday night's $111,514.24 Dexter Cup Trot. Dancer will make the decision by 11 o' clock tomorrow morning, but until then the identities of the men who will be in the sulkies behind Nevele Rascal and Gal lant Prince remain mysteries.

title: Apparel Maker Sees the Soviet
description: When Robert L. Leeds Jr., chairman of Manhattan In dustries, Inc., a large apparel and retail company, visited the Soviet Union last week, he could not resist taking a busman's holiday by inspect ing stores and production machinery there.

title: NIXON AIDES WEIGH RESHAPING A.E.C. FOR A WIDER ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Nixon Administration is seriously considering a plan to break up the Atomic Energy Commission and remake it into an agency dealing with all forms of energy.

title: July Draft Call of 15,000 Is Issued by the Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) A July draft call of 15,000 men was issued today by the Pentagon. It is the same as the quotas previously set for May and June.

title: Rep. Chisholm Sees Nation's Collegians Ripe for Agitators
description: Representative Shirley Chis holm told the academic world yesterday that it was burying its head in the sand while large numbers of disillusioned stu dents were ripe for political agitators.

title: Sullivan, Newest Director, Quits ParvinDohrmann
description: The ParvinDohrmann Com pany, which has been beset by a variety of investigations and management changes, an nounced yesterday that its newest director had resigned.

title: Dinteldyk Is Sold, Renamed
description: The HollandAmerica Line passengercargo liner Dinteldyk has been sold to the Orient Overseas Line. The 11,366 grosston steamship, with ac commodations for 60 oneclass passengers, was turned over to the new owners at Rotterdam, the Netherlands, last week. She was renamed the Oriental Fan tasia. Jacq. Pierot Jr. & Sons, brokers in the sale, said the 504foot vessel would trade be tween Southeast Asian and East Coast United States ports.

title: Con Ed Generates A Little Less Light As the Heat Rises
description: A combination of heat and high humidity had people turn ing up the airconditioning yesterday and one result was that the Consolidated Edison Company reduced the voltage it was delivering by 3 per cent in order to conserve enough generating capacity to meet peak demands for electricity.

title: AGNEW BIDS PARTY CITE NIXON RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Vice President Agnew appealed to Republican Congressional candidates tonight to campaign on the record of President Nixon.

title: POSTAL WORKERS PUT OFF A STRIKE
description: Members of Branch 36 of the National Association of Letter Carriers voted last night by a narrow margin to delay strike action.

title: Von Karajan Will Test Drugs' Effect on Music
description: VIENNA, June 11Herbert von Karajan, the 62yearold conductor of the Berlin Phil harmonic Orchestra, plans to offer himself as a guinea pig to investigate the experience of performing and listening to music while under the in fluence of drugs.

title: Books of The Times
description: Nicholas Delbanco is not yet 30 years old, and News is his fourth novel. The first threeThe Martlet's Tale, Grasse 3/23/66 and Consider Sappho Burning delighted and perplexed reviewers, when they were reviewed at all, for they seemed to refer to a world consisting wholly of words; to posit an autonomy of the imagination; to seek in language itself the solution to moral problems con ceived of as per ceptual problems: the way one sees accounts for the discrepancy be tween one's mo tives and one's motions. Very modern novels, to be sure, substitut ing memory for time, myth for logic, poetry for the long train of qualifying clauses all those freight cars of fact. Faced, then, with News, which the publisher describes as a novel about black separa tism and the white revolutionary, a re viewer must wonder whether Mr. Delbanco has been traumatized out of his autonomy by the headlines, or set upon by Benning ton Maoists and forced to sign an oath of relevance.

title: Kerensky
description: Alexander Kerensky has belonged to history for so long that it must come to many Americans as a surprise to learn that he died only yesterday. Having lost out to Lenin in 1917, it was his fate to live on for more than a half century, watching helplessly from afar while Lenin and his successors totally trans formed their native country.

title: STOCK MARKET RENEWS RETREAT
description: Glamour and investment grade issues came under re newed pressure yesterday as the DowJones industrial av erage tumbled 9.93 points to 684.42. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange continued to limp along at a slow rate that means red ink for the op erations of many brokerage houses.

title: ABUSE OF POWER CALLED A DANGER
description: Arthur J. Goldberg, calling for sweeping legislative reform, accused Governor Rockefeller yesterday of a cynical abuse of executive power that he said had robbed the Legislature of its independence and creativ ity.

title: Belmont Jockeys
description: *Apprennce.

title: Charges Voided Against 14 in '69 TakeOver at Cornell
description: ITHACA, N. Y., June 11 (AP) Indictments against 14 Ne groes charged with criminal trespass in con??ection with the takeover of the student union on the Cornell University cam pus in April, 1969, were dis missed today.

title: Record 1,805Pound Marlin Landed
description: HONOLULU, June 11 (AP)  The crew of the charter boat CoreeneC hauled in a 15foot, 1,805pound Pacific blue marlin yesterday. It was reputed to be the largest fish  other than a shark ever caught by rod and reel.

title: Amanda Luria Wed To Russell Handler
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., June 11  At Temple EmanuEl here today. Miss Amanda Luria, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Luria 3d, was married to Airman 1st Cl. Russell Hartmann Handler, who is on active duty with the Air National Guard at Lackland Air Force Base in Texas. He is the son of Julian H. Handler of New York and Mrs. Herbert L. Kern of Kings Point, L. I. Rabbi Mil ton Grafman performed the ceremony.

title: Pilch Reelected President Of the Typographical Union
description: COLORADO SPRINGS, June 11 (AP)  John Pilch has been re elected president of the Inter national Typographical Union by a margin of nearly 2 to 1, a tabulation of the biennial voting indicated today.

title: Queens Patrolman Wounded Trying to Balk a Holdup
description: A Queens patrolman was shot twice last night while try ing to stop a holdup at Topsy's Restaurant 11201 Queens Blvd.

title: British Polls Give Labor Strong Lead for Election
description: LONDON, June 11A week before Britain's scheduled elec tion, Prime Minister Wilson and his Labor party appear to hold a commanding lead.

title: Article 2  No Title
Lesson in Not Being Helpless
description: The parents of children at Public School 183 had wor ried for a long time about the inadequate opportunities for physical exercise at the school.

title: Stock Market Viewed By Chase Manhattan
description: The drop in the stock market has correctly indi cated the direction of eco nomic activity for the past year, the Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday, but the extent of the market decline bears no resemblance to the degree of business slowdown that has occurred or seems likely.

title: EXOFFICER TELLS OF SONGMY DATA
description: WASHINGTON, June 11A former Army intelligence officer has written in a magazine arti cle that the American Army unit involved in the alleged Songmy massacre received conflicting intelligence information.

title: AIR CONTROLLERS TO SWITCH UNIONS
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization said today that, with all but a few ballots counted, its members had voted 3,127 to 346 to affili ate with the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association.

title: EXECUTIVE LEAVES BUYING OFFICE POST
description: William T. French, chairman and chief executive officer of the Associated Merchandising Corporation, the country's larg est buying office and retail re search organization, announced yesterday his retirement, effec tive June 30, after more than 10 years as head of A. M. C.

title: Nixon's Reorganization Plan Follows Historic Advice
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 For 33 years, commissions, White House advisers and stu dents of the Presidency have insisted, with increasing ur gency, that the President of the United States does not have enough power.

title: A RAIL UNION SIGNS EXPERIMENTAL PACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The Illinois Central Railroad and the United Transportation Union signed today an 18 month experimental agreement calling for new operating meth ods and eliminating restric tive job rules to win new busi ness and create more jobs.

title: Eastern Air Lines Is Requesting A Limit on Unescorted Children
description: Eastern Airlines plans to ask the Civil Aeronautics Board to limit to five the number of un accompanied 5to11yearolds allowed on any of its flights.

title: World Cup Soccer
description: GROUP I

title: Adventists Open 10Day Convention
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 11 Robert H. Pierson, president of the Seventhday Adventist Church, said here today that his denomination had the best of two worlds.

title: In Memoriam
description: CARRENOTeresa. The Venezuelan Pia no Vituosa. Unforgettable Artist and Rare Friend. Her Remaining American Puolls.

title: Reid Cards Five UnderPar 66 and Leads $130,000 Western Open by Stroke
description: CHICAGO, June 11 (AP) Steve Reid, who bagged six birdies on the last eight holes, shot a fiveunderpar 66 today and took the firstround lead in the $130,000 Western open golf tournament.

title: Roundup: Cuellar Holds Showing of Old Art Form
description: Before the Baltimore Orioles acquired Mike Cuellar from the Houston Astros in December, 1968, for Curt Ble fary, they had heard from Jim Russo, their superscout, that he was more than a pitcher. Russo referred to the 33yearold Cuellar as an artist who had five pitches and complete command of them all.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
DAVID A. PINE, 78, OF U.S. COURT DIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)  David A. Pine, a retired United States District Court judge who once ruled that President Harry S. Truman acted unconstitutionally, died here today at the age of 78.

title: State Department Denies Vaughn Quit Over Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) The State Department said to day that Jack Hood Vaughn, director of the Peace Corps in the Johnson and Nixon Admin istrations was resigning as United States Ambassador to Colombia to return to private life.

title: Rangers' Sales Reach a Million In SecondHand Players' Mart
description: Would you pay $333,333.33 for a 37yearold hockey player who sat out the last two months of the season with a separated shoulder?
