description: POOLE, England, June 14 (AP)Stig Wennerstrom of Sweden finished 12th in to day's heat of the world Soling championships, but retained his overall lead with 16.7 points. John Dane 3d of New Orleans held second place with 21 points.

title: PADRES' RUN IN 9TH DOWNS PIRATES, 21
description: SAN DIEGO, June 14 (AP) Dave Campbell cracked a run scoring single in the ninth inn ing today, giving the San Diego Padres a 21 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates. Clay Kirby posted his first victory since may 10.

title: PETTY TRIUMPHS IN RACE ON COAST
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., June 14 (AP)Richard Petty, the ace stock car driver from Randel man, N.C., drove his Plymouth Super Bird to victory today in the Falstaff 400 at the River side International Raceway.

title: S.B.A. Deputy Named
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Einar Johnson, a former Chi cago banker, was named deputy administrator of the Small Busi ness Administration today, Hilary Sandoval Jr., S.B.A. ad ministrator, announced.

title: ERIE BLAKE, 87, GETS JAZZ PRIZE
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 14Eubie Blake, the lively 87yearold pianist and com poser of I'm Just Wild About Harry and Memories of You, received the first James P. Johnson Memorial Award from the Institute of Jazz Studies at Rutgers University yesterday. The award, named for the cele brated jazz pianist who died in 1955, will be given each year to someone who has carried forward the jazz neritage.

title: 50 Youths Arrested in Buffalo As Violence Mars Arts Festival
description: BUFFALO, June 14  The closing hours of the 13th an nual Allentown Arts Festival in downtown Buffalo tonight were disrupted by clashes between rockthrowing festivalgoers and police who retailiated with tear gas.

title: GONZALO ROIG, 80, COMPOSER, DEAD
description: MIAMI, June 14  Gonzalo Roig, a composer of operettas, and popular songs, died in Ha vana last night, the Havana radio said this morning. He was 80 years old.

title: SINGERS FIT ROLES IN MET'S CHENIER
description: There was nothing tentative about either the production or the performances of Giordano's Andrea Chnier by the Metro politan on Saturday night. Both, in fact, were uncommonly satisfying.

title: MRS. JOHN M'NALLY
description: Mrs. Josephine McNally, the mother of William J. Smyth executive director of the United States Auto Club, died Friday after heart surgery at Monte fiore Hospital, the Bronx. She was 71 years old and lived in Chester, N. Y.

title: GRABLE, LOLACHEVY, CONTINENTAL VICTOR
description: MONTEREY, Calif., June 14 (UPI)Ron Grable finished more than 40 seconds ahead of his nearest rival in winning the $25,000 Continental champion ship series race for Formula A sports cars today.

title: Trophy Goes to Patriot
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., June 14 Dwight Webb's Patriot won the F. Rogers Ketcham Trophy today as Huntington Yacht Club boats scored a sweep among the 45 boats that sailed in the club's annual 20mile Day Race.

title: Bonwit's Head Finds Challenges
description: Can the former publishing di rector of Harper's Bazaar, House Beautiful and Town & Country find selfexpression, even happiness, running a fa mous Fifth Avenue store? He can, responds William M. Fine, after a year as president of Bonwit Teller, and he can find a few surprises, too.

title: ITALY TO REFORM HER BUREAUCRACY
description: ROME, June 14  My new car cost $1,900, a high civil servant said, pointing at his gleaming Fiat sedan. We have calculated that if the state had to build it with our routine bureaucratic methods, the car would cost $19.000.

title: Soviet Reports It Has Largest Proven Reserves of Natural Gas
description: MOSCOW, June 14The So viet Union is experiencing boom in natural gas and some Western experts predict that incoming decades Moscow may turn out to be the major source of this cheap, efficient, non polluting fuel in Europe and Asia.

title: IOWA STATE OUSTS ARIZONA NINE, 71
description: OMAHA, June 14 (AP)Don Powers, an Iowa State fresh man southpaw from Brampton, Ontario, fired a sixhitter today for a 71 victory over Arizona. The loss eliminated the Wild cats from the College World Series.

title: DESTINE'S DANCERS SHOW ETHNIC GRACE
description: JeanLon Destine and his AfroHaitian Dance Company offered a wellbalanced profes sional ethnic dance program Saturday night at Kaufmann Concert Hall.

title: FULL I.O.S. POWER GAINED BY BRITON
description: GENEVA, June 14Sir Eric Wyndham White has con firmed his new role of strong man in the embattled Inves tors Overseas Services finan cial empire in a boardroom showdown with the I.O.S. founder, Bernard Cornfeld.

title: A Jesuit Tries Hand at Interior Decorating
description: He had never bought a chair or de vised a color scheme. Yet last year Richard P. Hunt did what few deco rators would dare. He redesigned and furnished 31 apartments at 220 West 98th Street in less than four months a deadline most professionals would con sider tight for completing even one fourroom flat.

title: Despite Throwing Error and Tough Chances Afield, Mets Go on to Sweep Braves' Series
Dianne Bedford, W. T. Marsden Marry in Jersey
description: MOUNTAIN LAKES, N.J., June 14Miss Dianne J. Bedford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Forrest Bedford, was married at the Community Church (Congre gational) here today to Wil liam T. Marsden, son of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Mars den. The Rev. Dr. Loral W. Pancake performed the cere mony.

title: American Eagle First to Finish As Fleet Lags in Newport Race
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 14 The 175mile yacht race that began yesterday off Oyster Bay, L. I., was in a state of flux tonight with nothing estab lished officially except that the converted 12Meter sloop American Eagle was the first yacht to finish.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for the week follows:

title: ELI B. ENZER
description: Eli B. Enzer, a former corres pondent for United Press Inter national, died Saturday at University Hospital of a brain tumor. He was 31 years old, and lived at 100 West 94th Street.

title: SERVER SURVIVES SHAKY BEGINNING
description: Doing their part to keep alive idle chater about an allNew York World Series, the Mets, who used to be the party of the second part in such wishful jok ing, completed a threegame sweep of the Atlanta Braves with a 75 decision at Shea Sta dium yesterday.

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 14The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: LIKE TAKES TITLE AT OX RIDGE SHOW
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 14 Corny Guest rode LiKe to the regular working hunter cham pionship at the windup of the 41st Ox Ridge Hunts Club horse show today.

title: DOMESTIC NEEDS FOR STEEL RISING
description: PITTSBURGH, June 14Steel producers see a change taking place in their market mix.

title: Chess:
AfroAmerican Policemen Laud Association of Black Students
description: Black policemen took a step toward narrowing the genera tion gap yesterday by honoring black students at a luncheon in the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.

title: Fordham Names Chairman
description: Felix E. Larkin, executive vice president and director of W. R. Grace & Co., has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of Fordham Univer sity.

title: Flag Day Observed On the First Day Of Weeklong Rites
description: Communities across the na tion took advantage yesterday of summerlike weather to pay special tribute to the American flag on Flag Day.

title: Ceylon to Recognize Vietcong; Plans Steps to Become Republic
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 14 (AP)The twoweekold Gov ernment of Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike, in a sharp swing away from the West, an nounced today that it would recognize North Vietnam, North Korea, East Germany and the Vietcong's provisional revolu tionary government of South Vietnam.

title: GURNEY TRIUMPHS IN CANAM OPENER
description: BOWMANWLLE, Ontario, June 14Dan Gurney, the new member of the McLaren racing team, picked up where the team left off last year by winning the opening CanAm race of the 1970 season today.

title: Maria Lo Pinto, Lawyer, 70, And Cook Book Writer, Dies
description: KINGSTON, N.Y., June 14 Maria Lo Pinto, a writer of Italian cook books and a law yer, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at her country home here. She was 70 years old.

title: Belmont Jockeys
description: *apprentice.

title: In Memoriam
description: DAVIDSONIn memory of George Davidson, artist departed 2/15/65. Beloved, you are always in our hearts. Wife Elsie & SON Alan.

title: Negro on Campus Panel Feels Solemn Duty to Stop Killings
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 The youngest member of President Nixon's new commis sion on campus unrest is half black, onequarter Filipino and onequarter Chinese, has sharp words about the Nixon Admin istration and feels he has solemn responsibility to pre vent further deaths on college campuses.

title: 350 at Kerensky Funeral Hear His Ideal of Freedom Praised
description: A funeral service for Alex ander Kerensky, who led Russia in the brief interval between Czarism and Communism in 1917 was held late yesterday afternoon at Frank E. Camp bell's Madison Avenue and 81st Street.

title: COMMANDOS EXERT POWER IN JORDAN
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 14 An Arab commando spokesman said today that the commandos had executed two Arabs who were implicated in the rape of two American women during last week's disorders here.

title: Sports of The Times
description: John Jacobs, son of the late Hirsch Jacobs, has taken strong exception to some reports concerning his father particular, he described as garbage the longheld belief that his father was bankrolled by the flamboyant Broad way ticket broker, Isidor Bieber, and he denied that his father characterized last year's horsemen's boycott Aqueduct as a classic case of the bluebloods against the Italians and Jews.

title: Monmouth Jockeys
If You Can't Afford Sable This Fall, How About Rabbit?
description: Don't pity the poor work ing girl who doesn't have $30,000 for a sable coat. She can wrap herself into a $250 rabbit skin and be every bit as warm when the blizzards come.

title: Public Opinion Experts Contend Youth Has Not Opposed War as Much as Many Believe
description: BOSTON, June 14Two stu dents of public opinion have concluded that the young and the collegeeducated have not opposed the war in Vietnam as much as popularly supposed.

title: Lewis Frazer Geer Weds Mimi Griswold
description: LITCHFIELD, Conn., June 14St. Michael's Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Mariana (Mimi) Van Rensselaer Gris wold, a 1970 graduate of Connecticut College, to Lewis Frazer Geer, a 1970 graduate of Yale.

title: Buffalo Car Race Off
description: BUFFALO, June 14 (AP) The 100mile USAC race at Lancaster Speedway slated for today, was postponed indefi nitely, track officials an nounced because of the seven car smashup yesterday at Syracuse.

title: Irish Catholic Youths Stone Police Guarding Paraders
description: DUNGIVEN, Northern Ireland, June 14 (AP)Roman Catholic youths hurled stones and bottles at policemen protecting a pa rade of 2,000 Protestants through this predominantly Catholic town today.

title: Suffolk's District Attorney And Wife Hurt in Car Crash
description: BAY SHORE, L.I., June 14 Suffolk County District Attor ney George J. Aspland and his wife were injured here early today when their automobile collided with one operated by a 19yearold New Jersey youth.

title: BRAZIL IS PREPARING TO RANSOM ENVOY
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 14 The Brazilian Government to day rounded up from jails in at least three cities the 40 prison ers to be freed in exchange for the kidnapped West German Ambassador, Ehrenfried von Holleben.

title: Sihanouk Leaves Peking By Train for North Korea
description: PEKING, June 14 (Agence FrancePresse)  Prince Noro dom Sihanouk, head of the Cambodian government in exile, left here today by special train for North Korea on an official visit.

title: Finch College Head Retiring to Think
description: Dr. Roland R. DeMarco, the second president of 70yearold Finch College, announced yes terday that he would retire on Sept. 1 just to take time off and think.

title: Pyrrhic Victory Likely In Newark
description: NEWARK, June 14  Every participant in the mayoral cam paign, including the two candi dates, agrees that the quality of life here will continue to reflect all aspects of urban misery no matter who wins on Tuesday.

title: Huge Slate of New Issues Heading for Bond Market
description: Corporate bond yields, which rose to record levels last week, are headed even higher.

title: Police Control Disturbance At Puerto Rico Graduation
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 14 (AP)Leftist students shouted Murderer! today and a young woman tried to slap the presi dent of the University of Puerto Rico, but the campus police maintained control at the uni versity's graduation exercises.

title: BRANDY COALITION SUFFERS SETBACK AS 3 STATES VOTE
description: BONN, June 14The Social Democratic  Free Democratic coalition led by Chancellor Willy Brandt was dealt a setback to day by West Germans voting for parliaments in three states.

title: REDS' M'GLOTHLIN BEATS PHILS, 101
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 14 (UPI)Jim McGlothlin scat tered six hits and drove in the Reds' first two runs with a single today as Cincinnati ham mered out 18 hits for a 101 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

title: 3,000 in Police Auxiliary Honored at Flushing Park
description: The 3,000 members of the city's auxiliary police force turned Flushing Meadow Park in Queens into a sea of blue yesterday at Police Volunteer Day.

title: Personal Finance
description: Last year, Congress enacted the Tax Reform Act 1969, the most massive overhaul of tax law in the nation's history. The following article is the seventh in a series that periodically will examine the implications for personal money management of the changes that were adopted.

title: AID EARNS CUBANS RESPECT IN PERU
description: LIMA, Peru, June 14 The flow of foreign aid arriving here in the wake of the disas trous earthquake two weeks ago has caused two pronounced political shifts. One is the sud den improvement in United StatesPeruvian relations and the other is the new respect that Cuba has earned in the eyes of many people here.

title: EINSTEIN IS UPHELD BY RADIO TELESCOPE
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 14 (AP)Astronomers said today that they had used radio tele scopes for the first time in a successful test of Albert Ein stein's 55yearold general relativity theory.

title: SINGLE BY MUNSON BREAKS TIE IN 9TH
description: KANSAS CITY, June 14 After spotting the Kansas City Royals a 20 lead in the first inning, the streaking New York Yankees settled down to work at Municipal Stadium today and pulled out a 32 victory that kept all their nice num bers alive.

title: SKILLED WHITES AFFECTED MOST BY JOBLESS RISE
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 The Labor Department said to day that the nation's sharp rise in unemployment this year had been felt most by skilled white workers in the aircraft, aero space, weapons and automo bile industries in the Middle West and on the West Coast.

title: Printed Linens Led to Shop's Success
description: Two years ago, when Adele Williams, a former stylist for Gumbinner  North Advertis ing Agency, opened Boutique de Cuisine at 200 East 61st Street, its limited quarters suited her modest aspirations. Before long, it was obvious that she had underestimated her own potential. Word soon spread of the boutique's hand some Paisley table cloths, its ele gant, customor der Liberty print sheets and matching, ruffled pillow shams and attracted East Side shoppers such as Mrs. Winston Guest, Mrs. Richard Berlin and Mrs. Amory Houghton, among others. To accommodate her burgeoning clientele, Mrs. Williams recently moved to new, larger quarters at 33% East 68th Street (between Madison and Park), and the colorful wares are now spread over three rooms decorated by Paul Kellogg in an attrac tive mlange of white brick, natural wood shutters, print lined picnic baskets and sturdy Parsons tables.

title: Rochester Home Sale Set In $300 Rental Bias Case
description: Robert J. Mangum, the New York State Commissioner of Human Rights, announced yes terday that, in a case without precedent in the 25year his tory of his agency, the house of a Rochester couple would be auctioned off to collect $300 in damages stemming from a housing discrimination case.

title: Hundreds in East Harlem Rampane
description: Hundreds of youths smashed store windows and set rubbish fires over an 11block area of predominantly Puerto Rican East Harlem last night after an outdoor rally called to protest the arrest of a Young Lords londer.

title: 100 Buddhists in Saigon Protest at Monk's Funeral
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14 (UPI)About 100 eld erly Buddhist women and youths carrying signs reading Americans go home joined funeral procession today for a 74yearold monk who immolat ed himself in the cause of peace. The demonstration was peaceful.

title: STOTT, IN PLYMOUTH, FIRST IN VULCAN 500
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 14 Ramo Stett, driving a Plymouth, won the $50,750 Vulcan 500 stockcar race today and increased his lead in the 1970 standings of the Auto mobile Racing Club of America.

title: DR. DOUGLAS FESSENDEN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 (UPI)Dr. Douglas A. Fessen den, retired head of the phy sical education department at San Francisco State University and former University of Mon tana football coach, died Thurs day at the age of 69.

title: May Clouts 2Run Homer
description: BALTIMORE, June 14 (UPI) Dave May's tworun homer with two out in the 10th inning today gave the Baltimore Or ioles a 42 victory over the Oakland Athletics.

title: Philadelphians Win No. 4 In Women's Title Lacrosse
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 14 The Philadelphia First team won two games today to finish undefeated with a 40 record in the national tournament of the United States Women's La crosse Association at Swarth more College.

title: ROBERT PARKER, BIOGRAPHER, DIES
description: Robert Allerton Parker, the author of several biographical books, died of a heart attack yesterday in his home at 1040 Park Avenue. He was 81 years old.

title: World Socialist Economy
description: The Soviet Bloc's Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (Comecon) is apparently moving into a new and more highly integrated stage of its activities. Soviet commentators are increasingly referring to a world socialist economy, while the recent Comecon summit meeting agreed on a major new institution, a Comecon Investment Bank, and upon much more direct contact between ministries, enterprises and other economic organizations in the member countries than has hitherto existed. There are also signs of efforts to get greater mobility of labor among Com munistruled countries, following the precedents set by Hungarians who work in East Germany and by Bulgarians and North Koreans who are employed in the Soviet Union.

title: MAYER TOPPLES ROSS FOR STATE NET TITLE
description: Unseeded Sandy Mayer of Woodmere, L. I., upset second seeded Steve Ross of Brooklyn, 63, 62, 60, to win the New York State men's tennis title at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club, Bayside, Queens, yesterday. It was the third tournament victory for the 18  year  old Mayer this season.

title: Flow Into Savings Banks Expanded Sharply in May
description: The flow of funds into the nation's mutual savings banks improved substantially during May, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, thus raising hopes that funds will be available later in the year for the longexpected uptourn in residential construc tion.

title: Misses Englehorn, Whitworth Play Off Today for Golf Title
Wagner Backs Marchiselli In Bronx Assembly Race
description: Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner yesterday endorsed wholeheartedly and unequiv ocally the candidacy of Vincent A. Marchiselli, who is seeking the Democratic nomi nation in the 86th State Assem bly District in the northeast Bronx.

title: City Will Activate Urban Task Force's Early Warning System to Head Off Crises in Communities
description: Mayor Lindsay's office has directed 48 Urban Action Task Force units and the heads of the major city administrations to submit weekly reports of neighborhood problems so that action may be taken to avert crises.

title: EDWARD T. FAGAN
description: Edward T. Fagan, a former New York Telephone Company official, died yesterday. He was 79 years old and lived at 974 East 26th Street, Brooklyn.

title: Delivery of Stock 72% Computerized
description: The New York Stock Ex change reported yesterday that 72 per cent of all eligible stock deliveries In May were proc essed by computers.

title: Miss Streisand Sings Bella Abzug's Praises
description: Bella Abzug, riding atop a sound truck, invaded the stronghold of Representative Leonard Farhstein on the Lower East Side yesterday.

title: Clothing to Be Accepted For Peru's Quake Victims
description: Donations of clothing for the victims of the earthquakes in Peru will he accepted this week by Catholic Relief Services at the Custom House on the south side of Bowling Green, Times Square adjacent to the Father Duffy statue, and Columbus Circle at Eighth Avenue and 59th Street.

title: NASSER AGAIN SPURNS CEASEFIRE ACCORD
description: CAIRO, June 14President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic repeated today that he firmly rejected reinstatement of the 1967 cease fire agreement with Israel until Israeli troops withdrew from all occupied Arab Lands.

title: Underrated Gowon Leads Nigeria Toward Reconciliation
description: LAGOS, NigeriaYakubu Go won is one army general who says it with conviction: he longs for the day when he can turn over political power to a civilian government.

title: Herrmann Takes 38th Le Mans Race as Porsche Sweeps First Three Places
description: Le MANS, France, June 14 Porsche finally won Le Mans today and 300,000 persons cheered at the end of a very strange 24 hours.

title: Sonna Chalek Is Wed To Howard Schupak
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 14Miss Sonna Chalek was married at home here today to Howard Marc Schupak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Schupak of Yonkers, by Rabbi Arnold Kaiman.

title: GreekAmericans Crush Hungarians In Playoff, 4 to 1
description: The GreekAmericans routed the GermanHungarians, 41, yesterday before 1,200 fans at Metropolitan Oval, Queens in the second game of the Ger manAmerican Soccer League playoffs, and captured the league title for the third year in a row. The first game had ended in a 22 deadlock.

title: Ballet: Season Finale
description: Last night, with a per formance of Balanchine's A Midsummer Night's Dream, the curtailed 50th season of New York City Ballet came to an end at the New York State Theater.

title: Charles T. Stewart Dead; Real Estate Boards Official
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) Charles T. Stewart, vice pres ident for public affairs for the National Assoication of Real Estate Boards, died Friday at the age of 59.

title: U.S. Jet Drops Burning Fuel
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 14 (AP)A United States Air Force Phantom fighter bomber jettisoned a blazing fuel tank into a lake crowded with bathers and pleasure boaters near here today, but no injuries were reported. The plane landed safely at Vaerloes Air Base.

title: Pitchfork Sinks Bethpage In Roth mann Polo Final, 73
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., June 14 The Pitchfork Polo team of Greenwich, Conn., defeated Bethpage, 73, today at Beth page State Park for the Roth mann Tournament Champion ship.

title: DR. CARL EIS
description: Dr. Carl Eis, assistant pro fessor of economics at Rich mond College of the City Uni versity of New York, died Sat urday, apparently of a heart attack, in his home, 19 Bascom Place, Willowbrook, Staten Is land. He was 31 years old.

title: Bnai Zion Elects President
description: MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 14 (UPI)Harold Bernstein, a 64 yearold Brooklyn lawyer ac tive in civil rights causes, was elected president of the Bnai Zion organization today, The election of officers by 400 Ole gates completed the 61st an nual meeting of the 25,000 member Jewish fraternal or ganization at Kutscher's Coun try Club in Monticello. Mr. Bernstein succeeds Raymond M Patt 51, a Manhattan law ver.

title: Mexico City Takes Its First Official Step Toward Combating Air Pollution
description: MEXICO CITY, June 14The growing problem of smog, which is recognized as a threat to health and tourism, has gener ated the first official steps to ward remedial action in this metropolitan area of more than 7 million people.

title: Boat Curbs Eased at Target Area
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 14 (AP)The United States Navy has announced a major eas ing of regulations for boats entering or leaving waters around Culebra Island, the controversial Navy target is land off eastern Puerto Rico.

title: Horton Clouts 2 for Tigers
description: DETROIT, June 14 (UPI) Willie Horton smashed two homers and Norm Cash added a tworun clout today as the Detroit Tigers downed the Cali fornia Angels, 84.

title: State Plans Laws to Curb Lead Poisoning in Children
description: ALBANY, June 14 Gover nor Rockefeller said today the State Department of Health was planning a program to detect lead poisoning in chil dren and to remove potential soures of the poisoning.

title: Transport News and Notes
description: LONDON, June 14 (UPI) An oil tanker safety guide for the world's seafarers has been issued by the International Chamber of Shipping.

title: Czechoslovak Team Wins
description: VIENNA, June 14 (UPI)The Czechoslovak soccer club, Union Teplice, heat Hannover 96 of West Germany, 61, today in an Intercup soccer match. Kollar and Bicovsky scored two goals apiece for the winners. Loof tal lied for Hannover 96 from a free kick.

title: Wrenn Takes Coast Hammer Event
description: The heralded polevault duel between John Pennel, the world recordholder, and Dick Rails back of the Los Angeles Strid ers at the Sacramento, Calif., invitation track and field meet Saturday night fell short of ex pectations. Neither won the event nor were they among the leaders.

title: Miss Myra Janice Goldenberg Bride of David Stephen Green
description: Miss Myra Janice Golden berg, daughter of Louis Gold enberg, president of Wilden stein & Co., and Mrs. Gold enberg of Larchmont, N.Y., was married here yesterday to David Stephen Green, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Green of Merrick, L.I. His father is vice president of RBS Fabrics, Ltd. The cere mony was performed by Rab bi Irving Koslowe at the St. RegisSheraton Roof.

title: Advertising: All About Eve and More, Too
description: A year ago a man at Philip Morris heard that R. J. Rey nolds was about to test the first cigarette designed totally and exclusively for women and he laughed.

title: Lieut. Jay Kaine Weds Miss Custer
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I. June 14In St. Aidan's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon, Miss Margaret Susan Custer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merton Davis Custer, was married to Second Lieut. Jay Wallace Kaine, U.S.A. The ceremony was performed by Msgr. John Byrne.

title: Kings Point Head Will Retire Today
description: Early each June of the last 18 years, cadet hats have been sailed into the air at the United States Merchant Marine Aca demy, Kings Point, L.I., as the traditional end of commence ment exercises.

title: Most Italian Papers Shut
description: ROME, June 14 (Reuters) Italy was without most news papers today because of a strike by typesetters that brought printing presses to a standstill for the fifth time in five weeks. The 24hour strike was called following a continuing dispute with publishers over negoti ations for a new labor contract.

title: TV: Olivier's Hamlet, Uninterrupted
description: Every once in a while it happens: the presentation of a film without interruptions on the home screen. On Sat urday evening, Bounty paper towels had a modest word to say at the opening of Sir Laurence Olivier's 1948 film version of Hamlet Then, from shortly after 9 p.m.. to about 11.40 p.m., there was only the Bard and not a blurb to be heard on WORTV (Channel 9).

title: Unveilings
description: WEINRose K. This is to announce the un veiling of a memorial to Rose K. Wein at the Acacia Cemetery in Brooklyn on June 21st 1970 at 11 A.M. on the grounds of the C. Klemes family plot. There will be no Postponement.

title: Eagleton Favors Restraint
description: BOSTON, June 14 (UPI) Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, Democrat of Missouri said to day that restraint would be necessary if the United States was to overcome the horren dous problems which are press ing in from all sides as never before. Speaking to 695 grad uates at Suffolk University, the Senator said, I think most of the violence in our socity to day has a common root in a pervasive sense of insecurity, in apprehensiveness, in fear.

title: Newark Votes Tomorrow In Bitter Mayoral Contest
description: NEWARK, June 14Both the incumbent, Hugh J. Addonizio, and Kenneth A. Gibson, his Negro opponent, put in a hard day today in the final, bitter campaigning for the mayoral election Tuesday.

title: Menetrey Retains Crown
description: GRENOBLE, France, June 14 (UPI)Roger Menetrey re tained his French welterweight title last night with a third round knockout of Yvon Ma riolle.

title: TV Campaigning Itself Is an Issue in Senatorial Race
description: Television, an evergrowing factor in elections, has become an issue in the primary con test for the Democratic sen atorial nomination.

title: Mrs. Karen Grossman Married To Oscar Brand, the Composer
description: CHELTENHAM, Pa., June 14Mrs. Karen Lynn Gross man and Oscar Brand, the balladeer, composer and mo tion picture documentary scriptwriter, were married here this noon by Rabbi David Wice at the Ashbourne Country Club.

title: MARIJUANA STUDY SPLITS CANADIANS
description: OTTAWA, June 14A report on marijuana has divided Can ada's Cabinet.

title: Designer of New Setup in Nixon's Office Denies It Will Demoralize Cabinet
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  The widely held notion that the recent reorganization of the Executive Office of the Presi dent will demoralize the Cabi net and create an allpowerful White House was challenged today by Murray Comarow, the architect of the reshuffle.

title: U.S. BANKS RENEW PHILIPPINE LOANS
description: A consortium of 33 major American banks announced yesterday that it had agreed to extend for a period of up to six years $250million in loans owed by the Central Bank of the Philippines, most of which were originally sched uled to come due this year.

title: Spear Tops Nastase To Give Yugoslavia Davis Cup Tie, 22
description: MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, June 14 (AP)  The last and decid ing match of the Davis Cup tennis series between Yugo slavia and Rumania was ad journed today, because of dark ness.

title: Eloise White Wed To Edwin Martin
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14In the Appleton Chapel at the Harvard Memorial Church here today, Miss Eloise Frances White was married to Edwin Hubbard Martin. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Hugh W. Hubbard, grand father of the bridegroom and a former Congregational missionary in China.

title: ISRAELI COMMANDOS RAID BASE IN JORDAN
description: TEL AVIV, June 14 (Reuters)  Israeli commandos attacked an Arab guerrilla base inside Jordan today as Israeli jets be gan their third week of almost roundtheclock bombardment of the Egyptian front line.

title: BOBBY UNSER TAKES RACE AT LANGHORNE
description: LANGHORNE, Pa., June 14 (UPI)Bobby Unser, speeding past his brother Al in the final moments, won his second con secutive 150mile national championship race today at the Langhorne Speedway.

title: Priest Gets LaFarge Post
description: The Rev, Daniel L. Flaberty, executive editor of the Jesuit weekly America, has been named director of the John La Farge Institute. He succeeds the Rev. Thurston Davis as head of the conference center at 106 West 56th Street. Father Davis has been appointed as astant for development to the director of the communications department of the United States ??.

title: Klecatsky and Quinn Win Double Sculls at Ratzeburg
description: RATZEBURG, Germany, June 14 (UPI)Larry Klecatsky and Tom Quinn, American sculling champions, continued their vic torious run today on the final day of the Ratzeburg interna tional rowing regatta.

title: Expos Acquire O'Donoghue From Brewers in Cash Deal
description: MONTREAL, June 14 (UPI) The Montreal Expos purchased John O'Donoghue, a lefthanded reliever from the Milwaukee Brewers today.

title: Lebanon limits ArmsCarrying
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14 (Reuters)New commando con trol measures are to go into effect in Lebandon tomorrow. A Government order will forbid the carrying of arms in Leba nese towns and villages by any commandos except those be longing to groups that are mem bers of the Palestine Armed Struggle Command. These com mandos will he able to carry arms only when on duty and with advance notice to Leba nese authorities.

title: Obert Brothers Advance In Title Handball Doubles
description: Carl and Ruby Obert of the New York Athletic Club, the topseeded team, gained the semifinal round of the National Amateur Athletic Union's one wall handball championship yes terday by defeating Andy Grosz and Mark Levine of Union Tem ple, 2115, 2117, at the Munic inal courts. Coney Island.

title: West Germany Defeats England, 32, in Quarterfinals of World Cup Soccer
description: MEXICO CITY, June 14 (UPI) West Germany and Uruguay gained overtime victories and Brazil and Italy won in regula tion time today to advance to the semifinals in the World Cup soccer championships.

title: Miss Lazarus Is Wed in Ohio
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 14 In the chapel of Temple Israel here this afternoon, Miss Marjorie Lazarus, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Y. Lazarus, was married to Stephen S. Schwartz, a New York architect, by Rabbi Jerome Folkman.

title: Manson Murder Trial Nears Opening
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14 One of the most bizarre crimi nal cases in the legal history of Californiaand possibly the nationis on the verge of corn ing to trial. The proceedings promise to be very long and very complex.

title: SCHOOL ELECTIONS ARE UNDER STUDY
description: The city is investigating the possibility that some winners in the recent local school board elections may be ineligible to serve because they hold Civil Service jobs.

title: Seat in Congress Sought By a Priest in Wisconsin
description: DE PERE, Wis., June 14The Rev. Robert A. Cornell, a Roman Catholic priest, has announced his candidacy for the Demo cratic nomination for the Con gressional seat held since 1944 by John W, Byrnes, Republican.

title: Saskatchewan Trying to Stem Migration
description: MEADOW LAKE, Saskatch ewan, June 6Here in the northwestern corner of the settled part of Saskatchewan, a sawmill and a pulp mill are coming along. They will create 1,400 jobs, a veritable superboom for a town of barely 4,000 population.

title: Week's Votes in Congress
description: Compiled by Congressional Quarterly

title: RurnrillHoyt Gets New President
description: The top creative man at RumrillHoyt, Eugene F. No vak, has been moved into the presidency of the agency. That means that Donald B. Miller has moved up to chair man but remains chief exec utive.

title: Book Industry Urged to Devote Day to Peace Action
description: A large group of executives, editor sand authors has ap pealed to the book publishing industry across the country to devote next Wednesday to positive action for peace by allowing employes to hold as semblies or lobby for political candidates opposed to the In dochina war.

title: NAVY CONDUCTING SABOTAGE INQUIRY
description: SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 14 (AP)A Vietnambound Navy destroyer has been sidelined for two months by what the Navy suspects was sabotage. Three sailors are being held.

title: Panel Will Urge Changes in Use of Vast Federal Land Holdings
description: LOS ANGELES, June 14On June 24, President Nixon and Congressional leaders will be handed copies of a bulky 450 page document proposing an swers to a question that has been bothering much of the country for generations: What should be done with the one third of the nation's land that is still Federally owned?

title: Russians Ready to Break U.S. Space Record Today
description: MOSCOW, June 14The two man Soyuz 9 spaceship logged 5 million miles in earth orbit today and closed in on the space endurance record now held by the United States.

title: WHITE SOX LOSE TWO TO SENATORS
description: CHICAGO, June 14 (UPI) Aurelio Rodriguez celebrated his biggest day in the majors today with a fivehit barrage, including two homers, to pace Washingon to its first double header sweep of the year as the Senators beat the Chicago White Sox, 84 and 53.

title: New Move in Welfare Reform
description: The Nixon Administration has added some imagina tive new features to its plan for reforming the nation's chaotic welfare system. The revisions, put forward to meet objections raised by the Senate Finance Commit tee, are an extension of the constructive teamwork between the White House and Capitol Hill that has been one of the most welcome aspects of this effort to make over welfare.

title: WILLIAM TURNER
description: William Turner, the head of two construction concerns here that specialized in government buildings, died at Mount Sinai Hospital Thursday of a heart attack, He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BIG BOARD SPURS ACCORD ON RATES
description: The New York Stock Ex change has been quietly calling leaders of the brokerage com munity to special meetings at the exchange in an effort to achieve membership harmony on a new commissionrate structure to be presented to the Securities and Exchange Com mission.

title: Allies Fight to Recapture City South of Pnompenh
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 14Cambodian and South Vietnamese troops fought un der cover of artillery barrages and fighterbomber attacks to day to regain control of the Cambodian city of Kompong Speu and keep open a vital link to the sea.

title: F. C. C. MAN BITTER AS TERM IS ENDING
description: WASHINGTON, June 14  Kenneth A. Cox, widely re garded as the ablest lawyer and most determined regulator on the Federal Communications Commission, approaches the end of his sevenyear term with an uncertain sense of ac complishment and a sudden bitterness about his rumored successor.

title: A Correction
description: A court fight between the B. F. Goodrich Company and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company over N.V. Rubber Fabriek Vredenstein, a Dutch rubber company, is due to be decided in the Netherlands on June 26. Goodrich contends it has about 53 per cent, or con trol, of the company. Good year, backed by Vredenstein, is believed to have 46 per cent. Due to a typographical error in Saturday's editions, the hold ings of the companies appeared incorrectly.

title: FUNDS IN EUROPE FACE TOUGH DAYS
description: GENEVA, June 14  Tough days are ahead for the mutual fund industry in Europe as it faces both stricter national regulation and a declining sales trend.

title: DualPupose Funds
Abrams Ask Investigation Of Entire Subway System
description: Bronx Borough President Rob ert Abrams has urged a Queens grand jury to expand its inves tigation into the May 20 sub way collision to include the en tire subway system.

title: Nixon Action in Behalf of Youth Spurred by Results of a Survey
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 14With the current school year drawn to a close, the Nixon Administration has shown great concern in recent days about what may occur during the next one.

title: George Birnbaum, Harvard '70, Weds Miss Janet Lathrop Stott
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14Miss Janet Lathrop Stott and George Philip Birnbaum, who were graduated at the first joint HarvardRadcliffe commencement exercises on Thursday, were married here this afternoon at the Har vard Memorial Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Wells Grogan of the First Congregational Church of Cambridge.

title: Holt Sparks 2 Rallies
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 14 (AP)Jim Holt tripled to spark a fourrun fourth inning and capped another fourrun flurry in the eighth with homer today as the Minnesota Twins scored a 102 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: GREAT DANE IS GIVEN JERSEY SHOW AWARD
description: FORT DIX, N. J., June 14 Kolyer's Kowtow Kim v Hedge Row, a 3yearold Great Dane owned by Mr. and Mrs. Edward Houston of Mata wan, N. J., topped a field of 1,597 contenders today in gain ing the bestinshow award at the 23d annual Burlington County Kennel Club show.

title: 35,000 March in Tokyo To Protest U.S. Treaty
description: TOKYO, June 14 (AP)  Thirtyfive thousand persons turned out for a snakedance demonstration in Tokyo to day to protest the Japanese Government's decision to con tinue its security treaty with the United States.

title: Argentine Junta's Choice
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 14 Until Saturday, when he was named President of Ar gentina, Brig. Gen. Roberto Marcelo Levingston was near ly as unknown to most mem bers of the armed forces as he was to the public.

title: New Detour to Throgs Neck Bridge
description: The city Traffic Depart ment is asking motorists to be on the lookout this morn ing for new directional signs guiding them from the Bruckner Circle in the Bronx to the Throgs Neck Bridge.

title: The Smell of the Beer Hall
description: BIRMINGHAM, England Enoch Powell was talking about the exploitation of what is called race when a frail young woman in the back of the hall cried out, By whom? Half a dozen stewards pushed through the seats and roughly grabbed her. A welldressed man stood up to try to protect her; without a word the stew ards manhandled him and dragged him out the door. The crowd cheered.

title: California Democrats Hope to Tie Reagan to Murphy and Nixon
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 14 California Democrats hope to beat Gov. Ronald Reagan this fall by forcing him to defend Senator George Murphy and the Nixon Administration and by arguing that he failed to produce on his 1966 campaign promises.

title: 2 IN ALBANY RACE EXCHANGE INSULTS
description: ROCHESTER, June 14 Arthur J. Goldberg and How ard J. Samuels met In their first twoman television debate here tonight. Within an hour the candidates for the Gover nor were angry enough to keep arguing even after the cameras were turned off.

title: News Summary and Index
description: MONDAY, JUNE 15, 1970

title: FREDERIC A. FENCER
description: Frederic Abilgaard Fenger, a marine designer and author, died Friday in Norwell, Mass. He was 88 years old.

title: Campaign Equality . . .
description: Once again a committee of distinguished citizens has looked into the financing of political campaigns in this country and found the picture deplorable. A task force of the Twentieth Century Fund, concen trating wholly on Congressional campaigning, differs little from other recent investigating bodies, though its personnel represents a wider political spectrum than is usually the caseRepublican and Democrat, black and white, business and labor, experience and youth.

title: Priorities in the Soviet
description: MOSCOW, June 14Today's uncontested elections to the Supreme Soviet, the constitu tional legislature, disclose little about the attitude of Soviet voters toward their Govern ment.

title: Status of Major Legislation in the House and Senate
KARL K. BECHTOLD
description: KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., June 14Karl K. Bechtold, a lawyer and former New York State Senator from Rochester, died at his home here Saturday. He was 59 years old.

title: London: A Prolonged Cultural Siesta
description: LONDON  In the second week of our heat wave, with the intrusive sun buttering London like a toasted muffin, the British are in a mood of euphoric Philistine exhaus tion, enjoying a prolonged Mediterranean siesta. The aters and movie houses are empty. Even reading seems

title: BOXER IS JUDGED BEST AT CONCORD
description: CONCORD, Mass., June 14 Salgray's Double Talk, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Hamilburg's brindle boxer, was named best in show today at the 56th annual Mid dlesex County Kennel Club event.

title: Foster Completes Sparring
description: Mac Foster completed spar ring sessions yesterday in preparation for Wednesday night's heavyweight bout against Jerry Quarry at Medi son Square Garden by working five rounds.

title: POLLUTION LINKED TO ILLS OF YOUNG
description: A team of researchers has found a close association be tween continuing exposure to air pollution and asthma and eczema in children under 15 particularly in boys under 5 years of age.

title: Royer's 273 Wins Western Open by One Stroke
description: CHICAGO, June 14 (AP) Hugh Royer, a perennial also ran who had never come close to winning a professional golf tournament, overtook Bobby Nichols today and won the Western open by a stroke with a 273 total.

title: Black Atlanta Venture Backfires on Liberals
description: ATLANTA, June 14A ven ture in black capitalism by two civil rights leaders who started out with a large inventory of idealism but a short supply of business experience has ended in rancor, distrust and a grow ing concern about the antiwhite feeling that has emerged among Southern blacks.

title: Canadian Prairie, in Economic Slump, Grows Resentful of East
description: CALGARY, AlbertaA grow ing feeling of alienation from Ottawa and the whole eastern Establishment, coupled with economic uncertainty, have brought discontent to the Canadian prairies.

title: Wilkins Voted to Wheelchair Shrine
description: Since Alonzo Wilkins be gan competing in the Na tional Wheelchair Games from the beginning, it was only fitting that he should be the first of five persons in ducted into the newly formed Wheelchair Sports Hall of Fame last night and also named handicapped athlete of the year.

title: For Michael Crichton, Medicine Is for Writing
description: Michael Crichton spent four years at Harvard Medi cal School, and what does he have to show for it? Seven novels, a movie, several more manuscripts and screenplays and a fastpaced, provocative book of nonfiction on the state of the American hospi tal, which was published last week.

title: Marine Gets 21 Days For Letting Hair Grow
description: SAN DIEGO, June 14 (UPI) Pfc. James Wallace, 23 years old, a Marine Corps Reservist and student at San Diego State College, was convicted at a courtmartial today of refusal to comply with regulations that Marines must wear their hair no more than three inches long.

title: Violence by Radicals Disrupting Turkey's Universities
description: ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 5 Tiny, tightly organized bands of radical rightwing and leftwing students, warring as much with each other as with the Government, are reducing higher education in Turkey to a shambles and raising the risk of new military intervention, in politics.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: STUDENTS DECLINE WESLEYAN OFFERS
description: Wesleyan University, Middle town, Conn., alone among the prestigious New England col leges and universities, has re ported that it was unable to fill its incoming freshman class with students whom it wanted the most.

title: Prank Proves Fatal
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 14 (AP)An 11 yearold girl, Me lisra Gay Spencer, was killed yesterday when she rode her bicycle into a steel wire that had been strung across a side walk. Police Detective Orin J. Peck described the incident as a foolish prank by teen agers hot said no charges would be filed because no ?? was committed.

title: LITTLE LEAGUERS ARE BIG IN TAIWAN
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 14  On a tworun homer by 12yearold Yang Fuhsing in the last in ning, the Seven Tigers recently won the right to represent Tai wan in its first defense of a world athletic championship.

title: Brazil Releases 40 Prisoners To Ransom Bonn Ambassador
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 15 Brazil's military Government freed 40 political prisoners to day, meeting in full the ransom demanded by terrorists for the release of the kidnapped West German Ambassador.

title: Eban, in Rome, Meets Moro
description: ROME, June 15  Foreign Minister Abba Eban of Israel arrived today for a threeday official visit and started con sultations with Foreign Minis ter Aldo Moro, who conferred with President Gamal Abdel Nasser in Cairo on May 23.

title: McCarver's Cast Removed From Broken Right Hand
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15 (AP)  Tim McCarver, one of two catchers for the Philadel phia Phillies injured May 2 against the San Francisco Giants, had the cast removed from his broken right hand to day.

title: A.J.C. Hails Ruling
description: The American Jewish Con gress hailed yesterday the Fed eral Court ruling in Providence as a landmark decision. The A.J.C. and the American Civil Liberties Union sponsored the test case.

title: In The Nation: The Ambiguity of O. M. B.
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 George Shultz is as able a man as this Administration boasts, and President Nixon has reached for control of the bureaucracy by putting him in charge of the new Office of Management and Budget. All the management consultants and former White House staffers seem to approve the plan as well as the man, so ordinary mortals will dissent at their peril.

title: Youth, 15, Fatally Stabbed at Queens School
description: A 15yearold youth was fa tally stabbed yesterday outside a St. Albans, Queens, junior high school, reportedly by a 13yearold fellow student at the school who was brandishing a hunting knife.

title: Trainer's Teenage Daughter Lends a Helping Hand in Barn Area at Roosevelt Raceway
Nixon Losing Hope for Tax on Leaded Gas
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 The Nixon Administration is losing hope of getting Con gress to impose a tax on lead additives in gasoline. Pro

title: Carnegie Peace Group Names New Chairman
description: The election of Milton Katz as chairman of the board of trustees of the Carnegie En dowment for International Peace was announced yester day. Mr. Katz succeeds Whit ney North Seymour, who had served as chairman since 1958.

title: Transport Strike in Paris Snarls Commuter Traffic
description: PARIS, June 15 (Reuters) Traffic jams built up in and around Paris this morn ing as commuters struggled to reach work with the city's public transportation system almost completely shut down by a 24hour strike.

title: Venerable Boston Latin School Under Attack on BoysOnly Policy
description: BOSTON, June 15The old est public high school in the country, Boston Latin, is un dergoing a challenge to its 335 years of tradition, during which it has never graduated a girl.

title: 4 Grain Exporters Named In Federal Antitrust Suits
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Government filed anti trust suits today charging four grain exporting concerns with making illegal agreements for exclusive stevedoring services at grain elevators in Destrehan, La., and Beaumont, Tex.

title: Eisenstadt Leaving Midwood
description: Murray Eisenstadt, coach of the Midwood High tennis team that won the Public Schools Athletic League title, is leaving the Flatbush school after 29 years and joining the new South Shore High School in Canarsie. His Midwood teams won four city and 15 borough championships.

title: Reputed L.I. Mafia Figure Convicted in Larceny Case
description: MINEOLA, L. L, June 15 (UPI)  Larry (The Fixer) Knohl, a reputed member of the Mafia family of the late Thomas Luchese, was convicted today of grand larceny by a Nassau County jury which de liberated for less than one hour.

title: Detective Who Would Retire Is Ordered to Stand Trial
description: State Supreme Court Justice George Starke refused yester day to bar a police depart mental trial of a detective charged with selling confiden tial information to private agencies.

title: A POLITICAL CRISIS IN ISRAEL AVERTED
description: JERUSALEM, June 15A po litical crisis that had threat ened to drive the National Re ligious party out of the govern ing coalition was apparently averted today when an Ameri canborn woman gave up her legal battle to have her conver sion to the Jewish faith by Reform rabbi declared legal.

title: Little to Fight in Italy
description: MILAN, Italy, June 15 (AP) Freddie Little of New Orleans, the world junior middleweight boxing champion, will defend his crown against Carmelo Bossi of Italy in Monza next month.

title: Brewers Down Orioles, 96, With 6 Runs in 8th
description: BALTIMORE, June 15 (AP) A basesloaded double by Ro berto Pena capped a sixrun Milwaukee rally in the eighth inning tonight as the Brewers downed the slumping Balti more Orioles, 96.

title: Miss Gonnerman Trounces Miss Allen at Eastern Net
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 15Louise Gonnerman of River Edge, N. J., who heads the draw, led the seeded players into the third round of the Eastern women's claycourt ten nis championship today at the Orienta Beach Club.

title: Governor Reports $373,000 In Campaign Costs So Far
description: ALBANY, June 15Governor Rockefeller, without opposition in gaining the Republican nom ination for a fourth term in office, has listed political ex penditures of $373,000 in report to New York's Depart ment of State.

title: AFTRA Members Approve New Network Contracts
description: The American Federation of Television and Radio Artists has announced ratification of new contracts with the three major television and radio net works and the stations they own. The contracts, which still have to be signed, provide for higher salaries, increased pen sions and better working condi tions. They will run through Nov. 15, 1972.

title: U.S STAR FORGES 86, 97 TRIUMPH
description: LONDON, June 15With the Wimbledon tournament only a week away, the American No. 1, Stan Smith, had a tremendous tussle with a parttime player, Bobby Wilson, before squeaking out an 86, 97 victory in the first round of the London grass court championships at the Oueen's Club today.

title: LONDON STOCKS DECLINE IN PRICE
description: Bond and share prices fell sharply on the London stock market yesterday following the announcement of a widening of the British trade deficit dur ing May.

title: Hazeltine Drops 330; Military Cats Are Cited
description: The Hazeltine Corporation of Little Neck, Queens, said yesterday it had terminated the employment of 330 em ployes. A spokesman attrib uted the dismissals to a re duction in military expendi tures. Almost half of those released were engineers.

title: Student Protesters Denouncing Thieu Also Assail the U.S.
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15For the second time in three days, there was a de cidedly antiAmerican flavor to the demonstrations staged to day by students protesting against the Thieu Government.

title: At Halston, New Fashion Team
description: Some of the clothes that stepped quietly, elegantly into Halston's heavily curtained showroom yesterday are the kind you don't see around much any more. They looked sculpted rather thin pasted together and they were the work of Charles James, erstwhile couturier and now fash ion consultantengineer to Halston Frowick. He helped shape the collection, like Balenciaga helped Given chy, Halston explained.

title: Postal Union Here Planning Strike Vote if Substitute Reform Bill is Passed
description: Morris (Moe) Biller, presi dent of the ManhattanBronx Postal Union, sharply criticized a postal reform bill yesterday that he said would eliminate a retroactive pay increase and also legislate his independent union out of existence.

title: MISS PITTS HEADS LACROSSE STARS
description: The United States Women's Lacrosse Association named the best 27 players in the country from a field of more than 200 yesterday.

title: Boulmetis Kin Debuts With a $106.40 Winner
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15 Anthony S. Black, nephew of Sammy Boulmetis, the famed retired jockey, rode a horse in a parimutuel race for the first time today and won with Stand By Me at $106.40 in the second race at Liberty Bell race track.

title: LINDSAY'S BUDGET IS CUT $82MILLION
description: The Board of Estimate and the City Council approved yes terday a record $7.7billion ex pense budget$82 million less than the 197071 austerity budget proposed by the Mayor last month.

title: Miss Haase Fiancee of G. H. Kuper 3d
description: Miss Dorothy C. Haase, a former State Department of ficer now with the Marketing Science Institute of Cam bridge, Mass., plans to be mar ried in September to George Henry Kuper 3d, executive vice president of the Boston Venture Management Com Deny.

title: Building Union for Williams
description: PATERSON, N. J., June 15 (UPI)  The 175,000member New Jersey Building and Con structions Trades Council today endorsed Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., New Jersey Demo crat for reelection in Novem ber.

title: Need to Modify Engines Hinders JumboJet Use
description: A growing number of en gines needing modification has slowed considerably the expan sion of Boeing 747 service, par ticularly on Pan American World Airways, the heaviest 747 user.

title: Screen: 'Strawberry Statement' Rash of Techniques:Horovitz Adapts Diary of Columbia Student Stuart Hagmann Makes Debut as Director
description: In the pound or so of heavily "now," swinging publicity material put out by his studio, Stuart Hagmann, who makes his debut as a feature film director with "The Strawberry Statement," is quoted as saying: "Directing dramatic TV series teaches you important things like sticking to schedules, budgets, deadlines and working with lots of people. . . . But I personally feel experience in making commercials presents more excitement and challenge. You can be more inventive. You have to be more inventive."Hagmann has been so inventive with "The Strawberry Statement," which opened yesterday at the Cinema II, that it only lacks an occasional, superimposed written message ("Strike to Prove Yourself Alive, Folks!") to look like a giant, 103-minute commercial, not for peace, or student activism, or community responsibility, but for the director himself.Do you have a dull, inanimate product you want to sell? Well, here's your man! He'll photograph it sideways, upside down, from the ceiling! He'll zoom in on it with pulsating rhythms so that the folks out in televisionland will feel as if they've made love to it! Are some of them blind? Then give them sound! Buffy Sainte-Marie! Crosby, Stills, Nash and Young! Butfor heaven's sakedon't give them time to think!This sort of speed treatment is great for boxes of detergents, and even for "Mannix" and "Mission: Impossible." Too much artificial stimulation, however, can be fatal to movies about recognizable human beings.The film is playwright Israel Horovitz's adaptation of "The Strawberry Statement: Notes of a College Revolutionary," the diary kept by James Simon Kunen, a 20-year-old Columbia student, before, during and after the 1968 insurrections on Morningside Heights. Like the book, the movie is the record-of-radicalization of a young man committed to crew instead of causes, a sweet-tempered fellow who joins the administration building sit-in more in pursuit of lust (it's where the girls are) than out of higher loyalties.Simon (Bruce Davison) is Holden Caulfied at the barricades, wondering, during the first night of his sit-in, if the Paris commune could possibly have been as dull, and sneaking out every morning to attend crew practice. His education is effected simultaneously by Linda (Kim Darby), a pretty face with an enormously appealing, muddled political spirit, and by a sudden, almost overwhelming realization of all the inequities that surround him.Essentially, however, Simon and Linda are the direct, if radicalized, descendants of the kids in "Girl Crazy," but the big show in "The Strawberry Statement" is a police bust, not a senior class revue en route to Broadway.When you look around, over and through the blur of technique put up by the director, it's possible to see and hear a lot of Horovitz ("The Indian Wants the Bronx," "Rats") and Kunen in the script.Simon is the type of guy who cannot walk by a ringing public telephone without answering it ("Gee, operator," he says politely, "I think you should know, but somebody urinated in this booth"), and he is not above using a conventional bloody nose as evidence of police brutality. There are lots of marvelous minor characters, including a "hard-hat" student (Murray MacLeod), who first calls the demonstrators "pinko spades and Mafia acid heads," and then happily joins them; and an efficient, intensely humorless student organizer (Bob Balaban) who is very comic.There is a frightening, completely meaningless encounter with violence in the park when Simon and Linda meet a gang of toughs who, with great efficiency, destroy Simon's movie camerawhich puts a bit of a strain on his newly acquired social consciousness. And there is Simon's fine, odd monologue about a parrot who could only say "Kiss off!" and who belonged to an uncle who committed suicide.These are importations from the dark, absurd world of Horovitz, a world where effects have little relation to causes, and a world that has little to do with the romantic one pictured by Hagmann.Somewhat like Simon, "The Strawberry Statement" finally stumbles into significance in a brutal encounter between the National Guard and the students that is not supported by anything in the movie, only by recent, real-life events. This is both the most moving, and the most tasteless, scene in the film.The students, gathered in the gym to await the big bust, sit cross-legged in circles, chanting the Beatles' "Let It Be." Suddenly the camera peers down from the ceiling, showing usnot people with ideas and attitudesjust a Busby Berkeley flower arrangement.

title: DEFICIT REPORTED BY GENERAL HOST
Dr.Robert M.MacIver, 88, Dies; Sociologist Headed New School
description: Dr. Robert M. Maclver, soci ologist, author and educator, former president and chancel lor of the New School for Social Research, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Palisades, N. Y.

title: 500 at Battery Honor Flag
description: About 500 people participated in a Battery Park ceremony yes terday observing the 193d an niversary of the adoption of the Stars and Stripes as the American flag. The spectators loudly applauded Thomas W. Gleason, president of the Inter national Longshoremen's Asso ciation, when he reiterated the continuing support of long shoremen for President Nixon's efforts to end the Vietnam war with honor. There were sev eral muted boos when it was announced that Mayor Lindsay had sent a telegram stating that he could not attend.

title: Hugh Joseph Addonizio
description: NEWARK, June 15When Hugh Joseph Addonizio was a boy in Newark, life pro ceeded at the measured, re assuring pace of the horse drawn wagons that still plied the streets. Growing up meant meeting challenges and seizing opportunities as they appeared. Success was a story of dili gence and hard work. I was born in the heart of the Central Ward, Mr. Ad donizio told a visitor at his campaign headquarters here the other day. In a sense, all of us come from the ghetto. Some make it and some don't.

title: Judith Webb Plans Aug. 29 Bridal
description: GREENVILLE, N. C., June 15Miss Judith Rae Webb, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Fred Webb Jr., plans to be married on Aug. 29 to Jean Edmond Lanier, French graduate student at Cornell she met aboard the liner France three years ago.

title: Finch Names Aide to Allen Acting U.S. Education Chief
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)Robert H. Finch, Secre tary of Health, Education and Welfare, named Dr. Terrel H. Bell today as Acting United States Commissioner of Educa tion to replace Dr. James E. Allen Jr., who was dismissed from the post last week.

title: Paris TV Newsman Quits Over Government Curb
description: PARIS, June 15The French Government has resumed its in tervention in the preparation of news broadcasts, it was dis closed today following the res ignation of a leading television journalist.

title: Jury Selection in Manson Case to Begin Today
description: LOS ANGELES, June 15 The selection of a jury in the trial of Charles M. Manson and three women accused of killing seven persons last year will start tomorrow here in the Hall of Justice.

title: Police Here Criticized on Recruiting and Promotion
description: The recruitment and promo tion procedures of the New York Police Department were criticized yesterday by a New York police sergeant who has successfully recruited Ivy League college graduates for the Washington, D. C., police force.

title: AntiwarBloc Educators Endorse 18 Candidates for Congress
description: A national antiwar coalition of college educators announced yesterday the endorsement of 18 candidates for Congress and the initial contribution of $50, 000 to their primary campaigns.

title: Munich Synagogue Entered by Vandals; Scrolls Desecrated
description: MUNICH, West Germany, June 15  Vandals desecrated Torah scrolls and other reli gious objects in a synagogue here last night in the rear of a Jewish old people's home that was burned down by arsonists in February.

title: WARPOWERS BILL IS FILED BY JAVITS
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 Senator Jacob K. Javits today broadened and perhaps ex tended the Senate's constitu tional debate by proposing that Congress limit by law the war making powers of the Presi dency.

title: ARGENTINE LEADER MEETS WITH JUNTA
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 15 (UPI)The armed forces com manders met today with Brig. Gen. Roberto Marcelo Leving ston, the man they chose to be Argentina's next President, to form a Cabinet and lay down down the ground rules for the new Government.

title: A Summary of Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: The Era of the Crocodile Handbag Ends at Mark Cross
description: When Mark Cross opened its doors at 9:30 A.M. yester day, a flock of welldressed women swooped into the Fifth Avenue store and head ed straight for the crocodile handbags. They knew what they were doing. The bags, originally priced from $230 to $1,200, were marked down by 30 to 50 per centa result of the store's deci sion to discon tinue the sale of all crocodile items. Crocodiles are in trouble, said George Wasser berger, the store's president, and we're going to stop sell ing the products in all seven of our stores.

title: Sabina C. Beekman Is Betrothed
description: The Rev. Gerardus Beek man, retired rector of St. Paul's American Church in Rome (Episcopal), and Mrs. Beekman of Cap d'Antibes, France, have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sabina Catherine Beekman, to Malcolm Steven son Forbes Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Forbes of Far Hills, N. J. The wedding is planned for next year.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS DRAFT EXEMPTION FOR ETHICAL VIEW
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  The Supreme Court ruled today that men who object to mili tary service for purely moral and ethical reasons are entitled to draft exemptions as con scientious objectors.

title: Col. Charles S. Lawrence, Survived Bataan March
description: ARLINGTON, Va., June 15 (AP)  Col. Charles S. Law rence, U.S.A. retired, a sur vivor of the Bataan death march, died at his home in Romney, W. Va., Friday. He was 78 years old.

title: A. B. TABACHNIK, 68, WRITER AND CRITIC
description: Abraham Ber Tabachnik, a writer, literary critic and editor for the Jewish Telegraphic Agency, a wire service for the Yiddish, Hebrew and Anglo Jewish press, died Saturday at Bellevue Hospital after suffer ing a stroke. He was 68 years old and lived at 266 East Broadway.

title: Killing Ground Ends Run
description: William Hanley's play, Slow Dance on the Killing Ground, starring George Voskovec, Billy Dee Williams and Madeline Miller, closed its Off Broad way engagement at the Sheri dan Square Playhouse Sunday after 36 performances.

title: Murro Out of N.C.A.A. Meet
description: TEMPE, Ariz., June 15 (UPI) Mark Murro of Arizona State, the American recordhold er in the javelin throw, will miss this week's National Col legiate Athletic Association meet at Des Moines, Iowa, with an injured ankle. Murro was injured June 6 in the Compton invitation meet in Los Angeles when he stepped in a hole on one of his throws. The ankle was still swollen today.

title: Invalidation of '70 Ballot Law Is Upheld
description: ALBANY, June 15  The Court of Appeals upheld today the invalidation by a lower, court of legislation that auto matically allocated to incum bent the top line on ballots in the primary election next Tues day in New York City.

title: Remsens Win Golf Event
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 15Richard Remsen Jr. and M. Jay Remsen, 12 years old, won the 51st annual Father and Son Golf Association tour nament with a net round of 851669 at the Garden City Golf Club today.

title: Edward Petry, 73, Founded Broadcast Sales Agency
description: NEPTUNE, N. J., June 15 Edward Petry, founder and for mer president of Edward Petry & Co., Inc., a New Yorkbased radio and television station rep resentative, died in a hospital here Friday. He was 73 years old and lived in Spring Lake.

title: OceanMining Unit Planned
description: HOUSTON, June 15 (UPI) Tenneco, Inc., announced today it intended to organize an oceanmining consortium with letallgesellschaft, A.G., of West Germany. Plans, based on the successful completion of their current test programs, call for a fullscale mining ship and a processing plant by 1975.

title: Bravo, New Program, To Bow at Concerts
description: When the next concert sea son bows so will the new Bravo, the national program for concertgoers.

title: SPENDING SCORED DURING TV DEBATE
description: Paul O'Dwyer and Theodore C. Sorensen, in a television de bate that steamed with acri mony, yesterday accused Richard L. Ottinger, one of their opponents in the race for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator, of try ing to buy the election.

title: Cougars Sign Williford
description: RALEIGH, N. C., June 15 (UPI)Vann Williford, top scorer in North Carolina State University's basketball history, was signed today to a contract by the Carolina Cougars of the American Basketball Associa tion. The 6foot6inch, 202 pound Williford scored 1,543 points in his three seasons, al ternating at center and forward for the Wolfpack.

title: Nations Separated By a Capital Gap
description: The capital gap between de veloped and underdeveloped nations remains vast and is in danger of widening in the new decade. This is the conclusion drawn by business leaders in 51 countries who were sur veyed by the National Indus trial Conference Board.

title: Cooper Shuns Governorship
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) Senator John Sherman Coop er, Republican of Kentucky said today that he had decided against running for Governor in his home state despite encour agement from many Kentucky Republicans. Mr. Cooper said at a news conference that he was sticking to his plan to re tire from politics at the end of his current termJan. 3, 1973.

title: PROSECUTORS OPEN NATIONAL COLLEGE
description: HOUSTON, June 15  About 90 prosecutors, most of them young assistant district attor neys in state courts, began classes today in the newly or ganized National College of Dis trict Attorneys at the Univer sity of Houston.

title: Article 3  No Title
FR STILL HOLDS CAMBODIAN CITY DESPITE ATTACKS
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 15A task force of South Vietnamese and Cambodians failed in three attacks today to drive enemy troops out of Kompong Speu and to break blockade of vital supplies from Cambodia's sole deep  water port.

title: Redundant Commission . . .
description: More than a year ago. President Calvin H. Plimpton of Amherst College warned President Nixon that, while there is no magic formula for campus peace, there is no hope for a moderate consensus so long as many students feel that the nation has no adequate plans for meeting the crises of our society.

title: High Court Backs Subpoena by S.E.C.
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI)The Supreme Court let stand today a decision authorizing the Securities and Exchange Commission to subpoena records of The Wall Street Transcript.

title: Paul A. Garrison, 42, Dies; Chairman of Valve Concern
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15 Paul A. Garrison, chairman of the board of the Walworth Company, an industrial valve manufacturer, died after a heart attack yesterday at Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived in Wayne.

title: . . . but a Needed Inquiry
description: The investigations ordered in the wake of the fatal shootings at Kent State University and Jackson State College had an unmistakably simple missionto deter mine what improper actions or command procedures led to the lethal use of firearms.

title: WHITE HOUSE DENIES INQUIRY ON PETITION
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The White House said today that no investigation was under way and no dossier being com piled on some 250 State De partment employes who signed a petition opposing Nixon Ad ministration policies in Cam bodia.

title: A.B.A. Head Scores Reserve Member
description: In an unusual personal crit icism of a member of the Fed eral Reserve Board, Nat S. Rogers, president of the Amer ican Bankers Association, took issue yesterday with J. L. Rob ertson, vice chairman of the Board, over a speech that Mr. Robertson made scoring the nation's major banks last month.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 16, 1970

title: ARAB GROUPS CLASH WITH JEWS IN PARIS
description: PARIS, Tuesday, June 16 (Reuters)Riot police today patrolled the Belleville area in northern Paris after street fighting between groups of Arabs and Jews. Dozens of shops were wrecked and at least five persons were injured.

title: THREE COURTS ACT IN PANTHER CASES
description: Associate Justice John M. Harlan of the United States Supreme Court refused to inter vene in the Connecticut pros ecution of eight Black Panthers charged with murder and kid napping yesterday, the eve of a trial for one of the defend ants.

title: Thais Begin Answering the Army's Call for Volunteers to Fight in Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 15Pratong Yoojun carried a small leather toilet kit under his arm today when he?? to the military head?? here to sign up for volunteer service in Cambodia.

title: British Trade Deficit Rose to $74Million in May
description: LONDON, June 15The Brit ish Government reported a $74 million deficit today in inter national trade for May  a surprisingly large excess of purchases from foreigners over sales to them. The May deficit rose $50million over April's.

title: TeenAger Conservation Corps For Summers Voted by House
description: WASHINGTON, June 15A new Federal program combin ing conservation and construc tive summer activity for teen agers was approved today by the House.

title: Vietnam Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) The Defense Department to day listed the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in Indochina:

title: Advertising: Woodstock Sees a Pot o' Gold
description: It just may be that the young entrepreneurs who created last year's Woodstock Music and Art Fair might find their way out of the fi nancial hole they went into while making history.

title: ADDONIZIO JURY HEARS EXECUTIVE
description: TRENTON, June 15An en gineering company executive testified here today in the ex tortion trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark and six other defendants that one of the accused men had taken him to the Mayor's office in 1964, introduced him to Mr. Addoni zio, then taken him into the corridor and demanded a 5 per cent kickback on the firm's fee on a city sewer project.

title: CASPER WILL PLAY IN OPEN TOURNEY
description: CHASKA, Minn., June 15 (UPI)The Hazeltine National Golf Club, site of the 1970 United States Open starting Thursday, reopened for play today and most of the qualifiers here set out on practice rounds.

title: Observer: Wanted, Lost, Help, Bargain
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The classified ads:

title: Jubilation Sweeps Rome Over Soccer Cup Victory
description: ROME, June 15At 2 A.M. today, young couples were still dancing in the Piazza Navona and packs of cars, their horns continually honking, were racing down the narrow Corso in a spon taneous outbreak of joy such as this city has not wit nessed for many years.

title: Banco Popular Is Taken Over By Peru's Military Government
description: LIMA, June 15The revolutionary military government became the second largest commercial banker here today by taking over Banco Popular del Peru. In doing so, the state also acquired control over many industries owing money to the bank.

title: RUMANIA IS UPSET IN DAVIS CUP, 32
description: MARIBOR, Yugoslavia, June 15 (Reuters)  Yugoslavia up set Rumania, 32, today in the Davis Cup tennis competition and qualified for the European Zone Section A final against Spain.

title: In Memoriam
description: CHALFINMirlam. In loving memory of Miriam Chalfin who passed away on June 16, 1969. Husband and children.

title: FINAL POSITIONS ARE NOT VERIFIED
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 15 The United States team of Carina, Equation and Bay Bea, was impressively ahead in the international sailing for the Onion Patch Trophy today fol lowing the first event of four, against Argentina, Bermuda and England. But whether the sweep of the first three places in the 175mile race from Oys ter Bay, L.I., would be main tained remained for the appearance of measurement certificates that had not yet reached the Ida Lewis Yacht Club's race committee.

title: COURT APPROVES MARITIME SUITS
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) The Supreme Court over turined as a no longer accept able law today a maritime rul ing that it made in 1886. The Court ruled unanimously that general maritime law allows lawsuits for death caused by violation of maritime duties.

title: Roundup: ExParatrooper On Cloud 9 With Indians
description: Jack Heidemann doesn't remember the name of his new Army Reserve unit and he doesn't know why he's suddenly hitting. He's just happy to be out of the para troopers and over .200.

title: Article 1  No Title
Tiger Free for an Hour
description: TOPEKA, Kan., June 15 (AP) A zooborn Bengal tiger, de scribed by the zoo director as just as afraid of people as they are of him, had an hour of freedom today before he was subdued by a tranquilizer dart and returned to his cage at Gage Park Zoo. The 450pound male tiger slipped out of his cage after an attendant failed to hook a gate.

title: Powell, in Race, Has Faith in Himself
description: Four Harlem Democrats are scrambling for primary votes in what they say is Adam Clayton Powell's most vulnerable year since he entered the House of Representatives in 1944. But Mr. Powell is conducting his noncampaign with his custom ary nonchalance.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: World Cup Soccer
description: GROUP I

title: George F. Foley, Founded Dog Show Organization
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15 George F. Foley, founder and chairman of Foley Dog Show Organization, Inc., a concern that manages dog shows throughout the country, died at his home here yesterday.

title: Guerrillas in Jordan Plan Increased Raids on Israel
