description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 15 The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that its commandos would step up their operations against Israel now that they had strength ened their position in Jordan.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Cerro Corporation has announced that C. Gor don Murphy has become the copper company's new president and chief executive officer. Mr. Murphy succeeds Robert P. Koenig, who held the offices for 20 years. The company said in a statement that Mr. Koenig has assumed the post of chairman, suc ceeding Charles B. Harding. The company said Mr. Harding has been named honorary chairman.

title: U.S. Doctor, Arab Hostage, Is Due to Be Freed Today
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 15 (Reuters)A spokesman for the Palestine Red Crescent organi zation here said tonight that Dr. Paul Shraum, one of the Americans seized as a hostage by Palestinian commandos last week, would be released to morrow.

title: MUSIC MARATHON COVERS 28 HOURS
description: PITTSBURGH, June 15Last midnight Alice Mae Victor, a New Orleans gospel singer, concluded a performance at Point State Park, winding up a continuous 28hour program billed as an Environmental Circus.

title: Kenneth Allen Gibson
description: NEWARK, June 15If Ken neth Allen Gibson is elected Mayor of Newark tomorrow, he will be the third black man in recent times to win that of fice in a large American city. His victory, if it comes, would not surprise him at all.

title: 17 Arrested at Pentagon During a Mass for Peace
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  Seventeen antiwar protesters were arrested today as they tried to celebrate a mass for peace inside the Pentagon.

title: Growth Study Head Named
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 15 Dr. Charles F. Westoff, chair man of the department of So ciology at Princeton University, has been appointed executive director of the National Com mission on Population Growth and the American Future, it was announced today In Washington at the first meeting of the com mission. The commission formed by legislation signed by President Nixon on March 16 is to report to the President and Congress in two years.

title: TACTICS ALTERED IN GOVERNOR RACE
description: ALBANY, June 15Arthur J. Goldberg, employing what some staff members describe as our new strategy, said today his opponent for the Democratic nomination for Governor, is running a campaign that lacks a basic sense of justice.

title: Cambodia Accuses Reds Of Mining Angkor Wat
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 15 (UPI) Cambodian military spokesmen said to day that the North Vietnam ese had set up a command post at the Temple of Lolei outside the Angkor complex of renowned temple ruins. The Vietnamese Communists were reported to have seized control of the area a few days ago.

title: TRADERS CAUTIOUS AS STOCKS ARE UP
description: The stock market inched ahead in extremely slow trad ing yesterday as caution con tinued to be the byword among investors, both big and small.

title: Views of Sport
description: The two basic philosophies of the sports fan's attitude have been termed life and death and fun and games. The former takes with intense seriousness all the events of the sports cosmos: the results of games, the statements made, the statis tics compiled, the business activities. The latter considers it all, first of all, enter tainment, something to be laughed at when possible and enjoyed lightheartedly precisely because it does not involve the lifeanddeath elements that we face in the rest of existence.

title: School Board Held By Brooklyn Group To Be Hiding Data
description: The Brooklyn Education Task Force, a group of private citi zens, issued a report yesterday charging high officials of the Board of Education with con spiring to conceal financial data and other information from the public.

title: Ormandy Postpones Surgery
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 15 Eugene Ormandy, music di rector of the Philadelphia Or chestra, had decided to post pone an operation on his hip, a spokesman for the orchestra said tonight. The operation, a major one, was previously scheduled to take place this week.

title: Maravich in Hawks' Camp
description: ATLANTA, June 15 (UPI) Pete Maravich, the former Lou isiana State basketball star who signed a $2million contract after leading the nation's col legiate scorers for three straight years, reported today along with 16 other rookies and free agents for the opening of the Atlanta Hawks' rookie summer camp. Maravich wound up with a career total of 3,667 points and an average of 44.2 points a game.

title: Bank Loans to Business Show Interest Rate Drop
description: The average interest rate charged by large New York City banks on shortterm busi ness loans fell to 8.24 per cent in the first 15 days of May from 8.65 per cent in the first half of February, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York's quarterly tabula tion.

title: BURGER CRITICIZES OBSCENITY RULING
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Supreme Court reversed today an Ohio news dealer's obscenity conviction over a strong protest by Chief Justice Warren E. Burger. Justice Bur ger complained that the Court had taken on a role not given it by the Constitution.

title: Hijacker Ordered to Get Sanity Test
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)  Standing mute and fidgeting slightly, Anther G. Barkley heard a Federal judge today order him sent to a mental hospital to determine whether he was sane the day he hijacked an airliner and demanded $100million in ransom.

title: Zoning Rule Eased For Office Tower Without Setbacks
description: The City Planning Commis sion approved a special zoning permit yesterday, clearing the way for a 44story squaretow er office building fronting on the east side of the Avenue of the Americas between 45th and 46th Streets.

title: ELECTRIC UTILITIES SEE 18.2% RESERVE
description: The nation's electrio utilities expect to have a reserve mar gin of 18.2 per cent over the peak demand expected this summer, according to the 47th semiannual electric power sur vey by the Edison Electric In stitute. This compares with a 16.6per cent margin over the summer peak established in 1969. The survey projected next summer's margin at 19.5 per cent. This will rise to 21.7 per cent in 1972 and more than 22 per cent for the years 1973 through 1975.

title: NEWARK INSURER TERMED INSOLVENT
description: Arthur D. Lerner, president of the Concord Insurance Com pany of Newark, which was de clared insolvent last week, said yesterday that active negotia tions were under way to ob tain new capital or to sell the company. Concord sells mostly auto coverage to substandard risks in New Jersey.

title: Bailar Defeats Baitman by Two Lengths on Belmont Turf
description: A return match between Stephen Clark's Bailar and Marion Frankel's Baitman took place in the feature event at Belmont Park yesterday, with the former gaming the victory. Although the race, a turf event of seveneighths of a mile, had 10 starters, the expectation among the 27,852 fans was that this pair would provide the Principal contention.

title: Pacific Gas Sets a Price Of $21.25 on Rights Issue
description: The Pacific Gas and Electric Company set yesterday a sub scription price of $21.25 on a rights offering designed to raise $49.93million through the sale of 2,349,467 common shares. Holders of record today may subscribe for the shares on the ration of one new share for each 25 held. The subscription period begins June 22 and ends July 7.

title: FAVORITES SCORE IN N.C.A.A. TENNIS
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 15 (UPI)Topseeded Haroon Ra him, a quick Pakistani with blinding serve, advanced to the third round today at the start of the National Collegiate ten nis championships.

title: AUTO SALES TREND IS SEEN IMPROVING
description: The trend of automobile sales, while still lagging behind the pace set in 1969, has shown a distinct improvement in recent weeks, data compiled yester day showed. Sales of automo biles in the first 10 days of June, for example, were at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 8.58 million units, according to seasonal adjustment factors developed by the National In dustrial Conference Board.

title: 1969 Plane Crash Is Laid to Strain on Controller
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) Faulty directions from a traf fic controller, working under conditions of stress, caused a Puerto Rico airliner crash last year in which all 19 occupants were killed, the National Trans portation Safety Board said to day.

title: 4 Foreign Oil Companies Are Nationalized by Algeria
description: ALGIERS, June 15 (Reuters) The Algerian Government an nounced tonight the national ization of four foreign oil pro ducing companiesthe Roya Dutch Shell Group, the Amer icanowned Phillips Petroleum the West German Elwerath and the Italianowned A.M.I.F

title: BRAZIL REMAINS WORLD CUP CHOICE
description: MEXICO CITY, June 15 (AP) As the trainers of the World Cup soccer semifinalists were ministering to their wounded, Brazil, Italy, Uruguay and West Germany began planning their strategy for the penultimate round contests Wednesday.

title: Fanny May Results Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Mortgage prices declined this week's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Associa tion disclosed today.

title: Proxmire Assails U.S. Aid For Private Corporations
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, criti cized today recent bids to in volve the Federal Government in helping private companies get out of financial difficulty.

title: G.M. Is Sued for $3Million Over a Fatality in Jersey
description: CAMDEN, N. J., June 15 (AP) A $3million suit was filed today against the General Mo tors Corporation, charging that a poorly designed head re straint caused the death of Dr. Benjamin R. Huddell Jr. of Cherry Hill, N. J.

title: Court Dismisses Injunction That Shut Down Kent State
description: KENT, Ohio, June 15 (UPI) A Portage County court dis missed today an injunction that had closed Kent State Univer sity following the shooting deaths of four students by Na tional Guard troops last month.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Contrary to a report pub lished in this column a few days ago, the Shinnecock (L. I.) Swordfish Tournament is not returning to Shinne cock. Or, to put it another way, there will be a sword fish tournament at Shinne cock, but it won't be the same one begun there six years ago.

title: WIDER RECRUITING FOR POLICE URGED
description: Adam Walinsky, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for State Attorney General, called yesterday for a funda mental restructuring of the New York City Police Depart ment through changes in re cruitment procedures, aimed particularly at attracting col legeeducated men to the force.

title: House Acts to Update MuleBaying by Army
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)The Army would no longer have to sell enlisted men 16 ounces of tobacco a month or buy horses and mules on the open market under a bill passed by the House today.

title: Bond Predicts Black Student Confrontations
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 Black students throughout the South are likely to force con frontations this fall over what they see as the fraudulent de segregation of their schools, Julian Bond, young black Georgia legislator, predicted to day.

title: 2 DOCTORS' GROUPS OFFER HEALTH PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The presidents of the nation's two leading medical associa tion's called today for a re placement of Medicaid with a federally subsidized health in surance program.

title: Sciacca Surrenders to Start 130Day Contempt Sentence
description: Paul Sciacca, reputed Mafia chieftain, surrendered yester day to start serving a 30day sentence for contempt of court. The sentence stemmed from his refusal to testify before a grand jury investigating criminal in filtrators into legitimate busi nesses.

title: TRUDEAU DEBATES MILITANT WOMEN
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, June 15Canadian wom en militants debated with Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau last night their view that the Government should repeal the criminal code penalties against abortions.

title: NADER UNIT TO STUDY NATIONAL CITY BANK
description: Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, announced yesterday that a group of students under his sponsorship would conduct a $15,000 scholarly study this summer of the First National City Bank.

title: BOND RATES RISE TO NEW HEIGHTS
description: Interest rates continued their historic climb yesterday, scaling record heights as investment bankers moved to sell an ex traordinarily heavy volume of new corporate bonds.

title: Susan Levine To Be a Bride
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 15Miss Susan Pearl Levine and Ronald Kaplan, doctoral candidates at Harvard Uni versity, will be married here June 28 at the home of the future bride's parents, Mr and Mrs. Jesse Levine. The prospective bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Lawrence Keplan of West Los Angeles.

title: Scanlan Names Publisher
description: Robert Arum, a New York corporation lawyer, has been named publisher of Scanlan's Monthly, it was announced here yesterday by the maga zine's parent firm, Scanlan's Literary House, Inc. Mr. Arum was born in New York. He graduated from Harvard Law School and is a partner in the firm of Phillips, Nizer, Benja min, Krim & Ballon.

title: Wennerstrom of Sweden Wins World Soling Title
description: POOLE, England, June 15 (AP)  Stig Wennerstrom of Sweden won the world Soling championship today, sailing Blott to a 2.3point victory over John Dane of New Orleans, at the tiller of Quest.

title: KILLIAN TO RETIRE AS HEAD OF M.I.T.
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 15  Dr. James R. Killian Jr., chairman of the Corporation of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, announced today he would retire next year after 48 years at the school.

title: Exclusively for MothersinLaw
description: CEDARHURST, L. I.In the family Chamber of Hor rors, mothersinlaw are right up there with Frankenstein and Dracula's Bride, accord ing to a group of women who got together here over the weekend to compare scars and seek guidance for the future.

title: AGNEW TO PURSUE A FEARLESS ROLE
description: DETROIT, June 15  Vice President Agnew said here to night that he would continue to speak out forcefully, factual ly and fearlessly and would not eliminate emotion from his public appeals.

title: ORESTES DIOGUARDI JR.
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 15Orestes A. Dioguardi Jr., a partner in the Greenpoint Casket Company of Brooklyn, died at Brooklyn Hospital yes terday after surgery. He was 52 years old and lived at 34 More wood Place.

title: Phipps Family Helping to Stage A Fair on L.I.
description: OLD WESTBURY, L. I., June 15Members of the Phipps family and their friends are all pitching in to insure that Saturday's fair at the Old Westbury Gardens is a success. In the event of rain, the fair at the former estate of the late John S. Phipps, the financier and sportsman, will be postponed until Sunday.

title: City to Stop Spraying Asbestos; Material Was Linked to Cancer
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday or dered the spraying of asbestos halted in all public construc tion projects.

title: Prouty to Seek Third Term In a Test of Nixon Policies
description: MONTPELIER, Vt., June 15 (AP)Senator Winston L. Prouty, Republican of Vermont, announced for reelection to day, putting himself into a race widely regarded as a test of Nixon Administration's policies.

title: Soyuz 9 Breaks Space Endurance Mark
description: MOSCOW, June 15  The twoman crew of the Soviet Union's Soyuz 9 spacecraft set a world endurance record today as their vehicle continued into its 15th day in orbit around the earth.

title: Mrs. Crimmins Has Bail Reduced
description: Mrs. Alice Crimmins, con victed of manslaughter in the strangling of her 4yearold daughter five years ago, ap peared in Queens Supreme Court yesterday for pretrial hearings of motions made concerning her new trial.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL DECLINES BY 0.8%
description: Steel production fell by 0.8 per cent last week, compared to output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Insti tute reported yesterday.

title: Nock and Wright Among 5 Signing Jets' Contracts
description: The Jets have signed five players, Coach Weeb Ewbank announced yesterday. Agreeing to terms were George Nock, a running back; Gordon Wright, a guard; Harry Theo filides, a quarterback coming up from the taxi squad; Ray Hayes, a tackle, and Richard Trapp, a wide receiver obtained from San Diego in exchange for Randy Beverly. All will report July 14 for the opening of training camp at Hofstra Uni versity, Hempstead, L. I.

title: Eikenberry Is Endorsed
description: Representative Shirley Chis holm endorsed Peter Eikenberry for the House yesterday and accused the incumbent, John J. Rooney, whom Mr. Eikenberry is running against in the Demo cratic primary in the 114th Con gressional District in Brooklyn, of being unresponsive to com munity problems. Mrs. Chis holm, a Brooklyn Democrat rep resenting the 12th C.D., praised Mr. Eikenberry at a news con ference for his record of in volvement in community and civic activities over the years.

title: Trading Resumed in Stock Of Alan Woodit Falls 4
description: Trading was resumed yester day in the shares of the Alan Wood Steel Company on the American Stock Exchange. Trading had been halted last Wednesday for a study of ac tivity in the issue by the exchange and the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE, THEN DIP
description: Profit taking took a big bite out of an early sharp advance in soybean futures prices yes terday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: WILLIAM L. FINKEL, SPEECH PROFESSOR
description: Prof. William L. Finkel, for mer chairman of the speech department of City College, died of a heart attack yester day at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 473 West End Avenue.

title: TWO APPROACHES VIE FOR DANCE LAURELS
description: Words and motion, contrast ed with sound and motion, made up the program presented at the Cubicalo last night.

title: Longshoremen Get U.S. Court Approval On Container Clause
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld a controversial clause in the current New York Ship ping AssociationInternational Longshoremen's Association la bor agreement.

title: Army Stockade Reform li Urged by Civilian Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 15A panel of civilian specialists appointed by the Army has reported that it found a host of inadequacies in the Army's prisons and stockades and recommended closing the Pre sidio stockade in San Fran cisco. recommended closing the Pre sidio stockade in San Fran cisco.

title: Japanese Protests on U.S. Pact Are Relatively Quiet
description: TOKYO, June 15The first of two weekends of protests against the United States Japanese security treaty ended tonight after a number of tense moments but with the level of violence far l: slow that of last year.

title: Miss Englehorn Takes Golf Playoff
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 15 (AP)Shirley Englehorn gained a measure of revenge by win ning the Ladies Professional Golf Association championship by four strokes today in an 18  hole playoff with Kathy Whitworth.

title: Progress on Rail Productivity
description: An agreement signed last week relating to the Illinois Central represents the longest step ever taken voluntarily by rail labor and management to attract increased rail traffic by eliminating featherbed prac tices and welcoming technology. The midwest carrier and the United Transportation Union have set up a joint commission with blanket authority to decide upon experimental work and service policies designed to secure new business for the Illinois Central. and the United Transportation Union have set up a joint commission with blanket authority to decide upon experimental work and service policies designed to secure new business for the Illinois Central.

title: Panel Scores Foreign Ownership In Canadian Securities Firms
description: TORONTO, June 15 (Canadian Press)A yearlong study by the investment industry has concluded that foreign com panies should no longer be allowed to acquire ownership interest in Canadian securi ties firms.

title: Record Manpower Training
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz said today that 454,826 people were enrolled in all Federal manpower programs on May I, setting a record for non summer months. He attributed the increase to growing par ticipation in jobtraining pro grams aimed at welfare re cipients and the hardcore, unemployed.

title: HENRI QUEUILLE, FRENCH PREMIER
description: PARIS, June 15 Henri Queuille, the head of three shortlived French cabinets be tween 1948 and 1951, died, here today at the age of 86.

title: POLL FINDS KENNEDY IS LOSING ESTEEM
description: Since the findings of the Chappaquiddick inquest into the death of Mary Jo Kopechne were made public, opinion na tionwide has grown more criti cal of Senator Edward M. Ken nedy, the Louis Harris survey reported yesterday, according to The Associated Press.

title: REPRISALS PREDICTED IN VIETCONG VICTORY
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) The Pentagon made public to day a study by the Rand Cor poration speculating on the pos sible effects of a Vietcong take over in South Vietnam. The study found that reprisal kill ings could number at least 100,000 and said this figure could easily he higher.

title: I Argentine Publisher Honored
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (UPI) An Argentine publisher, Al berto Gainza Paz, received the golden Pen of Freedom award today from the International Federation of Newspaper Pub lishers and told newsmen there is never a last battle in the fight for freedom. Sr. Gainza, publisher of the Buenos Aires newspaper La Prensa, was exiled from Argentina dur ing the reign of the former dictator, Juan Peron.

title: Books of The Times
description: There must be a hundred plotstarved novelists who Would have sacrificed a thumb to be on the Glienicke Bridge between Potsdam and West Berlin, Satur day morning, Feb. 10, 1962, when 60year old Rudolf Abel and 32yearold Francis Gary Powers were exchanged. Abel, after a decade as an undercover Soviet agent in the United States, had served almost years of a 30year sentence for espionage in an Atlanta prison. Powers, after his U2 spy plane was shot down over Soviet ter ritory by a SAM (surfacetoair missile), had served 21 months of a 10year sentence for espionage in Vladimir prison near Mos cow. We swapped an enigma for an all American boy. a decade as an undercover Soviet agent in the United States, had served almost years of a 30year sentence for espionage in an Atlanta prison. Powers, after his U2 spy plane was shot down over Soviet ter ritory by a SAM (surfacetoair missile), had served 21 months of a 10year sentence for espionage in Vladimir prison near Mos cow. We swapped an enigma for an all American boy.

title: Neighborhoods: Chinatown Is Troubled by New Influx
description: At Bayard and Mulberry Streets, among congested tenements, is Public School 23, one of the few schools left with the outdoor fire es capes of the last century. In side it is immaculate. The school's monthly attendance frequently exceeds 99 per cent, about 10 per cent above the city average. Nearly all the students are of Chinese origin.

title: City Drug Aide Sworn In
description: Jay Swift was sworn in yes terday as first deputy com missioner of the Addiction Services Agency. He had been assistant commissioner for community development in the city agency, which he joined in December. 1967. As first deputy, a $27,300ayear job, Mr. Swift will become the op erating head of the agency after the resignation of Com missioner Larry Alan Bear be comes effective Friday.

title: Israelis Bomb Instal3lations At Canal 16th Day in Row
description: TEL AVIV, June 15 (Reuters)  Israeli aircraft continued their concentrated bombing of Egyptian targets along the Suez Canal today, hitting fortified infantry positions, bunkers and gun emplacements.

title: Elmer E. Proctor, Directed Buying Abroad for Chain
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 15  Elmer E. Proctor, former man aging director of Metasco, Inc. in New York, the foreign buy ing subsidiary of the Allied Stores Corporation, the depart ment store chain, died yester day at his home here, apparently of a heart attack.

title: A.B.C. EASES CURB ON TV FUND PLEAS
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  Under pressure from the Demo cratic party, the American Broadcasting Company appears to have relaxed its rule against television advertising to solicit funds.

title: KILLEBREW SLAMS HOMER WITH 2 ON
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Jan. 15 (UPI)  Harmon Killebrew hit a threerun homer in the seventh inning to give the Min nesota Twins a 53 victory over the Washington Senators to night.

title: Public TV Stations Prepare For Challenges to Networks
description: HYANNIS, Mass., June 15 Public television, without mean ingful advertising resources but with some newfound aggres siveness, will attempt this fall to compete selectively on a programforprogram basis with the commercial television net works in prime time.

title: Laird Says U.S. Troop Cuts In Asia Aid Units in Europe
description: GRAFENWOHR, West Ger many, June 15 (UPI)Secre tary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that United States combat strength in Europe was increasing as it was reduced in Southeast Asia.

title: U.S. Touring Team Wins In Women's Lacrosse, 87
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 15 The 1970 United States tour ing team, which will play in Britain and Ireland, defeated a combined, newly selected Unit ed States first and second team, 87, in today's concluding fea ture of a threeday national tournament sponsored by the United States Women's La crosse Association at Swarth more College.

title: M.T.A. Will Test Rail Cars to Serve Stewart Base
description: The Metropolitan Transporta tion Authority plans this fall to order a small fleet of experi mental commuter rail cars that will make their own electricity with a jet engine.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL AID SOUGHT IN SUFFOLK
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 15 The Suffolk County Charter Revision Commission recom mended today that the county adopt an environmental bill of rights.

title: A RECORD 20,819 SEE WRESTLERS
description: A crowd of 20,819, the larg est wrestling turnout in the old and new Madison Square Gar dens, saw the favorite, Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, succumb to Crusher Verdu of Bilboa, Spain, last night.

title: EXPO'S NEIGHBOR IS TIRED OF IT ALL
description: SENRI, Japan, June 10 Expo '70 has brought the world to the doorsteps of this small city outside the fairground's main gate and, after three months, its residents are be coming a bit worldweary.

title: SAIGON IMPATIENT ON THAI WAR ROLE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15Authoritative South Vietnamese sources expressed impatience today with what they considered to be stalling by Thailand in rallying to the defense of Cambodia.

title: Romney Assures Mayors On Priorities for Cities
description: DENVER, June 15  George Romney tried today to persuade the nation's mayors that the Nixon Administration had com mitted itself to a course of reordering national priorities just as the mayors had been demanding.

title: Negroes in Newark Parade for Gibson; Addonizio Confident
description: NEWARK, June 15Hun dreds of chanting black men, women and children marched arm in arm through the down town section at noon here to day in a peaceful and emotion al outpouring of support for Kenneth A. Gibson, the black candidate in tomorrow's racial ly divisive mayoral election.

title: Securities Industry Offers Plan for Stock Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The securities industry presented to Congress today a plan to insure investors against losses, up to $50,000 apiece, from failures of brokerage firms.

title: Football Signings
description: AMERICAN CONFERENCE

title: NASA and 2 Companies Blamed for Apollo Blast
description: WASHINGTON, June 15An American lunar landing in 1970 became doubtful today after an official investigation blamed the space agency and two aero space companies for errors that led to an oxygen tank explosion that endangered the Apollo 13 crew.

title: 30 UniversityPress Books Are Cited
description: The vanishing art of qual ity book publishing won honors yesterday from com mercial publishers and a book store here as a counterpoint to fast, mass marketing op erations that are becoming ever more prevalent in the industry.

title: Memorial Services
description: HUHNGeorge Albert, April 16, 1970. Me morial service will be held at Calvary, Episcopal Church, Stonington, Conn., Fri day, June 19, 2:30 P.M. In lieu of flow ers contributions may be made to the American Cancer Society or St. Paul's School.

title: U. S. C. TROUNCES DARTMOUTH, 6 TO 1
description: OMAHA, June 15 (AP)Wild pitches and walks helped South ern California scored a 61 vic tory over Dartmouth tonight and eliminate the Indians from the National Collegiate baseball championship, the college world series.

title: Lambert Rites Tomorrow
description: A memorial service for Gary R. Lambert, musician and com poser who died of nephritis on June 4, will be held in the Actor's Temple, 339 West 47th Street, tomorrow at 3:30 P.M. Musicians will play some of his compositions for television, in cluding My Little Girl.

title: REPORT ASKS CUTS IN DEFENSE FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 15  After a fourmonth effort, A group of liberal Congressmen has nearly finished a research paper that recommends a num ber of cuts in the military budget.

title: WaterSkiing Mark Set
description: PERRIES, Calif., June 15 (AP) Sally Younger of Hacienda Heights, Calif., set a women's water skiing record of 105.14 miles an hour yesterday to be come the first woman to exceed 100 m.p.h.

title: 17 Are Wounded in Bolivia As Students Battle Troops
description: LA PAZ, Bolivia, Tuesday, June 16 (Reuters)At least 17 persons, including seven stu dents, were wounded in a seven hour gun battle last night be tween demonstrating students and squads of policemen and troops in the city of Cocha bamba east of here, radio re ports heard in La Paz said.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Politics on the Air

title: Excerpts From Ruling by Supreme Court on Conscientious Objection to War
description: The petitioner, Elliott Ash ton Welsh 2d, was convicted by a United States District Judge of refusing to submit to induction into the armed forces in violation of 50 U.S.C. App. Section 462 (a), and was on June 1, 1966, sentenced to imprisonment for three years.

title: U.S. Tries to Spur Aid to Businesses Run by Minorities
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 15The General Services Ad ministration, which is charged with purchasing equipment for the Government at the lowest possible cost, let 90 contracts this fiscal year, without bid ding, at an average cost of 10 per cent over what competitive awards may have cost.

title: Washington: For the Record
Artists Surface at Underground Show
description: Gilbert Reiter, Vincent Sac coccio, Naomi Washington, Vladimir Babakin, Robert Kline, Marcellus Portilla and other artists of the subter ranean school are represent ed in an exhibition of paint ings that went on display yesterday in Manhattan's newest, if not most fashion able, galleryla Galerie Mo derne d'Art Souterrain.

title: Fifth Ave. Coach Is Counting Ballots
description: The question of who shall manage Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., will not be de cided before today at the earliest. And it may take months or even years before the courts decide which of two slates voted on at yes terday's reconvened annual meeting shall take over the reins of the former bus system.

title: Mayor Requests $5Million From U.S. for Youth Jobs
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday urged Federal action to give New York City an additional $5million for its summer neigh borhood youth program.

title: M'CRACKEN CITES ECONOMIC GAINS
description: PARIS, June 15Against a background of increasing anx iety in Europe over American inflation and the position of the dollar, President Nixon's chief economic adviser offered scattered bits of evidence today of progress on the American Prices front.

title: Theater: Shakespeare in Connecticut
ZAPATA AGREES ON MERGER PLAN
description: The boards of directors of Zapata Norness, Inc., and of Southdown, Inc., approved yes terday a plan to merge Zapata into Southdown in a transaction valued at approximately $70 million.

title: Market Place:
description: A conglomerate? A neo phyte investor might well ask, What's a conglom. erate?

title: Minneapolis Rights Unit Charges Lack of Help by Police Leaves It Impotent
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 12For two and a half years the Min neapolis Human Relations Com mission has been trying to handle complaints of police harassment of the city's black and Indian minorities and to punish those found guilty of it.

title: Old Punchers. Throw Compliments Here
description: Over lunch yesterday in his Broadway restaurant, Jack Dempsey was smoking a cigar and Georges Carpentier was sipping a glass of beer.

title: Bridge:
description: STOCKHOLM, June 15 The Dallas Aces began well here tonight in their attempt to win the world team title for the United States for the first time since 1954.

title: Warnings for Brandt
description: The election results in three West German states clearly constitute a setback to Willy Brandt's effort to improve relations with the Soviet bloc. The Chan cellor himself had sought a vote for Bonn's policy on Germany and Eastern Europe.

title: Danny Kaye to Star in Rodgers Musical
description: Danny Kaye is returning to the Broadway stage in the fall as star of a Richard Rodgers musical, Two by Two, based on Clifford Odets's play, The Flowering Peach.

title: Miss Iowa, 19, First Negro In Miss America Contest
description: DAVENPORT, Iowa, June 15 (UPI)  A 19yearold girl from Queens, N. Y., will be the first Negro to compete for the Miss America title next fall.

title: REQUEST RENEWED ON PHONE RATE RISE
description: The New York Telephone Company asked the state Pub lic Service Commission yes terday to weigh current, rather than twoyearold economic conditions, in ruling on the company's request for a $175 million general rate increase.

title: Draft Files Hit in Providence
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 15 (AP)Draft files of four Selec tive Service boards were ruined in a weekend breakin at the state headquarters. Officials said that induction callups would not he affected.

title: BOARD CONFIRMS I.O.S. POWER SHIFT
description: GENEVA, June 15Investors Overseas Services confirmed today that the new head of its vast financial complex had been given full authority to carry out his plan for redress ing its troubled affairs.

title: 100,000 Gallons of Fuel Oil Spilled Near Bridgeport
description: Some 100,000 gallons of fuel oil spilled out of a storage tank into the waters of Johnson Creek near the Bridgeport, Conn., harbor Sunday, the Coast Guard reported yester day.

title: Man Bitten by a Rabid Bat Is Located
description: A citywide search for a mid dleaged man bitten by a rabid bat while picking flowers ended last night when the victim Isaac Solomon of 2430 Haring Street in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn called city health authorities to ask if he was the man they were looking for.

title: Negro Defined in Louisiana
description: BATON ROUGE, La., June 15 (AP)The Senate passed and sent to the Governor today a bill allowing a person with one thirtysecond Negro blood to declare himself white.

title: Former Young G.O.P. Aide Gets Two Years in Forgery
description: CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) Victor S. Kamber, the former chairman of a leadership con ference sponsored by the Young Republicans, was sentenced to day to two years in prison for submitting a forged letter to his draft board.

title: Expensive Oversight
description: The nation was shocked three years ago when a NASA review board revealed the incredible careless ness behind the January 1967 fire that took the lives of Apollo astronauts Virgil I. Grissom, Edward H. White and Roger B. Chaffee. Following the public in dignation roused by this expos, NASA and its con tractors promised a thorough review of the Apollo equipment and correction of weaknesses that might lead to other disasters.

title: Indian Party Bids Foreign Forces Quit Indochina
description: NEW DELHI, June 15Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Con gress party has demanded the withdrawal of all foreign forces from Indochina commencing with the Americans, as a prel ude for a negotiated peace.

title: NATO REVIEWING USE OF DRAFTEES
description: BRUSSELS, June 15  A comprehensive review of Europe's defense in this dec ade by the North Atlantic al liance is expected to encourage the revival of professional armies and the development of a more flexible strategy.

title: Science Center Cost Given
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP) a new science information, center, proposed for Oak Ridge, Tenn., by the Atomic Energy Commission, will cost an esti mated total of $10.2million, commission officials have said in testimony before a House Appropriations subcommittee.

title: World Cup Soccer TV At Forum Tomorrow
description: The semifinals of the World Cup soccer tourna ment, televised via satellite from Mexico, will be shown in The Felt Forum at Madison Square Garden Center tomor row, with the first game of the doubleheader beginning at 8 P.M.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Tuesday, June 16, 1970

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 16, 1970 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Co lonialism, Subcommittee on Indian Ocean Territories 10:30 A.M.

title: Lomax Plea in Tax Case
description: LOS ANGELES, June 15 (AP) Louis Lomax, author and for mer television commentators, pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today to four counts of violating Federal in come tax laws. Trial is set for Aug. 11 for Mr. Lomax, 47 years old.

title: Liberal Elected Moderator Of Presbyterian Church
description: MEMPHIS, June 15 (AP) Liberals gained a narrow vic tory yesterday with the elec tion of William A. Benfield Jr. as Moderator of the Presbyte rian Church in the U.S. (South ern), which has nearly one million members.

title: AMOSEAS' OIL OUTPUT IS REDUCED BY LIBYA
description: The Libyan Government has ordered Amoseas, a company jointly owned by Texaco, Inc., and the Standard Oil Company of California to cut back its production by about 100,000 barrels a day, Texaco an nounced yesterday.

title: Bills Go in Opposite Directions At Trea6sury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 Treasury bill rates moved in op posite directions at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

title: 1MAN,1VOTE DENIED ON ESTIMATE BOARD
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)The Supreme Court re fused today to consider re alignment of the New York City Board of Estimate along oneman, onevote lines.

title: JAMES MURPHY, 52, OF GEORGE SCHOOL
description: James A. Murphy, a faculty member of the Henry George School of Social Science and a research associate at the Downs state Medical Center of the State University of New York in Brooklyn, was found dead Friday, apparently of a heart Attack, at his desk at the cen ter. He was 52 years old.

title: Bonn's Ruling Parties to Pursue Policy Despite Election Setback
description: BONN, June 15  Despite heavy buffeting in yesterday's provincial elections, the two parties that make up West Ger many's coalition government insisted today that they would maintain their existing policies.

title: TEACHERS ON L.I. FINED FOR STRIKE
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 15 The Massapequa Federation of Teachers and two of its of ficers were found guilty of criminal contempt today for willful disobedience of a court order to end a strike against the school district last month.

title: MAINE G.O.P. PICKS MUSKIE OPPONENT
description: PORTLAND, Me., Tuesday, June 16Neil S. Bishop, school teacher, farmer and youth lead er, won the Republican sena torial nomination yesterday and will face Senator Edmund S. Muskie in the November elec tion. Mr. Muskie was unopposed in the Democratic primary.

title: Judge Curbs Pickets' Din At F.B.I. Hq.
description: With a reference to Bibli cal teaching and a sugges tion to hire a publicrelations adviser, a state judge restrict ed yesterday the nightly pick eting here by ItalianAmeri cans who are protesting what they call harassment by the Federal Bureau of Investi gation.

title: INDONESIAN IS FLYING TO SOVIET FOR TALK
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, June 15 (Reuters)  Foreign Minister Adam Malik left today by air to head an Asian peaceseeking mission in discussions about Cambodian with Soviet leaders.

title: Backed in Connecticut Race
description: WILTON, Conn., June 15 William H. Bonvillian of Signal Hill, a 23yearold Yale Divinity School student, has received the Democratic party endorse ment for State Representative from the 162d Assembly Dis trict. His opponent is expected to be 28yearold George Gui dera.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: U.S. Court Voids Rhode Island Pay For Lay Teachers
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 15 A three judge Federal court ruled here today that Rhode Island's Salary Supplement Act of 1969, under which the state would have contributed up to 15 per cent to the pay of lay teachers of secular subjects in parochial schools, was uncon stitutional.

title: Binghamton Editor Named
description: BINGHAMTON, N.Y., June 15 (AP)Erwin C. Cronk, man aging editor of The Bingham ton Press since 1959, was pro moted today to editor of that paper and of the Sunday Press. He succeeds Fred W. Stein, who died on June 7.

title: PAPER NEGOTIATORS SHIFT TO COLORADO
description: Top negotiators for the city's four major daily newspapers and Mailers Union No. 6 flew to Colorado Springs yesterday to continue their contract talks at the headquarters of the parent International Typograph ical Union.

title: PLAY BY WHITING BOWS IN LONDON
description: LONDON, June 15The Gates of Summer was John Whiting's last throw before quitting the theatre for the film industry; and when it closed in 1956 during a pre London tour, Whiting gave in structions that it was not to be presented in Britain again, and he excluded it from the collect ed edition of his plays.

title: Nixon to Address Nation On Economy Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 President Nixon will address the nation on the economy at noon Wednesday.

title: 28 Law Students Join Hogan's Summer Staff
description: The office of the Manhat tan District Attorney, Frank S. Hogan, got 28 summer helpers yesterday, each of them a secondyear law stu dent. And if tradition is re peated, at least six or seven of them will end up as as sistant district attorneys fol lowing their graduation a year from now.

title: Miss Volchok Will Be Wed
description: The engagement of Miss Marjorie Pamela Volchok to Dr. Robert Lewis Douglas, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold S. Douglas, has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stan ley Volchok. Both families live in New York.

title: PRISON TERM CUT IN RESENTENGING
description: Dominick Cappolla, the con victed extortionist who al legedly had tried in vain to bribe the judge who tried and sentenced him three years ago, was resentenced here yester day to a shorter prison term.

title: Shark!, Story of Hunt for Bullion
TOUR CALLED OFF BY BRITISH BAND
description: Spokesmen for an English rock group, Ginger Baker's Air Force, said yesterday, that the nineman band had canceled its eightweek tour of the United Statese partly out of sympathy with student demonstrators in this country. Mr. Baker also feared, according to his British manager, Robert Stigwood, that with so many young people boycotting and demonstrating, instead of attending rock con certs, his concerts might not sell the expected number of tickets.

title: Victim Blames Kids, Not Young Lords, for East Harlem Looting
description: When the Electric Indian, a women's mod apparel store, closed late Saturday night, it had begunafter five months to make an impression on the Puerto Ricans living in the vi cinity of the store, at 187 East 116th Street.

title: PRICES ON AMEX SHOW ADVANCES
description: Many prices on the Ameri can Stock Exchange managed to finish higher yesterday, al though some late selling pres sure reduced the Size of the earlier gains.

title: Upstate Convict Released Briefly for His Wedding
description: ROCHESTER, June 16A bookmaker was released from the Monroe County Penitentiary for several hours Monday to be married in his home in subur ban Irondequoit.

title: Budge Scores Insurance Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Hamer H. Budge, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, criticized today as materially lacking many as pects of a securities industry plan for insuring investors against bankruptcies of broker age firms.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Debutante Gala For Alexanders Attended by 200
description: Miss Emory Graham Alex ander and her sister, Miss Helen Campbell Alexander, were honored here last eve ning at a reception and a din ner dance, given by their mother, Mrs. Lloyd L. Groves of Fair Hills, Elkton, Md., Mrs. Groves is the former Miss Helen King Kleberg, the only daughter of Robert Justus Kleberg Jr. of the King Ranch in Kingsville Tex.

title: NEGRO JOBS LOSS FOUND IN SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Of ficials of the National Educa tion Association testified today before a Senate committee that 5,000 black principals and teach ers in Southern schools had either been dismissed or de moted as a result of desegrega tion.

title: Court Upholds Farber As Liberals' Candidate
description: ALBANY, June 16  The state's highest court ruled today the Barry Farber, New York City radio host, was the legal Liberal party can didate for Congress in the 19th Congressional District.

title: SOVIET CELLIST WINS TCHAIKOVSKY PRIZE
description: David Geringas of the So viet Union has won the cello prize at the international Tchai kovsky competition in Moscow, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported last night.

title: ISRAELIS ATTACK NEAR DAMASCUS
description: JERUSALEM, Wednesday, June 17A military spokesman said that Israeli forces struck deep into Syria last night to shell a military camp occupied by about 1,000 Syrian soldiers and to blow up a highway bridge.

title: A.D.C. TO PRODUCE LONGER TV FILMS
description: The American Broadcasting Company, which had substan tial success this season with its 90minute Movie of the Week television series, has created a new unit to make twohour feature films for tele vision, starting in 1971. The unit, to be called A.B.C. Circle Films, will be a subsidiary of A.B.C. Television and will be directly under Barry Diller, the network's vice president for feature films and program de velopment and the man respon sible for Movie of the Week.

title: MUTINY PENALTY FOR G.I. SET ASIDE
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  Citing lack of sufficient evi dence, an Army court of mili tary review set aside today the mutiny conviction of a private who was Courtmartialed for his participation in the alleged mutiny by 27 soldiers at the Presidio stockade in San Fran Cisco in October, 1968.

title: Dodge Trucks Recalled
description: DETROIT, June 16 (AP)The Chrysler Corporation announced today it was recalling 4,800 Dodge trucks for the correction of possible steering and brake defects. The vehicles involved were 1970 Dodge B100. B200 and B300 compact trucks, in troduced about two weeks ago.

title: DR. OPPENHEIM, LED 2 MEDICAL BUREAUS
description: Dr. Abraham Oppenheim, di rector of the adult hygiene and cancer control research bureaus of the New York City Depart ment of Health, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital after a short illness. He was 62 years lived at 70 East 10th Street.

title: 20 Children Given Awards For Art Work on Pollution
description: Twenty young artists, age 7 through 11, were given awards at City Hall yesterday for post ers and art work on pollution that were prepared for display on Earth Day last April.

title: Wimbledon Seedings
description: MEN'S DIVISION

title: Alabama School Integration
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 16 (UPI)Two neighboring westcentral Alabama counties were under Federal court or ders today to integrate their school systems, both about 80 per cent Negro, in a manner the court conceded would prob ably leave them allblack. The Marengo County system was ordered yesterday to imple ment a Government plan that divided the county into zones and required students to at tend the school in their zone.

title: Football Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: J. E. GRIFFITH JR.
description: SEA ISLAND, Ga., June 16  J. E. Griffith Jr., a retired vice president, group division, of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, died today at his home here. He Was 77 years old.

title: Allied Stores and A.&P. Sessions Highlight Meetings
description: The Allied Stores Corpora tion, the nation's secondlarg est departmentstore chain, has found that May showed no big turnaround and that the cur rent fiscal quarter's business was running at or slightly be low the 3.7 per cent gain in sales during the second quar ter, ended April 30.

title: High Court's Refusal to Upset Estimate Board Pleases Mayor
description: Mayor Lindsay was described as doubly pleased yesterday by Monday's Supreme Court action in letting stand a state Court of Appeals ruling that the one man, onevote doctrine was not applicable to the Board of Estimate.

title: $340.000 Awarded in Suit
description: NEWARK, June 16 (UPI)Al Federal jury awarded $340,000 last night to a woman who had filed a negligence suit after her husband was killed when he got off an ErieLackawanna train on the wrong side and was killed by another train. The award was to Mrs. Karen E. McGrath of Milwaukee, for merly of Oakland, Calif. District Court Judge James A. Ceolahan presided at the trial.

title: Rail Union Head Chafes at Delay In Diesel Dispute
description: CLEVELAND, June 16 (AP) The head of the United Transportation Union, the na tion's largest railroad operating union, said today that the or ganization will not tolerate further delay in settling the lingering dispute over the use of firemen in diesel locomo tives.

title: NIXON POSTAL BILL BARRED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 President Nixon and leaders of organized labor lost an open ing skirmish today as the House insisted on taking up its own version of a sweeping postal reformandpay bill.

title: Washington Gratified
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) A spokesman for Secretary of State William P. Rogers said, We hope this release will be followed by the release of other American and interna tional journalists captured it Cambodia in recent weeks.

title: Policeman Hit by Bottle Thrown in School Disorder
description: A patrolman was hit on the head with a bottle yesterday when he attempted to arrest a youth at the edge of a crowd of 300 students gathered out side Public School 108 in Ja maica, Queens.

title: Cabbie Stabbed in Dispute
description: A traffic dispute at 44th Street and the Avenue of the Americas yesterday ending in the stabbing of a taxicab driver and the arrest of a truck driver, the police reported. The cab driver, Restitudo Gonzales, 45 years old, of 337 East 138th Street, the Bronx, was taken to Polyclinic Hospital, where he was reported to be in critical condition. The truck driver, identified by the police as James Jarrett, 43, of 340 Man hattan Avenue, was charged with felonious assault and pos session of a dangerous weapon.

title: SWEIG, VOLOSHEN FACE TRIAL TODAY
description: House Minority Leader Ger ald R. Ford and two Senators said yesterday that they had been asked by Dr. Martin Sweig to appear as his defense wit nesses.

title: Foreign Affairs: Where the Middle East Begins
description: ERIVAN, U.S.S.R. in dis cussing Moscow's policy toward the Middle East, many people forget that the Soviet Union is itself a Middle Eastern power. The U.S.S.R. contains many Moslems and borders Afghanis tan, Iran and Turkey. Legend ary heroes of the Middle East ern past came from what is now Soviet territory.

title: Heath Sees a Devaluation; Wilson Charges a Scare
description: LONDON, June 16Edward Heath, striving to come from behind in the last days of the election campaign, charged to night that Britain would face another devaluation if the La bor party remained in office.

title: CON ED TO LEASE GENERATING UNITS
description: The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., following the longstanding practice of the railroads and lairlines, has arranged for long Iterm leasing for some of its badly needed generating equip ment.

title: Commandos in Amman Free U.S. Doctor, Detained Friday
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 16 (Reuters)An American physi cian who was detained by Pal estinian commandos in Amman Friday was released today, spokesman at the United States Embassy said.

title: Istanbul Has Martial Law After Leftist Labor Riot
description: ANKARA, Turkey, June 16 Martial law was proclaimed tonight in Istanbul after a day of rioting by militant leftwing workers over proposed changes in labor legislation.

title: Monmouth Jockeys
Sorensen Says He Would Ease Taxes on MiddleIncome Class
description: Standing on the steps of the old Subtreasury Building at Nassau and Wall Streets, Theodore C. Sorensen suggested yesterday a pacliage of tax law changes that, he said, would ease the burden of the middleincome taxpayer and homeowner.

title: Tenant Changes His Plea To Not Guilty in Assault Case
description: Herbert Kebeck, the tenant in an East Side luxury building who previously pleaded guilty to fighting with a policeman who had come to check on complaints from Mr. Kebeck's neighbors, changed his plea to not guilty in State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Slaying of a Classmate Brings Violence Home to Queens School
description: Twice last month Linden Jun ior High School was closedas were all city schoolsto give pupils time to reflect upon the violence at Kent State Univer sity and at Jackson. Miss.

title: Lien Threatened on Papp's Theater
description: A construction company yesterday threatened to take over the New York Shake speare Festival's Public Thea ter at 425 Lafayette Street unless a bill of more than $400,000 for work done on the structure is paid within the next few days.

title: Broyhill of Virginia Asks Republicans to Support Byrd
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) Representative Joel T. Broy hill, in a formal break with the state's Republican Governor and most of the Republican organization, said today that he would work for endorse ment by the party later this month of the Senate candidacy of Senator Harry F. Byrd Jr., who is running as an independ ent.

title: TODAY'S PROBABLE PITCHERS
description: Cincinnati at New York (8:05 P.M.) Simpson (91) vs. Gentry (64).

title: New Times Service Offers Weekly Biographical Profiles
description: Biographical profiles of per sons in the news are being re printed from The New York Times and mailed weekly to subscribers to The New York Times Biographical Edition, it was announced yesterday. The new service will include more than 1,000 biographical sketches each year.

title: Incumbents Get Edge
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 16 Incumbents were victorious today in three of the four con tested village elections in Suf ?? County.

title: Books of The Times
description: About a year and a half ago, I wrote a review in this column praising Eldridge Cleaver's PostPrison Writings and Speeches. A howl of protest went up that would have warned Leonard Bernstein of the pitfalls of Kaffeeklatsching with the Black Panthers. Dozens of letter writers wanted to know how I could lavish such praise on a mur derer. How could I even take seri ously the writings of a copkiller and an advocate of violence and race warfare? These were not all kook letters, ei ther; some of them came from distinguished peo ple who ought to have known that Mr. Cleaver had never killed one or muttered a word about race war fare. I was perplexed by the reaction, to say the least. (Remember: This was long before Cleaver surfaced in Algeria and came out in favor of training black guerrillas with Al Fatah.) To me, the letter writers seemed to be projecting some variety of fantasy onto the figure of Cleaver. But what fantasy and why?

title: BIG ANTIMONY FIND CITED IN MONTANA
description: John C. Lawrence, president of Agau Mines, Inc., and of the United States Antimony Cor poration, said yesterday that the affiliated concerns had veri fied the presence of major anti mony reserves on their property near Thompson Falls, Mont.

title: 2 Are Killed and 3 Injured In Fiery East Side Car Crash
description: Two men were killed and three others were critically in jured in a fiery automobile accident on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive early yester day morning.

title: U. S. and Soviet Negotiators in Vienna Moving Toward Accord on Key Issues on Limiting Strategic Arms
description: VIENNA, July 16After two months of meetings here on a possible limitation of stra tegic nuclear arms, United States and Soviet negotiators are edging slowly toward an agreement involving all the major categories of such weapons.

title: Linda Charlette Jones Betrothed
description: MIAMI SPRINGS, Fla., June 16Mr. and Mrs. Charles Edward Jones have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Charlette Jones, to Ens.. Vance Wiley Torbert 3d, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Torbert Jr. of Bernardsville, N. J.

title: Paris Slum Is. Calm After ArabJewish Rioting
description: PARIS, June 16  Tunisian Jewish merchants M the slum known as Belleville swept the glass from their shattered store fronts today and reopened for business. It was not the first time, and it would not be the last they said.

title: Ulbricht Suggests Exchange of Envoys With Bonn and 2 Germanys' Entry in U.N.
description: BERLIN, June 16  Walter Ulbricht, the East German leader, has suggested, in what could be a change of position, that the two German states exchange diplomatic repre sentatives and apply for mem bership in the United Nations before establishing full inter national relations.

title: Constable's in Deal To Acquire Builder
description: The Arnold Constable Corpo ration, the 145yearold retail concern, announced yesterday that it has agreed to merge with the American International Development Corporation, a Florida operator of condomin ium (or jointly owned) prop erties, in the latest phase of a diversification program.

title: Hortense Powdermaker Is Dead; An Authority on Varied Cultures
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 16 Dr. Hortense Powdermaker, an anthropologist and author who taught at Queens College for many years, died of a heart at tack at her home here last night, after returning from a movie. She was 69 years old. Dr. Powdermaker moved here three years ago after retiring from the Queens College fa culty.

title: W'CARTHY CALLS POWER RATES HIGH
description: MASSENA, N. Y., June 16 Representative Richard Max McCarthy came to this indus trial city of 16,000 near the Canadian border today and charged that high power rates set by the State Power Au thority were driving industry from this hardpressed area.

title: Hofstra Shifts Myers
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., June 16 (UPI)Howard (Howdy) Myers, the athletic director at Hofstra University the past 20 years, will relinquish the administra tive position to devote full time to duties as bead football and lacrosse coach, the school an nounced today.

title: Nixon Talk on Economy Set for Noon Broadcast
description: President Nixon's talk on the nation's economy will be carried live at noon to day on television and radio.

title: World Cup Soccer
description: GROUP I

title: 19THCENTURY TRIOS PLAYED AT CONCERT
description: A trio of trios from the 19th century made up the Evening of Romantic Chamber Music that was Monday night's Sampler at Alice Tully Hall. Two of them are among the best and most popular works in the repertory, Mendelssohn's Piano Trio in D minor, with its direct outpouring of melodies and its superbly elfin Scherzo, and the much more subtle Clar inet Trio in A minor by Brahms, with all its rhythmic complexi ties and intricately piecemeal themes. Piano Trio in D minor, with its direct outpouring of melodies and its superbly elfin Scherzo, and the much more subtle Clar inet Trio in A minor by Brahms, with all its rhythmic complexi ties and intricately piecemeal themes.

title: Negro to Seek Nomination For Governor in Arkansas
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 16 (AP)The Rev. R. J. Hampton filed today for the Republican nomination for Governor, be coming the first Negro in dec ades to run for the state's highest office.

title: Unit Food Price and Dating Studied
description: ATLANTA, June 16 (UPI) The management of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Com pany, Inc., announced at its annual stockholders' meeting today that it was studying three consumerprotection proposals, including unit pricing of items and dating of perishable goods.

title: Zachary Upset in Title Golf
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 16 George Haines Jr. of Somer set Hills, the 1968 champion, and one of the sectional quali fying medalists, Dave Muraskin of Rutgers, survived the open ing rounds of the New Jersey State Golf Association's 69th amateur championship today over the rolling Plainfield Country Club course.

title: Religion and the Draft
description: The heart of the Supreme Court's 5to3 ruling that men may legitimately object to military service on purely moral and ethical grounds is that it has re moved the requirement of religious belief from the legal concept of the conscientious objector. The deci sion properly eliminates from Federal law the impli cation that only those who subscribe to formal religions are to be credited with a fundamental aver sion to war and killing.

title: Bomb Charges Dropped
description: CHICAGO, June 16 (AP)The state's attorney's office dropped charges today against Gary Witzel, 22 years old, who was arrested March 30 in connection with the discovery of a bomb factory that the police believed was linked to radical groups. Mr. Witzel was seized in front of a North Side apartment where the explosives were found.

title: Bridge Toll Books by Mail
description: ALBANY, June 16The State Thruway Authority announced today that commutation toll book sales for the Tappan Zee Bridge will be handled by mail, beginning July 1.

title: Brian Piccolo Is Dead at 26; Halfback on the Chicago Bears
description: Brian Piccolo, a halfback for the Chicago Bears football team died here yesterday in Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases. The 26 yearold athlete's death was at tributed to cancer.

title: Walinsky Takes an Independent Stand
description: Adam Walinsky, a contender for the Democratic nomination for State Attorney General, vowed yesterday that he would run a very independent office if elected.

title: U.A.W. Opposes Wage Cut
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 16 (AP)  Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers, said today that the union would reject any effort by President Nixon to roll back union wage requests in forth coming negotiations with auto mobile manufacturers.

title: Five Writers Urge South Africa Return Author's Passport
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, June 16The South African Government cameun der new pressure today to re store the passport of the coun try's leading playwright, Athol Fugard.

title: PENTAGON BACKS SCRUTINY OF PX
description: PENTAGON BACKS SCRUTINY OF PX

title: A Liquidity Crisis?
description: Last week, when the Penn Central Company abruptly dis missed its chairman, Stuart T. Saunders, in the midst of what was (and clearly still is) a grave financial crisis, a tremor ran through the canyons of Wall Street.

title: Advertising: Helping Political Candidates
description: Through their national com mittees political candidates of the two major parties across the length and breadth of this fair land will soon be re ceiving a booklet on adver tising. Some of them use it, you know.

title: Brazil and Italy Picked In Cup Soccer Today
description: MEXICO CITY, June 16 (UPI) The oddsmakers and the ex perts agreed today that it will be a BrazilItaly final in the 1970 World Cup soccer cham pionship.

title: New Crisis Held Possible
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 16 The leader of the most leftist of the Arab commando move ments said today that the con flict between the Jordanian Ar my and the Palestinians could flare into a new and bloodier crisis within a few months or even with a week.

title: Trenton Mayor Defeated By Man He Beat in 1966
description: TRENTON, June 16 (AP) Former Mayor Arthur J. Hol land has defeated the man who ousted him four years ago, Carmen J. Armenti.

title: 16 HELD AS LINKS IN GAMBLING RING
description: The indictment of 16 personsl on charges of operating a $5 millionayear bookmaking and policy business in the Bronx was announded yesterday by District Attorney Burton B. Roberts.

title: Two Congos Hold Talks
description: KINSHASA, the Congo, June 16 (Agence FrancePresse) Twohour reconciliation talks between President Joseph Mo butu of the Congo and Presi dent Marien Ngouabi of the neighboring Congo People's Re public were held in an atmos phere of understanding, it was reported here tonight.

title: Toward Cleaner Air
description: The amendment to the Clean Air Act of 1967 approved by the House, 374 to 1, is positive recogni tion that national standards are essential to cut down emissions from motor vehicles and stationary (smoke stack) sources of pollution. By authorizing appropria tions of $775 million over the next three years, the House has nearly doubled the amount asked by the Administration.

title: French 12Meter Yachts Arrive
description: France's potential chal lenger for the America's Cup arrived by freighter yesterday at the Brooklyn Army Ter minal surrounded by two other 12Meter yachts, three motorboats, nine aluminum masts, nine French crewmen, a 1958 Bentley automobile and a tight curtain of secu rity.

title: CONSTRUCTION BAN DELAYED IN JERSEY
description: TRENTON, June 16 (AP) The enforcement of a court or der that could have led to a ban on all construction in a fourcounty area in northern New Jersey was put off today for at least two months.

title: The Tatler Plans a Push in U.S.
description: Take heart, you dancers at debuts, you frolickers at fetes and all you beautiful people who feel at home amid the smilax. The Tatler is coming to town.

title: Hilton Is Buying Minority Interest in Las Vegas Hotel Operator
description: The Hilton Hotels Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle, subject to certain conditions, to acquire from the Tracy Investment Company a 37.5 per cent interest in the International Leisure Corpora tion, which owns and operates the International and Flamingo Hotels in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: MANUEL MAURTUA
description: LIMA, Peru, June 16 (AP) Ambassador Manuel Felix Maurtua, head of Peru's per manent delegation to the United Nations, died today. He was 59 years old. Mr. Maurtua, 30 years in the diplomatic service, had earlier been pro fessor of international law at the University of San Marcos here.

title: Rise in Rail Pensions Gains
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee approved today a temporary 15 per cent increase in benefits for retired railroad employes.

title: C. P. M'CORMICK, 74, OF SPICE COMPANY
description: BALTIMORE, June 16 (AP) ACharles P. McCormick, busi nessman, educator, civic leader and author known for his multiple management system, died tonight in University Hos pital of a heart attack. His age was 73.

title: ADVANCE IS SHARP IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange made their biggest advance in almost two weeks yesterday as the list made good gains in fairly active trading.

title: 2 Young Doctors: Pay Is Better, but . . .
description: The patients at Mount Sinai Hospital have learned to distinguish between the two doctors named Waldman. They call the bubbly hazeleyed redhaired woman in the minidress, who's been making rounds during the last year as a senior medical student, Mrs. Dr. Waldman. The darkhaired, mustached, quiet one is Dr. Waldman.

title: Article 3  No Title
HOWARD M. HANF
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., June 16Howard M. Hanf, re tired partner of the J. W. & H. M. Hanf Company, New York importers, died Sunday in Woodland Nursing Home after an illness of three months. He was 71 years old and lived at 465 Eastern Parkway, Brooklyn.

title: Sihanouk Pledges Help
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk was reported yesterday to have pledged to continue to do everything I can to find news men missing in Cambodia.

title: Bill Allows U.S. Courts To Enforce Free Speech
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  A new law under whict Federal courts could prohibit and punish intefference with freedom of speech was proposed today by a Congressional coalition of Democrats and Republicans, both liberal and conservative.

title: 13 MADRIGAL SINGERS FROM SCHOOL HEARD
description: If someone didn't know, would have come as a shock to discover that the madrigal singers at Carnegie Recital Hall Monday night were students at James Madison High School in Vienna. Va.

title: ANTIWAR DEMOCRAT WINNER IN DELAWARE
description: DOVER, Del., June 16 (UPI) John Daniel lo, a Newcastle County councilman who ran on an antiwar platform, won the Democratic nomination for Con gress today in Delaware's only statewide primary election.

title: Changes at Manufacturers
description: C. Roderick O'Neil, vice pres ident, personal trust invest ment research, at the Manu facturers Hanover Trust Com pany, has been advanced to ex ecutive vice president in charge of the personal trust depart ment and a member of the general administrative board. Reese H. Harris Jr., executive vice president, was promoted to the new post of chairman of the trust committee and elected a member of the bank's gen eral administrative board.

title: New Haven Panther Trial Opens
description: NEW HAVEN, June 16The first trial in what is expected to be a drawnout series of trials of Black Panthers started quiet ly here today with an unusual assurance from the prosecutor that he had no intention of seeking the death penalty for defendant. Lonnie McLucas.

title: Penalties Barred for Protesting Diplomatic Officials
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  The State Department has as sured Government officials who signed a letter last month to Secretary of State William P. Rogers protesting the incursion into Cambodia that no formal or informal punishment would he taken against them, the American Foreign Service Asso ciation said today.

title: SILVER FUTURES RISE IN BUSY DAY
description: Silver futures rose yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange although prices re ceived at the Government's silver auction in Washington showed a decline.

title: Tiny West German Group Vows to Overthrow State
description: BERLIN, June 16A small group of West German leftist political extremists has served notice that it plans to set up guerrilla organization to over throw the parliamentary system in the state and in West Berlin.

title: Housing Starts Fell In May but Permits For Building Gained
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Housing starts declined slightly in May while per mits for new construction in creased, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: GENTILE GETS 70, PACES QUALIFYING
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 16 John Gentile Jr. of The Pat terson Club, Fairfield, Conn., won the medal by two strokes today in the qualifying round of the 51st annual Westchester County Golf Association ama teur championship.

title: Washington: For the Record
Pacer Earns a Rest at Westbury After 2Day Whirl of Canada
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 16  Everyone connected with Columbia George, the 3year old pacer who will be among the leading contenders in next Saturday night's Commodore Pace at Roosevelt Raceway, would like to forget about what happened to the colt last Sunday and Monday in Canada.

title: Marian E. Rian, Harp Student, Is the Fiancee of Brian J. Hays
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 16  The Rev. and Mrs. Edwin Harold Rian have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marian Ed wina Rian, to Brian Joseph Hayes, son of Mrs. Joseph H. Hays of Kenilworth, Ill., and the late Mr. Hays.

title: Two Italian Movie Prizes Go to Midnight Cowboy
description: ROME, June 16 (AP)The flirt Midnight Cowboy has won two David di Donatello prizes, the Italian equivalent of Hollywood's Academy Awards, it was announced today.

title: Queen Elizabeth Watches Her Horse Win at Ascot
description: ASCOT, England, June 16 (Reuters)A winner for Queen Elizabeth in the fifth race to day capped the opening of the fourday Royal Ascot race meeting.

title: Foster 85 Choice to Beat Quarry Tonight in Heavyweight Fight at Garden
description: In a meaningful match not only for the combatants but also for the heavyweight divi sion, Mac Foster will make his Madison Square Garden debut tonight against Jerry Quarry in a 10round bout. a 10round bout.

title: Agnew Bids Student Quit Panel, But White House Rejects Move
description: DETROIT, June 16  Vice President Agnew called today for the resigdation of the only student member of a new Presidential commission on campus unrest, but he was re buffed by both the student and the White House.

title: Article 4  No Title
Dance: Ballet Theater's Les Noces  A Brilliant Performance Sparks Season Debut
Jonathan Winters' Mother
description: SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, June 16 (AP)  Mrs. Alice Bahman, mother of Jonathan Winters, the comedian, died today in Mercy Medical Center here. She was 65 years old, and had been ill for four months. She is sur vived also by her husband, Richard, and two grandchildren.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Priest in Massachusetts Is Opposed as Politician
description: NEWTON, Mass, June 15 At the Massachusetts Demo cratic Convention last weekend a woman approached the Rev. Robert F. Drinan and told him she could not vote for him be cause he was a priest and be longed in a parish, not in pol itics.

title: N.L.R.B. EXTENDS RULE. TO SCHOOLS
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 The National Labor Relations Hoard extended its jurisdiction today to cover private colleges and universities. With operat ing budgets of roughly $6bil lion a year, such institutions have a clear impact on inter state commerce, the board said, and will Shave to operate under the labormanagement rules that govern other big busi nesses.

title: Miss Miller Has Nuptials
description: FARMINGTON, Conn., June 16Miss Elizabeth Harriman Miller and John Clayson Den nis were married here this afternoon at Sevenfold, the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Danforth Miller Jr., by the Rev. Roger W. Smith of St. James Episcopal Church here.

title: 3 FinancialData Concerns To Trade Marketing Rights
description: LONDON, June 16 (Reuters) Renters, Standard and Poor's and t Exchange Telegraph have reached agreement to exchange marketing rights to several of their specialized financial in formation services in the United States, Europe and elsewhere.

title: South African Gold Output Rose Sharply in 5 Months
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Afri ca, June 16 (Reuters)The Chamber of Mines of South Africa said that South African gold production in the first five months of this year was 409,758 kilograms valued at $4,610,914,050, compared with 393,084 kilograms ($4,427,514 000) in the 1969 period.

title: Another Postal Strike?
description: Interunion squabbling confronts the country with the dismal threat of a second postal strike. The central issue this time is the formula for union representation that the House of Representatives seals into the pro posed postal reform bill.

title: RAHIM, CRAMER PACE N.C.A.A. NET ADVANCE
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 16 (UPI)Haroon Rahim of the University of California, Los Angeles, and Pat Cramer of Miami of Florida led the way with two victories apiece in the. National Collegiate Tennis championships today.

title: First Straw Hat Prizes Awarded by Cary Grant
description: The first annual Straw Hat Awards, sponsored by the Council of Stock Theaters, were presented yesterday by Cary Grant at an informal reception held at the Faberg Townhouse, 5 West 54th Street.

title: Upstate Man Dies in War
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Defense Department said today that S. Sgt. John R. Wur tenberg of Newark Valley, N. Y., was killed in the war in Southeast Asia.

title: Market Summary
description: Tuesday, June 16, 1970

title: Rochester to Have Film Fete in Fall
description: Rochester, following the lead of New York, San Fran cisco, Chicago and Atlanta, will present an international film festival. A nonprofiit group, Rochester Internation al Film Festival, Inc., headed by Williiam V. Creighton, chairman and administrative director, and Fred Mintz, fes tival director, announced that the festival will run from Oct. 17 through 25.

title: Angry Ethnic Voices Decry a Racist and Dullard Image
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Voices of the white ethnic working class rose in ange?? at being ignored by govern ment and the press, anger at being ridiculed by intellec tuals, anger at being ex ploited by rightwing reac tionaries like George Wal lace.

title: Clark Returning to Bench
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 16 (UPI)Torn C. Clark, former Supreme Court Justice, is re turning to the bench, this time on the United States District Court in San Francisco. Mr. Clark, who never was a trial judge, will start work next Monday.

title: UnionLabel Grapes Get A Mixed Reception Here
description: Boxes of California table grapes bearing the safe pas sage stamp of the Farmwork er's A.F.L.C.I.O. union label a black Aztec eagle inset in a white circle against the background of a red flag are making their first appear ance here to what seems to be a mixed reception.

title: Executive Changes
description: Joseph P. Grant has been named president of the Licensing Corporation of America, as subsidiary of Kinney National Service, Inc.

title: Singer Takes Charm to Rikers Island
description: Eloise Laws, a sinuous singer sheathed in purple, did all she could to turn the cement block gymnasium andauditorium of a city prison into a nightclub yes terday afternoon, in a show for 500 male inmates on Rikers Island.

title: 2 Killed in Jersey When Small Plane Hits Building in Fog
description: VERONA, N. J., June 16A light plane bound for Teterboro Airport crashed into a luxury apartment building here this evening, killing the plane's two occupants.

title: CRUGUET SCORES IN 2 RACES AGAIN
description: Jean Cruguet, the French jockey who has been finding it difficult to get into the win ner's circle this season, scored his second double in two days at Belmont Park yesterday on mounts with interesting back grounds.

title: Annual Review by Congress Is Called Desirable
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  A spokesman for the Pentagon re acted favorably today to a sug gestion that its multibilliondol lar military exchange system undergo regular examination by Congress and the executive branch.

title: 4 Killed in Ohio Car Crash
description: LEBANON, Ohio, June 16 (UPI)Four women were killed today when two autos collided on Interstate75 in Warren County.
