The victims, all in one car, were identified by the po lice as Mrs. Alice Roe, about 60 years old of Hartsville, Mo.; her daughter, Mrs. Frances A. Ru dokas, 45, Middletown, Ohio, and Carol Ann Pfau and Eliza beth A. Spellmire, 17, both of Lebanon.

title: Israeli High Court Recognizes Marriage Not Performed by the Rabbinate
description: TEL AVIV, June 16The High Court in Jerusalem or dered the Government today to register as man and wife a Jewish couple who were mar ried without the participation of clergy in a private religious ceremony.

title: A New Post, Chairman, Is Filled by Lufthansa
description: Lufthansa, the West Ger man transAtlantic airline, has named Herbert Culmann to the new post of chairman of its fourman executive board, on which he has served since 1964.

title: Cronkite Hails Syvertsen, Victim of Indochina War
description: JACKSONVILLE BEACH, Fla., June 16 (UPI)  George N. Syvertsen, the Columbia Broad casting System newsman who was killed May 31 near Phnom Penh, Cambodia, was eulogized today as a gentle man who did not fit the popular conception of a war correspondent.

title: Chemical Bank Seeks Branch
description: The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company has ap plied for permission to open a branch office in Zurich, the bank's first in Switzerland and its fourth overseas, the weekly bulletin of the New York State Banking Department disclosed yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: STOCKHOLM, June 16 After tonight's thirdround play in the world champion ship here, the United States team, the title favorites, was left the only undefeated team. It had a bye round, for which it received a nom inal 10 points out of 20, for a total of 41 victory points. Apparently leading with 42 points is the Brazilian team, which beat Norway tonight, 164. In the other match Na tionalist China defeated Italy, 146.

title: Police Expert Urges Tighter State Conspiracy Laws Aimed at Crime Leaders
description: Tightening state conspiracy laws to apprehend the top leaders of organized crime instead of only jailing middle management and men on the streetwas the No. 1 recom mendation yesterday by the officer who commanded the Police Department's efforts against the crime syndicate for the last two years.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: For CeaseFire

title: Faisal Visits Algeria
description: ALGIERS, June 16 (Reuters) King Faisal of Saudi Arabia arrived tonight for his first of cial visit to Algeria. He was met at the airport by President Houari Boumediene.

title: Toronto Exchange Drops Trading in I.O.S. Shares
description: TORONTO, June 16 (Canadian Press)The Toronto Stock Ex change announced today that trading in Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., had been sus pendedbeginning today.

title: Marine in Danang Pleads Innocent in Killing of 16
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 16 (Reuters)A United States marine private pleaded innocent today to a charge of premeditated murder of 11 children and 5 women on Feb. 19 in a hamlet near this base city.

title: RECEIVER URGED FOR THE GRAY LINE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission, has asked a Fed eral Court to appoint a receiver for the Gray Line Corporation, which owns 24 per cent of the voting shares of the contested Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc.

title: Declines to Resign
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 Mr. Rhodes said today that he had no intention of resign ing from the commission in the wake of Mr. Agnew's com ments.

title: Blackfin, 72Footer, Leads 3,571Mile Pacific Race
description: LOS ANGELES, June 16 (UPI) The 72foot Blackfin led the 14boat fleet at the start of the second day of the 3,571mile Los AngelestoTahiti yacht race today.

title: FLORIDA STATE NINE SETS BACK OHIO, 20
description: OMAHA, June 16 (UPI) Florida State knocked Ohio Uni versity out of the College World Series tonight with a 20 tri umph in a superb pitching bat tle. The Ohio starter, Ed Rob bins, suffered his first loss of the season after 14 victories.

title: The Screen: Censorship in Denmark Begins Run
description: This is Tony, says the friendly narrator of Cen sorship in Denmark: A New Approach, introducing us to a pretty, ovalfaced girl with long hair who looks a little like Leigh TaylorYoung at loose ends.

title: DRABOWSKY BACK IN ORIOLE FOLD
description: The Baltimore Orioles, who have been under pressure lately from the New York Yankees, contributed to a flurry of ac tivity as the baseball trading deadline anived Monday at midnight.

title: BILL ASKS POWER FOR RAIL CREDIT
description: Two developments that could drastically affect the nation's railroads, were announced in Washington yesterday. They were:

title: ROLE AS A CRITIC ABJURED BY RUSK
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Dean Rusk, the former Secre tary of State, tonight broke 18 months of silence on United States foreign policy to say that he could not throw brick bats at President Nixon for his failure to find peace in southeast Asia because the Ken nedy andJohnson Administra tions had also failed.

title: Lindsay Is Less Critical of the Nixon Administration
description: DENVER, June 16After three days at the tinted States Conference of Mayors conven tion here, Mayor Lindsay has eased into a relaxed and even polite attitude toward the Nixon Administration that con trasts markedly with some of his sharp criticism earlier this month of the Federal Govern ment's urban policies.

title: POLICE WOUND 4 IN MIAMI UNREST
description: MIAMI, June 16 (AP)The police shot four men  two whites and two Negroeson a rooftop tonight as racial vio lence spread into three Negro section of Miami.

title: JUNE'S SON GETS SPECIAL HEARING
description: The 17yearold son of State Supreme Court Justice Samuel R. Rosenberg and three of his friends were arraigned at a po lice station early yesterday morning after being arrested on marijuana charges.

title: Joint Drive in Geneva
description: GENEVA, June 16The Unit ed States and the Soviet Union today launched a campaign to win approval for their projected treaty to keep the ocean floors free of nuclear weapons.

title: British Election
description: Americans rightly regard the usual British election campaigns as not only more restrained but more responsiblewith debate at a higher level and more attention to real issues than most campaigns this country. The campaign that ends with the election of a new House of Commons tomorrow has, unfortu nately, failed to meet the expected standard.

title: ADDONIZIO AIDES CONCEDE BITTERLY
description: The verdict of the ballot box was a sour one for several hundred followers of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio who had gathered last night at Thomm's, a restaurant in the heavily Ital ian North Ward.

title: KIDNAPPERS FREE BONN ENVOY IN RIO
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 16 Ehrenfried von Holleben, the West German Ambassador to Brazil, returned safely to his home here tonight, five days after he was kidnapped and held for the highest ransom yet demanded40 political prison ersin a rash of diplomatic kidnappings in Latin America.

title: Cup Scores on WQXR
description: Please do not telephone the New York Times or WQXR for scores. The calls tie up lines and interfere with the work of the newspaper and radio station. World Cup re sults will be given on WQXR lateevening hourly news re ports.

title: Births
description: CHNEIDERDr. Norman Barry and Eleanor Gershgorn of 950 49 St, Bklyn are pleased to announce the birth of a daughter, Renee Alexis, at Maimonides Hospital, June 15.

title: 2D DRAFT LOTTERY IS SET FOR JULY 1
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  President Nixon issued a proc lamation today setting. July I as the date of the next draft lottery drawing.

title: 55 M.P.H. Speed Due On Parkways in City
description: New speed limits on some 40 miles of parkways in the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens will go into effect gradually, starting tomorrow, as signs are installed. The maximum speed is being raised from 50 to 55 miles an hour.

title: Seoul Protests U.S. Plan for Withdrawal
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 16A highranking aide of President Chung Hee Park ac cused the United States today of a breach of international faith in planning to withdraw troops from South Korea.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Statement
description: MOSCOW, June 16Following is the text of a state ment titled This Is How We Live, by the Soviet author Alehsandr I. Solzhenitsyn, protesting the detention of the biologist Zhores A. Medvedev:

title: Jane Handler Wed to Christopher Beirn
description: Miss Jane Louise Handler and Christopher Beirn were married yesterday by Surro gate Samuel J. Silverman of New York County in his chambers. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Handler of New York. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Kenneth Beim of Southport. Conn.

title: BALTIMORE LEAD CUT TO 2 GAMES
description: CHICAGO, June 16  Roy White picked the Yankees up on his 170pound frame tonight and lifted them half a game closer to the top of the Ameri can League's Eastern Division.

title: 13 Nieman Fellows Are Picked to Study A Year at Harvard
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16 (AP)Harvard University an nounced today the names of 13 journalists who have been se lected as Nieman Fellows for 197071.

title: Politics in the Churches
description: In comparison with the meet ings last year when James For man, the black militant leader, was making the rounds in be half of reparations for the evils of slavery, this spring's meetings of the major Protes tant denominations have been about as tumultuous as Wednesdayevening prayer meetings. When the United Presbyterians con vened in Chicago last month, the most emotional de bate was over sex outside of marriage. For South ern Baptists, it was the author ity of the Bible. At the forth coming meeting of the Lutheran Church in America, it's likely to be the ordination of women.

title: Three Captured U.S. Reporters Are Freed in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 16 (AP)Three American cor respondents, captured May 7 by Communist troops in Cam bodia, arrived in Saigon today, apparently in good condition after being freed by their cap tors.

title: Christmas Observance Suit
description: RUTLAND, Vt., June 16 (UPI) A Rutland man and his mother have begun court action against city officials to block permanently the observance of Christmas in Rutland public schools. Some 25 court, sum monses were served yesterday against Mayor Harold Nichols and others by Kendall Wild, managing editor of The Rutland Daily Herald, and his mother, Elizabeth.

title: Peacemaker on Campus Panel
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 16To those who know him well, Joseph Rhodes Jr. is a complex, altruistic youth who is endowed with an extraor dinary ability to come up with inspiring new ideas and get other people to carry them out. He is, they say, rather oblivious to the ameni ties of life, does not like to dance and sometimes even eats candy bars for break fast. His friends and enemies describe him with such adjectives as charismatic, brilliant, vi sionary and particulate and say he is possessed of a leadership ability that he feelsnot always very mod estlymust be put to great use. rather oblivious to the ameni ties of life, does not like to dance and sometimes even eats candy bars for break fast. His friends and enemies describe him with such adjectives as charismatic, brilliant, vi sionary and particulate and say he is possessed of a leadership ability that he feelsnot always very mod estlymust be put to great use.

title: City Country Folk Play Fiddle Tunes At Village Church
description: Despite a bomb scare that delayed the start of the pro gram for half an hour, a lively assortment of fiddlers, guitar ists and banjo pickers gathered on the stage of the Washington Square. Church, 135 West Fourth Street, Monday night for the first annual string band festival, sponsored by Darco Music Strings, Inc.

title: Baird of Jets Retires, But Leaves Door Open
description: Bill Baird, a defensive back with the New York Jets for the last seven seasons, an nounced his retirement yes terday from pro football.

title: Panel Approves Hodgson
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The nomination of James D. Hodg son to succeed George P. Shultz as Secretary of Labor won unanimous approval today from the Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee after a brief, friendly hearing.

title: Ottinger Says a Goldberg Poll Shows Him Leading Sorensen
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., June 16Representative Richard L. Ottinger said today that he had heard through the grapevine that the latest Goldberg camp poll showed him overtaking Theodore C. Sorensen in the fourway Democratic senatorial primary.

title: U.S. Open Officials Struggle To Avert Washout Tomorrow
description: CHASKA, Minn. June 16  United States Golf Association officials prepared today to save their 70th Open championship from a washout as 150 golfers crammed hurried practice rounds into a delayed schedule.

title: NEW TEXTILE TRY IS DUE NEXT WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 16A final effort to work out a volun tary method of restraining Jap anese textile exports to the United States will be made early next week, it became known today.

title: SOME ARABS SHIFT ON THE FEDAYEEN
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 16 Leaders of radical Arab govern ments have assumed an aloof position toward the Palestinian commando movement in the aftermath of last week's crisis In Jordan, according to reports reaching here.

title: THANT BIDS BIG 5 CONFER FOR PEACE
description: THE HAGUE, June 16Sec retary General Thant of the United Nations suggested today that the leaders of the five great powers, including Com munist China, meet to discuss world problems. He said they should try to change from their hostile attitudes to the building of a safe and peace ful world.

title: Crealy Upsets Graebner in London, 62, 16
description: LONDON, June 16No soon er had the seedings been an nounced for next week's Wim bledon tournament than Clark Graebner, No. 9; Tom Dicker, No. 11, and Roger Taylor, No. 16, were knocked out in the second round of the London open grass court tennis cham pionships today.

title: Goodby Boom Boom
description: On a hot June morning four years ago, Bernard Andre (Boom Boom) Geoffrion strutted about a. Madison Square Garden conference room, his muscles stretching his Seventh Avenuechic, shimmering suit. He was on top of the world. He took care that his manicured fingernails stayed neat, and when he picked up a cup of coffee his Dinky discreetly stood at attention.

title: Nixon Names 14 to Panel On Financial Structure
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)  President Nixon an nounced today the formal organization of the President's Commission on Financial Structure and Regulation, which win make recommendations to improve the functioning of the private financial system.

title: Robb Leaving Marines To Go to Law School
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)Maj. Charles S. Robb, soninlaw of former Presi dent Lyndon B. Johnson, is leaving the Marine Corps to study law.

title: Transcript Release Opposed
description: CHICAGO, June 16 (AP)A top official of the Justice De partment opposed a Circuit Court petition today seeking the release of a transcript of a Federal grand jury investigation into the killing of two Black Panther party leaders In a Chi cago police raid. Jerris Leonard, Assistant United States Attor ney General in charge of the Civil Rights Division, said he opposed the petition unless a special state prosecutor was ap pointed to investigate the inci dent.

title: GIBSON DEFEATS ADDONIZIO IN NEWARK MAYORAL RACE; VOTER TURNOUT A RECORD
description: Kenneth A. Gibson, the Negro candidate in Newark's bitterly contested and racially divisive mayoral election, decisively de feated Hugh J. Addonizio, the white, twoterm incumbent, yesterday.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: M.T. A. Is Accused by O'Dwyer Of Mishandling Subway Funds
description: Paul O'Dwyer, campaigning yesterday for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator in the subway complex under Times Square, called on New Yorkers to take back control of the subway system, while we still have any rolling stock that still functions.

title: POWELL PREDICTS A 3TO1 VICTORY
description: Adam Clayton Powell pre dicted yesterday that he would win by 3 to 1 over my nearest opponent in his fight for re nomination to the House of Representatives despite the intrusion of outsiders.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Restriction on Jet Airport Fails To Halt Martha's Vineyard Line
description: A citizens' committee that waged a vain yearlong fight to prevent jet airline service to Martha's Vineyard won a le gal point this week, but the jets are still flying in.

title: PRICES OF BONDS ADVANCE SHARPLY
description: The credit markets, revived by record yields ranging as high as 11 per cent, sprang to life yesterday. Prices rose sharply as new issues sold swiftly.

title: Rosemary Elton Is Wed on Coast To Son of Count
description: CARMEL, Calif., June 16 In an ecumenical ceremony at Carmel Mission Basilica, Miss Rosemary Elton and Alexander Markowski were married this afternoon. The Rev. George McMenamin, pastor of the mission, per formed the ceremony. The Rev. Peter Farmer, pastor of All Saints Episcopal Church here, presented a homily and blessed the service.

title: Discharge Plea Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Army turned down today a West Point graduate who ap plied for discharge as a con scientious objector. The Army said that Lieut. Louis P. Fount, 23 years old, of Kansas City, did not qualify, but gave no reason.

title: Solzhenitsyn Assails Detention Of Medvedev in Mental Hospital
description: MOSCOW, June 16 Alek sandr I. Solzhenitsyn, the con troversial Soviet novelist, has assailed the continued deten lion in a mental hospital of Zhores A. Medvedev, a biologist and an outspoken critic of the regime.

title: CHARLES L. AYLING
description: BARNSTABLE, Mass., June 16 (AP)Charles L. Ayling, a director of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Com pany for 45 years, died yes terday in his home. He was 95 years old.

title: Astronomers Detect a Substance That May Have Aided Evolution
description: A substance widely consid ered to have been a key in gredient in the early evolution of life has been detected among the stars by a radio telescope atop Kitt Peak in Arizona.

title: Priest Denies Converting Church Funds to His Use
description: Msgr. Louis Risha denied yesterday that he had con verted church funds to his own use in Philadelphia.

title: Schlitz Appeals to Beer Taste: Offers a Cup for Racing Series
description: The sportscar people seem to be awash in beer these days and they couldn't be happier, what with the brew ers joining the list of non automotive sponsors of motor competition. The Sports Car Club of America and the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company have just completed arrange ments for a Schlitz Cup Series of events for the low  budget car enthusiast. The series will in clude 90 slalom eventstests of driving skill involving one car at a time against the clock. Such events have previ ously had local sponsorship, but this will be the first time support has been available on a uniform, nationwide basis.

title: HOUSE UNIT VOTES JOB SAFETY BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 16I The House Education and La bor Committee approved an oc cupational safety bill today, amid warnings by Republicanl members that they would con test the measure when it reaches the House floor.

title: DR. NORMAN S. COOPER
description: CATSKILL, N.Y., June 16  Dhr. Norman S. Cooper, who had practiced medicine in near by Athens for 35 years, died at the Greene County Memorial Hospital here yesterday. He was 76 years old.

title: 13 Injured in Blast At a Sewage Plant At Kennedy Airport
description: Thirteen persons were slight ly injured and a sewagetreat ment plant near Kennedy Inter national Airport was heavily damaged last night in an ex plosion apparently caused by accumulated gases.

title: 4 Police Get Law Degrees
description: Four city policemen were among 153 graduates who re ceived degrees yesterday from Brooklyn Law School in cere monies at the WaldorfAstoria hotel. They were Thomas Jas per, a detective in the Bronx District Attorney's squad; John Bray, a sergeant in the Ja maica, Queens, station; Louis Colangelo, a lieutenant in the trial commissioner's office, and James Murphy, a patrolman as signed to Police Headquarters.

title: U.N. and Citizens Group Join in Narcotics Fight
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. June 16United Nations of ficials and an American citi zens' group are planning a new worldwide fight against illicit traffic in narcotics.

title: Danielle Darrieux Due To Play Lead of Coco
description: Danielle Darrieux, the French stage and screen star, has been selected to succeed Katharine Hepburn in Coco, the musical based on the life of Coco Chanel, the French fashion designer. Miss Hepburn will give her final perfotrnance in the show, currently at the Mark Hel linger, on Aug. 1.

title: Recovery of 76 Miners' Bodies Delayed
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The recovery of the bodies of 76 miners trapped by a West Vir ginia explosion a year and a half ago may be delayed for up to two more years, a United States Bureau of Mines official reported today.

title: PROFIT MARK SEEN BY CENTRAL SOYA
description: The Central Soya Company, the nation's second largest soy bean processor and sixth larg est producer of broilers, ex pects to show the highest sales and earnings in its history for the fiscal year ending August 31, a spokesman for the Ft. Wayne, Ind.based company de clared yesterday.

title: Suit Will Press Ban on Useless Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, June 16  A lawsuit that may cause conster nation in the pharmaceutical, industry will be filed against the Food and Drug Administra tion tomorrow in an effort to force the Government to bar, useless drugs from the market.

title: 2 Black Nationalists Freed
description: DETROIT, June 16 (UPI)A jury today found two black nationalists not guilty of killing one policeman and shooting another outside a meeting of the Republic of New Africa more than a year ago. The jury of 10 Negroes and two whites acquitted Rafael Viera, 22 years old, a Puerto Rican from New York, and Clarence Fuller, 26, a Detroit Negro.

title: JAIL MATRON DEAD, 2 WOMEN ARE HELD
description: LOCKPORT, N. Y., June 16 Three women prisoners at the Niagara County Jail here were charged today with murder in the death of a 67yearold jail matron during what appeared to be an attempt to escape.

title: LORD THURSO, LED BRITISH LIBERALS
description: LONDON, June 16Viscount Thurso, wartime Air Minister and a former leader of the Liberal party, died last night at his home in Twickenham, a London suburb. He was 79 years old.

title: News Summary and Index
description: WEDNESDAY, JUNE 17, 1970

title: M'ANDREW VICTOR AGAINST MERRITT
description: .The mighty Mets, shrugging aside intermittent showers as easily as they did the Cincin nati Reds, posted an 81 victory at Shea Stadium last night in a game that lasted a couple of minutes vast midnight.

title: GOVERNOR SPEAKS ON ENVIRONMENT
description: Governor Rockefeller told in dustrialists at a conference on the environment yesterday that their sector of society should work to strike a balance, rather than a competition, be tween the economy and the ecology_

title: Samuels Detects Shift
description: SYRACUSE, June 16  Mr. Samuels, making his final swing through the upstate area he hopes Will provide him a heavy vote in the Democratic guber natorial primary, told support ers that his onceconfident op ponent was now desperate.

title: Corruption Inquiry Counsel
description: Michael F. Armstrong, a for mer United States Attorney who prosecuted the financier Louis E. Wolfson, yesterday was named chief counsel to the special commission investigat ing corruption in the city. The fiveman commission was created by Mayor Lindsay last month after a survey by The York Times disclosed wide spread corruption in the Police Department.

title: Prof. Raymond E. Davis
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 16  Prof. Raymond E. Davis, an Authority on engineering mate rials, whose research helped in the construction of the Golden Gate and San FranciscoOak land Bay Bridges as well as the Hoover and Grand Coulee Dams, died in his sleep here Sunday night, his birthday. He was 85 years old.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Casino Strike Spreads To Monte Carlo Hotels
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, June 16 (AP)A strike has closed the Monte Carlo Casino and spread today to some of the principal hotels and restaurants in Monaco.

title: Cambodian City Retaken, But Enemy Troops Escape
description: KOMPONG SPEU, Cambodia, June 16South Vietnamese and Cambodian infantry and armored units drove into this provincial capital and regional military headquarters today but found that the large enemy force they had hoped to trap had vanished.

title: Kathryn Horkan Wed To Andrew Campbell
description: UPPERVILLE, Va., June 16 Miss Kathryn Halliday Hor kan, a granddaughter of re tired Maj. Gen. George Anthony Horkan, former quartermaster general of the Army, was married this afternoon to Andrew Wilson Campbell.

title: 7 Long Branch Policemen Indicted in Firehouse Orgy
description: FREEHOLD, N. J., June 16 (UPI)A grand jury indicted seven members of the Long Branch, N. J., Police Depart ment today in connection with an alleged firehouse orgy May 18 involving the 17year old daughter of a minister. an alleged firehouse orgy May 18 involving the 17year old daughter of a minister.

title: Public TV Questions Left for Further Meetings
description: HYANNIS, Mass., June 16  As public television program managers this week were dis cussing ways to make their fall program schedules appealing to general audiences, other repre sentatives of the various segments within public broad casting have been speculating privately on the immediate and longrange future of their medium.

title: Hanoi Sees All Indochina as an Arena
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 North Vietnam has announced that it will fight shoulder to shoulder with the fraternal peoples of Laos and Cam bodia. The pledge is being viewed here as a commitment by Hanoi to merge the hostili ties in South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia into a single inte grated Indochin amilitary the ater.

title: McGrath Moves Upward
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 16 (AP) Mike McGrath of El Cerrito, Calif., moved into third place in the Professional Bowlers As sociation money standing with a sixthplace finish at Portland, Ore. McGrath's earnings total $26,260, Don Johnson of Akron is first with $36,390, and Dave Davis of Miami second with $27,360.

title: Anniversaries
description: DANIELNoah and Muriel. To mom and dad on their 25th.

title: Taxes Curb Vendor, 14
description: LEOMINSTER, Mass. (UPI) John David DiPrima is 14 years old and sells night crawlers to fishermen for 2 cents each as bait. Agents of the State Tax Commission called at his home recently to warn him that as a vendor he must have a permit, and he must collect the 3 per cent sales tax and turn it over to the state.

title: 5 ExParticipants of Programs Of Fresh Air Fund Win Honors
description: Five former participants in the Fresh Air Fund's free sum mer vacation programs have been awarded full $700 scholar ships for summer sessions of the Encampment for Citizen ship, a nonprofit organization that trains teenagers for com munity leadership.

title: Katharine Emmet Bride of David True
description: GLEN HEAD, L. L, June 16 The marriage of Miss Katha rine Temple Emmet to David Fulmer True, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis W. True of Mari etta, Ohio, took place here today at the home of Mrs. Richard Stockton Emmet, mother of the bride.

title: Market Place
description: William J. Haight is no runofthemill stock analyst. No, he's not a producer of instant research on farflung corporate empires. Far from it.

title: Gratz College Dean Elected Head
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16 The election of Dr. Elazar Goelman as president of Gratz College, the oldest Hebrew teachers' college in the Western Hemisphere, was announced here today.

title: Soviet and Indochina
description: MOSCOW, June 16Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indo nesia and colleagues from Japan and Malaysia flew here today and Secretary General Thant arrives tomorrow on separate but similar missions: to per suade Moscow to use its good offices to get negotiations started to end the fighting now spreading through out Indochina. But despite the burst of diplomatic ac tivity, the mood in Moscow these days is not encouraging for an early end to the bloodshed. Soviet officials have been advising dip lomats that while they will be happy to talk with the Asian envoys, they will probably not have much in a positive way to tell them about negotiations. despite the burst of diplomatic ac tivity, the mood in Moscow these days is not encouraging for an early end to the bloodshed. Soviet officials have been advising dip lomats that while they will be happy to talk with the Asian envoys, they will probably not have much in a positive way to tell them about negotiations.

title: Rogers News Conference Due Before Asian Trip
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) Secretary of State William P. Rogers will hold a news conference before he leaves on a Southeast Asian trip at the end of next week, Carl Bartch, his press officer, said today.

title: Cahill Signs Bill Merging Medical Schools in Jersey
description: TRENTON, June 16 (AP) Gov. William T. Cahill signed into law today his controversial measure merging the adminis trations of the Rutgers. Medical School and the New Jersey Col lege of Medicine and Dentistry.

title: Congressional Primaries
description: In New York City as a whole, where registered Dem ocrats outnumber all other voters by three to one, the Democratic nomination in a number of Congressional districts is virtually the equivalent of election. This the case in those of the city's primary contests dis cussed below, in which the Democratic choice in the June 23 elections will almost certainly be the winner in November. In the one Westchester district listed, an equivalent situation exists except that it is the Republicans who are in the overwhelming majority.

title: 84 Countries Convene to Fight Airline Hijackings and Sabotage
description: MONTREAL, June 16  Dele gates representing 84 countries opened an emergency session of the International Civil Avia tion Organization here today to plan measures to combat the extended wave of hijackings and sabotage against airliners.

title: A.E.C. Environmental Office
description: WASHINGTON, June 16A special Office of Environmental Affairs was created by the Atomic Energy Commission to day to help it meet its respons ibilities to the nation in that field. The new office will be headed by Joseph J. DiNunno, who for the last nine months has been the general manager's assistant for environmental af fairs.

title: Washington: A Small Staff in an Open Administration?
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 When Richard Nixon ran for the Presidency, he promised that he would have a small White House staff, and after he won, he said he would run an open Administration with a strong Cabinet of independent thinkers.

title: 10,000 U.S. TROOPS STILL IN CAMBODIA
description: WASHINGTON, June 16De fense Department sources re vealed today that there were about 10,000 American troops still in Cambodia. The President has pledged that all United States troops will be out by June 30.

title: S.E.C. Examiner Suggests Penalizing Former Banker
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) A Securities and Exchange Commission examiner has rec ommended barring Thomas D. Ledwith, former head of the se curity clearance department of the Marine Midland Grace Trust Company, New York, from en gaging in the securities busi ness.

title: DRAFT CHIEF BARS EXEMPTION BASED ON PERSONAL CODE
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 The Selective Service Director, Curtis W. Tarr, announced to day stringent new standards to be applied by draft boards to determine if young men can qualify for exemptions as con scientious objectors under yes terday's Supreme Court deci sion.

title: NIXON MAY BEGIN CAMPAIGN TO STEM WAGEPRICE RISES
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 President Nixon will embark on a more formalized education al campaign tomorrow to help check the rise in prices and wages, officials indicated today.

title: Stock Prices Surge As Dow Gains 18.90
description: This rally came out of the blue, a Wall Street secretary declared yesterday. On Mon day, the market looked dead.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Wednesday, June 17, 1970

title: Student Arrested at Beach; Accused of Desecrating Flag
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 16 (AP) A New York City student was arrested at Jones Beach today, and the police said he was rolling in the sand while wrapped in an American flag.

title: PRICES IN LONDON RALLY STRONGLY
Opera: Resnik's Carmen
description: Regina Resnik, who will be honored on the occasion of her 25th anniversary season as a Metropolitan Opera artist at a performance of Carmen on Friday night, assumed the title role in the opera on Monday night for the first time this season at the Met. Miss Resnik is, of course, a famous interpreter of Bizet's shady lady, and an unconventional one. Her Carmen came on like a com bination of alley cat and Mae West, swaggering and blowing cigarette smoke in men's eyes.

title: Roundup: A Grand Slam Decides Another Game
description: The argument over whether the ball is livelier this year goes on without a definitive decision, but there's no doubt that it has been lively in June with the bases loaded.

title: Employes at Newsday File For U.A.W. Representation
description: Maureen O'Neill, chairman of a unionorganizing committee at Newsday, said yesterday that a petition had been filed with the National Labor Rela tions Board here by editorial employes seeking to be repre sented in collective bargaining by the United Automobile Workers.

title: APOLOGY IS ASKED BY INDUSTRIALIST
description: Howard J. Samuels charged yesterday that Arthur J. Gold berg had sugested he was injecting racism into their campaign for the Democratic nomination for Governor. Mr. Goldberg emphatically denied the charge.

title: Ribella Dedines In States Using Vaccine Widely
description: German measles vaccine ap pears to be reducing the in cidence of the disease in states where the vaccine is widely used, the National Foundation March of Dimes said yesterday.

title: Kickback Bid Linked to Newark Work
description: TRENTON, June 16The president of an engineering concern testified today that he told the Newark City Council in 1965 that his company was withdrawing froin a sewer project because it was too busy, when it actually wanted to get out because of a kickback de mand.

title: Ohio Study Upholds Reports of Illegal Loans From State Treasury
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 16 A monthlong investigation of State Treasurer John D. Her bert's office has upheld re ports that a Herbert campaign contributor was allowed to arrange illegal loan of state funds for which the contribu tor's company received hun dreds of dollars in fees.

title: Hospital Union Here Uses Documentary Film to Stress a Point
description: In an unusual tactic in labor negotiations, Local 1199 of the Drug and Hospital Union yesterday showed a 28minute documentary movie on the 113day hospital strike last year in Charleston, S. C., to negotiators here for city's vol untary hospitals. The local is seeking a new contract for 22,000 workers.

title: Apollo 14 Craft Tested
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 16 (UPI)Two Apollo 14 astro nauts, Capt. Alan B. Shepard and Comdr. Edgar D. Mitchell of the Navy successfully tested their moon landing spacecraft today in a large steel chamber duplicating the vacuum of space. Captain Shepard, Com mander Mitchell and Maj. Stuart A. Roosa of the Air Force are scheduled to set out on the nation's fourth moon landing expedition Dec. 3.

title: In a Cambodian Town, War and Terror
description: KOMPONG CHHNANG, Cambodia, June 16No one got any sleep last night in Kompong Chhnang.

title: ELSA TRIOLET, 73, FRENCH NOVELIST
description: PARIS, June 16  Elsa Triolet, the Goncourt  prize winning novelist who was the wife of Louis Aragon, the poet, died of heart failure to day. Her age was 73.

title: Business Is Warned On Use of Narcotics
description: Manhattan business leaders were warned yesterday that the narcotics problem in industry was spreading and were urged to sharpen their detection methods.

title: AMERICAN YACHTS SCORE 2D SWEEP
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 16 The second of four races in the international team sailing for the Onion Patch Trophy pro duced another sweep of the first three places for the United States today, but again the of ficial outcome was inconclusive.

title: JUDGE'S SUIT SEEKS FUNDS TO RUN COURT
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16  President Judge Vincent A. Carroll of the Philadelphia Com mon Pleas Court brought suit in his own court today for ad ditional funds with which to operate the court.

title: Trial in Sharon Tate Killing Gets Under Way on Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 16 (AP) The longdelayed trial of four members of a nomadic clan charged with murdering actress Sharon Tate and six others be gan today, with each prospec tive juror questioned privately about the influence, if any, of pretrial publicity.

title: Incumbents Sweep to Victory In Long Island Village Tests
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 16In Nassau County's four contested village elections today, chal lengers generally failed to oust incumbent officials seeking re election.

title: Easy to Care For, The New Hairdo Named The Ape
description: Do you know The Ape? It's not the latest dance craze or a sciencefiction movie, but a scraggly, shaggy haircut that's turning up on socialites, secretaries, movie actresses, and rockgroups.

title: JOHN C. GEBHART, 83, LED N.A.M. RESEARCH
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 16 John C. Gebhart, former di rector of research for the Na tional Association of Manufac turers, died yesterday in a nursing home here. He was 83 years old.

title: Philadelphia Broker Firm Joins New York Concern
description: The merger of Woodcock, Moyer, Fricke & French, Inc., a Philadelphia  based brokerage house, and Cummings & Tay lor, Inc,, a New York brokerage concern, Was announced yes terday, Both companies are members of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Jamee Becker, P. H. Guilbert Plan to Marry
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 16Miss James Becker, a model and a screen and tele vision actress, will be mar ried July 18 to Dr. Philippe Heeni Guilbert, who, under a grant from the French Gov ernment, is a teaching fellow at the University of Califor nia at Los Angeles.

title: Indiana Democrats on War
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 16 The Indiana Democratic State Convention adopted today a resolution urging prompt and orderly disengagement of American forces from South east Asia.

title: 100 Tornadoes Reported
description: KANSAS CITY, June 16 (AP) Nearly 100 tornadoes were reported in the United States in a sixday period that ended this morning, the United States Weather Bureau said 25 of them in Kansas.

title: Decline Reported in Tars And Nicotine in Cigarettes
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI)The Federal Trade Com mission reported today a net decline in nicotine and tars in cigarettes compared with pre vious tests in November.

title: Reagan Asks Resignation
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 16Gov. Ronald Reagan said today that Mr. Rhodes should resign from the commission for, charging that Mr. Reagan was bent on killing people for his own political gain.

title: $30,000 Braque Painting Missed After Exhibition
description: PORT HURON, Mich., June 16 (AP)A valuable Painting by Georges Braque, owned by the Detroit Institute of Arts, is missing here according to the police.

title: 4 Hurt in Army Film Blast
description: An explosion at the United States Army Pictorial Center at 3511 35th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, yesterday injured four persons, at least one of them seriously. Army officials said the blast was caused either by a shortcircuit of a disinte grating machine, used to de stroy classified material, or by combustion of chemicals around the machine. The damage to the Army facility, which makes and stores Army films, was de scribed as very minor.

title: ExHockey Player Dies
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 16 (AP)Gerald W. Kilmartin, 42 years old, of Providence, mem ber of the 1952 Olympic hockey team who was assaulted Sun day in Newport, died last night in Rhode Island Hospital. He had been in critical condition since Sunday.

title: U.S. Backs Job Test Protest by Blacks
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)  The Nixon Administration urged the Supreme Court today to invalidate job tests that tend to prevent Negro workers from advancing without measuring their ability to do the job.

title: Old Tappan Police Chief In Gift Case Is Dismissed
description: OLD TAPPAN, N. J., June 17 (AP)The police chief of this Bergen County community has been dismissed by the Borough Council that he accepted gifts and authorized members of his department to take gifts from a reputed Mafia leader.

title: Sees Gains if We Are Not At Each Other's Throats
description: NEWARK, June 17Mayor elect Kenneth A. Gibson de clared today that under his administration Newark no long er will be a place of fear, and he called on the energies of all the people hereblack and whiteto build a new city.

title: Football Signings
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: 19th Test for Navy Missile
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 17 (UPI)The Navy fired its 19th Poseidon missile from land today in a test leading up to the rocket's maiden launch ing from a submarine this sum mer. The 34foot missile, carry ing a multiple warhead assem bly, streaked more than 1,500 miles to an Atlantic Ocean tar get area. It has a range of 2,800 miles.

title: Dartmouth Five Gets Aide
description: HANOVER, N. H., June 17 (UPI)Thomas J. O'Connor, an outstanding guard on Assump tion College's basketball team from 196468, was named to day assistant basketball coach at Dartmouth College. O'Con nor, from Union City, N. J., has been head basketball coach at Clinton (Mass.) High School the last two years. At Dart mouth, he will work under the head coach, George Blaney.

title: How Wall St. Journal Runs Its News as Ad
description: You'd be surprised about the number of people who were asking in amazement yesterday, Goodness, how does The Wall Street Journal run today's front page as an ad in today's New York Times? Well it's not easy, believe it.

title: HERMAN SHER,WROTE GUIDEBOOK ON TAXES
description: I. Herman Sher, a retired tax lawyer and author, died Mon day of a heart attack aboard the Jason, during a cruise of the Greek islands. He was 70 years old and lived at 45 Sut ton Place South.

title: Article 1  No Title
Heyerdahl at Midway Point
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., June 17 (UPI)Aided by good weather, Thor Heyerdahl's papyrus boat Ra II has passed the midway point in its Atlantic voyage and shoudl reach the West Indies in four weeks, the crew reported by radio yesterday.

title: CHANGES IN COURTS AND PRISONS ASKED
description: More state financial aid to local police forces, streamlined court procedures and more adequate prison rehabilitation programs were urged yester day by Arthur J. Goldberg.

title: A Plant Shop Is Nothing to Laugh At
description: It could be because Phyllis means green leaf in Latin.

title: Dance: Massine's Gaite Parisienne
description: Even the best of ballet companies need a few bad ballets, if only to keep people who like bad ballets happy. I was surprised, however, seeing the American Ballet Theater's new production of Leonide Massine's Gant Pari sienne last night at the New York State Theater to note how surprisingly bad it is.

title: Labor Still Has the Edge As Britain Ballots Today
description: LONDON, Thursday, June 18 The governing Labor party went into the election today as a firm favorite despite some lastminute wavering in the publicopinion polls.

title: Senators Hear How Carolina Schools Integrate Whites, Blacks and Indians
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 You know, Mr. Oxendrine, the Indian boy told his prin cipal, some of these white boys are not as smart as I am.

title: U.S. Spy Plane Collides With a Refueling Craft
description: EL PASO, Tex., June 17 (UPI)  An Air Force SR71 spy plane collided today with a tanker during inflight re fueling and crashed, injuring two crewmen.

title: Pig Day to Honor Police
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala., June 17 (AP)City officials have set aside Saturday, July 18, as Pig Day in honor of all law enforcement agencies of the city and county. In conjunction with Pig Day, the Tuscaloosa Sertoma Club announced yes terday that it was planning a watermelon cutting for the day and would distribute 10,000 lapel buttons and 10,000 bump er stickers bearing the slogan Pride, Integrity and Guts. The buttons will say I'm a PIG Rooter.

title: Skulnik Leaves $100,000
description: Menasha Skulnick, the Yid dish comedy actor who died June 4 at the age of 78, has left the bulk of his $100,000 estate to his wife, Anna, it was disclosed yesterday, when his will was offered for probate in Manhattan Surrogate's Court.

title: Nordwig of E. Germany Vaults Record 1710
description: BERLIN, June 17 (AP) Wolfgang Nordwig of East Germany surpassed the listed world polevault record to day when he vaulted 17 feet 10 inches at a meet involv ing East Berlin athletes, ADN, the official East Ger man news agency reported.

title: FLORIDA STATE NINE GAINS N.C.A.A. FINAL
description: OMAHA, June 17 (UPI)  The Florida State Seminoles eliminated the Texas Longhorns from the National Collegiate Athletic Association college world series tonight, 112, to earn the right to play Southern California's Trojans in the championship contest tomorrow night.

title: COURT BARS ADDING FINE AFTER 2D TRIAL
description: In a decision that sets a prec edent here, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit held yesterday that a convicted man who appeals and loses the second time around cannot be fined after the sec mid conviction if he was not fined after the first.

title: Suspicion A 2Edged Sword for Jersey Mountain People
description: MAHWAH, N. J.  Just across Route 17 from the Ford plant here there is a truck stop where a road be gins snaking up Stag Hill to an isolated community of mountain people who still cling to the hard, rocky soil of the Ramapos that their an cestors settled in Revolution ary times.

title: Bonn's Envoy in Brazil Gives An Account of His Kidnapping
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 17 (Reuters)The West. German Ambassador, Ehrenfried von Holleben, tonight described how guerrilla kidnappers forced him to crouch into a wooden box, pressed an ethersoaked patch over his face and took him to their hideout last Thurs day.

title: Soyuz 9 Sets a Record
description: Congratulations are in order for the crew of Soyuz 9 which has broken the spaceflight duration record set by this country's Gemini 7 back in December. 1965.

title: Lack of Witnesses Delays CourtMartial in Vietnam
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 17(Reuters)The trial of a United States marine accused of the murder of 16 Vietnamese women and children was ad journed today because two wit nesses were missing and a third was sick with malaria.

title: Sanitationmen Back Badillo
description: Former Bronx Borough Pres ident Herman Badillo, who is seeking the House seat from the 21st Congressional District, received the endorsement yes terday of the Uniformed Sani tationmen's Association.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Thursday, June 18, 1970

title: Nixon's Talk Disappoints Traders in Bond Markets
description: The credit markets listened to President Nixon's speech on the economy yesterday, and they found it unsurprising and disappointing.

title: Verbal Posturing, Mr. Agnew?
description: At first glance, Vice President Agnew's demand that Joseph Rhodes Jr. resign from the President's Com mission on Campus Unrest because he has engaged in verbal posturing looks like deliberate parody. Mr. Agnew would seem to have a personal stake in not making verbal posturing an offense that disquali fies one from public office.

title: Upstate Man Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)The Defense Department announced today the names of 12 men killed in the Indochina war. Among them was Stefano Giardina of Buffalo, a specialist 4 of the Army.

title: Corelli's Sore Throat Delays Boheme 3d Act 20 Minutes
description: The thirdact curtain of the Metropolitan Opera Company's performance of La Bohme was held for about 20 minutes last night while medication was administered to the tenor Franco Corelli, who complained of a sore throat, a spokesman for the opera said.

title: 8 Arrested at Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (Reu ters)Eight war protesters, all men, were arrested today by Defense Department policemen after they held an unauthorized religious service at the Penta gon. It was the third day of demonstrations organized by the Episcopal Youth Fellowship in the Pentagon's main shop ping area. So far, 29 persons have been arrested.

title: Garden Plans Deal
description: The Madison Square Garden Corporation and the Trans nation Development Corpora tion, which recently sought ownership of Roosevelt Race way, Inc., announced yes terday a merger plan of their own.

title: KERENSKY IS BURIED AT RITES IN LONDON
description: LONDON, June 17 Alexan der Kerensky was buried today in a small cemetery here, an exile who yearned vainly to re turn one day to his Russian homeland.

title: Personal Finance
description: Last year, Congress enacted the Tax Reform Act 1969, the most massive overhaul of tax law in the nation's history. The following article is the eighth in a series that periodically will examine the implications for personal money management of the changes that were adopted.

title: BILL TO LOWER VOTING AGE TO 18 BY THE '71 ELECTIONS APPROVED IN HOUSE, 272132
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 The House approved and sent to President Nixon today a bill to lower the voting age from 21 to 18 in all Federal, state and local elections beginning in 1971. The measure would open the political process to about 11 million young people.

title: Police Accuse Surgeon Here Of Shooting Gun Into Street
description: A 38yearold orthopedic surgeon was arrested yesterday after he fired four shots into the street from his apartment at 15 West 72d Street, ac cording to the police.

title: Soviet Affirms Opposition To New Indochina Parley
description: MOSCOW, June 17The So viet Union affirmed its opposi tion today to the convening of an international conference for negotiating an end to the fight ing in Indochina.

title: SINGLE BY MCRAE BREAKS DEADLOCK
description: Cincinnati's welladvertised scoring punch, held in check by the New York Mets for 16 in nings of a twogame series, as serted itself in the last two frames at Shea Stadium last night and produced a 74 vic tory, which gave the Reds a split.

title: OilSoaked Ducks Helped
description: CRANFORD, N. J., June 17 This town has built a pen on the Union College campus here for 50 ducks that were soaked by oil from a spill on the Rah way River in Union.

title: SCHOOL COMPLEX DUE IN BROOKLYN
description: Plans for a $16million com bined public school and 420 unit lowincome apartment proj ect in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn were announced yes terday by the New York City Educational Construction Fund.

title: O.E.O., in Shift, Will Back VISTA Draft Deferments
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI The director of the Office of Economic Opportunity has told VISTA volunteers that he will support their efforts to get oc cupational draft deferments if they asked for the deferment before April 23.

title: 3 U.S. Judges Rule Laws on Abortion Invalid in Texas
description: DALLAS, June 17 (AP)Tex as' abortion laws were declared unconstitutional today by a threejudge Federal panel that said the statutes infringed on the right of women to choose whether they wanted to bear children.

title: 3 OneActers on Films Serve as Boost for TV
description: Sold to the Movies is apparently dedicated to the proposition that you should not be in the Gotham Art Theater watching Sold to the Movies.

title: Students to Aid Students In City Narcotics Project
description: The Board of Education ap proved last night a program to train students in 16 high schools to work with fellow students and the schools' staffs in com bating narcotics use.

title: State Blames Penn Central For Deaths of Trespassers
description: Many of the fatal accidents to trespassers on the Penn Cen tral's tracks in the Bronx have been caused by the railroad's lax surveillance and security. the State Attorney General's of fice said yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Saigon's War Captives

title: Students to Be Reinstated
description: BOSTON, June 17 (UPI)A Federal judge ordered four Mas sachusetts school districts to day to reinstate students who had been suspended because of long hair. Judge Charles Wy zanski Jr. of the District Court handed down the ruling in the cases of Stephen Benjamin of Whitman, Mark Estes of Town send, Alden Southwick of Barre and Bruce Sanderson of Oak ham. The cases had been held up while the court waited for a decision on a similar case from the United States Court of Appeals.

title: African Countries Get Loans
description: Interestfree loans totaling $13.98million for improvement of road transportation in three of Africa's landlocked countries were announced yesterday by the International Development Association, softloan affiliate of the World Bank. The loans, which will strengthen shipment links with coastal countries, were made to Rwanda ($9.3 million), the Central African Republic ($4.3million) and Bu rundi ($380,000).

title: A BELLE, A LOOK, AND 75 CANDLES
description: A slight smile creased Jack Dempsey's face last night as a Dempsey punch smashed Jess Willard into the ropes. The crowd gasped at Madison Square Garden and Dempsey inhaled on his cigar.

title: $100,000 Award Made in Cahill Auto Injury Suit
description: CAMDEN, N. J., June 17 (UPI)Gov. William T. Cahill and his daughter. Patricia were awarded $100,000 today in an outofcourt settlement of a suit filed in connection with the auto accident that left Miss Cahill paralyzed for several weeks last summer.

title: Antigambling Unit Is Termed Corrupt At Policeman's Trial
description: A Bronx assistant district at torney said yesterday that an investigation had found that almost all the policemen as signed to suppress gambling in the southwest Bronx were corrupt.

title: Biologist Calls on Industrialists To Stress Quality Over Quantity
description: Modern industrial societies can survive only if they out grow the growth myth and if they make quality rather than quantity of production the criterion of their success, Dr. Rene Dubos, Rockefeller Uni versity biologist, told a gather ing of industrialists and pollu tioncontrol experts yesterday.

title: Riessen Sinks Smith in 2 Sets To Gain London Quarterfinals
description: LONDON. June 17Two Americans made their protest against next week's contro versial Wimbledon seeding by reaching the quarterfinals of the London grasscourt cham pionships today. Marty Riessen defeated the No. 7 seeded player, Stan Smith, 108, 62, on the strength of his heavily punched volleys and little Cliff Richey won, 62, 75, from Jaidip Mukerjea of India, who had knocked out 11thseeded Tom Okker yesterday.

title: Surgery for Two in Family
description: DENVER, June 17 (AP) Open heart surgery was per formed today on a brother and sister at the Colorado General Hospital. The children are Mar garet Salazar, 7 years old, and Matthew, 5, children of Santi ago Salazar of Sante Fe, N.M.

title: Economic Policy in Transition
description: President Nixon's message yesterday on the nation's economy bore the marks not only of struggles and compromises within the Administration but of uncer tainties within the President's own mind. Since Mr. Nixon has so often inveighed against wage and price restraints in the past, it must have been difficult for, him to move, however, slightly, in new directions.

title: PAPERS TO RESUME MAILER TALKS HERE
description: Bargaining agents for the International Typographical Union's New York Mailers' local and the city's four major daily newspapers returned from a twoday negotiating session in Colorado yesterday and ex pressed hope that the stalled negotiations could be revital ized.

title: U.S. Yachts Again Sweep Sailing
Cosmos 349 Launched
description: MOSCOW, June 17 (Reuters) The Soviet Union launched today an artificial earth satel lite designated Cosmos 349, Tass, the official press agency, reported.

title: GRAY SAYS RANGEL MISUSED CITY LOAN
description: Jesse Gray charged yester day that Assemblyman Charles B. Rangel had violated the con ditions of a $39,500 municipal loan by living rent free in a Harlem apartment house he had inherited. He demanded that Mr. Rangel turn the build ing over to poor people.

title: Floods in Puerto Rico
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 17 (UPI)A 25yearold woman was crushed under a rockslide today and a policeman drowned as rains flooded streams, blocked roads and isolated towns over much of the island. Waters reached the tops of cars in suburban Puerto Nuevo.

title: Post Endorses Candidates
description: The New York Post yesterday endorsed Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor and Paul O'Dwyer for Senator in the Democratic prix mary next Tuesday. The Post also endorsed Basil A. Paterson for Lieutenant Governor and Adam Walinsky for Attorney General.

title: Productivity Is a Mainspring of Growth in Economy
description: When President Nixon an nounced his decision yesterday to create a National Commis sion on Productivity, he was focusing on one of the main springs of growth in the econo my. For over the long run, eco nomic growth arises only from two factorsthe increase in the size of the labor force that is at work and gains in the amount of output that this labor force can produce for each unit of labor input.

title: Promenades Pay Tribute To Danube of Yesteryear
description: Each summer, for its cham pagne  washed Promenades concerts, when the New York Philharmonic removes the mainfloor seats at Philhar monic Hall in favor of round tables and somewhat square music, an effort is made to spice up these popular pro grams with oddities. At Tues day night's concert led by Andr Kostelanetz the spicy number was Liszt's nunga rian Fantasy, with Earl Wild as piano soloist.

title: Chess:
description: The recent European Zonal tournament No. 1 in Praia da Rocha was the first time Por tugal was host to such an important chess event.

title: McCarthy Thwarted in Attempt To Explore 5th Ave. Manhole
description: Representative Richard Max McCarthy, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Sen ator, was thwarted yesterday as he sought to climb down a steel ladder in a Fifth Avenue manhole to see what repairs and installations the New York Telephone Company was mak ing under midtown streets.

title: EDWARD T. MICIEK
description: ROSELLE, N. J., June 17 Edward T. Miciek of 525 Maple wood Avenue, Union County Bridge Superintendent and for mer president of the borough council here, died last night at the Elizabeth General. Hospital in Elizabeth. His age was 51.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Jerry Quarry came out of the west in 1966 to take his rightful place in a promising batch of young heavyweights that included Joe Frazier, Buster Mathis, Tony Alongi, Tony Doyle, Jim Woody and some forgotten. He had al ready fought a draw with Doyle and in the next four years he would fail to win every fight he had to win: two draws with Alongi, a draw with Floyd Patterson followed by an unpopular victory, a loss to Jimmy Ellis for the World Boxing Association title, a knockout by Frazier for the New York Stateplus title and a knockout, last Decem ber, by George Chuvalo.

title: C5A Woes Linked to Lack of Control
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 Air Force Secretary Robert C. Seamans Jr. suggested today that the troubleplagued history of the C5A supertransport air plane might have been different had the service obtained great er control over its development and production.

title: CITY U. RISE LOOMS IN GRADUATE FEES
description: Frederick H. Burkhardt, chair man of the city's Board of Higher Education, announced yesterday that there would be no increase in undergraduate student fees at City University next autumn.

title: Mrs. Dempsey's 153 Ties Mrs. Cici for Links Lead
description: JERICHO, L. I., June 17Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of Piping Rock, the metropolitan champion, carded 40, 3878 for a twoday aggregate of 153 and tied Mrs. Pat Cici of Cedarbrook for the lead in the 36th Women's Long Island Golf Association 54hole medal play championship at the Meadow Brook club today.

title: Russell Sage College Appoints 5th President
description: The appointment of Dr. Charles U. Walker, dean of Hemline University in St. Paul, Minn., as the fifth pres ident of Russell Sage College, was announced yesterday by the college's board of trustees.

title: NO MANSON JURORS PICKED AFTER 2 DAYS
description: LOS ANGELES, June 17  The chore of choosing a jury in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three codefend ants moved into its second day today with not a single juror yet seated.

title: Executive Changes
description: William McChesney Martin Jr., former chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Mrs. Jessie Ban croft Cox, widow of the late William C. Cox, have been elected directors of Dow Jones & Co., Inc. Mr. Cox had served on the board from 1946 until his death last month.

title: Fall From Car Kills Youth
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 17 James McGrath, 18 years old, of 118 Spring Hill Avenue, died today at Norwalk Hospital as a result of injuries suffered in an unusual accident at Con necticut Avenue. He was one of several youths helping a friend to start a disabled automobile and fell from the trunk of a car being pushed by another, strik ing his head on the pavement. He was the son of Patrick Mc Grath, a policeman here.

title: Mattingly Gets License
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 17 (UPI)  Lieut. Comdr. Thomas K. Mattingly 2d of the Navy, the astronaut who missed the neardisastrous Apollo 13 moon mission be cause of exposure to German measles, was issued a mar riage license on Monday. The bridetohe is Elizabeth Daily, listed on the license only as from California. Commander Mattingly became an astro naut in April, 1966.

title: Negotiations Ended By GAC and Levin
description: The GAC Corporation and the LevinTownsend Computer Cor poration announced yesterday termination of negotiations for the sale of LevinTownsend to GAC and the simultaneous loan of $20million to LevinTown send from the General Accept ance Corporation, the finance unit of GAC.

description: King Hussein's brave attempt to reassert his author ity in Amman at an elaborately staged press confer ence yesterday cannot conceal a radical transformation in Jordan that must profoundly affect prospects for a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: Deborah Korenblatt Of Cornell Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Kor enblatt of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deb orah Korenblatt, to Joseph P. Norelli. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Angelo A. Norelli of Eastchester. N. Y.

title: Coach Gets Added Duties
description: HAMPDEN, Va., June 17 (AP) J. Stokeley Fulton, head foot ball and baseball coach at HampdenSydney College, will take over the added duties of athletic director July 1, the school announced today.

description: CARACAS, Venezuela June 17 (UPI)Nine armed men took over the small town of Obispos late yesterday, disarmed the fiveman police force and sacked business establishments, it was reported today.

J.; Patricia Stewart of New York; Mimi Kanarek of New York, and Sylvia Hooks of Newark, seed ed in that order, won theft quarterfinal matches today in the Women's Eastern clay courts tennis tournament at Orienta Beach Club. courts tennis tournament at Orienta Beach Club.

title: 17 Held for Knoxville Jury
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 17  Seventeen persons were bound over from the City Court to the Knox County grand jury today on charges of disturbing public worship when President Nixon visited a rally by the Rev. Billy Graham in the Uni versity of Tennessee Stadium May 28. Bond for each was set at $1,000. Included in the group was Dr. Kenneth Newton, 47 carries a mandatory sentence of life imprisonment.

title: SYRIA SAYS ISRAELIS KILLED TWO AT BASE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 17 A Syrian military spokesman said today that two Syrian sol diers were killed and five slightly wounded in an attack by Israeli forces yesterday on the Syrian Army camp near Nebk. The town is 20 miles northeast of Damascus.

description: WASHINGTON, June 17 President Nixon eased today the nation's oil import quotas, authtorizing the purchase of 100,000 more barrels a day of foreign crude oil and 40,000 more barrels a day of home heating fuel for the states of the Northeastern Seaboard.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
Addabbo Wins Court Test

Ad dabbo of Queens was assured of reelection today after the Court of Appeals threw out the nominating petitions of a man who wanted to run against him in the Democratic primay. The court said that Seymour Fried man had failed to shift his party registration from Brook lyn to Queens in time to qualify as an enrolled Demo crat in the Seventh Congres sional District. Mr. Addabbo, a Democrat, already has been designated for another term by the Republican and Liberal parties.

title: U.S. Thrust Into Cambodia Called Success by Buckley
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 (AP)James L. Buck ley, the Conservative party's cnadidate for the United States Senate candidate from New York, described the allied thrust into Cambodian border areas today as a hell of a successful operation.

description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 17  Vietnamese Communist troops cut Cambodia's last working railway line today, capturing more than 200 tons of rice and other food supplies from a freight train about 40 miles northwest of here.

description: CHICAGO, June 17  Two Yankee winning streaks were snapped tonight as the club concluded a twogame visit to Comiskey Park with a 63 de feat at the hands of Jerry Janeski and the White Sox.

title: Prices Fail to Hold Gains on the Amex
Freed U.S. Doctor in Athens
description: ATHENS, June 17 (Reuters) Dr. Paul Shrum, an American physician who was held captive by Arab commandos in Jordan last week, arrived in Athens from Beirut tonight. Dr. Shrum, 45 years old, who is attached to the military aid group here, said his arrest seemed to have resulted from a case of mis taken identity.

description: A packed house that in cluded many dancers turned out last night at Kaufmann Concert Hall for a program that offered three premieres by Bertram Ross and the first revival in 18 years of Martha Graham's EL Penitente.

description: All along the East Coast concern is growing for the fish and shellfish that spend all or part of their lives in the fragile estuarine areas.

Y., June 17 John Gentile Jr. of the Pat terson Club, Fairfield, Conn., the medalist, won two matches at Sunningdale Country Club today to reach the quarterfinal round of the 51st annual West chester County Golf Associa tion championship but Gregory Zorila of Briar Hall, the de fending champion, was elimi nated in the second round.

title: Roberta Shapiro Is Wed in Boston
description: BOSTON, June 17Miss Roberta Shapiro and Marc E. Saperstein, graduate students at the Hebrew University in Jerusalem, were married this evening at Temple Israel.

description: A Federal judge denied a motion yesterday for a prelimi nary injunction to prevent Rep resentative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn from using his frank ing privileges to mail material intended to influence the pri mary election.

title: TRADING END SET FOR RYE FUTURES
description: After 112 years, rye futures will be suspended from trading next month on the Chicago Board of Trade. Beginning July 22, trades in rye futures for de livery in September and De cember, 1970, and May, 1971, will be permitted only for li quidation.

title: RAHIM OF U.C.L.A. DEFEATS LEONARD
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 17 (AP)  Southern California's faint hopes of retaining its Na tional Collegiate tennis title died today when topseeded Haroon Rahim of the favored University of California, Los Angeles, defeated Tom Leonard.

title: Incident Upsets Mrs. Wilson
description: LONDON, June 17 (UPI)A policeman's horse stepped on Mrs. Harold Wilson's toe today as the Prime Minister's wife was helping her husband cam paign in industrial Lancashire. An aide said that Mrs. Wilson had not been injured but that the incident had upset her.

title: Inflation Alert Something New in Economic Cures
description: WASHINGTON, June 17It is doubtful that President Nixon or any member of his economic team believes that the new inflation alert system he an nounced today will have an early or large effect in slowing the rise in prices. Nonetheless, it is an innovation not tried in this precise form in any other country  and nearly all indus trial countries have tried in one form or another, with little success, to influence private price and wage behavior short of mandatory analysis controls. The new system will involve periodic publication of an analysis by the Council of Economic Advisers of precisely what price increases have been important recently in raising the overall price level and, insofar as wages were a factor in pushing these prices up, the role of bargained wage settle ments.

title: Bergman and Quinn Are Stars Of 'A Walk in the Spring Rain'
description: Hardly anything seems real in "A Walk in the Spring Rain" except the blue-green haze of the authentic Smoky Mountain foliage, amid which there unfolds a dreary, tedious unconvincing drama of middle-aged love, that of a university professor's wife and a married, neighboring farmer.The picture, which came from a reportedly fine novel and co-stars Ingrid Bergman and Anthony Quinn, should have been a beauty. It's a bore. And the saddest thing about it is Miss Bergman's hope, as expressed in the film's promotion, for another "Brief Encounter." The picture moves self-consciously, like mountain molasses, under the direction of Guy Green, and the scenario by the producer, Sterling Silliphant, is a sketchily overstated exercise of no urgency and precious little warmth.With one exception, the five principal characters are vapid, dull and aimless people. Striving mightily and looking lovely, Miss Bergman sems merely a petulant woman who falls into the arms of Quinn for novelty, from boredom with her equally bored husband, Fritz Weaver, pecking away on a book in their temporary mountain retreat. Quinn, with his actor's image of a roaring, caged giant, is woefully miscast as a hearty, sweet-tempered mountaineer. Spying on the lovers, like a psychopathic young vulture, is Tom Fielding, as Quinn's son. As Quinn's sloppy wife, Virginia Gregg, one of Hollywood's best character players, droops around like a fugitive from Dogpatch. The exception is the character of Miss Bergman's daughter, a loving, sensible young woman, neatly played by Katherine Crawford. Briefly shown at the outset, she pops back into the picture at mid-point for a realistic mouthful that punctures it like a grounded balloon.

title: Cuisine That No Longer Has Homeland Is at Horne in Brooklyn
description: This is a kind of cooking, Copeland H. Marks said, that no longer exists as part of a total culture. It's from a civi lization that has, more or less, disap peared; it is the food of the Indian Jews of Calcutta.

title: Police Victim Gets $70,000
description: CHICAGO, June 17 (AP)An allwhite jury awarded $70,000 in damages yesterday to a black man who said that two policemen had violated his civil rights by beating him after they stopped him on a traffic charge. The Negro is Edward Shanks, 59 years old.

title: STOCK PRICES DIP AS VOLUME EASES
description: President Nixon's longex pected message on the economy had little, if any, effect on the stock market yesterday.

title: Militancy on Rise, Businessmen Are Told
description: William M. Kunstler, law yer for such militants as the Chicago Seven, warned a group of business executives here today that unless there is some shift in economic policies, some reconsidera tion of the concept of private property and some unequiv ocal act that would hasten the end of the Vietnam war, Armageddon is at hand.

title: In The Nation: Due Process for Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The office of the Attorney General of the State of New York has informed Federal Judge Con stance Baker Motley that one of her decisions, unprecedented in almost every aspect, had caused so much unrest among prisoners that it might become necessary to close the Wallkill State Prison. This is a short sighted response to a startling, perhaps historic, decision.

title: Screen: 'On a Clear Day You Can See Forever' Begins Its Run
description: Vincente Minnelli's "On a Clear Day You Can See Forever," the screen adaptation of the Alan Jay Lerner-Burton Lane musical play, is a movie of fits and starts, but because the fits are occasionally so lovely, and the starts somewhat more frequent than Fifth Avenue buses, I was eventually hypnotized into a state of benign though not-quite-abject permissiveness.The reasons have to do with nostalgia, and with expectation. "On a Clear Day" is the first conventional musical film to open this year, the first Minnelli musical since "The Bells Are Ringing" in 1960, and the first Barbra Streisand movie to suggesteven brieflythat she is capable of playing someone other than Fannie Brice in the seven stages of woman.The film, which opened yesterday at the Loew's State I and Loew's Cine Theaters, is solidly grounded in a casting coincidence: Barbra Streisand, a performer who sometimes seems too big for movies as well as for life, portrays a girl who is so full of life that she leads a succession of lives.Daisy Gamble (Miss Streisand), a normal, average, five-pack-a-day nicotine addict, who is also gifted with E.S.P., goes to see Dr. Marc Chabot (Yves Montand), a professor of psychiatry, about a quick cure for her smoking problems. In the course of treatment by hypnosis, she regresses to the early 19th century when she was one of England's most successful hangers-on at the Prince Regent's court. In a variation on the recurring Hitchcock theme of transferral of guilt, Daisy so enchants the doctor that she manages to transfer her fantasies to him, with the result that, from time to time, he finds himself transported into her earlier incarnation.Lerner's screenplay places great emphasis on its gags: (He: "Do you like painting?" She: "I don't knowI've gotten so used to wallpaper.") It seems often shaped to meet some very awkward song cues. However, it also dramatizes some attractively romantic ideas about love and the mystery of the life force. "On a Clear Day" may be the only comedy to end on the happy note that its lovers will be reunited in 2038 in, of all strange sites for reincarnation, Virginia.The movie is quite ordinary and Broadway-bland in most of its contemporary sequences. Miss Streisand, as a 22-year-old New Yorker whose Yiddish intonations are so thick they sound like a speech defect, defines innocence by sitting with her knees knocked together and her feet spread far apart, a mannerism she may have picked up from Mary Pickford.Minnelli's camera also is hard-pressed to find interesting things to look at in the humdrum settings (doctor's office, apartment, classrooms), and a lot of the time it just records exits and entrances, as if it all were taking place on a stage.However, the movie, Minnelli and Miss Streisand burst into life in the regression sequences, filmed at the Royal Pavilion at Brighton. Minnelli's love of dcor transforms the movie into very real fantasy, and the star into a stunning looking and funny character who mouths her arch, pseudo-Terence Rattigan lines as if she were parodying Margaret Leighton. She is so fine, in fact, that if I didn't know she was not terribly good at lip-sync, I would suspect someone else was reading her.The high-point of the film for me, and one of the most graceful Streisand moments ever put on film, is a royal dinner at which Minnelli's camera explores Miss Streisand in loving circling close-up while her voice is heard on the soundtrack singing "Love With All the Trimmings." It's lush lyricism from Minnelli's "Yolanda and the Thief period.The film has four other excellent songs, the title number, "Go to Sleep" (a duet featuring Miss Streisand and Miss Streisand), "What Did I Have That I Don't Have Now?" and "Come Back to Me," which Montand sings mostly on the soundtrack as a helicopter swoops around New York. Because the music is rather infrequent, it becomes all the more precious.It's apparently Montand's fate to be emasculated by big Hollywood actresses, and his role is largely that of a line-carrier for Streisand. He behaves himself like a gentleman, however, as do some other decent performers, including Bob Newhart, Larry Blyden and Jack Nicholson ("Easy Rider"), whose role, I understand, has been abbreviated.Nothing is allowed to get in the way of Miss Streisand, but Minnelli, unlike William Wyler (the director of "Funny Girl") and Gene Kelly (the director of "Hello, Dolly!"), has not been completely inhibited by her. He handles her gingerly (I have a feeling her comedy readings are all her own), but with an appreciation of her beauty and of the largely unrealized possibilities of her talent. Talent such as hers will not break when tested; it becomes enriched.

title: JACQUES L. VAUCLAIN

description: ARANYAPRATHET, Thailand, June 16  Srichai Luangsang thong, a Thai medicine sales man, was in this neighborhood this afternoon with some time to spare, so he crossed the frontier to take his first look at Cambodia.

description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 17 Isadore Katz, a labor lawyer and senior partner in the law firm of Lieberman, Katz  Aronson, died Sunday after a long illness at Long Island Jew ish Hospital in New Hyde Park. He was 68 years old and lived at 34 North Drive.

title: Blackout in Tijuana
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, June 17 (AP)A huge new power plant failed today, cutting off elec tricity throughout Tijuana, a border city of 335,000.

title: Miss Martha Coe to Be Bride Of Charles Frederick Irish Jr.
description: RUMSON, N. J., June 17 Mr. and Mrs. George Vernon Coe Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Bruce Coe, to Charles Frederick Irish Jr., son of Mrs. Mar garet Jensen Irish and Mr. Irish of Jacksonville, Fla., an architect. The wedding is planned for December.

title: Cambodia in Plea to U.N. To Protectangkor Rains

title: U.S.Aide Dies in Madagascar
description: TANANARIVE, Madegascar, June 17 (AP)Robert Richards, a 25yearold technician for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration from Audubon, N. J., drowned Sunday while boating in the Mangoro River, it was reported here today. Mr. Richards had been stationed in Tananarive since 1966.
