description: It may seem as if the en tire world is on a lowcalorie diet, but there are still enough people who eat cook ies and cake to make baking a rewarding task. And for those people, here are two recipes that would be good served with coffee or a tall glass of homemade lemonade.

title: SERIOUS CRIME UP IN THE U.S. BY 13%
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI)Serious reported crime in the United States increased 13 per cent during the first quarter of this year, compared to the like quarter in 1969 de spite the Nixon Administra tion's heavy emphasis on law and order.

title: RUNNERSUP GET MORE SERIES CASH
description: David L. Cole, an impartiall arbitrator selected jointly by the major league baseball owners and the Major League Players. Association, has direct ed the clubs to pay $82,420 in additional World Series shares to the four teams that finished second in their divisions in 1969.

title: Honeywell Strike Ended
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 22 (AP)Members of the Inter national Union of Electric Workers, Local 116, ratfied to day a new twoyear contract with the Honeywell Indsutrial Division at Fort Washington ending a twoweek strike.

title: Rubin Ordered to Jail
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) United States Appeals Court Judge Albert V. Bryan ordered Jerry Rubin, the Yippie leader, today to start serving a 30day jail sentence for disorderly con duct during antiwar demonstra tions in 1967. He will serve the term in the Alexandria, Va., city jail.

title: ARMS AIDE RETURNS TO U.S. FOR TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 Gerard C. Smith, chief United States negotiator at the talks with the Soviet Union on limit ing strategic arms, conferred with Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers after arriving from Vienna today for consulta tions.

title: New U.S. Peace Effort Hinted on Mideast
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 22  Secretary General Thant gave an indication today of a new Initiative by the United States State Depart ment that he believed might help to break the deadlock in the Middle East conflict.

title: Twofer Can Be a Play's Best Friend
description: One place where two can still live as cheaply as one, if only for a matter of hours, is a theater that is selling two fers.

title: Stans Sees Some Progress in Japanese Textile Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans reported some prog ress today in the first round of talks on the sensitive tex tile import question between himself and Kiichi Miyazawa, Japanese Minister of Trade and Industry.

title: HENRY ERNEST PERRY
description: DELLROY, Ohio, June 22 Henry Ernest Perry, area man ager for international sales in the power generation division of the Babcock & Wilcox Com pany, New York manufactur ers of power plants, drowned Friday, apparently after suffer ing a heart attack while sail ing on a lake near Massilon. He was 56 years old and lived at 43 Gordonhurst Avenue, Up per Montclair. N.J.

title: E. W. Bickford to Wed Miss Katherine H. May
description: CHAPPAQUA, N. Y. June 22Mr. and Mrs. William Frederick May have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathe rine Hartwick May, to Ed ward Watson Bickford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Davidson Bickford of Bethle hem, Pa.

title: FAVORITE, $4.60, 4LENGTH VICTOR
description: Ogden Phipps's Reviewer shattered a track record of 13 years standing when he won the $28,200 Nassau County at Belmont Park yesterday. Under a sound ride by Braulio Baeza, Reviewer raced the mile and an eighth in 1:46 4/5, eclipsing the standrd of 1:47 1/5 set by Gallant Man under 121 pounds in September, 1957.

title: Nixons to Attend Wedding
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (UPI) President and Mrs. Nixon and their daughter Tricia plan to attend the wedding Saturday of the President's niece, Lau rene Mae Nixon, at Newport Beach, Calif.

title: Weaver to Quit Baruch College; He Cites Financial Inadequacy
description: Dr. Robert C. Weaver, the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, re signed as president of Bernard M. Baruch College last night, citing the uncertainty and in adequacy of financing from the city and state and the growing frustration of his job.

title: Blackfin Maintains Lead In Yacht Race to Tahiti
description: LOS ANGELES, June 22 (AP) Blackfin, the 73foot ketch owned by Ken DeMeuse of San Francisco, continued to lead the Los AngelestoTahiti yacht race today after covering 1,298 miles, more than onethird the distance.

title: Gambler Testifies About Payoffs to Police in Patrolman's Trial in the Bronx
description: A convicted gambler testified in State Supreme Court yester day that he had paid the police $500 a month in protection money.

title: Far East Swim Tour Set
description: An American swimming team to tour the Far East will be selected on the basis al the Amateur Athletic Association longcourse championships at Los Angeles on Aug. 20 to 23.

title: Addonizio Trial Witness For U. S. Given Immunity
description: TRENTON, June 22  The Government's key witness in the extortion trial of Hugh J. Addonizio was granted formal immunity from prosecution to day at the request of the De partment of Justice so that he would testify.

title: Miss Dunker Is Wed To Roger R. Conant
description: The marriage of Miss In grid Junker to Roger Royce Conant, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Royce Conant of Pelham, N. Y., took place yesterday in the medieval Oddernes Church near Kris tiansand, Norway. The Rev. John Nilsen officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arne Johan Junker of Kristiansand.

title: Market Place:
description: If you bought Electronic Data Systems at 150, you may, have been horrified sev eral weeks ago when the stock dropped to 70 in just two days.

title: Scheel Is Backed By Party in Bonn On Liberal Policy
description: BONN, June 22  Foreign Minister Walter Scheel, the leader of the small Free Demo cratic party, received a vote of confidence, 240 to 100, and two minutes of applause and cheering at the party's annual convention here today after having delivered a defense of his policy of middleoftheroad liberalism.

title: Australia Plans to Double Economic Aid to Cambodia
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 22 Australia will double her economic aid to Cambodia but she will not send arms or troops, the Government decided tonight.

title: G. & W. Discussing Stock Purchase In Italian Concern
description: Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., the conglomerate, is hold ing discussions concerning the possible acquisition of a stock interest in Socit Generale Immobiliari, one of the largest realestate and construction companies in Italy.

title: 21% RISE IN RELIEF FORE CAST BY STATE
description: Continuing inflation and un employment have led the State Department of Social Services to estimate a 21 per cent rise in spending on relief grants, along with a 7 per cent in crease in statewide welfare recipients for the fiscal year that started April 1.

title: Police Group Gives Orphans a Day of Fun
description: It was a tossup at Pali sades Amusement Park yes terday whether Sister Mary Rosaire of Staten Island, sev eral hundred policemen and policewomen from all over the city, or several thousand orphans from the metropoli tan area had a better time.

title: Theater: Fugard's Gem
description: Athol Fugard, the South African playwright held vir tually captive in his own country, has written some fine plays, but certainly none better than the amazing Boesman and Lena, which opened last night at the Cir cle in the Square, and in stantly became the bestacted play in New York.

title: GREAT CANADIAN TRIMS ITS LOSSES
description: TORONTO, June 22Great Canadian Oil Sands, Ltd., the Sun Oil Company subsidiary that is extracting synthetic crude oil from the sands of northern Alberta, estimated to day that it lost $9million in the first half of 1970, compared with a loss of $16.2million for the same period a year earlier.

title: First Outsiders' Suit on Zoning Is Filed in Jersey
description: TRENTON, June 22Acting under a controversial new law, a real estate developer and 12 Iblack apartment seekers filed suit today against zoning ordi nances that they charged ex cluded Negroes and other low income minority groups from suburban community.

title: Medical Plan Called Step To Fiscal Irresponsibility
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 President Nixon vetoed a bill today for construction and mod ernization of medical facilities.

title: JAZZ GROUPS JOIN IN TULLY CONCERT
description: Jazz in some of its longer established aspects entered the Tully Hall Sampler series at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday night. The World's Greatest Jazz Band, Maxine Sullivan, the Teddy Wilson Trio and a septet led by Zoot Sims played a pro gram that went all the way back to Tin Roof Blues and came up to a recent composition by Bud Freeman called That D Minor Thing.

title: BMT SPLIT DELAYS 75 FOR 2 HOURS
description: Subway riders in Brooklyn were delayed up to two and a half hours yesterday when a BMT express train did a split, and its rear portion somehow ended up on a separate set of rails. No injuries were reported in the accident, which occurred at the 86th Street station.

title: Gleason Gets Divorce Under Liberalized Law
description: Jackie Gleason obtained a divorce from his wife of 34 years yesterday, ending a marital case that had set a legal precedent in divorce lit igation in the state.

title: DATA BACK THEORY ON ENZYME ACTION
description: Evidence supporting a new theory to explain the extraor dinary speed and precision with which enzymes catalyze bio logical reactions is being re ported today at a symposium in Riga, Soviet Latvia, by an American biochemist.

title: New Ferry Links Maine and Nova Scotia
description: PORTLAND, Me., June 22 (UPI) The luxury ferry Prince of Fundy completed her maiden roundtrip voyage this weekend between this city and Yarmouth, N. S., with a delegation of officials from Maine and Canada aboard.

title: Arms Purchased From G.I.'s
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 22Hardpressed Cambodian defenders of Kompong Speu used American grenade  lauoh ers and pistols illegally pur chased earlier from United States soldiers and South Viet namese troops, according to a Cambodian officer who was there.

title: C.B.S. Offers Free Time To Critics of White House
description: The Columbia Broadcasting System set a precedent last night by offering free time over the company's television and radio networks as a regular practice to whatever principal political party was not in oc cupancy of the White House.

title: TENNIS INCREASES GRAND PRIX PURSE
description: Prize money totaling $200, 000 will be awarded in the world Grand Prix of tennis and a yearend Masters tournament among the Prix leaders, accord ing to an announcement yes terday by PepsiCola, the spon sor in conjunction with the In ternational Lawn Tennis Fed eration.

title: Judith Ellen Seidel Fiancee of Lawyer
description: Miss Judith Ellen Seidel, an editor with the Twentieth Century Fund, and Leon Irwin Jacobson, a lawyer with Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, plan to be married on Aug. 30.

title: C.B.S. Selects a New Programing Vice President
description: Fred Silverman was pro moted yesterday to vice presi dent of programs for the Columbia Broadcasting System. He succeeds Michael H. Dann, who resigned over the weekend to become vice president of the Children's Television Workshop and assistant to its president, Mrs. Joan Ganz Cooney, pro ducer of Sesame Street.

title: CHIEFS BEAT YANKS IN EXHIBITION, 31
description: SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 22 (AP)The Syracuse Chiefs, the firstplace team in the Inter national League, whipped the parent New York Yankees, 31, tonight in an exhibition game before 9,475 fans.

title: JUBILANT CROWDS DANCE IN STREETS
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 22 The game that made Brazil the undisputed soccer champion of the world ended in Mexico City yesterday afternoon. The joyous outpouring of national pride that followed in Brazil went on all night and will probably end only after the team returns tomorrow.

title: 2d Cruise Ship to Be Built Under AirlineCunard Pact
description: Overseas National Airways, the Cunard Line and the Rot terdam Dockyard Company have reached agreement on the building of a second 17,000ton cruise ship.

title: Edmund H.H. Caddy Dead at 67; ExNew York Law School Dean
description: Edmund H. H. Caddy, former dean of the New York Law School, died of cancer Sunday at Memorial Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 544 East 18th Street, Brooklyn.

title: DEMOCRATS ASK FREE TIME ON TV
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  The Democratic National Com mittee asked the Federal Com munications Commissions today to guarantee opponents of President's policies free net work television time to respond to his televised advocacy of those policies.

title: State's Harness Officials Grant Gilmour License to Drive Again
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 22 William (Buddy) Gilmour, who was refused a license to drive at New York's standardbred tracks in January of 1967, was granted a license tonight by the New York State Harness Rac ing Commission.

title: The Elusive Issue: Judgeships for Sale?
description: The Joint Legislative Com mittee on Crime is expected to renew its inquiry soon into one of the most sensitive and ru morridden area of politics how a lawyer gets to be a judge.

title: LOSS IS SHOWN BY FOUR SEASONS
description: The Four Seasons Equity Corporation announced yester day that it would cease the de velopment of additional nursing centers because of a serious liquidity problem.

title: BANKS IN CANADA CUT PRIME RATES
description: TORONTO, June 22Cana dian banks, acting virtually in unison, said today they would lower their interest rates on business loans, mortgages and savings accounts. The move was a sign that Ottawa had modified its tightcredit policy because of the sharp rise in unemployment this spring.

title: Roosevelt Drivers
A Correction
description: The United States Department of Transportation has an nounced the award of a $1.4 million grant to the Institute for Rapid Transit, for research on subway design. Because of a typographical error, the amount was incorrectly listed in Satur day's editions of The Times as $14million.

title: SCHUYLER M. MEYER, RETIRED LAWYER, 84
description: DOVER, N. H., June 22 Schuyler Merritt Meyer, a law yer and former New York State legislator, died at a nursing home here yesterday. He was 84 years old, and lived in Hanover.

title: Falcons Sign Six Players
description: ATLANTA, June 22 (AP) The Atlanta Falcans announced today the signing of six free agents, bringing to 99 the play ers who will report to the Na tional Football League team's camp at Johnson City, Tenn., July 23. Those signed were Rob left Eskew, Stan Hearn, Dean Lotz, Gartha Morgan, Rod Ver key and John Walker.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL ADVANCES IN WEEK
description: Steel production edged 0.3 per cent higher last week, com pared with output the week be fore, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yester day.

title: Negro Is Defeated By Rep. McMillan In Carolina Runoff
description: FLORENCE, S. C., June 23 Representative John L. McMil lan, the dean of South Caro lina's Congressional delegation won convincing renomination over a Negro physician in to day's Democratic runoff pri mare in the Sixth District.

title: Rockefeller, Voting, Sees Very Tough Race in Fall
description: POCANTICO HILLS, N. Y., June 23 (AP)Governor Rocke feller, casting the 34th vote in his home district in today's primary, said he expected a very tough race in his bid for reelection in the fall.

title: Presidential Good Judgment
description: President Nixon has served the nation well in his handling of the combined Congressional action to extend the Voting Rights Act and lower the voting age to eighteen. He did not let his belief that an age qualification fixed by the Federal Government would require a constitutional amendment get in the way of his signing the legislation and thus clearing the way for the courts to resolve that question.

title: Aussie Aborigine, 18, Says It's GOOlagong
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 (AP)Evonne Goolagong says no one seems to pro nounce her name right. But Wimbledon tennis buffs are calling her a champion of the future.

title: Market Summary
description: (Volume 1140,760 shares)

title: Frank Wilson Dies; Led Secret Service From 1936 to 1947
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) Frank J. Wilson, former chief of the Secret Service, died yes terday at Georgetown Univer sity Hospital. His age was 83.

title: Miss Mary K. Cronkite Is Wed To Mark Stewart in Stamford
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 23  Miss Mary Kathleen Cronkite and Mark Robert Stewart were married here Saturday at noon in the meadow of Overbrook Farm, the country estate of Arthur Altschul, the financier, by the Rev. Gerald Deaton of the Covina (Calif.) Christian Church.

title: New U.S. Proposal Seeks Revival of Jarring's Role
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 23 A new United States proposal for a Middle East settlement calls for Israel and the Arab countries to accept renewed contacts with Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring of Sweden, the United Nations envoy, but makes no mention of direct or indirect talks between the parties in the conflict.

title: Miss. Ellen Dooling Engaged to Marry
description: John Dooling, cattle ranch er and resort owner in Jack son, Mont., and Mrs. Doro thea Matthews Dooling of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ellen Dooling, to Frederick Bell Draper 3d. He is the son of Mrs. Draper Jr. of Rock Island, Ill., and the late Mr. Draper.

title: More Time Asked to Curb Pollution
description: Corporate executives whose industries have been under fire as major polluters, turned in progress reports yester day. In every instance they hinted that more time was needed, primarily to develop better technologies to clean the environment.

title: Beaulieu, a Winner in Sulky, Takes No Chances at Window
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 23 Dr. and Mrs. George Smith Jr.'s Columbia George encountered no problems en route to his victory in last Saturday's Com modore Pace, in which he eas ily defeated Truluck, Most Happy Fella and other 3year olds at Roosevelt Raceway.

title: Jacklin Gets Warm Welcome in London
description: LONDON, June 23 (AP) Tony Jacklin, winner of the United States Open golf championship, arrived in Lon don from the United States today and immediately drove north to Lincolnshire to keep a sixmonthold promise.

title: Americanisms Get Stress In Dictionary's 2d Edition
description: The transitive verb de moralize, meaning to cor rupt the morals of, to de prave, is pure American. In deed, its purity traces to Noah Webster, the 19th cen tury American lexicographer, who coined ithis only im provisation.

title: Indians Reject U.S. Offer
description: CLEWISTON, Fla., June 23 (AP)  Florida's. Seminole In dians have decided to reject a $12.3million offer by the Fed eral Government for 40 million acres of Florida and taken from them by Gen. Andrew Jackson and his troops in the wars of 1823 and 1832 and by the In dian Removal Act of 1840. The Indians want $47million.

title: Best Seats at Opening Of the Met to Cost $60
description: In line with its raising of ticket prices for regular per formances next season the Metropolitan Opera is asking $60 for the best orchestra seats for its opening on Sept. 14. The price last season was $50. Traditionally the opening is a benefit for the company and part of the price is tax deductible.

title: Article 4  No Title
G.O.P. ACTS TO END CAMBODIA DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Nixon Administration forces acted today to bring to an end the protracted Senate debate on Cambodia in the hope of keeping the Democrats from focusing further political at tention on the war issue.

title: CITIES VIE TO HOST 1976 CELEBRATION
description: The struggle over which city, if any, will have a major ex position in 1976 when the na tion celebrates its 200th birth day heightened yesterday as the executive committee of the American Revolution Bicenten nial Commission began two days of closed hearings here to listen to further pleas from Philadelphia, Boston and Miami. The three cities are competing for the honor and the accompanying economic rewards.

title: Journalism Educators Pick Saturday Review for Award
description: TEMPE, Ariz., June 23 Saturday Review magazine has been selected to receive the 1970 Citation of Merit for journalistic excellence pre sented annually by the Ameri can Society of Journalism School Administrators.

title: GOLDBERG EDGES RIVAL IN SUBURBS
description: Virtually complete returns Showed early today that sub urban Democrats were almost evenly divided in their guber natorial preferences, with Ar thur J. Goldberg winning the narrowest of victories over his rival, Howard J. Samuels.

title: Governor Sargent to Run
description: BOSTON, June 23 (UPI)  Gov. Francis W. Sargent for molly announced today his can didacy for a full fouryear term as Governor. He became Gov ern in 1969 when Gov. John A. Volpe was named Transporta tion Secretary by President Nixon.

title: Misses West and Welch Mobbed at Film Debut
description: About 2,000 people await ing the arrival of Mae West and Raquel Welch jammed thearea of the Criterion The ater last night for the pre miere of Myra Breckin ridge.

title: Line to Sell Fleet
description: BUFFALO, June 23 (AP) The American Steamship Com pany, operator of a Great Lakes fleet, will sell the Reisst Steam ship Company of Sheboygan, Wis., within two years as a result of an antitrust action by the Government. Adam E. Cornelius Jr., president of American, said yesterday that his company and the Justice Department had agreed to a consent decree for the sale.

title: Study Says Killing of Four at Kent State, Not Cambodia, Set Off National Student Strike
description: CHICAGO, June 23At least 760 campusesabout 30 per cent of all colleges and univer sities in the countryplayed some role last month in the first national student strike in American history, a private re search group reported today.

title: American Enka Earnings Drop; Indian Head Profit Shows Gain
description: Textile markets continued to reflect weakness and caution in buying by trade outlets and consumers, the American Enka Corporation explained in re porting yesterday lower earn ings for the three and six months ended June 14.

title: Cambodians Claim Victory Near Capital
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 23  Enemy forces attacked Prek Tameak, a town on the Mekong River 20 miles north of Pnompenh last night but were repulsed by Cambodian troops after a night of fighting.

title: Benefit for Southampton College
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 23The Southampton College Scholarship Endowment Fund and the East Hampton Ladies Village Improvement Soci ety's civic projects will ben efit from an island safari on Friday, Saturday and Sunday when Robert D. L. Gardiner will be host on Gardiners Is land.

title: Market Summary
COLLEGE REFEREES WEIGH A BOYCOTT
description: LANCASTER, Pa., June 23 Eastern college basketball offi cials are threatening to with hold their services for the 1970 1971 season unless agreement is reached on a new fee scale with the Eastern College Bas ketball Association.

title: SHULTZ IS DELAYED ON JOB CORPS PLANS
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI)Labor Secretary George P. Shultz will leave his present job at the end of this month without having fulfilled his plans to open 30 new Job Corps centers by July 1.

title: Dow Plunges by 18 To Close at 698.11
description: The stock market gave way yesterday to a new set of anxietieswith fears of corporate liquidity the culprit this timeas prices tumbled along a broad front. The DowJones industrial average plummeted 18 points, falling steadily through the session, to finish at 698.11.

title: Park Concerts Open Tonight
description: The 53d season of free Gug genheim Memorial Concerts in the city parks will open tonight with a concert by the Goldman Band in Damrosch Park, Lin coln Center, at 8 o'clock. Mayor Lindsay will be the guest of honor. Richard Franko Goldman will conduct, and Delores Jones, soprano, will make her New York debut as soloist. In case of rain, the concert will be held tomorrow night.

title: Argentine Leader Says Elective Rule Is Still Far Off
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 23 (Reuters)  President Roberto Marcelo Levingston today af firmed that his Government was aiming at a return to constitu tional rule but he indicated that elections were still far off.

title: Heath Cabinet Is Confronted With Threat of Dock Strike in July
description: LONDON, June 23  Prime Minister Heath's new Govern ment faced its first test of will power today when dock workers called the first official nationall dock strike since 1926.

title: ...And for Top Model Stylish Goodby
description: When Yvonne Stamper was growing up on a wheat farm 100 miles east of Spokane, Wash., she would pore, through the Sears, Roebuck and Montgomery Ward cata loguesand see only the models.

title: U.S.JAPAN TALKS ON TEXTILES STALL
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Negotiations on textiles be tween the United States and Japan stalled today but further talks were scheduled for to morrow.

title: Namath Finds Football Scarce Item in Rome
description: At Joe Namath's request, the New York Jets have sent two footballs, two sweat suits and a rubber shirt to him in Rome, where he is acting in an Italian film.

title: Plans on Several Fronts Also Seek to Prevent Similar Difficulties
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The Congress moved rapidly forward on several fronts to day to help keep the PennCen tral Railroad running and to try to prevent similar problems on other lines.

title: World Soccer Federation Bars Rhodesia for 2 Years
description: MEXICO CITY, June 23 (UPI)The International Fed eration of Football Associa tions suspended Rhodesia for two years today by approving an Algerian proposal backed by all black African members.

title: Washington: For the Record
Grandmother Saves 6 of 7
description: A 58yearold grandmother suffered burns on the face early yesterday morning in rescuing six of her grandchildren from a fire at their home in Far Rock away, Queens. Mrs. Elizabeth Spencer was unable to save a seventh grandchild, Harry Lee Gray, 2 years old, who died in the blaze. The family lived in a twostory brick dwelling at 1520 Beach 12th Street.

title: Americans Win Wimbledon Matches
Board of Elections Inspectors Check Many Complaints in City
description: A balf hour after the primary day balloting started at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, Maurice J. O'Rourke was at Public School 194 in Harlem to check on reported trouble there with voting machines.

title: In Glens Falls, Voting Wasn't the Primary Issue
description: GLENS FALLS, N. Y., June 23Amid the freshly cut flow ers, the starched napery and the Continental ambience of the Queensbury Hotel here, a star tled businessman leaned slightly over his vichyssoise to day and said to a waitress:

title: ROSCOE TURNER, SPEED FLIER, DIES
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 23  Roscoe Turner, one of the most flamboyant and successful pilots of the scarfandgoggles era of the nineteenthirties, died in an Indianapolis hospital today after a twomonth ill ness. He was 74 years old.

title: Tax Conviction Appealed
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) A former West Virginia offi cial asked the Supreme Court Monday to review his conviction on income tax evasion charges. Clarence C. Elmore, former Commissioner of the West Vir ginia State Liquor Control Board, is seeking a review of his 1968 conviction and a de cision of the United States Ap peals in Richmond upholding the conviction and sentence of 18 months' imprisonment and $5,000 fine.

title: U.S. Monetary Reserves Fell $754Million in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 United States international monetary reserve assets de clined in May, mainly because of another large drop in for eigncurrency holdings, the Treasury disclosed today.

title: Y.C.C. for the Seventies
description: Creation of a Youth Conservation Corps that would provide useful employment in national parks and forests echoes the New Deal's Civilian Conservation Corps, which lasted from 1933 to 1942 and became one of President Roosevelt's most popular domestic recovery programs. Designed mainly to bring relief to the young unemployed, the C.C.C. brought lasting benefits to the nation through soil erosion control, forest firefighting and reforestation.

title: Senate Panel Considering Bank Holding Legislation
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The Senate Banking Commit tee took up bank holding com pany legislation today in closed session.

title: LITTON AWARDED NAVAL CONTRACT
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The Navy announced today that it was making a longde layed contract award of $2.[09] billion to Litton Industries to build 30 destroyers over the next eight years.

title: U.N. Unit Puts Off Decision on Funds For Expansion Here
description: GENEVA, June 23A United Nations organ today postponed until January a decision on whether to advance $10million toward an $80million addition to United Nations Headquarters in New York.

title: Reflections on Election Day in New York
description: About the only way you can tell it's Election Day in New York is that the bars are closed. Maybe it's the Puritan's re venge. The only thing worse than politicians with booze is politicians without booze, but anyway, Election Day passes in New York with most people grumbling about the political system and less than a third of the eligible voters even going to the polls.

title: Walbridge Is Renamed
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) Willard E. Walbridge was elected unanimously today to a second term as chairman of the 44member board of direc tors of the National Association of Broadcasters. Mr. Walbridge, who lives in Houston, is senior vice president in charge of cor porate affairs for the Capital Cities Broadcasting Corpora tion.

title: Consumer Bill Advances
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) A House subcommittee ap proved legislation today to create a new Government agency to represent the con sumer. The legislation's chances of House passage are consid ered excellent. A similar bill is under consideration in the Senate.

title: TV: Man in the Middle
description: The Man in the Middle, a study of three Metropoli tan area workingclass fami lies who find their cherished values of God, country, fam ily and hard work insuffi cient in a time of swift soci ological change, was pre sented last night on WNBC TV.

title: Sports of The Times
description: As Jack Sharkey approached Jack Demp sey in the middle of the ring, they mock ingly assumed fighting poses, laughed at their private joke and embraced. It hap pened at Madison Square Garden a week ago when the fight mob jumped the gun in paying public tribute to Dempsey on his 75th birthday, which actually is today.

title: REVISED POLICY FOR U. S. LANDS ASKED IN STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  A Congressional commission, af ter a massive fiveyear study, recommended today that the onethird of the nation's land that is federally owned be largely retained by the Govern: ment, but that major changes be made in its management and use.

title: Movement Started To Return Newark To Commission Rule
description: NEWARK, June 23A move to change the form of New ark's city government from a MayorCouncil back to a five member commission has been started by Anthony Imperiale, a white militant Councilman who lost out in his bid to be come Mayor in the May 12 elec tion.

title: Flutter Away Is Victor After Six Favorites Fail
description: STANTON, Del., June 23 (AP)  After six straight favorites had disappointed their backers, Augustus B. Gay's Flutter Away came to the rescue with a victory in the seventh race at Delaware Park today.

title: Digest of the Commission's Report and Recommendations on Public Land Use
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Following is a digest of the Public I.and Law Review Commission's Basic Con cepts and Major Recommen dations and highlights of 137 specific proposals by land uses:

title: NEWAUTO SALES ADVANCE BY 16.7%
description: Sales of new cars In the na tion rose 16.7 per cent in the June 1120 period, based pri marily on a record performance by the General Motors Corpora tion, the nation's largest auto maker.

title: 3 NEW ROLES TAKEN BY SINGERS IN AIDA
description: One by one the operas in the Metropolitan repertory are mak ing their last stands and Mon day night it was the turn of Aida to be heard for the final time at the Met this season.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: ATLANTASigned Wallace Jones, Jr., pitcher.

title: RUDY PEREZ DANCERS OFFER 3 PREMIERES
description: The Rudy Perez Dance Thea ter is a company of choreog raphers  Mr. Perez, Barbara Roan and Anthony La Giglia  each with a personal style but one that has some family re semblance to the others. Mr. Perez is slightly more sober sided, Miss Roan has a winning kookiness and Mr. La Giglia is the ebullient and flip ob server of incongruities. Each offered a premiere last night at the Cubiculo.

title: Suffolk Legislature to Fight An Infestation of Gypsy Moths
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 23 Long Island's invasion by red and blue polkadotted gypsy moth caterpillars today was ex tended to the Suffolk County Legislature, which greeted the hairy brown creatures with re vulsion and a resolution to eradicate them.

title: Researchers Develop Laboratory Weapon in Campaign Against Gonorrhea
description: CHICAGO, June 23A team of United States Public Health Service researchers reported to day that they had developed an improved culture medium in which to grow the bacterium that causes gonorrhea and that they now could infect an animalthe chimpanzee to study the commonest form of venereal disease.

title: Persuasive Land Use Counselor
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 One bright October day in 1963, President Kennedy called Representative Wayne N. Aspinall to the White House. Wayne, said the President, I'd like to have that wilderness bill.For several years, Mr. Aspinall had successfully blocked House consideration of the bill setting aside a perms nent wilderness area within the national domain. But by the time he left the White House that day, he had, given his word to see that the President got his wilderness bill early in the next session.

title: Fuji Ends Ring Career
description: TOKYO, June 23 (AP)Paul Fuji of Hawaii, a former world junior welterweight boxing champion, has announced his retirement and his scheduled 10round fight against Eddie Perkins of Chicago Sunday has been canceled, Japanese boxing officials said today.

title: RUMORS DEPRESS CHRYSLER STOCK
description: The move by the Penn Cen tral Transportation Company for reorganization under the bankruptcy laws spread its ripples across Wall Street yes terday as the stock of the Chrysler Corporation fell to a new low after a delayed opening following rumors of major liquidity problems at the auto maker.

title: RESERVE REMOVES INTEREST CEILING FOR BIG DEPOSITS
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The Federal Reserve Board, moving rapidly after the Penn Central Transportation Company filed for reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act on Sunday, acted today to help assure that banks would have enough funds to meet calls upon them by their creditworthy corporate borrow ers.

title: YIELDS ARE LOWER IN CREDIT MARKET
description: Shortterm interest rates as well as longterm bond yields declined once again yesterday.

title: YOUNG FANS TO GET ROY WHITE CARDS
description: Roy White, who helped out during the New York postal emergency last winter, will start an emergency of his own today when the Yankees re turn to the Stadium with doubleheader against the Cleveland Indians.

title: Jewish Charities Name Fund Leader
description: The appointment of fred erick P. Rose as chairman of the 197071 campaign of the Federation of Jewish Philan thropies of New York was announced yesterday by George H. Heyman Jr., presi dent of the organization.

title: Roundup: Dodgers' Singer Sews It Up
Republican Nominee for the Ohio Governorship Is Cleared by G.O.P. in Scandal
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 State Auditor Roger Cloud, Republican nominee for Gov ernor of Ohio, defended his role in a Statehouse scandal today and got a vote of con fidence from the Republican State Central Committee.

title: 5,000 FANS GREET SOCCER WINNERS
description: BRASILIA, Brazil, June 23 (UPI)A crowd of more than 5,000 greeted the Brazilian soc cer team at Brasilia Airport today when the team returned home after winning the World, Cup.

title: Rookie Quits Cavalier Camp
description: CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP) Billy Hahn of Cleveland, a former Tennesse University player, left the Cleveland Cav aliers' rookie camp today be cause of a back ailment. He told Bill Fitch, coach of the Ne tional Basketball Association expansion team, he had been suffering from the problem for the last two months and was unable to continue with the Cavaliers.

title: Sketches of Democrats Who Won Nomination for Statewide Office
description: Arthur J. Goldberg

title: REPORT ON CAMBODIA BY NIXON IS PLANNED
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) President Nixon plans to de liver a summation on the Cam bodian aspect of the Indochina war during a week or more to be spent largely at the western White House at San Clemente, Calif.

title: Foreign Affairs: What Happened to Stalin
description: GORI, U.S.S.R.This Geor gian town of 45,000 is the only place in the Soviet Union that still boasts a Stalin Avenue leading past a Stalin Museum into a Stalin Square dominated by a bronze statue of Stalin.

title: A.M.A. Backs PhysicianControlled Health Insurance
description: CHICAGO, June 23  The American Medical Association gave lukewarm support today to the concept of national health insurance but asked that doctors rather than the Gov ernment monitor such a sys tem.

title: Book by Woody Klein, Lindsay's First Press Secretary, Accuses Mayor of Credibility and Other Gaps
description: Mayor Lindsay's first press secretary has depicted Mr. Lind say as less than candid with the public, concerned with his public image, petulant and a poor administrator surrounded by young, powerhungry aides.

title: For Norell, a Show That Felt Right ...
description: Norell's siren sequin dress es are back and all's right with the fashion world. There's an extra added at traction on some of them too: rows of beaded fringe that shimmer when the manne quins shake. One male mem ber of the high fashion audience let out a cool, old fashioned wolf whistle as Gunn, the blonde in gold se quins, passed by. It was the right response.

title: O'Dwyer Manager Ties Up TV News With a Few Words
description: Around the city, candidates were backed up early this morn ing, waiting to go on television. Columbia Broadcasting System newsmen were, first, fidgeting, and then just plain annoyed. Only Paul O'Dwyer, a defeated Senatorial candidate, stood by, calmly.

title: Senator Byrd's Loophole
description: Efforts to restore Congressional responsibility in the warmaking process and to limit Presidential expansion of the war in Indochina have been unwisely weakened by the latest modification of the CooperChurch amend ment in the Senate.

title: M'COURTS FREED IN HASHISH TRIAL
description: A Maryland State Senator and his wife won acquittal yes terday in their trial here on charges that they helped smug gle 17 pounds of hashish, with a retail value of $30,000, into the United States.

title: Badillo Wins House Race; Rooney, Scheuer Victors
description: Representatives Adam Clay ton Powell and Leonard Farb stein were defeated for renomi nation yesterday in upsets in the Democratic primary elec tion.

title: BRIAN AUGER GROUP OFFERS ROCK MUSIC
description: There should be many Brian Augers. The British organist pianist and his group, The Trin ity, are playing through to night at Ungano's, 210 West 70th Street, and doing some marvelous things.

title: Rogers Memo on Legal Issue Reported
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (Reu ters)Secretary of State Wil liam P. Rogers has cautioned his advisers to pay attention to the legal implications of United States actions in future inter national crises.

title: Article 1  No Title
Gulf Oil Elects Directors
description: Gulf Oil Corporation has elected R. Hal Dean, chairman and chief executive of the Ralston Purina Company, and James H. Higgins, executive vice president of Mellon Na tional Bank and Trust Com pany, as directors.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Graham Deplores Distortion of Patriotism
description: The Rev. Billy Graham, who opens a fiveday crusade to night at Shea Stadium, deplores widespread identification of patriotism with the political right.

title: Bond Issue Voting Widened by Court
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The Supreme Court extended its oneman, onevote doctrine today to hold that persons who do not pay real estate taxes cannot be barred from voting on proposed general obligation bond issues.

title: 14 Belgrade Students Stage Hunger Strike for Miners
description: BELGRADE, June 23 (Reu ters)  A group of 14 stu dents have gone on a hunger strike at Belgrade's School of Philosophy over what they call the plight of miners and other hungry people in Yugoslavia.

title: John Lewis Simon Will Marry Miss Marylu Shore in August
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 23 Mr. and Mrs. Allan Edwin Shore have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marylu Shore, to John Lewis Simon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Simon of Bayonne, N. J.

title: Rupert Thompson Jr., 64, Dies; Guided Textron During Growth
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 23 Rupert Campbell Thompson Jr., who was a top executive officer for 11 years of Textron, Inc., the country's first indus trial conglomerate, died today of cancer in Jane Brown Hos pital here. He was 64 years old.

title: CONTRACTOR TELLS OF NEWARK GRAFT
description: TRENTON, June 23  The prosecution's key witness in the extortion trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark testified here today that Anthony (Tony Boy) Boiardo, a reputed Mafia operator, who is also on trial, had been introduced to him as the real boss of Newark.

title: In Flight With Guerrillas in Cambodia
description: The following dispatch is the second of a series by Richard Dudman, chief Washington correspondent of The St. Louis PostDispatch, who has returned home after being held prisoner by the Vietnamese Communists for six weeks and then released together with two other Ameri can newsmen.

title: Police Adding 4 Launches
description: The Harbor Precinct of the Police Department will put into service today at 11:15 A.M. four summer patrol vessels to augment its regular fleet of 12 launches. The vessels will be inspected at the East River and 23d Street before going to their stations. The boats will patrol the city's pleasureboat mooring areas and the beaches, enforc ing the State Navigation Law.

title: Becton Sells 130,000 Shares
description: Stockholders of Becton, Dickinson & Co., a large pro ducer of health products, dis posed of 130,000 shares yester day in a secondary offering managed by F. Eberstadt & Co., Inc. The shares were priced at $37.75, or two points above yesterday's closing price on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Banks Shifted by U. S. Auto Club To Safety Certification Position
description: Henry Banks, director of competition of the United States Auto Club, has been reassigned, and his new title is director of industrial rela tions and safety certification. In The Peter Principle this type of shift is characterized as a lateral arabesque, but it may turn out to be a bless ing to the club, which needs all the help it can get, and to Banks. It is no fault of this personable man, but Banks just wasn't the right man for that de manding job, which he had held for 11 years. Banks typi fied the backward look at the U.S.A.C.he never felt un comfortable with its preterist board of directors.

title: Advertising: New Toothpaste Candidates
description: Out Chicago way, the Al bertoCulver folk are testing a new toothpaste. At the mo ment it's called Excitement and the company is saying very little about it.

title: L.I. Water Rate Rise Denied
description: ALBANY, June 23 (AP)The Public Service Commission de nied today a rate increase the Long Island Water Corporation had proposed, effective July 1, for nearly 70,000 customers. The regulatory agency said it would hold public hearings on the rate proposal, which would increase the company's revenue by $1.7million a year. No dates were announced for the hear ings.

title: Furniture With Colored Light Inside
description: A sofa that lights up in red, yellow, blue or white, bar that pulses with chang ing fluorescent colorations, a shelving sys tem that incor porates cubes of light, and tables, chairs and lamps of glowinthe dark plastics are what Alt man's considers some of the most illuminating modern furnishings designs for to day's living.

title: The Screen: Hutton's Kelly's Heroes Begins Run
description: KELLY'S HEROES, directed by Brian G. Hutton; written by Troy Kennedy Martin; director of photography, Gabriel Figueroa; music by Leto Schifrin; pro duced by Gabriel Katzka and Sidney Beckerman; released by MetroGoldwyn Mayer. At Loew's Orpheum, 86th Street at Third Avenue, and Loew's State II, Broadway and 45th Street. Running time: 145 minutes. (The Motion Pic ture Association of America's Produc tion Code and Rating Administration classifies this film: GPall ages admitted, parental guidance suggested.)

title: Kranepool, Original Met, Goes to Minor
description: CHICAGO, June 23  Ed Kranepool, the last of the origi nal New York Mets, was sent to the minor leagues tonight and his place on the roster was taken by a 23yearold rookie named Ken Singleton.

title: Article 2  No Title
The Ballet: Tudor's Jardin aux Lilas
description: Antony Tudor's ballet Jar din aux Lilas is more than 30, years old, yet its beauty and poignancy remain un dimmed. First produced by the Ballet Rambert in Lon don during the late thirties, it was introduced by the American Ballet Theater dur ing its inaugural season in 1940. It wears its years light ly, because it is a work of genius and insight.

title: U.S. AND CANADA ACT ON POLLUTED LAKES
description: OTTAWA, June 23Repre sentatives of the United States and Canada took first steps to day to coordinate a joint plan to end pollution of the interna tional waters of the Great Lakes and the st. Lawrence River.

title: Major League Baseball
description: National League

title: R. A. Marks Fiance of Jean Rappy
description: The engagement of Miss Jean Rappy to Richard Aaron Marks has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas Rappy of New York, parents of the future bride. Mr. Marks is the son of Mrs. Jules Ep stein, also of New York, and the late Henry Marks.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE ON LONDON BOARD
Schering and Plough Plan To Merge in New Concern
description: The Schering Corporation and Plough, Inc., two large pharmaceutical producers, announced yesterday plans to merge into a new company to be named Scheringplough Corporation. The market val ue of the two companies, based on yesterday's closing prices on the Big Board, ag gregated $131.9million.

title: Sharon Taylor Will Be a Bride
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., June 23Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Taylor have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Sharon Lee Tay lor, to Timothy H. Avery, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Avery of Burbank, Calif.

title: Biscuit Trucks to Carry 2 Men on Slum Routes
description: Truck drivers for Sunshine Biscuits, Inc., resumed deliv eries in dangerous slum areas yesterday after the bakery company agreed to put two men on each truck as a deter rent against holdups.

title: Memorial Services
description: GOURLIEEdith Colman. Memorial service at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, N. Y., June 26, 1970, at 12 noon.

title: REV. R. S. HALL, 61, PARATROOP CLERIC
description: BRIDGTON, Me., June 23 The Rev. Raymond S. Hall, the first Army paratrooper chap lain, died in a hospital here Sunday. He was 61 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: PRINCIPATO. By Tom McHale. 311 pages. Viking. $6.95.

title: A WIDER INFLUENCE BY HOLDERS ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, moved to day to make it easier for share holders to influence corporate decisions affecting environmen tal and social problems.

title: 12 City Aides Held Prisoner In Coney I. Housing Protest
description: Coney Island residents who are being ousted from an urban renewal site and are demanding suitable replacement housing held 12 city employes prisoner yesterday until the Commis sioner of Relocation agreed to transfer two of his workers from the area.

title: Laird Says Saigon Will Have Free Rein To Act in Cambodia
description: LONDON, June 23Secre tary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that South Viet namese forces would be free to operate anywhere in Cam bodia after June 30.

title: Ranching a Family Affair as Cowboys Leave the Range
description: CIMARRON, N. M.Jiggs Porter refuses to live on day light saving time. His watch is always an hour behind and if he had his way, that hour would be years.

title: Bob Doyle Sailing Victor
description: MADISON, Wis., June 23 (AP) Robert Doyle, an alternate on the 1968 United States Olympic sailing team, defeated his broth er Richard yesterday for the singlehanded trophy in the In tercollegiate Yacht Racing As sociation's championships. The winner, a Harvard University junior, had 57 points in the twoday, 14race series.

title: The Shifting Economy
description: Operators of most 1971 model automobiles, soon to reach the market, will be paying as much as they are now, or more, for less efficient gasoline. Engines of the new cars are being adapt ed to use loweroctane, unlead ed fuel. In time, as more re fineries are changed over to produce the new fuel, unleaded gasoline will be marketed at oc tane ratings now commonbut at higher prices. By today's measures, the cost of living will show an other rise. No allowance will be made for the improvement in the atmosphere, the reason the refiners are being asked to remove the lead from gasoline.

title: FRENCH 12METER DOCKS AT NEWPORT
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 23 (AP)  The 12Meter yacht, France, the French contender for the America's Cup, has ar rived at Newport along with two other yachts owned by the same syndicate.

title: 2 Pianists Share Top Prize In Tchaikovsky Competition
description: MOSCOW, June 23 (Reu rers)John Lill of Britain and vladimir Kraincv of the Soviet Union shared first prize in the International Tchaikovsky Piano Competition tonight.

title: Lake Delaware Captures Grand National Chase
description: The longest and richest jump ing event on the New York Racing Association's spring cal endar, the $39,025 Grand Na tional Handicap Steeplechase, was won by Lake Delaware at Belmont Park yesterday.

title: OutofTown Exchanges
description: OutofTown Exchanges

title: Mademoiselle Appoints Publisher
description: After eight straight years in the agency business, Peter G. Diamandis is returning in glory to Cond Nast as pub lisher of Mademoiselle maga zine.

title: Assembly Candidate Arrested While Campaigning Near Polls
description: Norman Katz, an unsuccess ful candidate for the State As sembly in the Democratic primary in Brooklyn, was ar rested last night for allegedly lelectioneering too close to a polling place in violation of the law.

title: Article 5  No Title
Entertainment Events
description: Theater

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: American Interests

title: Protests in Japan Go On After U.S. Pact Extension
description: TOKYO, Wednesday, June 24  Rallies, brief wildcat strikes and scattered acts of violence by militant radicals erupted across Japan yesterday in pro test against the security treaty with the United States.

title: ROBERT C. LA BORDE, DEVISED WIRETAPS
description: GUILFORD, Conn., June 23 Robert C. La Borde, who in vented and manufactured wire tap devices, died at his home here last night. He was 69 years old and lived at 1045 Long Hill Road.

title: Widgeon Leads on Handicap In TransPacific Sail Race
description: LOS ANGELES, June 23 (AP) Widgeon, a Cal 40 yacht skip pered by Milton Stratford of San Diego, took over the handi cap lead today in the 3,571 mile Los AngelesTahiti trans Pacific yacht race.

title: Bronx Gambler Tells of Monthly Payoffs to Police
description: A Bronx gambler testified yes terday that he had paid various units in the New York Police Department $1,650 a month for protection from arrest.

title: Common Market Staff Out
description: BRUSSELS, June 23 (AP) The European Common Mar ket's staff struck for three hours today because the air conditioning in the European Economic Community's new 13 story glassandsteel headquar ?? working properly.

title: New Books
description: GENERAL

title: George W. Naumburg Is Dead; Banker and Philanthropist, 94
description: George W. Naumburg, re tired banker and philanthropist, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived at 778 Park Avenue.

title: Peter E. Yaeger And Miss Lloyd To Wed Aug. 30
description: POTOMAC, Md., June 23 Miss Diane Lloyd and Peter Emmet Yaeger will be mar ried Aug. 30 in Washington.

title: President Is Appointed For Wallachs Chain
description: Frank Reilly has been ap pointed president of Wal lachs, the New Yorkbased chain of 25 men's and women's apparel stores, effective Aug. 1. The chain has units here and in Con necticut, Massachusetts, New Jersey and Florida.

title: Ashe Conquers Pilic in 4 Sets and Nastase Tons Richey in 5 at Wimbledon
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 23Arthur Ashe reached the third round of the AllEngland tennis championships today but it took all his feline touch on stroke and volley to blunt the thunderbolts from Nikki Pilic's service in an enthralling fourset battle that raged over 2 hours 45 minutes.

title: AGNEW CRITICIZES USE OF MARIJUANA
description: HOT SPRINGS, Ark., June 23Vice President Agnew, de fending his generation against charges of hypocrisy, spoke out here today against the use of marijuana.

title: Owl Attacks Guards at Night
description: LEEDS, England (UPI)  Au thorities at Leeds University put up nets around the school's social club to trap an owl that had attacked five night security officers in two weeks. None of the men was seriously hurt.

title: George W. Naumburg Is Dead; Banker and Philanthropist, 94
description: George W. Naumburg, re tired banker and philanthropist, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived at 778 Park Avenue.

title: Coast Bout Is Put Off
description: LOS ANGELES, June 23 (UPI) A lightweight bout between Mando Ramos and Sugar Ra mos scheduled for Thursday night was postponed_ today be cause Mando is suffering from an allergy condition. He awakened this morning with his head swollen. He has suf fered from the allergy for sev eral years.

title: 20 Years After War's Outbreak, Korea Still Knows No Real Peace
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 19It is 20 years since the North Korean onslaught across the 38th Parallel on June 25, 1950. But there is no real peace in Korea today, and the Govern ment of South Korea still re mains in great doubt that it could withstand another such attack on its own.

title: Market Place
description: The question of who took a bath in the shares of the Penn Central Company continues to intrigue Wall Street. The answer appears to include a number of big holders.

title: Funds for Broadcast Unit Approved by House Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI)The House Commerce Committee approved a $35mil lion authorization bill today for activities of the Public Broad casting Corporation in fiscal 1971. The corporation provides programing and other support for educational radio and tele vision stations.

title: Land Law Review Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 23Following are the members of the Public Land Law Review Commission. The chair man is Representative Wayne N. Aspinali, Democrat of Colorado.

title: City University Fees Increased for Graduate Students
description: Graduate students at the City University will have to pay a $50 general fee instead of $18 and $10 more in instructional charges for each credit under a new fee structure detailed yes terday by the Board of Higher Education.

title: EVENING BAG WINS MONMOUTH RACE
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 23 (AP)  G. A. Sacks's Evening Bag came from last place to post a threequarterlength vic tory in the $12,000 Green Su perintendents Pursue at Mon mouth Park today.

title: 3 U.S. Riders Fail to Place In Aachen Qualifying Round
description: AACHEN, West Germany, June 23, (AP)Bill Steinkraus, Neal Shapiro and Frank Chapot of the United States failed to place in the second qualifica tion round today for the jump ing prize at the Aachen inter national horse show, but Steinkraus and Kathy Kusner won earlier events.

title: Prince Charles, Cambridge B.A. (With Honors)
description: LONDON, June 23Prince Charles won a Cambridge bachelor's degree with hon ors today, the first university degree to be earned by en heir to the British crown.

title: 2 EXCHAMPIONS DEFEATED IN GOLF
description: ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 23 Two former champions were eliminated as the first round the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 67th annual championship was completed today.

title: Qualifying Dates Are Set For First California 500
description: ONTARIO, Calif., June 23 (AP)Qualifying for the first California 500 auto race will be held Saturday and Sunday, Aug. 29 and 30, the Ontario Motor Speedway announced today.

title: JUDGE EXPUNGES SECRET JURY DATA
description: BALTIMORE, June 23A Fed eral District Court judge has ordered expunged from court records a special grand jury report that charged a contrac for here and his concern with conspiracy to corrupt Congres sional figures in Washington.

title: LEV ZENKEVICH DIES; OCEANOGRAPHER, 81
description: MOSCOW, June 23 (AP) Lev Alexandrovich Zenkevich, a prominent Soviet oceanog rapher, died in Moscow last Saturday at the age of 81, Pravda reported today.

title: Bridge
description: STOCKHOLM, June 23  The United States, represent ed by the Dallas Aces, and Nationalist China, or Taiwan, represented by four very tired young men and one al ternate, will oppose each other in the final of the 1970 world championship here to morrow and Thursday.

title: Times Promotes Six Executives
description: Arthur Ochs Suizberger, pres ident and publisher of The New York Times, announced several changes in the top management of the company yesterday.

title: O'Dwyer Finishes Second On Strong City Showing
description: Representative Richard L. Ottinger, helped by an energetic and expensively mounted cam paign, won the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York yesterday.

title: Apache Tribe Is Backing a Western
description: DULCE, N. M.The Jica rilla Apache Indians here, as well as other Indian tribes, had long had a fondness for Johnny Cash, the country folk singer, who has used his national television appear ances to sing and talk about Indians who have had their lands taken from them by force.

title: ROSS, SIEGEL TAKE TWO MATCHES EACH
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 23Steve Ross of Brook lyn and Steve Siegel of Tea neck, N. J., won two matches apiece to gain the quarter finals of the Eastern men's clay court tennis championship to day at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Scientists Call for Stiffer International Controls on Whale Hunting
description: LONDON, June 23  An in ternational scientific committee urged today that further re strictions be placed on whale hunting, including a reduction in catch quotas.

title: Safety Standards For Home Devices Urged on Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The National Commission on Product Safety, concluding a twoyear, $2million investi gation, urged Congress today to authorize mandatory Fed eral safety standards for products used by household ers and their families.

title: GIRL IS REBUFFED IN PLEDGE DISPUTE
description: The State Commissioner of Education ruled yesterday that students did not have the con stitutional right to remain seated as a protest while their classmates rose to recite the Pledge of Allegiance.

title: Bill Rates Show Sharp Decline At Treasury's Monthly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Treasury bill rates declined sharply at today's auction from last month's levels, the Govern ment reported late this after noon.

title: Carina Appears WellPlaced in OverAll Picture of Bermuda Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 23 Air observations of the New porttoBermuda race course made between 4 and 6 P.M. to day indicated that of the yachts bearing down on the new turn ing mark at Argus Tower, the 48foot Class C sloop Carina, appeared to be faring best in the overall picture.

title: Seoul Chief Terms U.S. Troops Vital
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 23President Chung Nee Park said today that the continued presence of American troops in South Korea was absolute ly necessary until this coun try has built up its own capa bility to defend itself against Communist aggression.

title: N.B.C. TO TELEVISE GEORGE M! SEPT. 12
description: George M!, the hit musical that recumnect highlights in tie career of George M. Cohan, will be televised as a 90minute spe cial on the National Broadcast ing Company network Saturday Sept. 12, at 7:30 P.M. Joel Grey, who created the role on Broadway and won a Tony Award for his performances as the cocky tunesmith, will star in the television version.

title: World Scientists' Parley Mystified by Polywater
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., June 23 On the platform of a Lehigh University auditorium here Dr. Frederick M. Fowkes, head of the university chemistry de partment, held up a test tube containing a thimbleful of water. As an audience of eminent chemists and physi cists watched, he tilted the tube and the liquid rolled about thickly.

title: Lincoln Center Honors John D. Rockefeller 3d
description: A plaque honoring John D. Rockefeller 3d for his in spiration and leadership in the conception and building of Lincoln Center for the Per forming Arts was dedicated here yesterday with Governor Rockefeller and other nota bles in the arts and in gov ernment attending.

title: Threat to World Trade
description: The showdown over Japanese textile exports to the United States has come with the arrival in Washing ton of the Japanese Minister of International Trade and Industry, Kiichi Miyazawa, and the Foreign Min ister, Kiichi Aichi. President Nixon's top foreign policy advisers have warned that failure to work out a textile agreement with Japan is likely to cause a serious deterioration in JapaneseAmerican relations just when Tokyo has decided to extend its security pact with Washington.

title: Tully Hall Ends Sampler Program
description: The good idea called Tully Hall Sampler, a mixed grill of programs presented by the Metropolitan Opera Studio, came to an end Monday night with a concert of 20th Century Romanticism from France. Three of the studio's young singerssoprano Col ette Boky, tenor Melvin Brown and Gene Boucher offered a shrewdly balanced menu of solo selections that ran from the zoological camp of Poulenc to the sensuous seriousness of Debussy.

title: Article 3  No Title
35th Art Biennale Beset by Problems At Venice Opening
description: VENICE, Italy, June 23On the second day of the official critics opening of the 35th Venice Biennale, carpenters were still working to get the showrooms in order, and artists were still waiting for power sources for their works.

title: Athens Frees 73 Prisoners
description: ATHENS, June 23 (Reuters) The armybacked Govern ment today released 73 political prisoners held as dangerous to public security since the mili tary coup d'tat in April, 1967, the Ministry of Public Odred announced. There are still 1,200 prisoners in camps on small is lands and in villages.

title: Win Renominations for the House
News Summary and Index
description: Arthur J. Goldberg won a close race with Howard J. Samuels last night for the Demo cratic nomination to oppose Governor Rockefeller in November. Representative Richard L. Ottinger was the Democratic United States Senate nominee in a close win over Paul O'Dwyer. [Page 1, Columns 48.]

title: In Mermoriam
description: BRODSKYJudith. Remembering and loving, a devoted wife and mother.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Special Committee on Co lonialism, Subcommittee on Caribbean Territories3 P.M.

title: JEWS RAID OFFICE OF AMTORG HERE
description: At least 27 youthful members of the Jewish Defense League brought routine importexport business to a sudden stop yes terday afternoon when they stormed through offices of the Amtorg Trading Corporation in retaliation for recent arrests of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Zinsser Appointed at Yale
description: NEW HAVEN, June 23The appointment of William K. Zinsser to be editorinchief of The Yale Alumni Magazine was announced here today. Mr. Zinsser, an author and former staff member of The New York Herald Tribune, also will teach an undergraduate course in writing as a fellow of Calhoun College at Yale. Reynold F. Frutkin, who has been acting chief editor, has been appointed managing editor.

title: COURT SUIT TESTS 18YEAR VOTE AGE
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) A test case of the new Fed eral voting rights law was filed today in the Federal District Court here.

title: 3 Officers Exonerated by Army On Songmy CoverUp Charges
description: WASHINGTON, June 23The Army dismissed criminal charges today against a briga dier general and two other of ficers implicated in an alleged coverup of the Songmy inci dent.

title: A.B.C. and N. B.C. Give Views On TV for White House Critics
description: The American Broadcasting Company and National Broad casting Company, in response to the Columbia Broadcasting System's offer of free time to critics of White House policies, stated yesterday that they be lieved they could give fairer television coverage by making casebycase judgments.

title: CERNIK LEAVES POST AS PRAGUE MINISTER
description: PRAGUE, June 23 (Reuters) Former Premier Oldrich Cer nik, one of the leading reform ers of 1968, resigned as Minis ter of Technical and Invest ment Development today.

title: Israelis Say Syrian Tank Force Has Nearly Doubled Since 1967
description: JERUSALEM, June 23Is raeli military sources asserted today that since the Arab Israeli war of June, 1967, Syria had impressively increased her military inventory, almost doubling the number of tanks at her disposal.

title: Slain A. & P. Manager Mourned by Patrons
description: The A. & P. food store at 1211 Madison Avenue, be tween 87th and 88th Streets, will be closed from 9 A.M. to noon tomorrow for a final ac counting of the loss of its foremost asseta human life.

title: Witness Links Gerald Ford Lobbyist to Voloshen
description: Edward M. Gilbert, the one time multimillionaire convict ed on Federal and state charges of swindling and looting cor porate accounts, testified yes terday that a lobbyist for House Minority Leader Gerald R. Ford Jr. sent him to Nathan M. Voloshen for help in getting a suspended sentence in a New York state court.

title: Carla M. Kraus Planning Bridal
description: CRANFORD, N. J., June 23 Miss Carla Marion Kraus, a senior at American Uni versity in Washington, and Richard David Katz, a for mer student at the univer sity's Washington College of Law, plan to be married in January.

title: LONDON METAL MARKET
description: (Prices In Sterling Per Metric Ton)

title: S. E. C. Issues Guidelines on Sale Of Funds to Foreign Investors
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission issued guidelines today for the offering and sale of shares in mutual funds and openend investment companies to investors outside the United States

title: PRICES DIP AGAIN IN AMEX TRADING
description: Growing worry over the ramifications of the move by the Penn Central Transporta tion Company for reorganiza tion under the bankruptcy laws probably was the cause of the decline yesterday in prices on the American Stock Exchange.

title: A.B.A. PANEL URGES REFORM IN ETHICS
description: A special committee of the American Bar Association has recommended strict changes in the 46yearold Canons of Ju dicial Ethics to prevent con flicts of interest by judges in municipal, state and Federal courts.

title: The Democratic Primary
description: The distinguished record of public service Arthur Goldberg brought to the contest for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, plus his stranglehold on or ganization support, gave him a hardwon victory yesterday's statewide primary. The loser, Howard J. Samuels, earned respect for the intensity of his cam paign, but he could not triumph over the solidity of the Goldberg record as Supreme Court Justice, Secre tary of Labor and Ambassador to the United Nations.

title: GOLDBERG. AND PATERSON WIN; OTTINGER TOPS 3 SENATE RIVALS; POWELL AND FARBSTEIN BEATEN
description: Arthur J. Goldberg won a close victory over Howard J. Samuels yesterday for the Democratic nomination for Governor as State Senator Basil A. Paterson and Adam Walinsky easily won the party's nominations for Lieutenant Governor and Attorney General.

title: In Fur, Choice Is Up to You
description: Leo Ritter, the furrier, doesn't believe in being a fashion dictator. He's very accommodating about lengths, for instance. Although he's showing a lot of boottop hemlines, a number of his new coats are just below the knee and others several inches above.

title: Two Key Backers of Abortion Reform in the Legislature Are Defeated Upstate
description: The two key figures in the politically explosive abortion reform struggle in the 1970 Legislatureone a Republican the other a Democratwere defeated in party primary elec tions yesterday.

title: U.S. Judge Fullam Picked to Handle the Myriad Problems of Carrier
description: Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Phila delphia was named yesterday to handle the reorganization of the Penn Central Transporta tion Company under the bank ruptcy laws.

title: Governor Names Surrogate
description: ALBANY, June 23 (AP)Gov ernor Rockefeller announced to day the appointment of Thomas it Hadawny, Orange County Attorney, as Surrogate of that county for a term running until Dec. 31. The position will be on the ballot in the November elec tion. Mr. Rockefeller also desig nated Ernest L. Boyer, vice chancellor of the State Univer sity, a trustee of the State Uni versity Constitution Fund.

title: U.S. CONCERNS HIT BY E. E. C. REPORT
description: BRUSSELS, June 23What amounts to a Censure of Ameri can corporate activity in Eu rope, one of the severest yet made by an official body, has been produced in a secret re port by the Executive Commis sion of the European Economic Community.

title: Anaconda to Cut Output
description: The Anaconda Company said yesterday that it would cut production by 12 per cent, be ginning Monday, at its zinc re finery near Great Falls, Mont. The refinery produced 167,000 tons of zinc last year. The move followed similar actions by other producers to meet a slump in demand for the metal.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES AGAIN MOVE AHEAD
description: Soybean futures prices leaped ahead yesterday in ac tive trading, following news that the Commodity Credit Cor poration had advanced the sell ing price of number one yellow soybeans for September by one cent a bushel. This follows an increase of 2 cents a bushel last week by the Government agency.

title: ROUNDUP FOLLOWS COUP IN ECUADOR
description: QUITO, Ecuador, June 23 University professors and busi ness leaders are reported to have been jailed by the military here following the assumption of supreme powers by Presi dent Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra yesterday.

title: S.E.C. CURBS UTILITY IN HOUSING ACTIVITY
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today refused to allow Michigan Consolidated Gas Company to engage in any more financing of homebuild ing in Michigan.

title: Goodell Says His Vote In '72 Depends on War
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI)Senator Charles E. Goodell, Republican of New York, said today that if the United States was still in volved in the Vietnam war by 1972, I will not support President Nixon for redec tion.

title: BenGurion, 83, Hospitalized
description: TEL AVIV, June 24 (AP) David BenGurion, the former Premier of Israel, was hospital ized today with high fever and nausea. A spokesmen at Tel Hashomer Hospital near here reported, however, that the 83 yearold statesman was in good condition.

title: Montefiore Names Official
description: The appointment of Dr. Paul Elenkind as chief of the depart ment of ophthalmology at Mon tefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx was an nounced yesterday. Dr. Hen kind, who is also professor and chairman of the department of ophthalmology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, has been director of ophthalmic patholomy at the New York University College of Medicine since 1965 and associate pro fessor of ophthalmology there cinne 1968.

title: 4 Workmen Die in Fall From Bridge
description: KITTERY Me., June 24 (AP) Four construction workers plunged nearly 100 feet to their deaths today when the staging on the under side of a bridge from Kittery to Portsmouth, N. H., collapsed.

title: Lieut. Saxbe Tells Senator Saxbe War Is Wrong
description: WASHTNGTON, June 24 (UPI) Lient. Charles R. Saxbe, ?? Marine officer, wrote to his father, Senator William B. Saxbe, Republican of Ohio If this war doesn't end soon, I see an underground, develops ment that would seek to dis rupt the country with arson, sabotage and assassination.

title: Personal Finance
description: Income tax deductions for gifts to charity begin with some basic homework, or at least complications of the new tax law make it seem more necessary than ever to do some figuring.

title: COMBINATION DRUGS REMOVED BY F.D.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Food and Drug Administration today completed the legal re, quirements for removing from the market 48 combination antibiotic drugs that were ruled ineffective more than a year ago after a major study.

title: Unity Hall Wins Stakes
description: Unity Hall continued her un beaten ways yesterday by tak ing the $31,000 National Stal lion Stakes, filly division, by 3, lengths at Belmont Park.

title: CHARLES J. COLGAN
description: TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 24 Charles J. Colgan, executive vice president and general counsel of the United Tanker Corporation in New York, died in a hospital here today after an illness of several months. He was 52 years old and lived at 29 Langdon Avenue, Ards levonHudson.

title: Marine Freed in Vietnam Slayings
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 24 (AP)A young ma rine who testified he had never kille danyone, even an enemy in combat, was ac quitted today of charges of having taken part in the slaying of 16 Vietnamese women and children on a patrol in February.

title: CONTRACTOR INQUIRY PUSHED IN MARYLAND
description: BALTIMORE, June 24  George Beall, the United States Attorney for Maryland, said to day that he would continue the investigation that led to charges that a prominent Baltimore contractor, Victory H. Frenkil, had conspired to defraud the Federal Government.

title: Text of 1964 Gulf of Tonkin Resolution
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Following is the text of the Gulf of Tonkin resolution on military action in Indochina, which the Senate voted today to repeal:

title: Burma Is Switching to Right
description: RANGOON, Burma (UPI) All of Rangoon's streets have been converted to one way as the first step in switching from left to righthand driving.

title: BRAZE ASKS O.A.S. TO ACT ON TERROR
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Brazil has proposed that the Organization of American States formally exclude terrorists from the right of political asylum as a way of combating the ex tended wave of kidnappings of and attacks on foreign diplo mats and government officials in Latin America.

title: U.S. Judge Rejects Suit Seeking Vote at Age 18 in New York State
description: A Federal judge ruled here yesterday that the State Legis lature and the voters, not the Federal courts, had the power to lower the voting age in New York State, and he dismissed a suit challenging the present minimum age for the franchise of 21 years.

title: GOLDBERG TO PRESS ROCKEFELLER LINK TO NIXON AS ISSUE
description: Arthur J. Goldberg opened his campaign against Governor Rockefeller yesterday by link ing the Republican incumbent to President Nixon and Vice President Agnewa link that is essential to the Goldberg campaign strategy of rebuilding the traditional Democratic coali tion of liberals, working people and minority groups.

title: Rockefeller Names Aide
description: The appointment of John L. Sinn of Great Neck as Nassau County chairman of the Com mittee of independents for the Rockefeller Team was an nounced yesterday by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Dance: Fracci and Nagy in Top Form
description: For some years now, part of the American Ballet Thea ter's popularity has been tied to Erik Bruhn's coattails and this is unhealthy. Mr. Bruhn's injury and conse quent very sad absence this seasonit is hoped that he will be fit for the forthcom ing European tourmay, in one sense, be a blessing in what is traditionally known as disguise.

title: Football Signings
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: Bennett, 58 and 148, Is Making Big Imprint in Decathlon World
description: SOUTH LAKE TAHOE, Calif., June 24Can a 5foot 8inch 148pound athlete find success and happiness in the decathlon, track and field's most versatile and physically demanding event?

title: McSurelys' Defense Loses Plea to Widen Trial Scope
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) Judge John Lewis Smith Jr. of Federal District Court re fused today defense moves to broaden the scope of the con temptofCongress trial of Alan and Margaret McSurely.

title: Chess:
description: The international master D. Minic of Yugoslavia fin ished in first place during the recent European Zonal Tourney No. 1 in Prais de Rocha, Portugal by the Son nebornBerger tiebreaking system.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES OFF AGAIN IN AMEX TRADING
description: Prices of American Stock Exchange shares plunged again yesterday for the third succes sive trading session, and the drop was accompanied by in creased, activity. Volume in creased to 4,050,235 shares, well above me 3.14 million shares moving on Tuesday. The index closed at 20.42, down 0.21.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I.  A stiff breeze that slanted against Hay Beach from the east failed to die, as it often does along the sea coast at sunset, making it difficult to cast our big saltwater streamers.

title: Focus on Public Land
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The public land report just handed down by a Congressional com mission is binding on absolutely nobody, yet it is something that promises to be a focus of con troversy for years to come. Congress asked the Public Land Law Review Commission for advice on what to do about the one  third of the nation's real estate 755 million acres that is federally owned. Should the Government get rid of it, or keep it, and how?

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES STAGE A RETREAT
