description: Soybeans futures which had been hitting new highs recently fell back yesterday and closed at lower prices for the day after advancing early in the session. Soybean oil and meal futures also closed lower.

title: RAIL HELP VITAL, VOLPE TESTIFIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Nationalization of the na tion's railroads is the alter native to giving troubled car riers a Government guarantee of bank borrowings for work ing capital, John A. Volpe, Sec retary of Transportation, said today.

title: 6 SEIZED FOR SITIN AT BABIES HOSPITAL
description: Six persons were arrested for criminal trespass yesterday dur ing a sitin at Babies Hospital, part of the ColumbiaPresby terian Medical Center.

title: Rome's Top Incomes Noted
description: ROME, June 24 (UPI)Prince Alessandro Torlonia and Dino le Laurentis the film producer, reported the highest taxable in comes among Rome's 2.5 mil lion citizens last year, the city tax office reported today. The office said the prince, whose income is primarily from prop erty, had reported an income of $600,000, on which he paid taxes totaling $86,400. Mr. de Laurent's reported an income of $480,000.

title: Labor Party Warns Tory Government Against Resuming the Sale of Arms to South Africa
description: LONDON, Juno 24 The Labor party's executive body, meeting today for the first time since the election, warned the new Conservative party Gov ernment against resuming the sale of arms to South Africa.

title: Fighting Flares in Golan Heights As Syrian Tanks Attack Israelis
description: JERUSALEM, June 24  Heavy fighting broke out to night on the SyrianIsraeli ceasefire line in the occupied Golan heights, and both sides were reported to have ex changed shellfire for three hours and 15 minutes.

title: J.D.L. CHIEF SEES COLLUSION HERE
description: The head of the Jewish De fense League charged yester day that the United States Departmerit and Soviet rep resentatives had acted in collu sion to promote severe charges against 28 league members ar rested Tuesday at the offices of the Amtorg Trading Corpo ration, a Soviet Government trade agency.

title: Bridge:
description: STOCKHOLM, June 24The United States, represented by the Dallas Aces, recovered from a poor start in the world championship final here to day and led Nationalist China, or Taiwan, 2515, at the half way stage in the match. This is a substantial lead, but not necessarily a decisive one.

title: Hospitals And Union At Impasse
description: Contract negotiations be tween the drug and hospital union and the League of Voluntary Hospitals and Homes of New York have reached a stalemate, with both sides expressing con cern about the possibility of a strike next Wednesday.

title: PRICES OF BONDS CONTINUE TO GAIN
description: Bond prices rose and interest rates declined again yesterday as investors continued to worry about corporate liquidity, the stock market and the health of the economy.

title: An Appeals Court Upholds Landlord On No Dog Clause
description: A state appeals court ruled yesterday that a landlord tenant lease with a no dog clause was binding despite tenant's assertion that a dog was needed for protection.

title: Mrs. Dempsey Reaches Semifinals in Metropolitan Golf
description: ESSEX FELLS, N. J., June 24 Two Long Island players, one from New Jersey and one from Westchester reached the semi final round of the 67th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

title: Prominent Citizens Back Nixon on ABM Expansion
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) A group of prominent citi zens headed by a former Dem ocratic Secretary, of State and a onetime Republican VicePresidential nominee an nounced today the formation of a committee to back Presi dent Nixon's proposal to ex pand the antiballistic missile system.

title: U.S. Golf Pros Quickly Take Up Gary Player's Team Challenge
description: CLEVELAND, June 24  United States golf professionals responded with a challenge and as smile today to Gary Player's remarks that they were not the best in the world and that he could pick a team that would beat them.

title: Windward Passage Is First Yacht to Finish in NewporttoBermuda Race
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 24  The NewporttoBermuda yacht race began to end in the predawn darkness today when Windward Passage completed the course as first to finish. By midafternoon, with only a small part of the 149 starters over the St. David's Light finish line, a pattern of performance was forming.

title: New President Elected For C.F. & I. Steel Corp.
description: The C. F. & I. Steel Corpora tion, a subsidiary of the Crane Company, announced yesterday that C. Clay Craw ford, a 52yearold vice presi dent, had been elected presi. dent and chief operating of ficer, succeeding Frederick A. Fielder.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: Today, June 25

title: Wholesale Prices Show Small Rise On Industrial List
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Industrial wholesale prices rose by onetenth of 1 per cent in June, the smallest amount in a year, the Depart ment of Labor reported to day.

title: No Back Talk, Winner by Neck, Survives Monmouth Foul Claim
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 24 (AP)  D. Havemeyer McCon ville's No Back Talk scored an upset today to win the $22,400 Tyro Stakes at Monmouth Park by a neck from Brazen Brother, whose rider's foul claim was denied.

title: Excerpts From Mansfield's Speech Giving Democrats' Reply to Nixon on Economy
description: In recent days you have heard from the President on the state of the nation's economy. It is on the same matter that I ask your atten tion.

title: . . . and End of Powellism
description: The regular political machines can draw little comfort from the results of the Congressional pri maries in and around New York. The voters displayed a remarkable abilityespecially in those districts where multiple names were on the ballotto zero in on the candidates who held forth a hope for reform leadership, for liberal approaches in impacted areas where racial difficulties are omnipresent, for new efforts to end the war and reorder priorities.

title: SHIELDS CARDS 65 FOR STROKE LEAD
description: BELLEVILLE, N. J., June 24 Bob Shields of Alpine, who used a cart because of a 15 stitch gash in his left leg, scored a 32, 3365 and took a onestroke lead in the first round of the New Jersey Pro fessional Golfers Association tournament today.

title: Shriver to Head Unit Promoting Democrats in Fall
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Sargent Shriver today accepted the leadership of a committee to promote the election of Democrats to Congress this fall, thereby formally ending his unannounced candidacy for Governor of Maryland.

title: $15MILLION GIVEN TO WASHINGTON U.
description: The Danforth Foundation of St. Louis announced yesterday that it was granting $15mil lion, with no strings attached, for the general support of Washington University and its medical school.

title: Requests to a Marriage Broker: Plumpish Brunettes
description: Some of her conclusions are rather startling: Gentle men no longer prefer blondes. (They like brunettes better.) Their ideal woman is plumpish rather than skinny  as  a fashion  model. And they're becoming more tolerant about considering marriage with an unwed mother.

title: STEIN ASKS INQUIRY IN NARCOTICS DEATH
description: Assemblyman Andrew Stein, DemocratLiberal of Manhat tan, charged officials at the Sheridan Rehabilitation Center yesterday with criminal negli gence in the death of a 19year old narcotics patient at the state facility June 4.

title: Lindsay Urges U.S. to Give Floyd Bennett Field to City
description: Mayor Lindsay asked the Federal Government yesterday to transfer Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn to the city for use as a general aviation airport. The 1,100acre Naval Reserve facility will soon be vacated by the Navy.

title: Books of The Times
description: In his foreword to A Certain World, W. H. Auden writes that biographies of writers, whether written by others or them selves, are always superfluous and usually in bad taste because a writer is a maker, not a man of action. Mr. Auden is right, of course; and his words should be stamped, like a medical warning on the spines of all future literary biographies, espe eially those that confuse politick ing. Idylssetting, hunting, fishing, drinking and go ing insane with the profession of writing. But are there then no al ternatives to plow ing one's way through an inter esting writer's published and un published works, to sifting his im agery and his col lected letters and bills, in order to understand his possessions and creative urges? Judging from A Certain World, there is at least one: that is to ask writers to produce commonplace books before their time is up.

title: T.W.U. Dental Coverage
description: Group Health Dental Insur ance, Inc., announced yesterday that 40,000 members of the Transport Workers Union would receive comprehensive dental coverage as a group under a contract with the corporation, Dr. George W. Melcher Jr., president of Group Health, said the plan would also cover the members' 63,000 dependents, starting next Oct. 1.

title: HIJACKER'S GIRL UNHAPPY IN CUBA
description: GASTONIA, N.C., June 24 (AP)  Diane McKinney, 17 years old, of Gastonia says that she is staying in a place called Hijackers Hotel in Cuba and wants to come home.

title: Day Will Head Public Broadcast Unit
description: James Day was officially recommended last night to be president of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation in consolidation of the activities of Channel 13 and National Educational Television.

title: Miss Venus Contest to Seek Potential Stars for Movies
description: An annual Miss Venus beauty contest, to select potential film stars, was announced yesterday by Dino De Laurentiis, the Ital ian movie producer, and Robert Oliver, president of the newly organized Miss Venus Interna tional, Ltd., and a former di rector of the Miss Universe pageant. The contests are slated to be held in two cities, here and abroad, with the first scheduled for next spring in a city vet to be selected.

title: Miss Elaine P. Donovan Betrothed
description: Thomas J. Donovan of New York and Mrs. Horace W. Dietrich of Brick House Farm, Ellicott City, Md., and Key Biscayne, Fla., have an nounced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Paul Donovan, to Justin Ed ward Beals of Washington. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Justin Beals of Hillside, Prince George County, Mr. The couple plan to be mar ried in January.

title: ROBERT W. ROOT, 55; TAUGHT LITERATURE
description: SENECA FALLS, N. Y., June 24Robert W. Root, professor of comparative literature at Eisenhower College here, died of a heart ailment last Thurs day at Strong Memorial Hos pital in Rochester. He was 55 years old and lived on Cayuga Lake Boulevard.

title: DUST COMMANDER SET TO RETURN TO RACING
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., June 24 (AP)  Robert Lehmann, the owner of the Kentucky Derby winner, Dust Commander, said today the colt had returned to the track and would run in the $100,000 Monmouth Invitation on Aug. 8.

title: French Atom Test in Pacific
description: PARIS, June 24France ex ploded a nuclear device in the Pacific today. The lowyield ex plosion took place above the lagoon of the Muruoa Atoll test site, according to a Defense Ministry announcement. It was the fourth in a planned series of eight tests, which arc report edly designed to improve trigger devices for hydrogen bombs.

title: EARNINGS DECLINE AT DIAMOND CORP.
Dallas Memorial Dedicated to Kennedy 200 Yards From Site of Slaying
description: DALLAS, June 24A ceno taph, or empty tomb, was ded icated today to the memory of President Kennedy in brief ceremonies held 200 yards from the site of his assassination Nov. 22, 1963.

title: Ottinger Starts Bid for Senate With Goldberg's Backing and Lame File on Rival
description: With a wellresearched dos sier on his Republican oppon ent but without the immediate endorsement of two of his three primary election rivals, Representative Richard L. Ot tinger went to work yesterday as the Democratic nominee for Senator from New York.

title: Market Place:
description: If you want Robert Zoll ner's advice  don't take anybody's advice on the stock market.

title: British Market Aide III
description: LONDON, June 24 (Reuters) Anthony Barber, Britain's new representative in Common Market negotiations, was hos pitalized last night for tests and observations. His wife said that Mr. Barber, who is 49 years old, felt a slight pain for some weeks and that it became severe last night.

title: 40 From the Media Invited by President To Briefing on War
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 President Nixon has invited leaders from 40 newspapers and broadcasting networks to a fiveandahalfhour private briefing Friday at the Presi dential compound in San Cle mente, Calif.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Thursday, June 25, 1970

title: Mayer and Ullrich Capture British Victory Golf Laurels
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 24 James D. Mayer Jr., and Wal ter Ullaicrh of Winged Foot won the Westchester County Golf Association's British Victory Cup tournament today when Mayer sank an 18foot down hill putt for a birdie4 on the second hole of a suddendeath playoff art Round Hill Club.

title: NEW ALFREDO SINGS IN MET'S TRAVIATA
description: The Metropolitan Opera's seventh and final La Traviata of the season Tuesday night had a new Alfredo, Ion Buzea, who sang the role of the first time with the company.

title: Head of Boston Reserve Calls Moves Gimmicks to Rechannel Credit
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston sharp ly criticized yesterday Congres sional attempts to use the Fed eral Reserve System to force more money into the housing market.

title: Gulf of Tonkin Measure Voted In Haste and Confusion in 1964
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 The 1964 Gulf of Tonkin reso lution, which the Senate voted to repeal today, was conceived in crisis and haste as a demon stration of national unity. It came to be depictedat least by Johnson Administration of ficialsas a declaration of Congressional authority for the American involvement in Vie nam.

title: Miss Linda Hoff To Be the Bride Of Roy A. White
description: Miss Linda Louise Hoff, a senior at Boston University, and Roy Albert White, who is studying for a master's de gree at the university's School of Theology, will be married next autumn.

title: Vigil at Welfare Agency Seeks Clothes for Camp
description: Mrs. Joanne Smitherman, mother of five and head of the Bronx Council for Welfare Rights, has been fasting since Monday to dramatize what she calls the lack of clothing for welfare children who want to 20 to summer camp.

title: WASHINGTON RHODES, PUBLISHER, 74, DEAD
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (AP)E. Washington Rhodes, publisher, lawyer and a long time leader of the black com munity of Philadelphia, died today He wag 74 years old.

title: Lieut. F. E. Jones to Wed Linda Wingate
description: Livingtton L. Wingate, ex ecutive director of the New York Urban League and Mrs. Wingate of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Elizabeth Wingate, to Lieut. (j.g.) Frederick Eugene Jones, U.S.N. He Is the son of Mrs. Elbert Jones of Conemaugh, Pa., and the late Mr. Jones.

title: Quake in British Columbia
description: MASSETT, B.C., June 24 (AP)A strong earthquake, centered near the southern tip of the Queen Charlotte Island, shook a wide area of northern British Columbia today but ap parently caused no injury or damage. The quake registered at 7.4 on the Richter scale. Shocks with readings above 6 can cause damage in heavily populated areas.

title: U.S. Aides Accused Of Using Computer To Cheat on Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) The Internal Reve nue Service said today that some of its employes had dis covered ways to cheat the Gov ernment for their own gain by feeding false information into computers used to process in come tax returns.

title: Dove to Stage Bead Tangle
description: Bead Tangle and A Bad Place to Get Your Head will be presented by the Dove Com pany at St. Peter's Church, 346 West 20th Street, July 14 through 18 and July 20 through 25, at 8:30 P.M. The plays are by Robert Patrick, the recipient of the 1969 Show Business Best Off Off Broadway Playwright Award.

title: CHAIM BRISMAN
description: TEANECK, N. J., June 24 Chaim Brisman, an actor, di rector and sculptor, died of can cer today at Englewood Hospi tal. He was 67 years old and lived at 143 Voorheos Street.

title: Post Filled By State U. At Buffalo
description: Dr. Robert L. Ketter, a 41 yearold civil engineer who was formerly vice president of the State University of New York at Buffalo, was named president of the insti tution yesterday, effective July 1.

title: Phils Reactivate Briggs
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 2 (UPI)The Philadelphia Phillies reactivated an outfielder. John ny Briggs, from the disabled list today. Briggs had been on the list since he pulled a muscle in his left leg May 22. At the time, he was batting .266 in 36 games.

title: OneThird of a Nation
description: Luckily for the country the endproduct of five years of work by the Public Land Law Review Com mission is a report, not yet a piece of legislation. As a study, curiously outmoded in tone, it can be read, pondered and put on the shelf. As an omnibus bill for the reform of American land policy, it would call for alarm signals from every conservation group in the land.

title: When Clothes Need Some Flair
description: One of the joys of preg nancy is not, generally speaking, the clothes. In fact, it's a point of pride among most expectant mothers to stay out of maternity clothes as long as they can.

title: Steel Dust in Subways Cited in Pay Request
description: Mayor Lindsay was asked by the Transit Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yes terday to grant subway policemen hazardousduty pay, because of fmdings that because of steel dust it is more hazardous to work in the city subways that it is to work in a coal mine.

title: G. & W. Buys Into an Italian Real Estate Concern
description: ROME, June 24  The So ciet Generale Immobiliare, Italy's largest real estate corporation, announced today that Gulf & Western Industries, Inc., had acquired 15 million shares, representing 10.5 per cent of its common stock.

title: RAUL COMESANAS
description: ELIZABETH, N.J., June 24 Raul F. J. Cornesanas of 622 Livingston Street, founder of two Spanishlanguage newspa pers here, died yesterday at his home after a brief illness. He was 69 years old.

title: Susan Osborne Planning Nuptials
description: CRANFORD, N. J., June 24 Superior Court Judge Harry V. Osborne Jr. and Mrs. Osborne have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Wallace Osborne, to Pierre A. Orsoni of Montmorency, France. A Wedding next month is planned.

title: Fireworks Ban Stressed
description: Fire Commissioner Robert O. Lowery said yesterday that his department would crack down hard on firecrackers dur ing the Fourth of July holiday and the weeks ahead. The pos session, sale, storage or use of fireworks without a permit, he warned, is punishable by a jail sentence of up to six months, a $500 fine or both.

title: Headmaster Is Appointed
description: SHORT HILLS, N.J., June 24 Edwin Hascall Brown has been appointed headmaster of the Short Hills Country Day School, the school's board of trustees announced today. Mr. Brown, who had been assistant to the headmaster at Newark Academy, replaces John C. Murphy, who is leaving to teach at Valley School of Ligonier in Pennsylvania.

title: Business Records
description: EASTERN DISTRICT

title: War Foe Undaunted By Colorado Setback
description: BOULDER, Colo., June 24 (AP)In a light municipal turnout, a resolution urging prompt withdrawal of all United States military per sonnel from Southeast Asia in a manner consistent with their safety was defeated yesterday by a 4,960 to 4.401 vote.

title: House Panel Visits War Units
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 24 (Reuters)Twelve visiting American Congressmen today continued their visits to United States and South Viet namese military units and vil lages in South Vietnam and Cambodia. The Representatives, members of the House Select Committee on Southeast Asia, arrived in Saigon Sunday for a twoweek visit to investigate United States military involve ment in Southeast Asia.

title: MSGR. DANIEL O'REILLY
description: BAYONNE, N.J., June 24 Msgr. Daniel O'Reilly, pastor of St. Andrew's Roman Catholic Church since 1950, died today in St. Francis Hospital, Jersey City, after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Mixing It All Up With Fabric and Wall Patterns
description: Mixing different fabrics and wail ?? one room can he a tricky business for the amateur. But Gimbels has found an easy way. The store recently in troduced a group of five cotton fabric patternsall bright contemporary geomet ries or floralsin matched color combina tions. Thus, the predominately green color com bination in the stylized floral called Shapes will blend with the mostly green color combinations in all the pat terns. The color choices are: shades of green, shades of yellow, tones of blue, a pink and orange, a black and gray, and black and rust. The fabrics. 48 inches wide, are all colorfast and soil resistant. Costing $3.50 a yard in the seventhfloor yard goods department, they would lend themselves to any summer decor or informal room.

title: Despite Pollution, Air's Oxygen Found Constant After 60 Years
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Despite pollution, pesticides and the largescale burning of coal and oil, the amount of oxygen in the earth's atmosphere seems to have remained essentially constant over the last 60 years

title: Manson Orders Lawyer Not to Question Prospective Jurors
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24 Charles M. Manson, who is ac cused of slaying seven persons here last year, instructed his attorney today to stand mute and not to question prospective jurors for his trial.

title: Box Scores of Mets' Games
description: FIRST GAMES

title: House Votes Extension
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The House voted today 30day extension of the Defense Production Act, thereby post poning a showdown on con trols over prices and wages. Legislation to continue the act, which expires next Tuesday, is before the House Banking Committee. Democrats are trying to write into it a pro vision to authorize President Nixon to freeze wages and prices. The extension resolution now goes to the Senate.

title: New Day in State Politics...
description: A new day is well begun in New York State politics. In the first, full test of the state's challenge primary law, designed to give the rank and file a larger say in the selection of party nominees, Democratic voters exhibited a commendable independence of judgment. Though organization candidates won as well as lost, official designation by the state convention clearly proved no badge of honor. Oldline party leaders will probably never again exercise the same power.

title: MANSFIELD URGES NIXON TO DO MORE TO AID ECONOMY
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Disputing President Nixon's as sessment of the economy, the Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that re cession was an economic fact and the rhetoric of a radiant tomorrow does not alter it.

title: 6 SATES REACH ANTICRIME PACT
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 24 Six Middle Atlantic states formed today an anticrime compact directed chiefly against interstate traffic in narcotics.

title: AGNEW FINDS SENATE INDECISIVE IN CRISIS
description: DENVER, June 24Vice Pres ident Agnew said here tonight that the lengthy Senate debate over the President's warmak ing powers proved that the Senate was not suited to crisis response.

title: HOUSING ON RIVER BACKED ON FUNDS
description: The City Planning Commis sion yesterday approved a re vised proposal for financing the construction of the Water side Housing Development, a 1,470apartment, mixedincome project to be built on a plat form over the East River. Plans have been stalled since 1967 by financial problems.

title: Myra Breckinridge Unveiled on Screen
significant Faculty Support Claimed for Nixon on Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 President Nixon has signifi cant support among college educators for sending United States troops into Cambodia, professors said at a news con ference here today.

title: Charles W. Lippitt, Aide Of Joseph P. Day Realty
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 24  Charles W. Lippitt, vice president and secretary of Joseph P. Day Realty, Inc., in New York, and a retired colonel in the Army Reserve, died Mon day at Norwalk Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Wilton.

title: In the Surfeit of Books on Gastronomy, a Few Are Worthwhile
description: In ages to come, the nine teensixties and seventies in America may come to be knownin a frivolous sense, of course  as the Hungry Era.

title: Advertising: Magnavox to Farm Out Work
description: Magnavox will be leaving Kenyon & Eckhardt with the intention of farming out the various functions, of a full service agency to independent companies, according to a memo circulated yesterday at the agency.

title: Ruby Keeler Says Yes, Yes To Role in No, No, Nanette
description: Ruby Keeler, the dancing star of stage and films, is returning to Broadway in November as star of Vincent Youmans's 1925 musical hit, No, No, Nanette, after an absence of 41 years.

title: Council to Get Rent Plan With Increases of 4 to 15%
description: Leaders of the Democratic majority in the City Council yesterday proposed smaller rent increases for most tenants than had been requested by Mayor Lindsay as part of his plan for a vast revision of the city's 27 yearold rent control law.

title: INDIANS LOSE, 54, AFTER 72 VICTORY
description: Comedy, neartragedy and plain oldfashioned baseball he roics consumed a long after noon at Yankee Stadium yester day, where the New York Yankees and Cleveland Indians split a doubleheader before a crowd of 31,925 and Bobby Murcer hit four straight home runs for the Yankees.

title: MAILERS BREAK OFF NEWSPAPER TALKS
description: George E. McDonald, presi dent of Mailers Unit No. 6, said yesterday that contract negotiations with the Publish ers Association of New York City were broken off late in the afternoon because of a lack of movement.

title: H. G. Lepow Fiance of Sally Tryon
description: VILLANOVA, Pa., June 24 Mr. and Mrs. Philip Tre maine Tryon of Villanova, formerly of Fairfield, Conn., have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Sally Victoria Tryon, to Howard Gerald Lepow. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin H. Lepow of New York. A wedding in the fall is planned.

title: U.S. ARMS DELEGATE CONFERS WITH NIXON
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  President Nixon conferred to day with his chief delegate to the talks on the limitation of strategic arms to discuss details of a formal proposal to the So viet Union.

title: Rennie Davis Scores Honor America Day
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Rennie C. Davis, the radical leader, met today with organ izers of Honor America Day and charged that their planned celebration July 4 was designed to show a phony consensus for Richard Nixon's foreign and domestic policies.

title: Transcript of Panther Jury Is Released for Examination
description: CHICAGO, June 24 (UPI) Chief United States District Court Judge Edwin A. Robson ruled today that the transcript of a Federal grand jury investi gation into the shooting deaths of two Black Panther party leaders could be examined by a Criminal Court judge, Joseph A Power.

title: Sholokhov Assails Poets Who Criticize Soviet and Recite in U.S.
description: MOSCOW, June 24Milchail A. Sholokhov, the Nobel Prize inovelist, today rebuked Soviet poets who look for things to criticize and who are willing to recite their poems in the Cap itol in Washington.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES POWERS FOR THIEU
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 24A controversial bill that would give President Nguyen Van Thieu extraordinary eco nomic powers for five months was passed by the National As sembly today and sent to the Senate.

title: POWELL REQUESTS BALLOT RECOUNT
description: Representative Adam Clayton Powell, who lost the Demo cratic primary by a 203vote margin to Assemblyman Charles Rangel in Harlem's 18th Congressional District on Tues day, asked for a recount yes terday.

title: Awake to Resume Sept. 15
description: Awake and Sing!, the re vival of the Clifford Odets play at the Bijou Theater, begins a summer hiatus starting next Monday. It will resume per formances on Sent. 15.

title: Purchases Are Planned to Draw Savings Units Into Vital Market
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The Federal Home Loan Bank Board announced today a new program of purchase of Gov ernment  backed mortgages from savings and loan associa tions and mutual savings banks.

title: A 30DAY MISSION INSPACE FORESEEN
description: MOSCOW, June 24  The chief designer of the Soyuz 9 craft said today that the first tests of the two astronauts, Col. Andrian G. Nikolayev and Vitaly I. Sevastyanov, had shown that man could work in space for at least a month.

title: Baggage Handling Halted At 2 Air Terminals Here
description: The handling of baggage was suspended yesterday at the East Side and West Side Air lines Terminals when 50 bag gage handlers called in sick, apparently as a result of a labor dispute.

title: Seoul Resists Koreanization
description: President Nixon's doctrine of military selfsufficiency in Asia is receiving short shrift in Seoul. The South Korean Government objects vociferously to a reported plan for the gradual withdrawal of 64,000 American troops and airmen still stationed in that country seventeen years after the Panmuniom armistice.

title: ALGERIA EXCORIATES BIG OIL COMPANIES
description: ALGIERS. June 24 (AP) President Houari Boumediene of Algeria told the world's major oilexporting nations today to bypass the international oil companies and deal directly with the governments of the consumer countries.

title: SENATORS, 81 TO 10, VOTE FOR REPEAL OF TONKIN ACTION
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The Senate voted today in favor of repeal of the 1964 Gulf of Tonkin resolution, once interpreted as the statutory equivalent of a declaration of war in Vietnam.The legal effect of the action, by a vote of 81 to 10, is prob ably minimal since the Nixon Administration has stated that it is not relying on the resolu tion, enacted at the request of President Lyndon B. Johnson, as authority for current policies in Indochina. But the vote may have marked a turning point in the increasingly acerbic bick ering in the Senate over the war.

title: Kerensky Left His Estate To a Son, Ignoring Second
description: Alexander Kerensky, the Rus sian revolutionary leader, left his estate of 15,000 to $30,000 to a son in London, it was dis closed yesterday when his will was filed for probate in Surro gate's Court.

title: Detective in Disputed Retirement Is Arrested Here
description: A detective who retired last week before the completion of his Police Department trial on charges of selling confidential information was arrested yes terday in a private East Side hospital and ordered trans ferred to Bellevue Hospital's psychiatric ward for observa tion.

title: Benefit Is Set At All's Well
description: STRATFORD, Conn., June 24  A benefit performance of All's Well That Ends Well, With Eva LeGallienne, will be given Friday evening at the American Shakespeare Festival Theater to aid the Alcoholism Council of South ern Connecticut.

title: 2D A.&P. MANAGER IN 5 DAYS SLAIN
description: Another A. & P. food store manager was shot to death yes terday in an attempted holdup in Brooklyn that took place only a few hours after the police arrested two suspects in the fatal shooting of an A. & P. manager in Manhattan Sat urday.

title: COMPETITION CUT BY ARBITRATOR
description: TRENTON, June 24The State Commission of Investiga tion beard testimony today that building maintenance companies hired a many with alleged ties with organized crime to minim ize competition while at the same time reparations were paid by a firm that took a contract from another.

title: News Summary and Index
description: The Senate, acting on a resolution offered by a conservative Republican Senator, voted 81 to 10 yesterday in favor of repeal of the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution. The Administra tion has said that it does not need the reso lutionpassed in 1964 and pointed to by President Johnson as the legal basis for esca lating the Vietnam warto justify the cur rent American involvement. [Page 1, Col. 1.]

title: DOLLY MADISON, INC., IN BANKRUPTCY STEP
description: Dolly Madison Industries, Inc., which recently sold its ice cream and furniture manufac turing businesses, filed a peti tion in the U.S. District Court in Philadelphia yesterday for reorganization under the Chap ter X provisions of the Bank ruptcy Act. The company, listed on the overthecounter market, reported a severe cash short age.

title: U.S. Considering ValueAdded Tax To Help Exports
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy said today that the Treasury was studying In depth the adoption of a valueadded tax, mainly as a means of helping the nation's trade balance.

title: Hospital Program Cuts Toxic Reaction to Digitalis
description: CHICAGO, June 24  Two Canadian physicians reported today that by conducting an educational program among physicians at the Montreal General Hospital they had al most halved the incidence of adverse reactions among pa tients receiving the heart med icine digitalis.

title: 2 GROUPS SEEKING CLAY TITLE FIGHT
description: With an eye to a multimil liondollar gate, a serious at tempt is under way to match Joe Frazier against Cassius Clay in Detroit or Seattle on Sept. 22.

title: JOHN ROLL
description: UNION, N.J., June 24John Roll of 21 Carpenter Place, formerly a general manager of the Elizabeth plant of the Singer Manufacturing Compa ny, died yesterday at his home. His age was 68.

title: Market Summary
description: (Whine 4050,325 shares)

title: Roosevelt Drivers
E. STERLING NICHOL, A HEART SPECIALIST
description: Dr. E. Sterling Nichol, pioneer in cardiology and founder of the Miami Heart In stitute, died yesterday of leu kemia. He was 73 years old.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: GENERAL

title: Hispanic Band Series Planned for City Parks
description: A series of 14 free Hisparic band concerts will be pre sented in parks in Manhattan and the Bronx from July 7 and through Aug. 20, it was announced yesterday by City Recreation Commissioner Jo seph Halper.

title: MSGR. GEORGE KILLEEN
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 24Msgr. George H. Killeen, pastor emeritus of the Roman Catholic Church of the Sacred Hearts of Jesus and Mary, died Sunday at his home on North Sea Road. He was 82 years old.

title: Baptist Leader Bids Public Pray for Vietnam Victory
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 24 (UPI)The President of the American Baptists Association urged yesterday that Americans forget partisan arguments over the Vietnam war and pray that divine providence bring Amer ica victory.

title: Herring Gull, 491, Captures Prix ides Drags at Auteuil
description: PARIS, June 24  An Irish 491 shot, Herring Gull, won the Prix des Drags steeplechase over 2 miles at Auteuil today.

title: Brooklyn College Names 2
description: The appointment of two deans at Brooklyn College was announced yesterday by Joseph P. McMurray, president of the college. Prof. Nathaniel H. Siegel, chairman of the sociol ogy department, was named dean of faculty, and Prof. E. Richard Covert, a former act ing dean of students, was named dean of students.

title: South Korea Sacrifices Liberties For Security and Economic Growth
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 19South Korea has undergone a profound political and eco nomic transformation in the 20 years since the North Korean Communists launched their at tack across the 38th Parallel on June 25, 1950.

title: Nippon Steel's U.S. Venture
description: TOKYO, June 24 (Reuters) The Japanese steel industry plans to establish an American joint venture for leasing rail road freight cars, the Nippon Steel Corporation said today. The joint concern will hold 4,000 cars to be leased to the Norfolk & Western Railroad for carrying coal.

title: Court Studies Levin's Move
description: Federal Judge Morris E. Lasker reserved decision yes terday on a motion by the LevinTownsend Computer Cor poration for a preliminary in junction against the Interna tional Business Machines Corporation. I.B.M. seeks to repossess computers from the leasing company, which is $15 million behind in its payments to I.B.M.

title: Baseball Transactions
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: Maharaja of Jaipur, 58, Dies During Polo Match in England
description: LONDON, June 24The Ma haraja of Jaipur, former ruler of a state in India with more than three million people, died today during a polo match at Cirencester, Gloucestershire, about 90 miles from London. His age was 58.

title: Western Pacific Elects
description: Howard A. Newman has been elected chairman of the West ern Pacific Railroad, the board announced yesterday. Mr. New man was chairman and presi dent of the Philadelphia and Reading Corporation from 1956 to 1968.

title: Cahill's Son Quits Job
description: TRENTON, June 24 (UPI) John P. Cahill, Gov. William T. Cahill's 19yearold son, who has been arrested twice this year on charges of possessing marijuana, has quit his job with the State Environment Protection Department, where he began work some three weeks ago. He was said to have resigned to take a job in private industry.

title: Draft Officials Redesign Lottery Procedures to Make the System More Random
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The selective service system announced today elaborate preparations intended to insure complete randomness In the draft lottery next week.

title: Article 1  No Title
Bar Association Governors to Study Anticrime Bills in Special July Session
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The American Bar Association's Board of Governors will meet in a special session next month to decide whether the associa tion should oppose controver sial portions of President Nixon's proposed an ticrime legislation.

title: Sports of The Times
description: A young Puerto Rican tapped on the restaurant win dow until Jack Dempsey turned and waved. Then the young man carefully took a cigarette out of his mouth and struck a classic boxing pose.

title: U.S. and Japanese Fail To Agree on Textile Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stens announced today that negotiations with Japan for voluntary restrictions on ex ports of textiles to the United States had failed.

title: Billy Graham Crusade Begins
description: The crack of the bat at Shea Stadium gave way last night to the ageold call to repent as the Rev. Billy Graham opened a fiveday evangelistic crusade here.

title: Chairman Is Elected By City Investing Co.
description: Mr. Walker, chairman and chief executive officer of the Rheem Manufacturing Com pany, a wholly owned sub sidiary of City Investing, suc ceeds Robert W. Dowling, who is the son of the founder of City Investing.

title: Rockefeller Supersedes County, Orders Hobart Violence Inquiry
description: Governor Rockefeller super seded District Attorney Willard C. Best of Ontario County yes terday and ordered a special grand jury inquiry into recent student disorders on the campus of Hobart and William Smith Colleges in Geneva.

title: Father Offers to Teach In Hanoi to Free Son, 29
description: PARIS, June 24 (UPI)A retired United States Govern ment teacher said today that he was willing to work in North Vietnam in exchange for the freedom of his son, a prisoner of war.

title: JOFFREY TO PRESENT 4 NEW WORKS IN FALL
description: The City Center Jeffray Bal let will present four new pro ductions, including two works by Todd Bolender, in its fall season. The sixweek engage ment at the City Center will run from Sept. 29 through Nov. 8.

title: Senate Semantics and New War Rationale
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Twenty years have passed since President Harry S. Truman led the country* into what he skit tishly called a police action in Korea, and the controversy thus raised about a President's power to make war still haunts this capital.

title: S.E.C. FILES A SUIT TO CLOSE LOOPHOLE
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission went to court yes terday to close what it con tends is a legal loophole that enables the shares of privately owned companies to be issued publicly without registration.

title: Six Incumbents in State Assembly Are Defeated
description: Six of the 150 members of the State Assembly went to defeat Tuesday in the rash of primaries for the Legislature across the state that involved the four major parties.

title: U.S. SAID TO URGE SUEZ BUFFER ZONE
description: The proposals were viewed by moderates here as an at tempt to start a new movement toward a permanent settlement despite mounting tensions in the area.

title: Pops Backs Church Reforms
description: ROME, June 24Pope Paul VI told pilgrims at his weekly general audience in St. Peters' Cathedral today that gradual, but not timid, reforms would shortly give the Roman Catholic Church an image of poverty in the spirit of the gospels. The Pontiff denied that the church possessed fabulous riches. The church must be poor, the Pope, said. Not only thatthe church must appear to be poor.

title: New York Primary Results Spur Republican Hopes of Picking Up 3 House Seats
description: With the primary election out of the way. Republican campaign strategists yesterday were counting on picking up three Congressional seats from the Democrats this fall, and New York City appeared to be virtually certain of sending the first Puerto Rican to the House of Representatives.

title: Roundup: Reds Triumph In Crosley Field Finale
description: When the Cincinnati Reds played professional baseball's first night game at Crosley Field on May 24, 1935, Presi dent Roosevelt turned on the lights by pushing a button in the White House.

title: Crangle Denies Goldberg's Loss In Erie Augurs Ill for the Future
description: BUFFALO, June 24Joseph F. Crangle, the Erie County Democratic chairman, whose statewide advocacy of Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor was surprisingly rebuffed in his home county yesterday, denied today any permanent damage to the candidate or himself.

title: Nichols Captures Panic of Catch22
North Korea Offers to Sign Pact With South if U.S. Troops Go
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 24 (UPI)North Korea today marked the 20th anniversary of the beginning of the Korean war by offering to sign a non aggression pact with South Korea and take other steps leading to eventual reunifica tion of the country. The con dition was that all American forces be withdrawn first from the peninsula. There was no immediate re action from Seoul.

title: Meehan Hospitalized In State of Exhaustion
description: SUFFERN, N. Y., June 24 Rockland County District At torney Robert R. Meehan, 39 years old, who was defeated by Adam Walinsky in the Democratic primary for At torney General, was admitted to a hospital today in what was described as a state of exhaustion.

title: N.B.C. Cancels In Which We Live Ecology Series
description: The National ?? Company television network has canceled its weekly series on ecology, In Which We Like, less than two months after its publicized premiere. Lack of sponsor and viewer Interest and the general tight ening of network television budgets were cited by Reuven Frank, president of N.B.C. News, as the reasons for the cancellation, which was not announced by N.B.C. Word of the program's demise leaked out following a meeting last week of the network's news executives at which the de cision to cancel was made. At that meeting, a network source said, it was decided that there would be no public announce ment of the death of the pro gram, since it might be the of embarrassment.

title: PRICES RETREAT ON LONDON BOARD
$7.9 Million in U.S. Arms Being Rushed to Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 24The United States, which has promised $7.9million in arms aid to Cambodia for this fiscal year, has stepped up its shipments to this country in the last several days.

title: 60 Picket at McGrawHill In a Bid for Unionization
description: About 60 publishing house employes picketed in front of McGrawHill, Inc., at 330 West 424 Street, yesterday to urge the unionization of its em ployes.

title: Crews Retains Brooklyn Leadership
description: A group of Brooklyn Re publicans attempting to unseat John R. Crews, their county leader for 36 years, picked up strength in Tuesday's primary but apparently lack enough votes on the county executive committee to achieve their objective.

title: Operating Costs Found Too High for Tenant Income in Public Housing Crisis
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  A study by the Urban Institute shows that inflation has creat ed a financial crisis for public housing authorities in major cit ies across the country and that the trend is expected to con tinue.

title: Mae West, 76, Still Finding New Generations of Fans
description: Ask the woman a question, you get an answer. For in stance, are those rocks real?

title: Wedding on July 30 Is Planned By Mrs. Marianne Reynolds
description: Mrs. Marianne O'Brien Reynolds of Miami and New York, second of the four wives of the late Richard J. Reynolds, the tobacco heir, plans to remarry on July 30. Her bridegroom will be Lee Meyers, a public relations man, also of Miami.

title: Road of Dog Show Judge in Austria Paved With Work and Study
description: VIENNAMrs. Ida E. Bub lik holds a singular position in the Austrian dogshow world. The Viennese woman is the only allround judge of the 250 in the country, gives the only course to train new judges and is the author ity who determines whether they are suitable to rule in rings. She also heads the dog museum, founded in Vienna by Prof. Emil Hauck, which contains the skulls of 1,200 dogs and traces the history of the animal compiled through a halfcentury of research by Hauck.

title: U.S. JUDGE ISSUES MINE STRIKE BAN
description: PITTSBURGH, June 24  A Federal judge granted an anti strike injunction today against thousands of dissident members of the United Mine Workers of America who quit the western Pennsylvania coal mines Mon day in a dispute with their un ion leaders over enforcement of Federal safety laws.

title: Guerrillas Explained Revolutionary Aims to 3 Captured Newsmen
description: The following dispatch is the third in a series by Richard Dudman, chief Washington cor respondent of The St. Louis PostDispatch, who has returned home after being held prisoner by the Vietnamese Communists for six weeks and then being released with two other Ameri can newsmen.

title: Miss Wickenden Prospective Bride
description: MARION, Mass., June 24 The engagement of Miss Meredith Wickenden to M. Edwin Birkins Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Birkins of Glen Head, L. I., has been an nounced by the future bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James W. Wickenden.

title: Progress Is Slow On Merger Rules
description: An 18man accounting board began meeting here yesterday to determine the final form of controversial new principles governing mergers and acquisi tions. The board was reported scrabbling hard to find areas for compromise among its vari ous factions.

title: Prague Ousts Dubcek From Ankara Post
description: VIENNA, June 24Alexander Dubcek, the discredited leader of the Czechoslovak reforms of 1968, has been dismissed from his post as Ambassador to Tur key, according to an announce ment today by the official Czechoslovak press agency C.T.K.

title: Trial Told of Raising Kickback Cash
description: TRENTON, June 24The Government's key witness in the extortion trial of Hugh J. Addonizio testified here today that he had raised cash for a New Jersey kickback at the headquarters in New York of Abraham D. Beame, Frank D. O'Connor and Mario A. Procac cino in the 1965 mayoral cam paign there.

title: Assurance Shows Zest and Durability On Stage in London
description: LONDON, June 24Among London's lesser debts to the Aldwych Theater is the discov ery that Dion Boucicault was not only the most famous hack of the Victorian stage but also the author of several notably good plays. The salvage work, which began with the revival of The Shaughraun, con tinues with Ronald Eyre's pro duction of London Assurance, which opens the Royal Shake speare Company's new season.

title: GEORGE BENNETT, PUBLICITY AGENT
description: George Bennett, president of Bennett Public Relations, Inc., died yesterday in Doctors Hos pital after a long illness. He was 53 years old and lived at 1059 Brighton Street, Union, N. J.

title: In The Nation: Sharing the Bully Pulpit
description: Dr. Frank Stanton may have solved one problem and raised some others by his agreement to let the opposition party have free television time on the Co lumbia Broadcasting System to reply to Presidential pronounce ments.

title: STOCK PRICES SLIP AS RALLY FIZZLES
description: The stock market, burdened by fears of corporate liquidity, posted another loss yesterday after a midsession rally failed to hold.

title: Mrs. Nixon to Fly To Peru With Aid For Quake Victims
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)Mrs. Richard M. Nixon is to leave Sunday on a three day trip to Peru to take money and relief supplies from private United States groups to help the victims of that country's earthquake of May 31.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
A.M.A.'s Head Asks for More Doctors
description: CHICAGO, June 24  The new president of the American Medical Association called to day for doctors of medicine to Practice medicine.

title: Soviet Satellite Launched
description: MOSCOW, June 24 (Reuters) The Soviet Union has launch ed a new meteorological earth satellite, the Meteor, Tass said today. The satellite is supposed to obtain pictures of cloud and snow cover on the earth and data on the heat energy reflect id and radiated by the earth and its atmosphere.

title: HAACK CITES DROP IN FIRMS' PROFITS
description: Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Ex change, has told the Securities and Exchange Commission that there has been a serious de terioration in the overall prof itability of member firms.

title: Observer: Heroics on the Dollar Front
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 President Nixon's men who un derstand such things keep ad vising us not to worry about the way prices keep rising, For months now they have had him reassuring us that the worst is over and that prices will settle down contentedly somewhere and stay there.

title: I.O.S. Sales Subsidiary Filling Executive Posts
description: GENEVA, June 24Hal W. Vaughan, former United States Foreign Service Officer, has been promoted to senior vice president of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., the principal sales subsidiary in the I.O.S. Mutualfund complex, it was announced today.

title: Richardson and Finch Inducted Into Their New Posts
Memorial Services
description: GOURLIEEdith Colman. Memorial service at St. Matthew's Church, Beford, N., June 26, 1970, at 12noon.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Wild Goose Chase Helps Solve An Ecology Problem in Jersey
description: BRIGANTINE WILDLIFE REFUGE, N.J. June 23 captured, confused, honking, hissing Canada goose creates a disturbance. Six hundred and twenty create pandemo nium.

title: GuyanaSurinam Talks Open
description: GEORGETOWN, Guyana, June 24Forbes Burnham, Guyana's Prime Minister, and Dr. Jules Sedney, president of Surinam, opened talks here today aimed at improving relations between the two countries. The two leaders talked for 95 minutes, mainly on an agreement to de militarize a disputed 6,000 squaremile area bordering on the two South American coun tries.

title: A New Flash Cube Is Introduced
description: Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., and the Eastman Kodak Company introduced yester day a new flash cube that requires no battery or exter nal power source when used in a new line of cameras. Spokesmen for the two com panies indicated both the flash sources, to be marketed as Magicubes, and the new cameras, designated the In stamatic X line, will he avail able immediately in retail outlets.

title: Christine Smith To Wed in July
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 24Mr. and Mrs. Julian C. Smith have announced the engagement of their daugh ter. Miss Christine Louise Smith, to Charles Merrill Ambler Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ambler of Jenkintown, Pa.

title: In Memoriam
description: CARLOZZIPasquale A. In loving memory of my beloved father.

title: Ceylon Decides to Ask U.S. Peace Corps to Leave
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 24 (P)The new leftist govern ment decided today to ask the United States Peace Corps to leave the country.

title: Vote in Samuels Areas Too Light to Win Race
description: Arthur J. Goldberg won the Democratic gubernatorial nom ination because the areas he carried tended to vote more heavily than those areas won by his opponent. Howard J. Samuels, according to an analy sis of assembly districts and sample election districts throughout the state.

title: Productive Politician
description: Charles B. Rangel, who de feated Representative Adam Clayton Powell in the Dem ocratic primary, showed up for the start of the 1965 civil rights march from Selma, Ala., dressed in city clothes dark suit, white shirt with cufflinks, raincoat and hat appropriate for the brief, symooiic appear ante he planned. Some four days and 54 miles of hiking later, Mr. Rangel was still with the marchers, led by the late Rev. Martin Luther King Jr., as they reached Mont gomery. He was still in the dark suit, white shirt with cufflinks, raincoat and hat a bit dusty and wrinkled from days of tramping and nights of sleeping outdoors but he had bought a pair of sneakers along the way.

title: Mets Beat Cubs Twice and Take Murcer Hits 4 Homers as Yanks Split
description: CHICAGO, June 24  The New York Mets made it four in a row over the Chicago Cubs today by winning a double header and swept into first place in the National League's Eastern Division  something they did not manage last year until Sept. 10. They did it in a rousing style, too, taking the first game, 95, behind the sevenhit pitching of Tom Seaver. Then they put down the Cubs, 61, in the sec ond game on just two hits one off Nolan Ryan in the first seven innings and, after he left with a blister on the finger, one off Tug McGraw in the last two.

title: Greek Church Backs State On Closing of Nudist Camp
description: ATHENS, June 24  Church and state in Greece have joined forces to curb a small colony of foreign nudists on the fashionable Aegean island of Myconos.

title: POLICEMAN FIGHTS PERJURY CHARGE
description: The lawyer for a New York policeman accused of lying about his connections with gamblers sought yesterday to discredit the testimony of a key prosecution witness.

title: A DEADLINE DELAY ON AIR BAGS ASKED
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)  The General Motors Corporation asked the Govern ment today to delay for two more years the 1973 deadline for installing inflatable safety air bass on new cars.

title: Newly Found Mark Twain Letter Accuses Business Aide of Theft
description: The New York Library an nounced yesterday the acquisi tion of a hitherto unknown manuscript by Mark Twain possibly the last he ever wrote, in which he related how he had allegedly been swindled by a young Englishman and his female secretary.

title: Bulova Helping Establish A Watch Company in Japan
description: The Bulova Watch Company, Inc., and the Citizen Watch Company, Ltd., of Tokyo have established a new watch manu facturing companythe Bulova Citizen Company, Ltd.  in Tokyo.

title: Screen: 'Two Mules for Sister Sara'
description: Directed by Don Siegel after a story by Budd Boetticher, "Two Mules for Sister Sara," which opened yesterday at the Cinerama Theater, ought to be the realization of a movie lover's dream. And, by the happiest juxtapositions of imagination and talent, it is. I'm not sure that it is a great movie, but it is very good, and it stays and grows in the mind the way only movies of exceptional narrative intelligence do.Intelligence is the operative word; for although the film is also charming, funny, cruel, sad and occasionally quite terrifying, it is by the richness and complex vigor with which it combines events, ideas, images and people that it chiefly lives.Essentially, just two people: Hogan (Clint Eastwood), an American mercenary working for followers of the 19th-century Mexican patriot Jurez, and Sara (Shirley MacLaine), a nun whom Hogan rescues from rape by desperadoes but who, as an avid Juarista, is in greater danger from the governing French. On horseback and mule (hence the title, which I don't like) the pair set off on an odyssey that is partly flight from pursuing troops and other dangers, and partly an expedition to plunder and destroy a French garrison at Chihuahua.Between Hogan and Sara (two good performances from Eastwood and Miss MacLaine) a basic tension exists as between one who practices a profession and one who follows the call to a vocation. But within Sara, a most suspicious sister, the tension also existsand within Hogan as well, for he carries a stick of dynamite near his heart, as a nun might wear her cross, and with his black gunpowder he effects miraculous cures.Furthermore, Sara is most mysteriously spiritual when most openly physical (a paradox enforced by Ennio Morricone's gracefully functional musical score), and everywhere this Western adventure film proceeds through a course of intricate, flexible and deeply satisfying dialectics.In its development of major themes and minor preoccupations "Two Mules for Sister Sara" sounds mostly like the work of Don Siegel ("Coogan's Bluff," "Madigan," Hell Is for Heroes," etc.), and in its narrative shapeliness it feels very much like Budd Boetticher ("The Rise and Fall of Legs Diamond." "Comanche Station," etc.a fine and somewhat neglected filmmaker). I have no idea that the two men collaborated, but I am very glad that both names are involved.One collaboration should be mentionedthat of the director, and the film editors (Robert Shugrue and Juan Jos Marino) and the great Mexican cinematographer Gabriel Figueroa. Figueroa photographed "Los Olvidados," "Nazarin", "Exterminating Angel" and Simon of the Desert," but nothing in his work with Buuel exceeds such passages as the exposition of desert predators in the opening title sequence of "Two Mules for Sister Sara" or, as a prelude to the film's climax, the solemn lucidity of the ascent to the Juarista mountain stronghold.

title: Wimbledon Cheers Hoad, 35, as He Loses 5Set Struggle Against El Shafei
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 24What the AllEngland ten nis championships at Wimble don needed today was an ex plosion to set it on fire.

title: Soviet Musicians Dominate Results Of the Tchaikovsky
description: MOSCOW, June 24Soviet musicians dominated the re sults of the fourth international Tchaikovsky Music Competi tion, which ended early this morning with the announce ment of winners in the violin and piano contests.

title: Parole Chief Tells of Calls by Sweig and Rebuke to Speaker's Staff
description: Russell G. Oswald, chairman of the New York State Parole Board, testified yesterday that he had rebuked the office of the Speaker of the House of Representatives for having asked him for the release of a prisoner who was at least on the fringe of organized crime and closely involved with a Mafia leader.

title: COURT APPROVES DRUG SUIT OFFER
description: A Federal judge approved yesterday an $82.5million offer by five major drug companies to settle damage suits brought against them by 66 states, cities, counties and druggists and thousands of individual consumers who charged the companies with fixing high prices on tetracycline and other wonder drugs.

title: Group Creates Ads Against War
description: Advertising People Against the War is a new group that has created newspaper and television advertising that can be used by local groups.

title: North Carolina Gets School Star
description: MANSFIELD, Pa., June 24 (UPI)Tom McMillen, 6foot 11inch high school basketball star sought by 250 colleges, picked the University of North Carolina because of its academic, as well as athletic standards, his coach said to day.

title: Public School Property Transferred to Segregation Academies, Senate Panel Is Told
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Books, microscopes, footballs, helmets and even whole build ings are disappearing from Southern schools that are de segregating, only to reappear in new, allwhite segregation academies, four young civil rights lawyers said today.

title: House Votes Public Works
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The House passed today by voice vote a $5.24billion public worke hill, emphasizing waste treatment plants and improve ment of water quality.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: June 24, 1970 THE PRESIDENT

title: SOVIET PILOTS SEEN IN WIDER U.A.R. ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (Reu ters)Foreign intelligence re ports said here today that So viet pilots in Egypt were flying combat missions south of the Suez Canal and had Challenged Israeli jets that crossed the Gulf of Suez.

title: Blackfin Leads Yachts In Race Across Pacific
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24 (UPJ)The leaders in the Los AngelestoTahiti yacht race neared the halfway point to day in the longest scheduled ocean race in the world.

title: Anueilings
description: LaVINEUnveiling of the monument in loving memory of the late Harold J. La Vine will take place on Sunday, June 28, 1970 at 11 a.m. Union Field Cemetery, Cypress Ave. Bklyn (rain or shine).

title: MRS. FRED KNOOP
description: CINCINNATI, June 24Mrs. Annette Wurlitzer Knoop died here yesterday in her suburban home in nearby Clermont County.

title: SCRIPPS WILL SELL CINCINNATI ENQUIRER
description: CINCINNATI, June 24 (UPI) Jack R. Howard, president of the E. W. Scripps Company, an nounced an agreement today to sell Scripps stock in The Cincin nati Enquirer to Francis L. Dale, president and publisher of The Enquirer.

title: Fishing Reports
description: AREA AI think the fish ing in this area has im proved, said John Falkiewicz in Surf City. Kingfish are being taken on the beach about two dozen a man, us ing bloodworms mostly. Other fishermen reported an occasional striped bass hang ing around if they were lucky. Summer flounder (fluke) were also being caught at the extreme ends of the bay, from Beach Haven to Barnegat.

title: Work Is Started in Italy On 115m.p.h. Rail Link
description: ORVIETO, Italy, June 25  In a valley north of this an dent hill town, work started today for a railroad that by 1975 will whisk travelers from Rome to Florence in an hour and 25 minutes at an average speed of 115 miles per hour.

title: 2 Puerto Ricans Debate Tactics
description: Two young Puerto Ricans one advocating violent rev olution, the other calling for peaceful changeconfronted each other yesterday in an emotional, ideological duel before the graduating class of Benjamin Franklin High School.

title: KOOSMAN VICTOR ON 7HITTER, 83
description: CHICAGO, June 25  The rampaging Mets completed their rout of the Chicago today by beating them for the fifth straight time, 83, and left town with a 1game lead in the Eastern Division of the National League.

title: Twins' Carew Sidelined 10 Weeks After Surgery
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 25 (AP) Rod Carew, the Minnesota Twins' AllStar second baseman and leading batter in the Amer ican League, lay in a hospital bed last night as his team mates beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 32.

title: Bronx Democrat Demands Assesmbly Vote Recount
description: Assemblyman Edward Steven son, Bronx Democrat, charged yesterday that he was the vic tim of hanky panky at the Board of Elections and demand ed a recount of votes cast Tues day in the 78th Assembly Dis trict.

title: Belmont Jockeys
HENRIQUE GALVAO, SEIZED SHIP IN '61
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 25 Henrique Carlos Malta Galvo, who called world attention to his campaign against the Sala zar regime of Portugal in 1961 by seizing a luxury liner in the Caribbean, died today, after a long illness, in So Paulo.

title: Aerospace Group Predicts Big Drop in Employment
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Aerospace Industries As sociation forecast today a 12 per cent decline in employment in the aviation and space man ufacturing industry by Septem ber, from totals of a year ago.

title: McMillen Still a Free Agent; Parents Balk at North Carolina
description: The parents of Tom McMil len, the year's most sought aft er high school basketball star, have expressed strong objec tions to their son's plans to at tend the University of North Carolina. As a result, the 6 foot11inch athlete may not go there although he signed an agreement to that effect Wed nesday.

title: Cambodia Issues Decree For General Mobilization
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 25  The Cambodian Govern ment issued a general mobiliz ation decree today, requiring every citizen between the ages 0.18 and 60 to perform either military duty or some service of national interest.

title: Ohio Brass Raising Prices
description: The Ohio Brass Company said yesterday in Mansfield, Ohio, that it would raise prices July 13 by 3.5 to 6.5 per cent on some of the products it makes for electric utilities.

title: Mrs. Bryan Is Wed To Leonard Henry
description: In the chapel at St. Bar tholomew's Episcopal Church yesterday, Mrs. Elizabeth Gibson Bryan, widow of Stewart Bryan of Manakin, Va., was married to Leonard D. Henry, a retired Air Force colonel, who is assistant to the president and chief exec utive officer of the Avco Corporation here. The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay per formed the ceremony in the presence of members of the immediate families.

title: Dining Out: Greek Food in the Hamptons
description: A selective list of restau rants in New York and vicin ity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored in the restaurants where indi cated.

title: Cubs Get Reinforcements: Buy Pappas and Spangler
description: CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) The Chicago Cubs purchased Milt Pappas, a righthanded pitcher, from the Atlanta Braves today for considerably more than the waver price of $20,000.

title: Department Store Sales Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Department of Commerce reported today that department store sales for the latest week, ended June 24, were an esti mated $762million an increase of 18 per cent above the $644 million sales for the corres ponding week of last year. To tal retail store sales for the latest week were an estimated $7.373billion an increase of 7 per cent above the $6.884bil lion sales for the same period last year.

title: Scarsdale School Budget Passed by Voters on 3d Try
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 25 On the third attempt, the school budget was approved here today.

title: Nixon Plans to Report On Cambodia Tuesday
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 25  President Nixon will deliver his final report on the American operations in Cambodia next Tuesday.

title: RIBICOFF REQUESTS AGRICULTURE STUDY
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) A Congressional watchdog report charging that United States inspectors allowed filthy, ratridden meat packing plants to stay in production has brought a demand from Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff for an investigation of the Agriculture Department.

title: Soviet Is Asked Anew To Let Oistrakh Tour
description: GENEVA, June 25The So viet Ministry of Culture has been asked to reconsider its refusal to permit David Dia trakh to play at the Gstaad Music Festival organized by Yehudi Menuhin. The reason for the ministry's refusal is its contention that Mr. Men uhin supports the Zionist aggressors in the Middle East.

title: HOUSE OVERRIDES HOSPITAL AID VETO BY VOTE OF 27998
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The House voted 279 to 98 to day to override President Nixon's veto of the $2.79bil lion bill for construction and modernization of medical facili ties, 27 more votes than the twothirds majority required.

title: ALGERIA ASKS CURBS ON BIG OIL CONCERNS
description: ALGIERS, June 25 (UPI)Al geria and Libya led a drive to day to cut the refining and marketing role of American and other international oil com panies in the 10 nations that produce half of the world's petroleum.

title: WOES OF PENNSY AFFECTING BONDS
description: The Penn Central's financial troubles are making investors much more credit conscious as they buy bonds.

title: MADDOX SON GUILTY IN THEFT ATTEMPT
description: ATLANTA, June 25 (UPI) Lester G. Maddox Jr., the eldest son of the Georgia Governor, pleaded guilty today to a charge of attempted burglary, his second such offense in five years.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankees vs. Boston Red Sox, at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street, the Bronx, 8 P.M. (TelevisionChannel 11, 8 P.M.) (RadioWHN, 7:55 P.M.)

title: Dance: Unfinished River
description: Did we see it or did we not? There appeared to be a certain judicious doubt about last night's premiere by American Ballet Theater at Lincoln Center's New York State Theater.

title: License Jam Is an Ordeal For Drivers
description: Thousands of New York ers applying for drivers' li censes this summer are wait ing in threehourlong lines the longest lines in mem orythat often make women weep and men's tempers flare.

title: FUND VIOLATIONS CHARGED BY S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged yesterday that Arnold Bernhard, a leading figure in the mutual fund indus try, had violated provisions of four Federal securities laws in the operation of his fund man aeement company.

title: F.C.C. Bars 3 Major Networks From Ownership of Cable TV
description: The Federal Communications Commission issued an order yesterday barring the three ma jor television networks from owning cable television systems. It also forbade television broad casters from owning cable TV systems in their local broad casting areas and set three years for them to eliminate any existing crossownerships.

title: U.S. Plans to Expel A Pravda Reporter For Improper Acts
description: WASHINGTON, June 25A New York correspondent for Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper, will be ex Felled from the United States for what sources here described today as improper activities.

title: For Blacks, Still Those Subtle Indignities
description: Mrs. Verta Mac Grosvenor is a woman of commanding presence, imposing height and black skin. She is an author, a musician and a mother whose daugh ter recently had a book of poems (Po ems by Kali) published.

title: PETER WOOD WINS TROT AT WESTBURY
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 25 If additionnal evidence were needed to emphasize how much the synthetic rubber surface at Roosevelt Raceway moves up a standardbred, it was supplied tonight by Peter Wood, a 6 yearold trotting gelding.

title: BostonNew York Turbo Train Gets More Service on Weekends
description: The little threecar turbine powered train that negotiates the twists, turns and tricky roadbed between here and Bos ton and on better stretches zips at speeds up to 105 miles an hour will have an expanded weekend service starting today.

title: Aborting Political Careers
description: Abortion law reform, long overdue and finally en acted at the last session of the State Legislature, emerged as an ugly and divisive campaign issue in some primary contests.

title: Augusta Student Arrested In Disturbance Before Riot
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., June 25 (AP) A Paine College student, Edward Sapp Jr., has been ar rested on charges of creating a public disturbance and misuse of a flag in connection with an incident shortly before a riot broke out that left six dead and 60 injured in Augusta.

title: Distribution of News Is Delayed By a Meeting of Mailers' Union
description: Members of Mailers Union No. 6 at The Daily News stopped work and held a union meeting for about an hour last night, delaying distribution of the first edition of the paper.

title: Premier Says If Necessary, Thais Will Enter Cambodia
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, June 25 (AP)Premier Thanom Kittika chorn told a cheering Parlia ment today that Thailand would send her army into Cambodia if necessary.

title: H.E.W. CHIEF VOWS INTEGRATION PUSH
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) Elliot L. Richardson, the new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, took a tough stand against Southern school segre gation today and expressed willingness to terminate Federal aid.

title: Books of The Times
description: One would hope that the Great Synthesiz ersthose who look at the world through a knothole instead of a kaleidoscopehave bad dreams. Marx should grapple with Freud; and Freud, with Marx. Toynbee near dawn should see an antiChrist or a very inscrutable Buddha, on a pogo stick instead of the historical cycle. Spengler's nocturne should be afflicted with the bluebird of happi ness. Norman O. Brown should be recruited by Lu ther for the Gen ital Organization, and Marshall Mc Luhan should be chased by Guten burghers out of the Garden of Haptic Harmony into the alphabet soup. Even Heraclitus should learn about ice cubes. And dur ing the night what mare should C. D. Darlington ride? Fellow of the Royal Society, Sherardian Professor of Botany and Regius Professor of Biology at Oxford, Director of the Innes Horticultural Institution and Keeper of Ox ford's Botanic Gardens, Dr. Darlington must be in terror of some alternative to his ide fixe....

title: Business Records
description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: JERSEY HEARING TOLD OF WARNING
description: TRENTON, June 25Two partners in an Elizabeth win dowcleaning company testified today at a public hearing of the State Commission of In vestigation that a previous wit ness had visited their office early this morning and had advised them:

title: Carnegie Study Favors Community Colleges
description: CHICAGO, June 25  The Carnegie Commission on High er Education proposed today Chat 230 to 280 new, twoyear community colleges be estab lished in the United States by 1980. The proposal would put one community college within commuting distance of 95 per cent of all Americans.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON ADVANCE SLIGHTLY
description: Prices on the London stock market closed slightly higher yesterday after a quiet trading session.

title: Excerpts From the News Conference by Rogers
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Following are excerpts from a news conference held here today by Secretary of State William P. Rogers:

title: First Negro Appointed To Mississippi Faculty
description: OXFORD, Miss., June 25 (AP) Jeanette Jennings of Hat tiesburg has become the first fulltime Negro faculty mem ber at the University of Mis sissippi.

title: Jim Burnes of A. B. C., 42, Dies; Covered U.S. Urban Disorders
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 25 Jim Burnes, an A.B.C. News correspondent, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 42 years old.

title: Canada Offers 91Day Bills
description: OTTAWA, June 25 (Canadian Press)New 91day Govern ment of Canada Treasury bills auctioned today totaled $150 million at an average price and yield of 98.541 and 5.94 per cent, compared with 98.553 and 5.89 per cent last week. The 182day bills offered today totaled $40million at 97.118 and 97.118 per cent, against 97.095 and 6.00 per cent last week.

title: Tate Extends Emergency
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 25 (UPI)Mayor James H. J. Tate extended a state of limited emergency for two weeks yesterday in a racially tense section of south Philadelphia.

title: Canada Charts a Foreign Policy Course for Decade Stressing Independence From U.S.
description: OTTAWA, June 25  The Government declared today that Canadian foreign policy in the nineteenseventies must diligently pursue national aims and interests, including the pro tection of Canada's independence and cultural identity when deal ing with the United States.

title: Article 2  No Title
Japan Air Lines Buys 747's
description: Japan Air Lines announced yesterday it had bought its 10th and 11th Boeing 747 jet liners from the Boeing Com pany at a price of nearly $22 million each. Delivery is sched uled for 1972.

title: Tonkin Repeal
description: The Senate has repealed the Tonkin Gulf resolution with the same haste and confusion of purpose that attended its adoption six years ago.

title: News Summary and Index
description: FRIDAY, JUNE 26, 1970

title: New Books
description: Countdown, by Frank G. Slaughter (Doubleday, $6.95). The lives of some people at an aerospace complex.

title: Israeli Soccer Team Wins
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25 (UPI)  A goal by Moshe Ro mano made it 43 and one by George Borha ended the scor ing as Tamers World Cop soc cer team scored a 53 victory over the Los Angeles AllStars last night.

title: MONROE, ON 134, LEADS IN JERSEY
description: BELLEVILLE, N. J., June 25 Lloyd Monroe, who has yet to make his mark in the paying ranks, took over the lead in the New Jersey Professional Golfers Association championship today with 134 at the halfway point of the 72hole tournament.

title: DAVID RACOOSIN, 74, LED RAYBOND FIRM
description: David Racoosin, president and founder of the Raybond Electronics Company in Nor wood, Mass., died Wednesday at his home after a brief illness. He was 74 years old.

title: In Defense of the Pollsters
description: Everybody seems to be de nouncing the pollsters these days for not calling the out come of the British election, but they should be thanked for their failure. For the more the pollsters fail, the more the democratic process is likely to succeed.

title: Major Elements Of Warner Bros. To Move to Coast
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25 Ted Ashley, chairman of War ner Bros., confirmed today ru mors that the company would transfer major elements of its New York headquarters operations to its Burbank, Calif., studios.

title: Board Votes Clinics' Use
description: The city's Board of Health voted yesterday to permit abor tions in clinics as well as in hospitals, but only if stringent standards are met.

title: Rogers Moves for Peace in Mideast
Macneil of Barra Is Dead at 80; 45th Chief of Scottish Clan Neil
description: BRATTLEBORO, Vt., June 25 (AP)Robert Lister Macneil, the Macneil of Barra, an Amer ican who had been chief of the Scottish clan Neil since 1915 died here yesterday. He was 80 years old.

title: Ecuador Prohibits Cable Dispatches; U.S. Reporter Held
description: QUITO, Ecuador, June 25  The Ecuadorian Government yesterday banned outgoing news dispatches by cable without no tice.

title: Executive Changes
description: Bernard S. French 3d has been named to the new post of executive vice president of the Rohitshek Schneider Company, outerwear manufacturer, a division of Hart Schaffner & Marx.

title: Gorman Beats Drysdale; 5 From U.S. Gain Wimbledon 4th Round
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25The long established names of Arthur Ashe, Stan Smith, Dennis Ralston and Marty Ries sen reached the fourth round of the AllEngland tennis cham pionships today, here just as they were supposed to do, along with a fifth American who ad vanced on the finest victory of his career.

title: Canadian Merger Bids
description: Two Canadian companies were the targets yesterday of mergerminded companies here and in West Germany.

title: Warkentin Wins A.A.U. Decathlon Title
