Mrs. Hart to Meet Mrs. Bower Today For Crown in Golf
description: ESSEX FELLS, N.J., June 25 Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Es sex County will meet Mrs. Al bert Bower of Pelham in the 36hole final of the 67th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf As sociation championship tomor row.

title: TV Review
description: Happy Days, which the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem introduced last night as a new summer series, suffers badly from generational schizophrenia. Billed as a nos nostalgic look at the music and comedy of the 30's and 40's, the show has sought to be all things to all men. The producers have opted for a format that combines stand ard TV variety with the latest and invariably poorly exe cuted  quickcut gimmicks from Laughin, As a re sult, only the most senti mental of the over40 set are likely to find much to be happy about in Happy Days.

title: Singh Is Said to Quit Cabinet As Mrs. Gandhi Shuffles Posts
description: NEW DELHI, June 25  Foreign Minister Dinesh Singh offered his resignation tonight following a sweeping Cabinet shuffle ordered by Prime Minis ter Indira Gandhi.

title: 110,000 IN PEKING MARK KOREA WAR
description: PEKING, June 25Up there on the electric scoreboard, where in other places you might see batting averages or outoftown results or perhaps a blurb about children's day at the old ballpark, was a slogan in 22 giant Chinese characters: People of the world, unite and defeat the United States ag gressors and all their running dogs.

title: Velasquez Rides Two Winners on Turf at Belmont Park
description: Jorge Velasquez, the calm Panamanian, showed his com petence as a grass rider by winning both turf races in which he participated at Bel mont Park yesterday. One of these events was the feature on the card, a purse named the Citizens Budget Commission, which attracted a field of eight older horses.Guiding Mr. Leader of the Cragwood Stable in thise vent of a mile and a sixteenth, Velas quez rode to a stirring triumph over Zarco of the Watermill farm, and his own stablemate, Red Reality. There was less than a halflength separating all three, Mr. Leader preceding Zarco by a neck and Zarco beating Red Reality by a nose.

title: Smith Returns to Vienna
description: VIENNA, June 25 (AP)Ger ard C. Smith, chief United States negotiator at the talks on the limitation of strategic arms, re turned to Vienna today after a visit to Washington and talks with President Nixon on spe cific proposals for cutting back the United StatesSoviet arms race.

title: To Stop Shooting
description: Secretary of State Rogers shed little light on the new American peace initiative for the Middle East yesterday, but it is evident that a major effort is under way to get the Arabs and the Israelis to stop shooting and start talking.

title: Foreign Affairs: Peacemaking a la Russe
description: MOSCOW  Exactly twenty years ago, June 25, 1950, North Korea invaded South Korea and the United States became in volved in its first unpopular Asian campaign, an involve ment which has not yet ended because a fourstar general commands the thousands of troops still committed to pro tecting the South. The story of the conflict itself is painfully well known.

title: Jaycees Cheer Nixon Talk on What Is Right in U.S.
description: ST. LOUIS, June 25Pres ident Nixon came to Middle America today and appealed to young businessmen to help him bridge the generation gap and bring racial peace to the nation. Facing an audi ence of 12,000 delegates in Kiel Auditorium at the 50th annual meeting of the Jaycees, Mr. Nixon received the most enthusiastic reception of his Presidency to date. The sev enminute earsplitting stand ing ovation came from whistleblowing Indiana dele gates dressed as referees, Alabamians waving Ameri can flags, Oklahomans in Indian war dress, young en trepreneurs from Colorado in buckskin coats, staid Virgin ians in coats and ties. It was the kind of audience modern Presidents can confront with out fear, but to which this Republican President, a formes Jaycee, offers special appeal. No demonstrators and few blacks were present, and what the audience seemed to want to hear was that the country was in pretty good shape and the economy was sound.

title: Senate Sets Vote Tuesday on CooperChurch Proposal
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Senate agreed today to end its prolonged debate on Cambodia Tuesday and voting then on the CooperChurch amendment to restrict future military activities in Cambodia.

title: Bank Holding Company Set By First National of Boston
description: The First National Bank of Boston, one of the few major banks in the country that has no holdingcompany affiliation, announced yesterday the for mation of a onebank holding company to acquire its shares and possibly also those of one or more subsidiaries.

title: Nixon Plans to Forgo Fall Campaign Talks
description: BELLEVILLE, Ill., June 25 (AP)President Nixon said today that he planned no po litical campaign speeches in 1970. He said that he felt he could best serve Republican candidates by making as good a record as possible in Washington.

title: Japanese Buy More 747's
description: TOKYO, June 25 (AP)Ja pan Air Lines said today that it had signed a contract with the Boeing Company to pur chase two more 747 jumbo jets, bringing its 747 fleet to 11. The carrier said it would open six weekly transPacific 747 flights next Wednesdayfour to Honolulu and two to San Francisco, via Hawaii.

title: Precedent May Be Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Federal Trade Commission in a unanimous decision that may set a precedent in anti trust law, ordered the Bendix Corporation today to divest it self of the Fram Corporation.

title: Advertising: Researching for Newspapers
description: The desire of many agen cy men, advertisers and newspapers, too, to get standardized audience re search rolling in the news paper business was given a big push yesterday when Newspaper 1 announced that 20 of its 30 members had signed up for the Simmons Local Index Study.

title: Alice J. Mendell to Be Bride Of Kenneth W. Starr in August
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 25Mr. and Mrs. Ira L. Men dell have made known the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Alice Jean Mendell, to Kenneth Winston Starr. He is the son of the Rev. and Mrs. William Douglas Starr of San Antonio, Tex. A wedding in August is planned.

title: Unveilings
description: LeVINEUnveiling of the monument in Inv ing memory of the late Harold J. LeVine will fake Place on Sunday, June 28, 1970, at 11 A.M. Union Field Cemetery, Cypress Ave., Brooklyn. (Rain or shine.)

title: 6 City Air Pollution Inspectors Accused of Lying About Bribes
description: Six inspectors in the city's Department of Air Resources were indicted yesterday on charges that they had falsely denied having told a fellow in spector that they had either re ceived bribes or had been able to get bribes if they wanted.

title: RAIL TONMILEAGE SHOWS 2% INCREASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Freight traffic on United States railroads in the wek ended June 20 was above the corre sponding week of last year. In tercity truck tonnage in the same period affected by work stoppages throughout the coun try was considerably below the volume in the like period last year.

title: Carol Michaelsen Planning Nuptials
description: Miss Carol Ann Michael sen and Robert M. Owens plan to marry in October.

title: SENATE APPROVES AN EDUCATION BILL
description: WASHINGTON, Friday, June 26 (AP)The Senate, working past midnight to clean up a legislative backlog caused by the Cambodian debate, passed a $4.8billion education bill early today.

title: Retired Major Links McCormack and Sweig to Hardship Discharge From Army for Client of Voloshen
description: A retired Army major testi fied yesterday that House Speaker John W. McCormack telephoned him at Fort Jackson in South Carolina to inquire about the status of a soldier's application for a hardship dis charge.

title: Boating Outlook
description: The United States Weather Bureau issued this forecast at 8 P.M. yesterday for New York Harbor, Long Island Sound, Long Island South Shore and nearby coastal waters.

title: The Jaycees Convention: Parties, Beer, Parades and Politics and Concern for Community Service
description: ST. LOUIS, June 25The generation that will provide the nation's leaders in an other decade or so sent some representatives to town this week, and they dropped a few hints about their char acter and hopes.

title: Bridge:
description: STOCKHOLM, June 25 The United States captured the world team champion ship here this afternoon, win ning the final with some thing to spare against the young team representing Na tionalist China, or Taiwan.

title: TALLEY EARNINGS DECLINE IN YEAR
description: Talley Industries, Inc., diver sified industrial producer and makers of products for the aerospace industry, yesterday reported a sharp decline in earnings to $2,711,951, or 43 cents a share, for the fiscal year ended March 31, from the previ ous year's net of $12,342,562, or $1.99 a share.

title: BRONX POLICEMAN DENIES BRIBERY
description: A New York policeman yes terday denied charges that he had lied to a Bronx grand jury about meeting with gamblers to receive bribes.

title: War Is Protested in Capital by New York Executives
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 One hundred executives from almost as many national cor porations flew from New York to the capital today in a move to bring an end to the Vietnam war.

title: 2 Justices Dispute Orders of 3 Others
description: Two State Supreme Court justices acted yesterday to as sure that their orders prevailed over those of three other judges of the same court, whose ac tions had helped a Westchester County contractor avoid ap pearing before a New York County grand jury.

title: Powell Contends That He Won Primary
description: Representative Adam Clay ton Powell of Harlem contended yesterday that he won the Democratic primary election in the 18th Congressional District on Tuesday by some 2,000 votes.

title: College Names 23YearOld President
description: Twentythreeyearold Leon Botstein, who was a student until a year ago, yesterday was named president of Franconia College, a small experimental school in northern New Hamp shire, making him what is thought to be the youngest col lege head in the country.

title: N.C.A.A. GOLF LEAD TAKEN BY WADKINS
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 25 (AP)The University of Hous ton and Lanny Wadkins of Wake Forest took leads today after the second round of the National Collegiate golf tourna ment.

title: Mrs. Meir Plans Statement
description: JERUSALEM, June 25Pre mier Golda Meir plans to make a political statement in the Knesset, or parliament, Mon day, when she is expected to give some indication of Israel's attitude toward the United States peace initiative.

title: Social Reasons Accepted
description: CHICAGO, June 25  The American Medical Association voted for the first time in its 123year history today to al low doctors to perform abor tions for social and economic reasons, as well as medical.

title: 3 CHOREOGRAPHERS DISPLAY NEW WORKS
description: It is a curiosity among thea tergoers that the unfinished work at times evokes a strong er emotive response than the thoroughly polished piece.

title: Black Clergy Issue a Declaration of Independence
description: The National Committee of Black Churchmen issued a Black Declaration of Independence yesterday. It urged the black community throughout America not to participate in annual Fourth of July activities but to celebrate its own Black Lib eration Day this Sunday.

title: Pound Circulation Increases 8.067Million in the Week
description: LONDON, June 25 (AP)The statement of account of the Bank of England for the week ended Wednesday in thousands of pounds follows:

title: Puerto Ricans In Hoboken Win Some Demands
description: HOBOKEN, N. J., June 25 A group of 500 Puerto Ricans protesting alleged police dis crimination marched on City Hall tonight but disbanded peacefully after talks with Mayor Louis De Pascale and Police Chief George Crimmins produced a series of conces sions.

title: Cambodians Await Attack
description: ALONG THE MEKONG RIVER, opposite Prek Tameak, June 25If it rains, we will be fighting the Vietcong, pre dicted Cpl. Koe Vong.

title: Hijacker's Trial Postponed
description: ROME, June 25 (AP)The trial of Raphael Minichiello, the United States marine who forced a jetliner to fly from California to Rome last Novem ber, was postponed today for the second time. It is expected now to be held in November.

title: Bronx Officer Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Pentagon today identi fied 17 servicemen as having been killed in the war in South east Asia, including First Lieut. William D. Bridge of the Bronx, of the Army.

title: Valiant Slips From Berth; 12Meter Yacht Undamaged
description: NEWPORT, R.I., June 25 (AP)  Valiant, the America's Cup contender, was undamaged aft er running aground off her berth last night at the Newport Ship yard.

title: BenGurion Recovering
description: TEL AVIV, June 25 (UPI) Former Premier David Ben Gurion is making a good recov ery and regaining his old vigor, a hospital spokesman said today. Mr. BenGurion, 83 years old, was admitted to Tel Hashomer Hospital Tuesday, running a high fever and suffer ing from headache and nausea.

title: 3 DIRECTORS OF LTV GO TO J. & L. BOARD
description: Three directors of Ling TemcoVought, Inc., including the president of the Dallas based conglomerate, James J. ?? ?? ?? to the board of the Jones & Laughlin Steel Corporation.

title: French Reserves Rise
description: PARIS, June 25 (UPI)The Bank of France said today its visible gold and foreign ex change reserves rose $2.1mil lion in the week ended June 18. France's total reserves at the end of the week stood at $3.9 billion.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, June 25. 1970

title: WHITE HOUSE ASKS LAW TO RESTRICT TEXTILE IMPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Nixon Administration threw its reluctant support today behind legislation to im pose import quotas on textiles. In so doing, it may have opened the way to much broader im port restrictions.

title: Justice Agency Asks Court to Clarify Busing Stand
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to issue a ruling explaining the obligation of urban school sys tems in the South and in the North to bus students to elimi nate racial imbalance.

title: Bank Debits Here Declined in May
description: Charges against checking accounts in New York City banks declined last month by 3.9 per cent from the April level to $4.25trillion, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

title: Yugoslav Sees Kosygin
description: MOSCOW, June 25 (AP) Premier Mitja Ribicic of Yugo slavia had a frank exchange of views with Soviet Premier Alexei N. Kosygin today, Tass, the Soviet press agency, re ported.

title: HEARING OPENS HERE ON U.S. HEROIN FLOW
description: Members of a Congressional committee opened four days of hearings here yesterday on heroin traffic in New York City and heard pleas for Fed eral action to cut off the supply of the drug at its source.

title: Shakespeare Festival Alarums
description: Shakespeare wrote the script in 1596 for the plight that besets the free Shakespeare Festival in Central Park in 1970. Anticipating the seasonal scrounging of Joseph Papp, the troupe of players and the pleasures of New Yorkers watching live theater, his midsum mer night's dreamers said:

title: Israeli Jets Bomb Camps On Outskirts of Damascus
description: JERUSALEM, June 25  Is rael's jets bombed Syrian mili tary camps on the outskirts of Damascus today and shot down a Syrian MIG21 as an intense exchange of fire broke out for the second day along the cease fire line, a military spokesman said.

title: Judge Tells McSorley's to Open AllMale Saloon to All Women
description: Since it opened its doors 116 years ago, McSorley's Old Ale House has served only beer and ale and only to men. But yes terday a Federal judgemale ruled that the sawdustfloored haven was just another public place that must admit any customer who comes in, even a woman.

title: Nuclear Blast in Soviet
description: UPPSALA, Sweden, June 25 (UPI)The Soviet Union today set off an underground nuclear explosion apparently aimed at the flow of water into the the Caspian Sea. The Seismologic Institute announced.

title: Names of 334 U.S. Captives Hanoi Admits Holding
Writer Starts Black Publishing House
description: When Joseph Okpaku, an established author, play wright and editor at the age of 27, considered starting a black publishing house, he was encouraged by announce ments from the publishing in dustry that it would be de lighted to help black entre preneurs.

title: TEXAS GIRLS' CHOIR HEARD AT CONCERT
description: In these days of equal op portunity it was only natural that the success of the Texas Boys Choir should inspire the formation of a Texas Girls' Choir. Now an eightyearold institution, the latter stopped here Wednesday night to give a concert at Carnegie Recital Hall on its way to a European tour.

title: New President Is Named At Hart Schaffner; Net Off
description: Jerome S. Gore has been elected president of Hart Schaffner & Marx, Chicago, succeeding John D. Gray, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer. Mr. Gore was formerly executive vice president.

title: Texas War Foe, 19, Gets 4 Years for Burning Flag
description: DALLAS, June 25 (UPI) Gary Allen Deeds was sen tenced to a fouryear prison term yesterday by a Dallas jury that found him guilty of burn ing an American flag.

title: Nader Urges Muskie to Act
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) Ralph Nader urged Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine, today to rally to support in Congress for a national timetable for cleaning up the environment. He told Mr. Mus kie in a letter that he should champion tougher air pollution restrictions if the 1970 air pol lution legislation is to be some thing better than a fraud on the public.

title: SIMON WASSERMANN
description: Simon Wassermann a Phila delphia architect, died at Epis copal Hospital there Wednes day. He was 75 years old.

title: The Midi Is the Message for Salesgirls
description: In a few weeks, even if you can find a mini for fall in the leading stores, chances are the midivurveyors will use maxisell to talk you out of it.

title: Nixon Accused of Bypassing Congress to Spur Timber Cutting
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The nation's principal conserva tion organizations are accusing President Nixon of attempting an end run around Congress by ordering increased timber cutting in the national forests.

title: Coal Strike Is Over; Senator Promises Mine Safety Inquiry
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 25 (AP)  Thousands of coal miners picked up their tools and returned to the mines in Pennsylvania, West Virginia and Ohio today as a United States Senator announced an investigation into their charges that Federal mine safety legis lation was not being enforced.

title: Two Top Executives to Direct The Consolidated Foods Corp.
description: The Consolidated Foods Cor poration, based in Chicago, again will be headed by two top executives instead of one, as has been the case since last December.

title: JERSEY ARRESTS 15 IN GAMBLING RAIDS
description: PATERSON, N. J. June 25 (AP)The state police broke up what they estimated was a $5millionayear gambling op eration today in raids in four North Jersey counties.

title: Market Summary
description: Thursday, June 25, 1970

title: Picasso Linocuts Offer Familiar Ideas
description: Never having been able to work up a great surge of en thusiasm for Picasso's lino leum cuts (linocut seems now to be the accepted abbreviation), I was happy to discover that the exhibition that opened Wednesday at the New York Cultural Center on Columbus Circle affords a very pleasantexperience. The 100 prints in the show rep resent all of Picasso's output in this medium during the period from 1958 through 1963, and they tell much better as a group than in dividuallywhich means that hereafter they are going to look better one at a time than they used to.

title: New Muddle on Rents
description: The attempt by Democratic leaders in the City Council to put their own distinctive imprint on reform of the rent control law has resulted in a legislative hodgepodge that is likely to prove impossible for tenants, landlords or the city to live with.

title: Soviet Sets Crash Program To Bring In the Harvest
description: MOSCOW, June 25 (Reuters) The Soviet government and the Communist party announced to day that last year's sweeping and costly program to bring in the harvest would he repeated.

title: 2 CONCERNS PLAN TO BUY OWN STOCK
description: OwensIllinois, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it had agreed to buy 800,000 shares of Its stock from the Allied Chemical Corporation for $33.6 million.

title: Governor Selecting 2 Lawyers For Hobart Disorder Inquiry
description: Governor Rockefeller will appoint two lawyers from Rochester to act as special prosecutors in an inquiry he has ordered on student disorders on the Hobart College campus in Geneva and the activities of a police undercover agent known as Tommy the Traveler.

title: Stalin's Bust Placed on Grave in Red Square as Move in Rehabilitation
description: MOSCOW, June 25A fatherlylooking bust of Stalin was revealed without cere mony today at his grave be hind the Lenin mausoleum on Red Square. It was the latest and most symbolic step in the gradual campaign to rehabilitate Stalin's once dis credited image. About 10:30 this morning, workmen took down a wooden fence that for about a week had blocked from view both Stalin's gray granite bust and a similar one of former Presi dent Kliment Y. Voroshilov, who was buried last Decem her. The unveiling, done without any publicity, is sure to be known throughout Mos cow within days, but in the first hours neither Soviet nor foreign tourists in Red Square who saw the Stalin bust seemed to pay special atten tion to it. Policemen appeared surprised by the attention being paid the bust by Western journalists. The bust, the work of Nikolai V. Tomsky, the president of the Academy of Arts, is slightly larger than life size. Stalin looks gentle and wise, as he did in many of the paintings and small busts that were seen every where in the Soviet Union while he lived and until Nikita S. Khrushchev's deStalinization drive of 1956, when Stalin's face virtually disappeared from the Soviet scene.

title: Hanoi Said to Confirm List Putting Prisoners at 334
description: North Vietnam has reported ly declared that a list of 334 American prisoners, compiled by a peace group in New York, is a complete list of all pri soners held in North Vietnam and has insisted that it does not hold any men who are not on the list.

title: Governor Warns Polluters At Ceremony for State Aide
description: Governor Rockefeller warned both state agencies and private corporations yesterday that they would have to pay increas ing concern to the impact of their construction and opera tions on the state's environ ment.

title: Maryland Wedding For Mrs. Thompson
description: ABERDEEN, Md., June 25 Mrs. Rosalie Hunter Thomp son of Havre de Grace, widow of Andrew A. Thompson Jr., was married here Saturday to Josiah Van Kirk Thompson of Greenwich, her late husband's brother, near Bridgeton, N. J.

title: Research on Waste Reuse Approved by Senate Panel
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Senate Public Works Committee approved today a $422million, fouryear program of research to develop systems for reuse of solid waste ma terials.

title: BALTIMORE JURY CITED OVERT ACTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The text of a report prepared by a grand jury in Baltimore and now expunged from Feder al Court records lists 45 overt acts through which a Bal timore contractor allegedly sought to defraud the United States Government.

title: Apartment Houses Facing Threat of Strike Tonight
description: The threat of a strike by 25,000 apartment house work ers was revived yesterday when spokesmen for landlords of rentcontrolled buildings declared that they would cut their employes' salaries if the City Council failed to approve adequate rent increases.

title: Evangelist Rolls Cross Into the City
description: The Rev. Arthur Blessitt arrived in Manhattan yester day with a message of salva tion and what was probably the only pneumatictired cross ever to be trundled across the George Washing ton Bridge.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Back in the glory days of Murderers' Row, two Yankee musclemen, Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, hit more home runs be tween them during the 1927 season than did 14 of the 15 other teams in the big leagues. They established the home run as the Yankee trademark and the Bronx Bombers boisterously blasted their way to championship after championship.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Guidelines for Draft

title: Recount Due in Queens Race
description: The Board of Elections an nounced yesterday that it would conduct an official recount to day to determine the winner be tween J. David Love and Lawrence G. Linnekin for the Republican nomination for the Assembly from the 27th District in the Forest HillsRego Park section of Queens. An official recount yesterday showed Mr. Linnekin receiving 1,111 to 922 for Mr. Love, reversing the elec tion night returns, which gave Mr. Love a fivevote winning margin.

title: Saigon Seizes Papers' Issues
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25A Government spokesman announced that today's issue of 10 Saigon newspapers had been seized. Eight were accused of erroneously having reported an alleged bombing mishap in Rachgia province in the Mekong delta. The newspapers said Gov ernment aircraft had strafed fishing vessels off Rachgia.

title: Olympic Group Invites 44 To 3Week Court Drills
description: Fortyfour basketball players have been invited by the United States Olympic Committee to paticipate in a threeweek training program July 5 through 26 at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs.

title: Ann B. Dickinson Is Wed in St. Croix
description: Miss Ann Bancroft Dick inson and Stephen Chittenden. Turner were married yester day in St. John's Anglican Church, Christiansted, St. Croix, the Virgin Islands. The Very Rev. Dean Francis Sayre of the Washington Cathedral performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Stephen Gow of St. John's Church. A reception was given at the Beach Hotel of St. Croix.

title: Luck of Kennedy Aides
description: WASHINGTON, June 25In his memoirs, Pierre Salinger tells about an old man who met him at the airport when he re turned to California in 1964 to run for the Senate. The man, a stranger, pressed a Kennedy halfdollar into his hand and said, If you carry it with you all the time you can't lose. But the charm failed Mr. Salinger, who had been press secretary to Presi dent Kennedy, was roundly defeated by Senator George Murphy and this year the pattern has persisted.

title: HOSPITALS WANT FUNDS ASSURED
description: Officials of the city's volun tary hospitals sought assur ances yesterday from the state that the hospitals would be re imbursed for higher labor costs that might result from a new contract covering more than 22,000 service, mainte nance, clerical and other non professional employes.

title: Money Expansion Slows; No Stir on Pennsy Filing
description: The Penn Central crisis produced scarcely a ripple in the nation's money markets, banking data published yesterday showed. The pace of monetary expansion appeared to be more moderate than was characteristic in ate May and early June.

title: Militants Denounce Plan
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25 Militant Arab governments and Arab guerrilla groups de nounced today Washington's plea to stop shooting and start talking about peace in the Middle East.

title: Gen. Noble in Vietnam Post
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25 (Reuters)Maj. Gen. Charles C. Noble today assumed com mand of United States Army Engineers in South Vietnam. He succeeds Brig. Gen. Robert M. Tarbox, who took over the command last month following the death in a helicoper crash of his predecessor, Maj. Gen. John Dillard.

title: U.S. to Aid Kent State Inquiry
description: RAVENNA, Ohio, June 25 (UPI)The Federal Government pledged its full cooperation to day to the Portage County prosecutor Ronald Kane in his investigation of the deaths of four Kent State University stu dents on May 4.

title: FARM PRODUCTS RISE IN BUSY DAY
description: In heavy trading, futures prices of the major agricultural commodities shot upward yes terday on the Chicago Board of Trade. In many cases, the trad ing was the most active so far this year.

title: Stocks on the Amex Again Show Drop
description: For the fourth day in a row more stocks declined than ad vanced on the. American Stock Exchange. However the down trend slowed noticeably, Yes terday declining issues totaled 467 compared with 683 on Wednesday, and advancing is sues totaled 287 compared with 144.

title: Saigon Opens New Drive
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25Five thousand South Vietnamese troops began a new operation in rugged northeast ern Cambodia yesterday, less than a week before the dead line set by President Nixon for withdrawal of American troops from Cambodia.

title: Liston Aware Wepner Bout Could Be Last Stand
description: JERSEY CITY, June 25 Suddenly, in the stale, sweaty fragrance of Bufano's Gym today, the noise stopped. The other fighters ignored the bags they were punching, or rolled up their ropes. Sonny Liston was in the ring, and the dozen other fighters and three dozen spectators were watching him.

title: U.S. Tells U.N. of Concern Over Safety of Angkor Ruins
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 25The United States has assured the United Nations of its concern that the temples and monuments at Angkor in Cambodia are not damaged, but it has not guaranteed the safety of the temples if the enemy should use them for military purposes.

title: In Memoriam
description: DAVISDonald H. On your birthday darling. We miss you today and every day of our lives.

title: Upswing Is Seen for jazz As Newport Series Nears
description: Jazz reached a nadir of popularity last year, accord ing to George Wein, producer of the Newport Jazz Festival.

title: Capital Is Sought By Hayden, Stone
description: Hayden, Stone, Inc., a major securities house, disclosed yes terday that it was taking steps to raise $7.8million in addi tional capital in the second major capital infusion for the concern in the last four months.

title: State to Buy Land for Park
description: ALBANY, June 25 (AP)The state will purchase more than 6,700 acres of mountain wilder ness in Ulster County for de velopment as the Minnewaska State Park, Governor Rockefel ler announced today.

title: Staggered Hours Ease Transit
description: The staggered work schedule program to ease peakhour pressures on mass transit serv ing the Manhattan financial district, introduced April 1 for 50,000 commuters, is working out to the satisfaction of its cosponsors.

title: Ward's to Develop Computer Retailing
description: I would doubt that more than 20 per cent of the goods sold in stores today are affected by the computer. In the sev enties, that figure should rise to between 90 per cent and 95 per cent of all merchandise, said Edward S. Donnell, presi dent and new chief executive officer of Montgomery Ward, Chicago.

title: Cotton Market
description: NEW YORK COTTON

title: DISMISSAL SUIT LOST BY SCHOOL BOARD 14
description: State Supreme Court Justice J. Courtney McGroarty ruled yesterday that Local School Board 14 could not dismiss the district superintendent or dele gate authority to miniboards in the WilliamsburgGreenpoint section of Brooklyn.

title: Southern Group Shares First Bill At Jacob's Pillow
description: LEE, Mass., June 25  A fledgling dance company from North Carolina as well as the New York City Bal let's Patricia McBride and Edward Villella opened the 38th Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here this afternoon.

title: A Correction
description: An article in The New York Times last Sunday stated in correctly that the Downstate Medical Center and Kings County Hospital had jointly opened the city's first clinic for treatment of sickle cell anemia. The first such clinic in the city was opened at Jamaica Hospi tal in 1966, and others have been opened since at St. Luke's Hospital, Sydenham Hospital and Montefiore Hospital.

title: ROBERT G. SPIVACK, COLUMNIST, DIES
description: Robert G. Spivack, a syndi cated columnist and former Washington correspondent for The New York Post, died yes terday, apparently of a stroke, in Riverside, Conn. He was 55 years old.

title: Graham Rallies Draw National Flock
description: They are the saved. They come from all over the country, individually and in groups, usually carrying Bibles, and they are the backbone of the mass evan gelistic rallies of Billy Gra ham.

title: Jeffrey S. Grant And Miss Rudel Planning Bridal
description: Miss Madeleine Franoise Rudel and Jeffrey Steven Grant plan to be married in December.

title: $25Million More in Fines
description: Checking on parking viola tors with a computer should put at least $25million more into the city treasury in the year beginning July 1, Anthony H. Atlas, head of the new Parking Violations Bureau pre dicted yesterday. He said that computer supervision should double the efficiency of the present system.

title: Newspaperman Is Named As City Police Press Aide
description: Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced the ap pointment yesterday of Wilfred N. Home, a former newspaper man and city administrator, as deputy commissioner in charge of press relations for the Police Department, a $26,320ayear position.

title: Ottinger Is Scornful of Goodell On Alliance With Rockefeller
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Representative Richard L. Ot tinger, Democrat of New York, returned to the House today after winning his party's nom ination for the United States Senate and promptly went on the attack against his Repub licanLiberal opponent, Senator Charles E. Goodell.

title: Effort to Fill New Haven Panther Jury Fails Again
description: NEW HAVEN, June 25The arduous effort to assemble a jury to hear the first of a series of trials of Black Panthers charged in connection with the slaying of a party member was stalled again here today.

title: Washington: For the Record
Two U.S. Envoys Approved; Senate Unit Delays on 3d
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reu ters)The Senate Foreign Re lations Committee today ap proved the nomination of am basadors to Venezuela and Niger but held up a controver sial appointment to the United States embassy in South Africa.

title: Clifford Zieger, 63, ExPilot For Eastern Airlines Dies
description: Clifford Zieger, a retired Eastern Airline pilot who had flown more than 30,000 hours, died Wednesday at his home in Ridgefield, Conn. He was 63 years old.

title: Carl J. Austrian, Lawyer, Dies; Aided Depositors in Depression
description: Carl J. Austrian, the lawyer who directed the recovery of more than $100million in sav ings for 400,000 New Yorkers who thought they had lost all when the Bank of United States closed in the Depression, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hos pital, after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 20 Sutton Place South.

title: D. NICK FRATE
description: DARIEN, Conn., June 25D. Nick Frate, for many years chairman of the Darien Parks and Recreation Commission, died yesterday at his home, 16 Maple Street. His age was 57.

title: Market Place
description: If you live in the East and you're worried about a reces sion, think about the people in sunny California where a substantial part of the de pressed aerospace industry is based.

title: DR. FRANK BABBOTT, HEADED L.I. COLLEGE
description: MORRISTOWN, N.J., June 25  Dr. Frank Lusk Babbott, former president of the Long Island College of Medicine, died yesterday in Morristown Me morial Hospital after a short illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Bernardsville.

title: Article 3  No Title
Magnavox Is Changing To Lois Holland Agency
description: The Magnavox Company, which is splitting with Ken yon & Eckhardt, yesterday announced that Lois Holland Callaway will take over the creation of the advertising for its consumer electric products.

title: Hinson Leads Cleveland Golf by Shot on 5UnderPar 65
description: CLEVELAND, June 25Larry Hinson took the first  round lead today in the $150,000 Cleveland open with a 65 while Dave Hill equaled the current tour record of 29 for nine holes.

title: Senator Gets Peace Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) Senator Stephen M. Young, Democrat of Ohio, accepted today petitions opposing the Indochina war. Sponsors said that the signatures numbered 75,000. Roger Evans of Cleve land, chairman of the Ohio Peace Petition Committee, pre sented the petitions to Mr. Young.

title: PETERSON ALLOWS INDIANS 9 SINGLES
description: A checked swing at a break ing pitch, resulting in a soft popup, ended Bobby Murcer's bid to become the first major league player to hit five con secutive home runs.

title: House Vote Overriding Hospital Veto
SATO AND CABINET DISCUSS TEXTILES
description: TOKYO, June 25The Jap anese Government issued a statement today saying it would do its utmost to settle the textile dispute with the United States.

title: Vietnam Talks Still Stalled As 2 Sides Trade Charges
description: PARIS, June 25The Viet nam peace talks remained blocked today as each side ac cused the other of aggression and of rigid refusal to heed the other's proposals.

title: President of Stanford Resigns After 2 Years of Disturbances
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 Dr. Kenneth S. Pitzer, after two years of campus turmoil, re signed today as president of Stanford University.

title: Alma M. Talley, 72; Writer Devised Crossword Puzzles
description: Alma Mabrey Talley, a writer, movie critic and crossword puzzle expert, died of a stroke yesterday at French Hospital at the age of 72. She was the wife of Victor W. Talley, retired Sunday picture editor of The New York Times, and lived at 100 Central Park South.

title: Mets' Records
description: BATTING

title: Jersey Panther Trial Hears Reporter
description: JERSEY CITY, June 25  Walter H. Waggoner, a report er for The New York Times, today answered a subpoena to testify in Superior Court about a story he had written on the machinegunning of a police station here, but he refused to name police sources he had quoted in the story.

title: ARGENTINA ACCUSES 3 FOREIGN COMPANIES
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 25A business court judge has charged three foreign meat  packing companies under the anti monopolies law with manipulat ing prices at the Buenos Aires central cattle market.

title: Radicals Give Demands for July 4 Fete
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Organizers of Honor America Day met for the second time today with a group of young people led by Rennie C. Davis, the radical leader, and said they would consider a list of 13 demands that Mr. Davis presented.

title: Brazil Razes Big Coffee Area to Halt Leaf Fungus
description: SAO PAULO, Brazil June 25 (AP)The government has authorized the destruction of coffee plants in an area four fifths the size of Texas, if nec essary, to try to avoid a major catastrophe in this nation's most important product.

title: Physicians Urge Exercise of Caution in Prescribing Drugs During Pregnancies
description: CHICAGO, June 25  A panel of physicians urged doc tors today to be more cautious in writing prescriptions for pregnant women and newborn infants. Some drugs, they said, can damage the unborn child and the effects of many other medications in these situations are largely unknown.

title: Urban League Elects Head
description: The election of William Toles, equal employment opportunity officer for the International Telephone and Telegraph Cor poration, as chairman of the New York Urban League was announced yesterday. Other new officers elected at the league's annual meeting in its headquarters, 204 West 136th Street, were Richard Green, an officer of the Carver Savings bank, as treasurer, and John Paterson, chairman of the league's Manhattan advisory committee, as assistant treas urer.

title: Rhode Island G.O.P. Nominates Priest
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 25  A Liberal Roman Catholic priest who opposes the war in Indochina won the Republican nomination for the United States Senate tonight, becoming the first priest ever to run for the Senate.

title: U.S. Exports and Imports Rose to Records in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Both exports and imports rose Ito record levels in May and the export surplus increased to $334million from $202million in April, the Department of Commerce reported today.

title: A Correction
description: In yesterday's editions of The New York Times the name of J. Edward Meyer, winner of the Republican contest in West chester for the Assembly nomi nation in the 92d District, was incorrectly given. Mr. Meyer defeated the incumbent, Rich ard Cerosky, by a vote of 7,174 to 5,494.

title: POLLUTION CURB SET FOR LAKE CHAMPLAIN
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., June 25 A joint Federalstate confer ence on pollution in Lake Champlain ordered today that the International Paper Com pany and the State of New York, identified as the two major polluters of the lake, take prompt steps to improve the situation.

title: U.S. War Deaths 80 for Week; Total Is Lowest Since March
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 25 (UPI)United States combat deaths in Indochina last week were at their lowest level since the end of March, but the number of wounded was near ly double that of the previous week, the United States com mand reported today.

title: Roundup: Pirate Hits Give Carlton Food for Thought
description: Steve Carlton stood on the mound waiting to pitch to Bob Robertson, the first bat ter in Pittsburgh's ninth in ning. Get Robertson and the next two batters, Carlton thought to himself, and it's two straight shutouts.

title: TERMINAL PLANNED FOR LIQUEFIED GAS
description: The Distrigas Corporation an nounced yesterday that it planned to build a $60million deepwater terminal on Staten Island to receive and redis tribute liquefied natural gas from Algeria. Jacek Makowski, the concern's president, said the terminal would be a 40acre tract on the southwest shore of Staten Island.

title: CONGRESS VOTES YOUTH JOB FUND
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Congress approved today the $50million in additional funds requested by President Nixon to provide summer jobs for youths.

title: Article 1  No Title
INTREPID IS VICTOR IN OPEN JUMPING
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 25Rafik Torkia's In trep:d captured the first open jumper class today as the Mid dlesex County horse show onened a fourday run in John son Park.

title: U.S. JUDGE BALKS A SONG MY CHARGE
description: ATLANTA, June 25A Fed eral district judge ordered to day a temporary halt to the Army's prosecution of a soldier accused of murdering Vietnam ese civilians at Songymy.

title: ONE DEAD, 3 INJURED AT RENOVATION SITE
description: One man was killed and three others were injured yes terday afternoon as part of a building that was being reno vated collapsed and crashed through a protective sidewalk tunnel at 255 West 14th Street, near Eighth Avenue. Two of those injured were pedestrians.

title: Two Recipe Ideas For the Weekend
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with en asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Barristers' Wives' Party
description: The New York City Chap ter of Barristers Wives will hold a dance on the Audubon Terrace at the Hispanic Mu seum, 155th Street and Broad way, from 7 P.M. to midnight tomorrow. Proceeds will go to Inwood House, a home for unwed mothers, and to the Black Cultural Opportunity Program for parents and chil dren of P. S. 133 in Harlem. The benefit cochairmen are Mrs. George Sena and Mrs. George D. Covington.

title: Bronx Man Is Arraigned After Firecracker Incident
description: A 24yearold man who al legedly threw a firecracker onto the playing field at Yankee Sta dium Wednesday, injuring baseball player, was arraigned in Bronx Criminal Court yester day. Judge Neal Bottiglier held Luis Estada, of 615 East 140 Street in $1,500 bail pending hearing on Monday.

title: PENNSY PAYROLLS SEEM UNCERTAIN
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Secretary of Transporta tion, John A. Volpe, said here today that he was unable to say with any degree of cer tainty that the Penn Central Transportation Company can or can not meet its payrolls.

title: Music: Generation Gap?
description: Looking out at the wide spectrum of ago groups that made up the audience on Monday night for the sum mer's opening program of the Goldman Band at Damrosch Park, Oscar S. Straus felt im pelled to describe these Gug genheim Memorial Concerts as a Woodstock for all ages. That was off the mark in at least one respect, for there was no grass in evi dence. Damrosch Park, which adjoins the Metropolitan Op era House on Lincoln Cen ter's south side, is an entirely paved area.

title: O.A.S. IS DIVIDED ON TERROR ISSUE
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The foreign ministers of the Organization of American States began consultations today on an interAmerican formula to counteract the dangers of po litical terrorism and urban guerrillas.

title: Arms Depot Attacked
description: PNOMPENH, June 25 (AP) A large enemy force tried to capture one of the Cambodian Army's largest supply depots only 20 miles north of Pnom penh today but Government troops seemed to have broken up the attack after 10 hours of fighting.

title: Ulla M. Lehtokoski Becomes a Bride
description: Miss Ulla Maria Lehtokoski and Jeffrey David Holzman were married here yesterday afternoon in the home of Mrs. Louis Klein Jr., the bride groom's sister. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, senior rabbi of Temple EmanuEl, performed the ceremony.

title: ADDONIZIO NAMED IN KICKBACK TRIAL
description: TRENTON, June 25  The prosecution's key witness in the conspiracyextortion trial of Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark named and pointed to Mr. Addonizio today as a man to whom he had paid $3,000 in bribes in 1968.

title: ACCUSED DETECTIVE MOVES TO RETIRE
description: A detective charged with con spiring to receive a $5,000 ille gal payment from Montgomery Ward submitted his retirement papers to the Police Depart ment yesterday.

title: Rockefeller and Goldberg Are Critical Of Each Other on Vietnam War Stands
description: Governor Rockefeller and his Democratic opponent, Arthur J. Goldberg, played political at tack and counterattack for the first time yesterday. The Gov ernor charged that Mr. Gold berg supported the war poli cies of President Johnson, and the Democrat charged that Mr. Rockefeller supported President Nixon's enlargement of the Indochina war.

title: BIG MORPHINE CARGO IS SEIZED IN FRANCE
description: MARSEILLES, France, June 25 (AP)French and Italian police, working in cooperation with United States narcotics agents and Turkish and Leba nese police, have seized a ship ment of 343 pounds of mor phine base.

title: U.S. MIDEAST PLAN URGES BOTH SIDES TO START TALKING
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The United States today for mally announced the launching of a broadly based diplomatic campaign in the Middle East to encourage Israel and the Arab countries to stop shoot ing and start talking under United Nations auspices.

title: SOUTH KOREA MARKS ANNIVERSARY OF WAR
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 25As South Koreans ob served the 20th anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean war today, President Chung Hee Park called on his nation to continue to build up its strength in order to crush any new Communist aggression.

title: Rory O'Dwyer Weds Miss Hargen
description: Miss Myrta Hargen, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Hargen of San Juan, P. R., was married here yesterday afternoon to Rory O'Dwyer, whose father, Paul O'Dwyer, was defeated in his bid for the Democratic nomination for Senator from New York in Tuesday's primary.

title: BERMUDA TROPHY GOES TO CARINA
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 25  While other yachts were being blasted by knockdown winds and shattering seas, the NewporttoBermuda race still was in progress for half tee 149 starters. Richard S. Nye's Class C. sloop Carina, from Green wich. Conn., meanwhile had a serene troublefree passage and was confirmed as the main winner today.

title: Hard Work and Hunting
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Rather than risk criticism for mixing pleasure with busi ness, Secretary of Commerce Maurice Hubert Stans called off a jaguar hunt in South America in April. Judging by the criticism he has received, Mr. Stans might well have canceled a few other items in his busy sched ule. The Secre tary, a very suc cessful biggame hunter and re garded as the only American ever to bag a bongo (antelope) in the Congo, has not enjoyed a particularly successful tour of duty. He failed in his at tempt to enlarge the depart ment's influence in economic matters. His efforts to get some kind of massive black capitalism program moving have not been notably pro ductive. And he was unsuc cessful at persuading Ameri can allies, especially Japan, to voluntarily curb textile ex ports to prevent legislative restrictions from being im posed by Congress.

title: Memorial Services
description: GOURLIEEdith Colman. Memorial service at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, N. Y., June 26, 1970, at 12 noon.

title: Wednesday Fights
description: Naples, ItalyFranco Zurlo, 188 pounds, Italy, outpointed Enzo Farinelli, 118, Italy, 15 rounds; Zurlo retained Euro pean bantamweight title.

title: BIG BOARD DRIFTS ON LOW TURNOVER
description: My biggest business these days is in bonds, a securities broker said yesterday in Wall Street.

title: U.S. Proposals for Mideast Peace Rebuffed by Nasser
description: CAIRO, June 25  Presi dent Gamal Abdel Nasser to night rebuffed the latest Unit ed States plan designed to bring about a peaceful settle ment between the Arabs and Israel.

title: Excerpts From Trudeau Cabinet's Foreign Policy Statement
description: During the postwar dec ades, Canada and Canadians acquired a certain taste and talent for international ac tivities of various kinds. Ca nadians took pride in the skill with which their politi cal leaders, their military and civilian peacekeepers, their trade and other negotiators conducted the nation's busi ness abroad.

title: Billy Rose Fund Gives $250,000 to City Center
description: The Billy Rose Foundation has given a grant of $250,000, to be allotted over a fiveyear period at $50,000 a year, to the City Center of Music and Drama, Inc., it was an nounced yesterday by Charles Wohlstetter, foundation di rector.

title: O.A. S. Soccer War Success
description: In a world where peace seems increasingly elusive, the quiet success of the Organization of American States in resolving the soccer war between El Salva dor and Honduras should not go unnoticed. The Foreign Ministers of the five Central American nations, acting for the O.A.S., worked out an agreement for demilitarized zone on the disputed border.

title: Nasser Cuts Libyan Visit
description: CAIRO, June 26President Nasser flew back to Cairo to day from Libya, ahead of sched ule, and the Government of the United Arab Republic prepared to undertake consultationswith other Arab countries on the lat est United States proposals.

title: ISRAEL AND SYRIA BATTLE THIRD DAY IN THE GOLAN AREA
description: JERUSALEM, Saturday, June 27Israeli and Syrian forces fought with tanks, artillery and jets yesterday in the Golan area as the biggest Middle Eastern, battle since 1967 went into its third day.

title: Columbia Spectator Undergoing Inquiry Into TaxExempt Status
description: The Columbia Daily Specta tor, an undergraduate daily that has taken strong stands on political issues and candi dates, is being investigated by Internal Revenue Service agents to see if its taxexempt status is legal.

title: Shaw's Aerials Counted on to Down Eastern Eleven
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., June 26 (AP)The 10th annual Coaches AllAmerica football game to morrow night is expected to be a highscoring duel of two powerful offenses, with the West rating a slight edge over the East on the strong passing arm of Dennis Shaw of San Diego State.

title: Detroit Edison Offers Stock
description: The Detroit Edison Company began yesterday offering its shareholders the right to sub scribe for 2,885,486 additional common shares at $16.50 on the basis of one new share for each 10 held of record Thurs day. The offering, managed by Morgan Stanley & Co., Inc., Myth & Co., Inc., and Lehman Brothers expires July 14.

title: Screen: 'Beyond the Valley of the Dolls':Film Seems to Parody His Earlier Efforts
description: Any movie that Jacqueline Susann thinks would damage her reputation as a writer cannot be all bad."Beyond the Valley of the Dolls" isn'twhich is not to say it is any good. It is to say that on the scale that measures the comparative values of incomparable things, for example, termites versus tides, "Beyond the Valley of the Dolls" comes off with a slightly higher rating than Miss Susann's novel, "Valley of the Dolls," and the movie that Mark Robson distilled from it, making tap water out of tap water, as it were.The courts having denied Miss Susann's plea for an injunction against the film's release, "Beyond the Valley of the Dolls" opened here yesterday at the Penthouse and Cinema Rendezvous Theaters. It is apparent that intelligences quite different from Miss Susann's and Robson's are at work from the opening title card, which disowns its predecessor ("This is not a sequel") and goes on to say that the new film, "like 'Valley of the Dolls,' deals with the oft-times nightmare world of show business, but in a different time and context."The time and the context are very much out of the imagination of the movie's producer-director, Russ Meyer ("The Immoral Mr. Teas," "Vixen," "Cherry, Harry and Raquel"), whose work has been the subject of a retrospective at Yale and analyzed by Leslie Fiedler (get back to your raft, Leslie honey).With a screenplay by Roger Ebert, the Chicago film critic who is also one of Meyer's most appreciative, most astute interpreters, and with the financial backing of 20th Century-Fox, Meyer has made the quintessential Hollywood movie we all knew he could with $1.5-million. After all, he's been making them on budgets of far less for years."Beyond the Valley of the Dolls" is bigger but not necessarily better than "Lorna" and "Finder's Keepers, Lovers Weepers," principally because Meyer is now, quite consciously, attempting to parody his earlier movies, most of which were unconscious, robust parodies of conventional Hollywood presentations of sex, violence, breast sizes and sin.Meyer's earnestly vulgar sensibility, which once met the audience on its own level by giving it exactly what it wanted, has become patronizing. Meyer makes fun of the audience, and of himself. What's worse, he has become downright inhibited, at least in terms of female, nudity on display, but it may be that, at heart, Meyer is a prudeThe oft-times nightmare world of show business of "Beyond the Valley of the Dolls" looks very much like the vision one might get of Los Angeles, if one's reading were confined to The Enquirer and to the early conjectures regarding the murders of Sharon Tate and her companions last year It's a tacky, flashy milieu of sports-cars, pot puffed self-consciously, and of houses and apartments that seem to have no relation to the people who inhabit them.Most prominent among the characters are the members of an all-girl rock trio, Kelly (Dolly Read), Casey (Cynthia Myers,) who is beautiful, has Lesbian tendencies and is the daughter of a United States Senator, and Petronella (Marcia McBroom), who is black and beautiful.There are also Ronnie Barzell (John LaZar), a swinging hermaphrodite and king of the pop music world Lance Rocke (Michael Blodgett), a gigolo who literally loses his head over Ronnie; Ashley St. Ives (Edy Williams), the prototype for all earlier Meyer heroines ("men were toys for her amusement"), and Porter Hall (Duncan McLeod), a middle-aged lawyer, a sort of nasty Mr. Teas who, when he goes to bed with Kelly, strips down to his boxer shorts, his black dress socks and his garters.There is so much love-making in the film (very soft-core, very ersatz) that, to squeeze it all in, Meyer must often cut between seductions non-stop. There is a funny, fast, typically Meyer montage of Los Angeles sights (bare breasts, shacks, bare breasts, freeways, bare breasts), and never a moment of silence. When the sound-track is not pulsating with rock, it is moaning with a soap opera organ, just to let us know that it is supposed to be funny.Sometimes it is funny, as when the narrator, at the end, piously enumerates the failings of each character ("Susan Lake? Perhaps she was too good  sometimes excessive love makes us blind to human failings"). The failings of most of the characters, happily, are not so positive. They fail with an intensity of mindlessness forever beyond the creatures of Miss Susann's vapid imagination.

title: Executive Changes
description: Frederick A. Fiedler has been named president and chief operating officer of Continental Copper & Steel Industries. He formerly was president, di rector and chief executive officer of the MI Steel Corporation.

title: GOVERNOR VISITS 8 HOUSING SITES
description: Governor Rockefeller yester day toured eight sites that have been proposed for statesubsi dized housing, insisting that re election politics. Was not his ran tive, but beaming at some high praise offered along the way by the Democratic Minority Leader of the StateSenate, Jo seph Zaretzki.

title: NEW YORK STREAK ENDS AT 5 GAMES
description: MONTREAL, June 26The Expos walloped three home runs in Jarry Park tonight and brought the New York Mets down to earth, 65. The defeat ended a five game winning streak that the Mets had run up against the Cubs in Chicago this week.

title: Silent Witness Gets Year
description: Samuel Cavalieri, a reputed member of the Mafia family of the late Thomas (ThreeFinger Brown) Luchese, was sentenced yesterday to one year in jail for refusing to answer ques tions of a Bronx grand jury that was investigating gam bling. Cavalieri, 58 years old, of 34.25 150th Place, Flushing, Queens, was tried in May and found guilty on 25 counts of criminal contempt, all mis demeanors.

title: THANT SENDS PLEA FOR BUILDING FUNDS
description: GENEVA, June 26Secretary General U Thant appealed to the governing council of the United Nations Development Program today to pledge $10 million immediately toward the construction of the proposed $80million extension to United Nations Headquarters in New York.

title: CORN OFF THE COB FAVORED ON COAST
description: Corn Off the Cob and Ter lago, 3yearolds who were un placed in the Kentucky Derby, are the top weights for today's $123,200 Hollywood Derby at Hollywood Park.

title: CABLE CONCERNS HAIL F.C.C. RULES
description: The wideranging bloc of cable television regulations and proposals issued Wednesday by the Federal Communications Commission have prompted fa vorable responses from the cable TV industry and silence from commercial television sources.

title: AN ARTS COMPLEX OPENS IN HARLEM
description: A threeday celebration in volving black artists from throughout the city began last night in the new Mount Morris Park Recreation Center and Amphitheater in Harlem.

title: Gala for Ecology Group
description: Gala Event No. 2, spon sored by the Environmental Action Coalition, which spon sored Earth Day, will take place on Monday at the Directoire, 160 East 48th Street. Proceeds will be used for the group's work in con sumer and community edu cation. Tickets, at $10 each, are tax deductible and in clude hors d'oeuvre, drinks and dancing. The tickets are available from Miss Susan Zornberg at the coalition of fice, 235 East 49th Street, or at the door.

title: THURSDAY NIGHT FIGHTS
description: Portland, Me.Pete Ricci telli, 178 pounds, Portland, knocked out Jacques Boulay, 181, Montreal, 2 rounds.

title: Floods Kill 13 in Thailand
description: BANGKOK, Thailan, June 26 (Reuters)Thirteen persons, in cludting 10 children, drowned in Floods this week in northern Udon and toey provinces near the border with Laos, oifficial sources said today.

title: Humphrey Backed For Senate Contest By Minnesota Party
description: DULUTH, Minn., June 26 (UFI)  The Minnesota State Democrat  Farmer  Labor party helped Hubert H. Humphrey lalong the comeback trail today, but adopted a peace plank very close to that advocated by Sen ator Eugene J. McCarthy two years ago.

title: MRS. TRELAWNEY GAYER
description: LONDON, June 26 (UPI) Mrs. Marilyn Wills Gayer, cousin of Queen Elizabeth II, died yesterday five months after her wedding. She was 22 years old.

title: CHECKING USE OF RAILS' ASSETS
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The interstate Commerce Com mission opened an investiga tion today of two railroads in a move that could have pos sible implications in the Penn Central case.

title: Police Trial in Gratuity Case Scheduled to Open Tuesday
description: The Police Department will begin Tuesday a departmental trial of a detective charged with conspiring with Lieut. Watkins T. Parry to receive an illegal $5,000 gratuity from Montgomery Ward, Inc.

title: JERSEY GOLF TITLE TAKEN BY SCHWAB
description: BELLEVILLE, N. J., June 26 Pat Schwab, the 37yearold professional from Crestmont, put together final rounds of 66 and 70 to win the 72hole New Jersey. Professional Golfers As sociation championship today with a 272 over the par71 Hen dricks Field course.

title: Blue Cross Here to Cover Single Women's Abortions
description: Blue Cross of Greater New York has decided to extend its coverage for abortions per formed in hospitals to include single women and dependent children after the state's new abortion law takes effect Wednesday.

title: Rockwell Expects Bomber Contract To Increase Jobs
description: The North American Rock well Corporation expects to add about 15,000 workers at its Los Angeles plant as a direct result of the recent award of the con tract for the B1 bomber, Wil lard F. Rockwell Jr., chairman and chief executive officer, said in an interview here yesterday.

title: N.E.T. Protests to Nixon Over Interview Exclusion
description: James Day, president of Na tional Educational Television, protested yesterday the exclu sion of public television from President Nixon's televised con versation with feature corre spondents from the three major commercial networks. The pro gram will be broadcast Wednesday night.

title: Czech Regression
description: The former chief of the Czechoslovak Communist party, Alexander Dubcek, has now been removed from his ambassadorial post and expelled from the party, while former Premier Oldrich Cernik has been ousted from his Cabinet position. These changes virtually complete the long process of purging from Czechoslo vakia's political life all who played important roles in the 1968 effort to create a socialism with a human face. The only exceptions are those who, tike the present party chief, Gustav Husak, jumped on the Soviet bandwagon immediately after the August 1968 invasion, or, like President Ludvik Svoboda, are too weakened by age to offer even potential resistance to Moscow's wishes.

title: State Unhappily Returns Money Sent by Mail for Special Lottery
description: The State Tax Department, which prefers to collect money rather than refund it, is now facing the sad job of returning hundreds of dollars to people all over the world who have heard that they might become a millionaire through a $3 lot tery ticket.

title: INSIDE LOANS CUT IN HALF AT I.O.S
description: GENEVA, June 26  Inves tors Overseas Services an nounced today that loans and other financial arrangements made in favor of insiders and other persons associated with the giant mutualfund complex had been nearly halved in the last five months.

title: Belinda A. Adams to Marry on July 18
description: GLEN ROCK, N.J., June 26 Mr. and Mrs. Valda L. Adams Jr. have announced that their daughter, Miss Be linda Antoinette Adams, and Donald Dill Eddy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Eddy of Miami, will be married in the Com munity Church here on July 18.

title: U.S. ASKED TO PAY '58 CENTRAL LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 The Irving Trust Company of NeW York, as trustee of $16.9million Governmentguar anteed loan to the former New York Central Railroad, took the first step today to get the Treasury to make good on the guarantee.

title: Dutch Court Stops U.S. Concerns' Bid
description: Both the B. F. Goodrich Com pany and the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company were barred yesterday from using any rights attached to the shares of Rubberfabrick Vred estein, N.V., that they had ac quired earlier this year. The decision, handed down by J. Slotemaker, president of The Hague District Court, set off flurry of charges and counter charges here by the two Amer ican rubber companies.

title: National O.T.C. Clearing And N.A.S.D. Seek Merger
description: The National O.T.C. Clearing Corporation yesterday con firmed that it was negotiating a merger with the National Association of Securities Deal ers to form a key link in the N.A.S.D.'s plan to create a na tional clearing system for un listed securities.

title: De Gaulles Return to France
description: BAYONNE, France, June 26 (AP)France's former Presi dent, Charles de Gaulle, and his wife returned to France by car today after a vacation in Spain.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Saturday, June 27, 1970

title: BALI CO. COMPLETES REFUNDING OF DEBT
description: The Bali Company, a leading producer of foundations and lingerie, announced that it had completed a refunding of $9.1 million of short and longterm debt with three major New York banks and had arranged through other sources for an additional $3million of working capital.

title: Sartre Is Arrested at Last, but Briefly, for Role on a Maoist Weekly
description: PARIS, June 26JeanPaul Sartre has been thumbing his nose at the French Govern ment, intellectually speaking, for more than a month. For some time the Government did not react, but today Mr. Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir, his longtime companion, were ar rested briefly.

title: Four Seasons Nursing Centers Files a Reorganization Petition
description: Four Seasons Nursing Cen ters of America, Inc., a major operator and builder of nurs ing homes and childcare cen ters, filed yesterday in the United States District Court in Oklahoma City for a petition to reorganize the troubled com pany under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: Chinese Visit Brazzaville
description: BRAZZAVILLE, Congo Re public, June 26 (Agence France Presse)A military delegation from Communist China has ar rived here to take part in cere monies marking the fourth an niversary of the People's Army of the Congo Republic, the former French Congo. The Chinese Ambassador gave a re ception last night for the dele gation and Congolese officials.

title: Reimbursement Levels For Doctors Sustained
description: BALTIMORE, June 26 (AP) The Social Security Ad ministration announced to day that it would temporar ily continue to reimburse physicians and other sup pliers of medical services under the existing levels under part B of Medicare, which is due to be changed July 1.

title: Dayan Is Choice In $95,835 Trot
description: WESTBURY, L. I., June 26 It was last Aug. 2 that Nevele Pride won the Realization Trot at Roosevelt Raceway in 2:07 25, setting a world record for 1 116 miles at that gait over a halfmile track.

title: British Bill Rates Decline
description: LONDON, June 26 (Reuters) The average rate at today's tender of British Treasury bills fell to 6.855 per cent, from 6.860 per cent last week. This week's 120 million offer of 91day bills met applications of 210,780,000. Next week 120million bills will be of fered, replacing 120million of maturities.

title: POWELL COMPLAINS AS RECOUNT BEGINS
description: The official canvass of the votes in the 18th Congressional District began yesterday as Representative Adam Clayton Powell charged that Tuesday's Democratic primary was fraud ulent and should be held over again. The Harlem Representa tive called the election the biggest scandal I have ever seen. Here in New York City we have been confronted with a major scandala Black Tea pot Dome, he said.

title: 747 Engine Flames On Landing Here; 12 Injured on Exit
description: A Trans World Airlines Boe ing 747 developed a fire in one of its engines after landing at John F. Kennedy International Airport yesterday, and a dozen passengers were slightly injured as they fled from the jumbo jet.

title: JULY 4 GROUP BARS RADICALS' DEMANDS
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 A spokesman for the Honor Amer ica Day Committee said today that the morning program for the group's July 4 celebration in Washington had been complet ed and would not include any thing demanded yesterday by Rennie C. Davis, the radical leader.

title: The Pentagon Plays More Than War Games
description: WASHINGTON  The sixth side of the Pentagon is its lighter side.

title: Laird Asserts Bombing Will Go On in Cambodia
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird today reiterated Washing ton's plan to continue American bombing raids inside Cambodia after the June 30 deadline for the withdrawal of American troops here.

title: New Mechanical Heart
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 A New York engineer has in vented an artificial heart that uses body powermove ments of the diaphragm. The normal human breathing rate of 12 to 16 strokes a minute is converted to 60 or 70 strokes for the mechan ical heart. Joseph La Russa, manager of ad vanced engineering for the Farrand Optical Company, Inc., will receive Patent 3,518,702 for the implantable heart on July 7. The patent also covers similarly powered equipment that surrounds and assists a partly disabled natural heart. So far as Mr. La Russa knows, his is the only artificial heart that does not require electrical or atomic power. There is no problem of dissipating the heat that might be created by a motor.

title: Miss Kathy Bowman Wed to H. L. Loomis
description: NEW HAVEN, June 26 Miss Kathy Lou Bowman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Carleton F. Bowman of Den ver, was married today to Henry Luther Loomis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luther Loomis of New York and Sharon, Conn. The civil ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace George Longyear. There were no attendants.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Bombing Suspect Indicted
description: Carlos Feliciano, 41 years old, of 313 East 118th Street, was indicted yesterday by Bronx grand jury on a charge of placing two pipe bombs at the Army recruiting station at Southern Boulevard and 163d Street at 2:05 P. M. May 16. Mr. Feliciano was charged with attempted arson, possession of a bomb, reckless endangerment of citizens and possession of an explosive substance. Supreme Court Justice Sidney A. Fine set bail at $100,000 and sched uled a hearing for Tuesday.

title: ALGERIA OUTLINES ECONOMIC GOALS
description: ALGIERS, June 26  Algeria has launched an ambitious four year economic expansion pro gram that President Houari Boumediene says will enable the former Frenchruled coun try to turn the page once and for all on the heritage of un derdevelopment left by colo nialism.

title: Roundup: F. Robinson Hits Two Grand Slams in Row
description: Neither a sore back nor a sore throat could keep Frank Robinson from playing last night, and neither Joe Cole man nor Joe Grzenda could keep Robinson from hitting grandslam homers.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) The Defense Department an nounced today that the follow ing servicemen from the New York area had been killed in Southeast Asia:

title: ONLY ONE CONCERN FILES A NEW ISSUE
description: The newissue market stum bled through another period of lower prices and weak trading activity this week, with only one company managing to ne gotiate a successful fullyregi stered offering.

title: HelpWanted Ads Off To 180 in Month of May
description: The index of helpwanted ads in metropolitan newspa pers dropped sharply again in May, the National Indus trial Conference Board re ported yesterday.

title: 44 French Priests Resign in Protest
description: PARIS, June 26  Forty four French priests have re signed en masse, declaring that while faithful to the Gospel they can no longer in con science accept a great many of the present structures of the Church.

title: Frank Lynch, $23.60, Wins
description: MIAMI, June 26 (AP) Mary Edwards's Frank Lynch took the lead in the stretch, and scored a threelength victory today at Tropical Park. He ran six fur longs in 1:10 35 and paid $23.60 for $2 to win.

title: Senate Panel Approves Rise in U.S. Debt Limit
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP)  The Senate Finance Committee approved today Housepassed bill to raise the temporary national debt ceil ing to $395billion.

title: KNEEL WILL RETURN TO AID PAPER TALKS
description: George E. McDonald, presi dent of Mailers Union No. 6, said yesterday that Theodore W. Kheel, mediator in the news paper dispute, had informed him by telephone that he would cut short a European vacation and return to help resolve the union's differences with the Publishers Association of New York City.

title: JOSEPH J. O'HARA
description: Joseph J. O'Hara, a senior account executive with South ern Outdoor Markets of New York, died of a heart attack yesterday at Ms home at 1660 East 8th Street, Brooklyn. He was 38 years old.

title: STATE OFFICIAL JOINS CITY HOSPITAL TALKS
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, moved into the New York City hospital negotiations yesterday at the direction of Governor Rockefeller.

title: RAIN POSTPONES YANKEES, RED SOX
description: The New York Yankees, al ready suffering considerably be cause of bad weather on at tractive dates this season, con tinued to suffer last, night when a heavy rainstorm forced the postponement of the opener of a fourgame series with the Boston Red Sox at Yankee Stadium.

title: CHICAGO DRIVERS REJECT NEW OFFER
description: CHICAGO, June 26  Truck drivers and terminal workers in the Chicago area have over whelmingly rejected a proposed new settlement of their 78day combination strike and lockout, thus continuing their threat to upset a national master freight truck settlement reached April 2, it was announced today.

title: Rogers, at O.A.S. Talks, Favors Pact to Counter Political Terror
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  Secretary of State William P. Rogers told the hemisphere for eign ministers today that the United States favored a new international agreement to counter the rising tide of world wide political terrorism.

title: Washington: For the Record
Profit of General Instrument Up 41% on 8% Rise in Sales
KARAJAN TO LEAVE PARIS ORCHESTRA
description: PARIS, June 26Herbert von Karajan has resigned from the Orchestre de Paris effective in 1971.

title: Market Place
description: Where are the gogo funds of yesteryear? Is it true that the bad stocks, the thinly capitalized issues, the fads and other foible stocks have been purged from the per formance portfolios?

title: Susan Belden Is Bride Of Robert James Egan
description: Miss Susan Beaven Selden and Robert James Egan were married here yesterday after noon at St. John'sinthe Village Episcopal Church by the Rev. Charles Howard Graf and the Rev. John Mulheam. A reception was given at the River Club.

title: State to Seek Death Penalty For Manson and 3 Women
description: LOS ANGELES, June 26 (UPI)  The prosection announced today that it would demand the death penalty for Charles Man son and his three female co defendants accused of seven killings.

title: Dr. Borden S. Veeder, 86; Led Pediatricians' Group
description: ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) Dr. Borden S. Veeder, a widely known pediatrician, died Wed nesday of infirmities at St. Luke's Hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: Jordan's Premier Resigns
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 26 Premier Bahjat alTalhouni of Jordan resigned tonight, and King Hussein asked his Foreign Minister, Abdel Monem Rifai, to form a new Government. Mr. Rifai has been conducting nego tiations with the Palestinian commandos, and it was thought his appointment was a gesture to conciliate them.

title: HENRY H. DREIFUS, 50, PLANNING OFFICIAL
description: Henry H. Dreifus, city plan ning official and reform Demo cratic leader in Brooklyn, died Thursday at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn of a heart attack. He was 50 years old, and lived at 636 Brooklyn Avenue in the borough.

title: Cambodia Says Prince Sold a Relic to Pay Debt
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 26 (Agence Prance Presse)Pri nee Norodom Sihanouk, deposed Cambo dian Chief of State, has sold the sacred sword of the throne for several million dollars to pay off gambling debts, the official Cambodian press agency reported today.

title: Greece Orders Retirement Of 12 More High Officers
description: ATHENS, June 26  The Greek militarybacked regime announced today the compul sory retirement of 12 major generals, bringing to 60 the number of senior officers re tired in the last semiannal re view of armed forces personnel.

title: Thunderstorm Postpones Play In 2d Round of Cleveland Golf
description: Cleveland, June 26A two hour thunderstorm washed out play in the seoondround of the $150,000 Cleveland open golf tournament today and forced a postponement until tomorrow.

title: All Bermuda Sail Winners Established
description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 26Patrick E. Haggerty's Bay Bea, from Dallas, succeeded Thomas J. Watson Jr.'s Palawan of Greenwich, Conn., as the runnerup in Class B today in one of the final bits of busi ness associated with the New porttoBermuda yacht race.

title: Florence Larue Has Son
description: HOLLYWOOD, June 26 (UPI) Florence La rue Gordon, a member of the Fifth Dimension singing group, gave birth yes terday to a 5 pound 12 ounce son at Cedars of Lebanon Hos pital. The child, who has been named Geoffrey, is also the son of Marc Gordon, manager of the singing group.

title: Barring of Women From McSorley's Will Be Continued
description: McSorley's Old Ale House, whose 116yearold practice of turning away women with a variety of hoots, clangs and whistles was held on Thursday to be illegal, will be able to keep on barring women, at least until Tuesday.

title: 3 Clashes Are Reported Within 35 Miles of Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 26Scattered fighting was re ported at several points within 35 miles of this capital today, but elsewhere in Cambodia military activity remained gen erally low for the third con secutive day.

title: U.S. GROUP CLOSING HOSPITAL IN MEKONG
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 26 (UPI)The Thomas Dooley Medical Foundation, an Ameri can charitable group, is closing its hospital facilities on Khong Island in the Mekong River on the LaosCambodia border be cause of Communist operations in the area, military sources said today.

title: Treasury Statement
Start a Boutique Line, and Presto, It Outdoes Parent Company
description: The infant offspring of the snootiest fashion concerns are doing nicely, though many of them are not yet a year old. They're proving that a designer's name packs wallop even when the de signer steps into a lower price bracket.

title: Miss Louisa Dixon To Wed in Omaha
