description: Premier Golda Meir's lowkey response to the new American peace initiative keeps alive the opportunity for quiet diplomacy to break the dangerous Middle East impasse.

title: Divorces Given a Roosevelt And a Rockefeller in Mexico
description: JUAREZ, Mexico, June 29 (AP)Members of two well known American families  Roosevelt and Rockefeller  were granted divorces today in this Mexican border town.

title: BASKETBALL SIGNINGS
description: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION

title: PROCEDURES BLAMED IN 1968 BAY LANDING
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Improper landing procedures were blamed by the National Transportation Safety Board today, for the crashlanding in San Francisco Bay Nov. 22, 1968, of a Japan Airlines DC8 airliner.

title: Brooklyn Suspect In Murder of 3 Gives Himself Up
description: A 29yearold Brooklyn man being sought by the police for the murders of three narcotics pushers last Wednesday night walked into a police station in the BedfordStyvesant section last night and surrendered.

title: Common Market Signs Pact With Israel
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 29 The European Economic Com munity and Israel signed a five year preferential trade agree ment today that Foreign Minis ter Abba Eban said had signifi cance beyond its economic con tent in providing the basis for deeper political relationships.

title: Dr. Salk Weds Francoise Gilot in France
description: PARIS, June 29 (AP)Dr. Jonas E. Salk, developer of the Salk polio vaccine, and Frangoise Gilot, former mis tress of Pablo Picasso, were married today in suburban Neuilly.

title: Letters to the Editor of The Times
description: Dialectics of History

title: Contractor Here Fined for Contempt
description: A case that embroiled five State Supreme Court justices in angry clashes last week ended yesterday with the central fig urea Westchester contractor wanted by a New York County grand jury as a material wit ness in a bidrigging case fined $250 for contempt, but he was released from a $100,000 bail obligation imposed last Thursday.

title: Guild Hall to Be Aided
description: EAST HAMPTON, L. I., June 29The Guild Hall will benefit from a special pre view of. Frank Perry's film Diary of a Mad Housewife on July 3 at 5:30 P.M. The screening will be followed by a garden party at the 17th century home a Mrs. Harry W. Watts.

title: DECLINE RESUMES IN AMEX TRADING
description: After five downdrifting days last week, stocks on the Amer ican Stock Exchange could find little impetus yesterday to rise. As a result the index closed at 20.13. down .09.

title: Nixon and the State Race
description: When Arthur J. Goldberg and Howard J. Samuels were still battling for the Democratic nomination for Governor, some one asked Governor Rockefeller who he thought had the best chance of beating him in No vember. Mr. Rockefeller an swered: Dick Nixon.

title: HEALTH GROUP TO AID IN FAMILY PLANNING
description: CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) Plans were announced here to day for a family planning proj ect that, for the first time, will involve a professional health organization in planning a na tional program aimed at im proving health care for the poor.

title: Lucia in Park Tonight
description: Donizetti's Lucia di Lammer moor will be given in Central Park's Sheep Meadow tonight at 8:30, opening the fourth season of free concerts by the Metropolitan Opera in the city parks. Anna Moffo will sng the title role, with Sandor Konya, Frank Guarrera, John Macurdy and Leo Goeke in the cast. Ignace Strasfogel will conduct. If it rains the opera will be given Thursday.

title: Golf Tour Makes a Stop in the Tall Corn
description: IOWA CITY, June 29Golf and industry merged today for a proamateur tournament deep in the cornbelt country that cost more than $100,000 to pro duce.

title: Conservationists Call for Halt On Chesapeake Bay Atom Plant
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  Three conservation groups peti tioned the Atomic Energy Com mission today to halt construc tion of a nuclear power plant on Chesapeake Bay pending studies of the effect the plant's discharges of hot water and nuclear wastes would have on the ecology of the bay.

title: NETS OPEN CAMP FOR ROOKIE TRIALS
description: Just down the road from Jamaica, Queens, where Lou Carnesecca coached St. John's basketball teams for the last five seasons, the little man is sued his first practicedrill orders yesterday in preparation for a new season. But this time Carnesecca was conduct ing workouts for 34 young men hopeful of playing professional basketball next winter.

title: 2 BLACKS CHARGED IN POLICE AMBUSH
description: DETROIT, June 29Two Ne groes, reportedly part of a small extremist group, were charged today with attempting to mur der Detroit policemen.

title: Manson's Trial Is Moved Into Court
description: LOS ANGELES, June 29 Legal arguments in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three young women moved from the judge's chambers to open court today following a protest by the District Attor ney's office.

title: A Cover Girl Symbolizes RumanianChinese Ties
description: PEKING, June 29There she sits in full color, a sultry blond Rumanian with her shirt open down to a peek of black lace an unlikely cover girl for a magazine in Chinese circulated in Peking.

title: Bill Rates Register a Decline At Treasury's Weekly Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Govern ment reported late this after noon.

title: M'COVEY MOVES UP IN ALILSTAR VOTE
description: Willie McCovey, the San Francisco slugger, has regained the lead over Richie Allen of St. Louis in the voting for first baseman on the National League AllStar team.

title: NEW HAVEN ROAD TOPIC OF RULING
description: The Supreme Court yester day sent back to the Interstate Commerce Commission and the Federal District Court in New Haven a reorganization plan for the New Haven Railroad.

title: To Be a Bride
description: MUTTONTOWN, L. I., June 29Mr. and Mrs. Dan G. Kramer have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Laura Dean Kramer, to Charles Seymour 3d.

title: N.E.T. and Channel 13 Merge; Ford Funds to Insure Solvency
description: National Educational Televi sion and New York's Channel 13 announced yesterday that they would merge into a single broadcasting organization, the Educational Broadcasting Cor poration.

title: NASSER IN SOVIET FOR VITAL TALKS
description: MOSCOW, June 29Presi dent Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic ar rived today for talks with Soviet leaders that are ex pected to shed some light on the possibilities of a political settlement of the Middle East conflict.

title: Washington: For the Record
Bills Sign No. 1 Choice, Cowlings From U.S.C.
description: BUFFALO, June 29, (AP) The Buffalo Bills signed to day their No. 1 draft choice, Al Cowlings of the Univer sity of Southern California.

title: City Employes Stop Work
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 29 (AP)About 550 hourly city employes here refused to report to work this morning in sup port of demands for union rec ognition and better pay and working conditions. The work stoppage included employes of the sanitation and maintenance departments. Office personnel and the police and fire depart ments were not included.

title: City Asks Funds to Buy Papp's Theater
description: A day after the New York Shakespeare Festival's 11 hour marathon presentation of The Chronicles of King Henry V and Richard III in Central Park, Mayor Lind say agreed to submit a budg et modification to the Board of Estimate for the purchase of the festival's Public Thea ter at 425 Lafayette Street.

title: 2 CHOREOGRAPHERS DISPLAY TECHNIQUES
description: Robert Streicher and Peggy Cicierska collaborated on a program of dances Sunday night at the Cubiculo. Both are accomplished technicians who developed their dances out of a secure base of craftsmanship. Neither, however, managed to rise far above the admiration that one reserves for sheer skill.

title: Hospitals Strike Here Still Threatened
description: Vincent D. McDonnell, chair man of the State Mediation Board, met separately yester day with both sides in the criti cal hospital dispute in an effort to avert a walkout tomorrow morning.

title: Roundup: Rodriguez Puts A Mexican Hex on Orioles
description: The difference in Aurelio Rodriguez when he was a California Angel and now that he's a Washingting Sen ator is this simple:

title: The Evolution of a Rocking Chair
description: A chair can be like a pretty girl in a good dress you don't have to see all the curves, but you know they are there, said Marc Held as he sank into one of his three roundbottomed Fiberglas rocking chairs that look like inverted crash helmets.

title: Mrs. Jeremy Thorpe Killed; Wife of British Liberal Chief
description: LONDON, June 29  Mrs. Jeremy Thorpe, wife of the lead er of the Liberal party, was killed in an automobile accident in Basingstoke today. She was 32 years old.

title: Woman Killed in Car Crash
description: Mrs. Mary Maginn, 25 years old of 9720 56th Avenue, Queens, was pronounced dead yesterday at St. John's Hospital in Elmhurst shortly after a 1 A.M. accident on the Long Is land Expressway. Her husband, Vincent, also 25, apparently lost control of the wheel of their 1968 Volkswagen, the police said, and went through the divider and hit a westbound car operated by Julio Rivera, 34, of 568 Prospect Ave., the Bronx. Mr. Maginn was re ported in serious condition, with multiple fractures, at St. John's, where Mr. Rivera was attended for cuts and bruises and re leased.

title: U. S. Aide Comments
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (Reuters)  Commenting on Moscow's action on Mr. Cole, the State Department spokes man, Carl E. Bartch, said today, Any action we take will be governed by what best pro tects the interests of U. S. newsmen in Moscow.

title: Fire Losses Estimated
description: The Insurance Information Institute reported yesterday that the estimated dollar losses by fire in the United States to taled $186.94million in May, a decline of less than 1 per cent from the April level but 18.7 per gent higher than in May, 1969.

title: Supreme Court Bans Merger Of 2 Small New Jersey Banks
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Supreme Court, in a 52 decision, held today that the merger of two small banks in Phillipsburg, N. J., violated the Clayton Act and the Bank Merger Act of 1956. It was the first time that the High Court had ruled on the merg er of banks so small in a community so small. Merger Act of 1956. It was the first time that the High Court had ruled on the merg er of banks so small in a community so small.

title: State Officials Quarrel With Sociologist on Part of $300,000 Study of Drug Addiction Here
description: Officials of the State Nar cotic Addiction Control Com mission who retained a Colum bia University sociologist to study some facets of the ad diction problem have done an evaluation of his evaluation.

title: Soviet Bank's Pay Rise Averts Strike in London
description: LONDON, June 29 (AP) A London bank owned by the Soviet Government struck a bargain with British labor to day and granted its employes a wage increase.

title: NAVAJOS UPHELD ON LAND CLAIMS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)  The Navajo Indians won a major victory today in a fight to prove title to 40 mil lion acres of Western land.

title: News Summary and Index
description: TUESDAY, JUNE 30, 1970

title: The First Ladies of U.S. And Peru See Quake Area
description: HUARAS, Peru, June 29  Mrs. Richard M. Nixon strolled through the streets of this earthquake  stricken Peruvian community today to accept gifts of flowers from children, look at the damage, and chat with survivors.

title: LUTHERANS VOTE TO ORDAIN WOMEN
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 29The Lutheran Church in America overwhelmingly approved to night the ordination of women to the ministry.

title: New Betting System Is Where the Action Is; For Quiet, New Park Is Where Relaxation
Jacklin Bows to Amateur
description: SUNNINGDALE, England, June 29 (AP)Tony Jacklin, the United States Open champion, lost an 18hole challenge match today by five strokes to the British Amateur champion, Mi chael Bonnallack. Bonallack shot 69, Jacklin 74.

title: Flyover to Honor Wheeler
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, the retiring chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, will be honored by a flyover of 26 planes dur ing ceremonies Thursday at nearby Andrews Air Force Base, the Pentagon announced today. General Wheeler is retiring after 38 years of military serv ice. He will be succeeded by Adm. Thomas H. Moorer.

title: Railroad Electricians Strike
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 (UPI)Railway electricians of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers struck Southern Pacific Company terminals today from El Paso, Tex., to Portland, Ore., in a work rule dispute.

title: EXECUTIVE DEFENDS RAILS' OPERATIONS
description: William N. Deramus 3d, pres ident of Kansas City Southern Industries, Inc., said yesterday that we are confident that we can show that since the forma tion of the holding company in 1962 our rail carrier subsidiaries have been operated in a man ner consistent with the public interest.

title: Minnesota Abortion Law Upheld in First Court Test
description: ST. PAUL, June 29Minne sota's 77yearold abortion law was upheld as constitutional today in its first court test.

title: Physicians Here to Record All Abortions as Deaths
description: Physicians who perform abor tions under the new state law that goes into effect tomorrow will issue a death certificate for the fetus, a spokesman for the city's Health Services Ad ministration confirmed yester day.

title: J.M. Moskin Fiance Of Maureen Gallaty
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 29 Mrs. Frederick Urbin Gal laty has announced the en gagement of her daughter, Miss Maureen Anne Gallaty, to Jeffery Michael Moskin, son of Mrs. William H. Fine shriber Jr. of New York and the late Richard Moskin. The wedding is planned for July 26.

title: Raise for 700,000 in State As Minimum Pay Increases
description: An estimated 700,000 men and women workers will get a raise tomorrow under New York State's new minimumwage law, which increased the hourly, minimum from $1.60 to. $1.85.

title: Observer: Everything Should Be Perfectly Fine
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 There was an immense mess. It was spreading over the United States at a rate that titillated science. From time to time the television networks showed spe cial news film of the immense mess advancing through Chi cago or Boston. It was depress ing to watch.

title: AUSTRALIAN BALLET, NUREYEV, DUE HERE
description: LONDON, June 29The Aus tralian Ballet will tour the Unit ed States for 10 weeks, with Rudolf Nureyev as guest artist, it was announced here today.

title: Boy Dies in Thermal Pool
description: YELLOWSTONE PARK, Wyo., June 29 (AP)A 9yearold boy, Andrew Hecht of Williamsville, N. Y., died yesterday when he fell into a thermal pool near Castle Geyser in Yellowstone National Park. The temperature of the water Is above 200 de grees. Officials said the death was instantaneous.

title: Illinois Governor Praises New Antipollution Law
description: ST. CHARLES, Ill., June 29  Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie signed here today an Illinois pollution control act that he described as the most compre hensive in the nation.

title: N.A.A.C.P.'s Head Brands, Administration AntiNegro
description: CINCINNATI, June 29The Nixon Administration was de nounced as antiNegro here to night by the chairman of the board of the racially moderate National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

title: Retiring Shearson Chief Calls for Changes
description: Fortytwo years ago, on July 9, 1928, a young Cor nell graduate joined the Na tional City Company, the in vestment banking affiliate of the National City Bank, as an $80amonth mail clerk.

title: Politicians Change, but British Civil Service Goes On
description: LONDON, June 29In his first week at the Foreign Of fice, Sir Alec DouglasHome has seen the top 50 or so peo ple in the department. Every one of them worked for him the last time he was Foreign Secretary, seven years ago.

title: LYON FIRST ENTRY IN $125,000 TROT
description: WESTBURY, L.I., June 29 Lyon, a 6yearold bay from Sweden, was the first horse chosen today for the $125,000 Roosevelt International, the world's richest invitation trot.

title: FOOTBALL SIGNINGS
description: NATIONAL CONFERENCE

title: JORDAN DISBANDS SPECIAL ARMY UNIT
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 29 (Reuters)The Chief of Staff, Maj. Gen. Mashur Haditha, to day announced the disbanding of the army's Special Branch, a unit accused by the Palesti nian commandos of having fo mented clashes and having plotted the assassination of Palestinian leaders.

title: Surtax on Income To End at Midnight
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)The income tax sur charge ends at midnight to morrow.

title: Negro Rape Appeal Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Supreme Court rejected unanimously today an appeal by Thomas C. Wansley, a young Negro from Lynchburg, Va., who had been convicted of rape and sentenced to life in prison. The Court made no comment on contentions by Wansley's lawyers that a confession at tributed to him had been invalid and that Lynchburg newspaper articles had prejudiced the case.

title: MUTINY CONVICTIONS OF TWO MORE UPSET
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The United States Court of Military Review has reversed the mutiny convictions of two more men involved in the pro test by prisoners at the Army's San Francisco Presidio stock ade, the Pentagon said today.

title: Foe Renews Assault
description: SAIGON, June 29 (AP)As the last American combat troops withdrew from Cambo dia today, Vietcong and North Vietnamese troops renewed their assault on the Cambodian munitions depot at Longvek, 23 miles north of Pnompenh, and shelled Cambodian troop positions with mortars in the SiemreapAngkor area in the northwest.

title: 3 Boys Held as Milk Thieves
description: MILLVILLE, N. J., June 29 (UPI)Three boys, aged, 15 and 16, were under the supervision of juvenile authorities today after the police said they had found that the boys were get ting up before dawn, leaving notes in home milkdelivery boxes ordering chocolate milk and orange drink, and then picking up their orders before the actual customers got up.

title: Supreme Court's Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: F.C.C. Lets Alabama TV Setup Drop BlackOriented Programs
description: WASHINGTON, July 29The Federal Communications Com mission ruled today, by a 4to3 vote, that Alabama's education al television system was free to drop the blackoriented pro gramming of the National Edu cational Television Network as a matter of taste or judg ment.

title: College to Keep R.O.T.C.
description: WAREHAM, Mass., June 29 (AP)University of Massachu setts trustees decided today to continue Reserve Officers Training Corps programs but to withdraw academic credit for military indoctrination courses and drill. The proposal will be made to the Department of De fense in renegotiating the uni versity's R.O.T.C. contract for the year beginning in Septem ber, 1971.

title: Soviet Scientist Assails Pollution From Coal Mines
description: MOSCOW, June 29 (UPI) A Soviet conservationist has said that the great Kuznetsk coal mines are devouring fer tile lands, poisoning the air and polluting the water.

title: Transplant Patient Dies
description: STANFORD, Calif., June 29 (UPI)The 22d patient to re ceive a heart transplant at Stanford University Hospital died of unknown causes today, 46 days after receiving the new organ. Eric Wainwright, 62 years old of Menlo Park was never discharged from the hos pital after receiving the trans plant on May 13. A hospital spokesman said an autopsy would be performed to deter mine the cause of death. Nine of the hospital's 24 heart trans plant patients are still living.

title: MRS. KENNEDY BACKS HUSBAND'S VERACITY
description: Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy says she believes everything Ted said about the events sur rounding the accident on Chap paquiddick Island last summer that involved her husband, Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts, and took the life of a young secretary, Mary Jo Kopechne.

title: Market Place:
description: How do you get the two bestknown iconoclasts in the accounting profession on the same side?

title: Coppolino Plea Refused
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Supreme Court refused today to review the second degree Florida murder convic tion of Dr. Carl Coppolino. The 38yearold anesthesiologist faces life in prison. Coppolino's appeal, by the noted Boston lawyer F. Lee Bailey, challenged the sufficiency of evidence to convict him in the 1966 slaying of his wife. Carmela.

title: Soviet Advises Correspondent For C.B.S. to Leave Country
description: MOSCOW, June 29  The Foreign Ministry today advised William Cole, Moscow corre spondent for the Columbia Broadcasting System, to leave the Soviet Union because he had engaged in activities in compatible with the status of a foreign journalist.

title: Congo Envoy in Bonn Shot
description: BONN, June 29 (Reuters)A Congolese student shot and in jured the Congo Republic's charg d'affaires, Elie Dinga, outside the embassy in the Bad Godesberg area today after his request for a passport was re jected. A hospital spokesman said Mr. Dinga was undergoing surgery but his life was not in danger. The assailant was captured.

title: Blackmun's First Action On High Court Is Dissent
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)Associate Justice Harry A. Blackmun issued today his first opinion, a dissent, since taking office June 9 as a member of the Supreme Court.

title: TWO MORE CAUGHT IN PRISON ESCAPE
description: Two more of the five pris oners who escaped Sunday evening from the Federal House of Detention at 427 West Street were captured yester day, leaving only one at large.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: MUSQUARO LAKE, Quebec When Gordon Blair set our amphibious plane, a Grum man Mallard, on the dark smooth waters of Musquaro Lake in eastern Quebec, a shower of silvery spray rose past the windows and for moment we could not see the neat little tent cottages of the St. Lawrence Fishing and Hunting Club.

title: SOYBEANS PRICES REACH NEW PEAKS
description: With one eye on the weather, traders bought heavily on the Chicago Board of Trade yes terday, sending newcrop corn and soybeans futures soaring again to new highs for the season.

title: ADDONIZIO'S LAWYER QUESTIONS WITNESS
description: TRENTON, June 29  The lawyer defending Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark, who is on trial here with five other defendants for extortion and conspiracy, took the prosecu tion's key witness today through an extended crossex amination.

title: Generator Pact Signed
description: Gulf General Atomic, Inc., and the Foster Wheeler Corpo ration announced yesterday that they had signed a coopera tive agreement for the design and manufacture of steam gen erators for Gulf General Atom ic's high temperature gas cooled reactor systems. Gulf General Atomic, a subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation, is the prime contractor to the Public Service Company of Colorado for the Fort St. Vrain nuclear generating station.

title: CONTACTS ACUITY LAID TO VOLOSHEN
description: John F. Donato, a public re lations man, testified yesterday that Nathan M. Voloshen gave him the use of the office of House Speaker John W. Mc Cormack, and that he, Mr. Do nato, in turn, arranged for his employer, the Sperry Gyroscope Company, to engage Voloshen with a monthly retainer of $1.250.

title: Dr. Vaughan Mason, 55, Dead; Head of County Medical Society
description: Dr. Vaughan C. Mason, an obstetrician, who was installed a month ago as president of the New York County Medical Society, died at Sydenham Hos pital yesterday morning after a brief Illness. He was 55 years old and lived at 28 Priscilla Avenue in Yonkers.

title: Adams Accuses Gubernatorial Rivals on War Stands
description: Paul Adams, the Conserva tive party candidate for Gov ernor, criticized his two oppo nents last night for their stands on American foreign policy.

title: ARTS AGENCY GIVING $2MILLION IN GRANTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The National Endowment for the Arts announced today that it would soon make $2million in grants to support and en courage selected arts groups across the nation.

title: New Peace Step Foreseen
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 29President Nixon conferred with Secretary Rogers today amid recurring reports that the Administration was preparing to take new diplomatic steps to add life to the Paris peace negotiations.

title: FIXED RATE SEEN ON CANADA DOLLAR
description: TORONTO, June 29The Bank of Nova Scotia, a leading Canadian bank, said today that the sudden movement of Unit ed States troops into Cam bodia intensified pressures on the Canadian dollar and forced Ottawa's May 31 decision to let the dollar float freely in the foreignexchange market.

title: TV's Loyal Opposition
description: The offer by the Columbia Broadcasting System to allow free time to the loyal opposition party out Of powerDemocratic or Republicanis a construc tive response to the problem of fair access raised by Presidential domination of the airwaves.

title: Patricia Mertens to Be Married Laura Kramer
description: Judge William Mertens of the City Civil Court and Mrs. Mertens have announced the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Patricia Ann Mer tens, to Stephen Ross Beck with, son of Mrs. Robert E. Beckwith of Glenview, Ill., and the late Mr. Beckwith.

title: Clare B. Buck Becomes Bride Of D. M. Dalva
description: Miss Clare Bowen Buck, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Orton Buck of New York, was married There yesterday to Da vid Morrison Dalva son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Dalva of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Donald C. McFerren at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: City Buys Bush Terminal As Containership Facility
description: The city bought the 100acre pier property known as Bush Terminal in Brooklyn yesterday as part of a plan to turn the facility into the borough's first containership terminal.

title: Construction Contracts Dropped Sharply in May
description: A sharp drop in nationwide construction contracts in May caused the Dodge index of con struction contract value to dived to 170 from 203 in April, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Sys tems Company reported yes terday.

title: TRANSPORT NEWS: 747 FIRE ASSESSED
description: Trans World Airlines said yesterday that an engine fire that erupted during the landing of a T.W.A. Boeing 747 jet liner here Friday night was caused by an accumulation of Fuel in the engine's tailpipe. The fuel was pumped into the tailpipe after the engine's air compressor stalled during the landing, it was said.

title: Leary Cautions Public On Fireworks Danger
description: With the Fourth of July celebration coming up, Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary warned the public yes terday of the dangers of fire works and at the same time called upon every member of the force to prevent the il legal sale of the explosives.

title: Facsimile of Times Sent To Expo '70 Via Satellite
description: A special, reducedsize fac simile of page one of yester days's Nam York Times was sent to the United Nations pavilion of Expo '70 in Osaka, Japan, via communications satellite and a telenews system developed by The Asahi Shimbum, the Tokyo newspaper.

title: Ouster of Sihanouk Depicted as Almost an Accident
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The overthrow of Prince Noro dom Sihanouk of Cambodia, the event that thrust another Asian country into the Indochina war, appears to have been almost an accident for everyone con cerned.

title: War Casualties
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) The Defense Department an nounced today the names of the following servicemen from the New York area as having been killed in action in Southeast Asia:

title: British Encyclopedia To Name Y. & R. in Fall
description: Young & Rubicam will be getting the assignment to advertise the installment form encyclopedias that are being published by Marshall Cavendish, Ltd., the British concern.

title: REFUSE STILL DEEP IN BROWNSVILLE
description: Two weeks, three days and several extra garbage pickups since a section of Brownsville erupted in angry disgust over sanitation services, the Brook lyn neighborhood remains fil thy.

title: JAMES W. CAMERON
description: PEEKSKILL, N. Y., June 29 James W. Cameron, a traffic manager for the Union Carbide Corporation, died at Commu nity Hospital here Saturday. He was 42 year old and lived in Yorktown Heights.

title: Finley, A's Owner, Gets Oakland Franchise From National Hockey League
description: The National Hockey League awarded yesterday the star crossed Oakland Seals to Char les O. Finley, the controversial, owner of the Oakland Athletics baseball team.

title: Negro Sworn In at Ceremony As Chief Patent Examiner
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  Lutrelle F. Parker of Arlington, Va., was sworn in by Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans today as an examinerinchief and as a member of the Patent Office Board of Appeals.

title: $113 Winner Spices Goshen Opening
description: GOSHEN, N. Y., June 29 Here, in the cradle of trotting, where since 1838 harness racing has been a way of life, the Grand Circuit moved into His toric Track today for the 58th time since 1873. This touring school of juvenile and sopho more standardbreds annually provides a common meeting ground for the bigcity gamblers and the bluejeaned townfolk.

title: Flintkote to Raise Prices on July 20
description: The Flintkote Company an nounced yesterday that it would raise prices from 10 per cent to 20 per cent above current market prices on all gypsum wallboard and lath products.

title: Peak Capital Crowd Foreseen On July 4 Honor America Day
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Bob Hope, the comedian, who is national cochairman of Honor America Day, forecast this morning that the July 4 celebration in Washington would attract the biggest crowd that has even gathered for any show, estimating that more than 400,000 persons would come for the day's events.

title: In The Nation: The Specter of Ronald Reagan
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 American ground troops are out of Cambodia on schedule. That is all to the good and emphasizes, rather than dimin ishes, the need for the Senate to pass the CooperChurch amendment on Tuesday.

title: $6BILLION FUND BILL VOTED BY CONGRESS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)  Senate passage by voice vote completed Con gressional action today on a bill that includes an emergency $50million appropriation to provide summer jobs for dis advantaged youths.

title: PARENTS APPROVE COLLEGE SIGNING
description: MANSFIELD, Pa., June 29 (UPI)The parents of Torn Mc Millen, one of the nation's most widely sought high school bas ketball player said today that a minor misunderstanding had been ironed out and that they agreed with Tom's deci sion to enroll at the University of North Carolina.

title: In Brooklyn's Italian Section, Businesses and Mouths Are Closed
description: At 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon a red sedan, mod ified and chromed, with the name Bad Sicilian scrawled on its fender, went roaring down 86th Street, the major thoroughfare in Brooklyn's heavily Italian Bath Beach.

title: A Listing of New Books
description: FICTION

title: Union Signs Grape Growers
description: DELANO, Calif., June 29 (UPI)Between 15 and 20 per cent of California's table grapes are being grown in vineyards with union contracts, according to the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee. The Union also reported yesterday signing pacts with nine more growers, bringing the total to 30.

title: 7 SEIZED IN SUFFOLK IN WELFARE FRAUD
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 29 Seven men were arrested by Suffolk County police today on charges of fraud involving the cashing of welfare checks.

title: U.S. URGED TO AID BLUECOLLAR MAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 29In a confidential report to the President, a special White House panel recommends ur gent Administration assistance for millions of bluecollar workers, described as economi cally trapped, socially scorned and overripe for a politi cal response to the pressing needs they feel so keenly.

title: G.I.'s, Back in Vietnam, Are Hard at WorkGlad but Exhausted
description: FIRE SUPPORT BASE EUNICE, South Vietnam, June 28Twentyoneyear old S. Sgt. Stanley Zeager of Rocky River, Ohioone of the more than 30,000 American soldiers sent to Cambodia is back in Vietnam and glad of it.

title: Orioles Call Up Infielder
description: BALTIMORE, June 29 (AP) The Baltimore Orioles recalled Bobby Grich, an infielder, to day from Rochester in the In ternational League.

title: Senate Unit Votes to Double Food Stamp Appropriations
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)The Senate Appropria tions Committee voted to double funds available for the food stamp program in the next 12 months, to a total of $1.25 billion.

title: Justices Put Off a Ruling On Objectors to One War
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The Supreme Court put off until next term today a ruling on whether young men who op pose the Vietnam war but not Ian wars are entitled to be ex cused from military duty as conscientious objectors.

title: Reserve Board Adopts Rule About Subordinated Notes
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The Federal Reserve Board adopted a new rule today re quiring that subordinated notes or debentures issued by banks to raise funds have a maturity of at least seven years and a minimum denomination of $500 if they are to be exempt from interest rate ceiling under Regulation O.

title: Wilson Reelected Labor Party Leader by Acclamation
description: LONDON, June 29  Harold Wilson was reelected leader of the Labor party today despite unhappiness at the election up set June 18 that threw the party out of power.

title: Specialists of 30 Nations Discuss Help for Poor
description: BADEN, Austria, June 29 Consumerprotection ex perts opened an international conference in this garden spa today amid growing anxiety that they were failing to reach the needs of the poor.

title: Boeing Adds Director
description: George H. Stoner, senior vice presidentoperations, has been elected a director of the Boeing Company. His election fills a post left vacant by the recent death of John O. Yeasting. Be fore becoming senior vice presi dent last April, he was Boeing's aerospace group vice president.

title: Executive Changes
description: Robert Macht has been elected vice president of the Southeast Bancorporation, Inc., effective Aug. 1. He recently resigned as chairman of the board of Jordan MarshFlorida and as executive vice president of the parent company, Allied Stores Corporation. He has been a member of the board of the bank holding company.

title: COURT WILL RULE ON SCHOOL BUSING
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the issue of school busing to achieve integration, but it did not say whether its ruling would come before schools open in the fall.

title: REPUBLIC STEEL ENDS TRUST SUIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 29In the third such case against a major steel company in little more than a year, the Justice Department brought suit today against the Republic Steel Cor poration for engaging in alleg edly illegal reciprocal business arrangements.

title: Seaborg Renominated to the A.E.C.
description: SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., June 29 (AP)President Nix on nominated Dr. Glenn T. Seaborg today, to another fiveyear term as chairman of the Atomic Energy Com mission.

title: STOCKS IN LONDON DRIFT DOWNWARD
Miss Iowa, the Black Girl From Queens
description: ALGONA, IowaCheryl Browne, who jokingly calls herself the girl who came to dinner, came to this small northwest Iowa town over the week end to let the locals get a glimpse of royalty Iowa style.

title: Heath's Other Side: A Gifted Musician
description: LONDON, June 29If Ed ward Heath had not become Prime Minister of Britain, in his own view, he really could have done well as a conduc tor.

title: COURT BACKS I.B.M. IN FORECLOSURE BID
description: A Federal judge refused yes terday to prevent the Inter national Business Machines Cor poration from foreclosing, if it wishes to, on $45million worth of installment payments on computers bought by the Levin Townsend Computer Corpora tion.

title: Cambodian Decision: Why President Acted
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 President Nixon's venture in to Cambodia is ending with proclamations of unprece dented military gain, but it was launched for the broader purpose of rescuing Cam bodia from sudden Corn mist domination and that purpose is still unrealized.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: All Hours Given in Eastern Standard Time

title: John W. Rawlings, 58, Dies; Commercial Photographer
description: John W. Rawlings, a fashion and commercial photographer, died Sunday of cancer at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 421 East 54th Street.

title: Steel Output Up a Bit
description: Steel production showed slight gain of 0.1 per cent last week, compared with output the week before, the American Iron and Steel Institute report ed yesterday.

title: Profits and Sales Set Records In Nine Months at A. C. Nielsen
description: A. C. Nielsen Company re ported yesterday in an unau dited statement for the nine months ended May 31, a record profit of $5,564,852, or $1.05 a share, This compares with $4, 924,055, or 93 cents a share, for the comparable 1969 period. Sales of services also reached a record of $78,92.1,221, up 7.8 per cent from $73,179,480 a year earlier.

title: 2 JUSTICES BACK A UNION OBJECTOR
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger and Justice William O. Douglas declared today that a worker may have a constitutional right to be a conscientious objector against union membership.

title: 2 Fronts in War to Aid Consumer: In Supermarkets Here and at World Parley
description: When Dr. Nunzio Rini, a retired surgeon, and his wife, a dermatologist, went shop ping at a Grand Union super market at 4768 Broadway the other day they discovered that the store had made available to them what some food retailers regard as the wave of the future  unit pricing.

title: Market Summary
description: Monday, June 29, 1970

title: Liston Stops Bloodied Wepner in 10th
description: JERSEY CITY, June 29In a bloody sacrifice that evoked more sympathy for the loser than prestige for the winner, Sonny Liston was awarded a 10thround knockout at the Jer sey City Armory tonight when Chuck Wepner was determined unfit to continue after nine rounds.

title: Officials Prepare Dates and Numbers for Draft Lottery Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)Selective Service offi cials began today stuffing 730 plastic capsules with dates and numbers that will determine the 1971 draft se quence of hundreds of thou sands of youths with 19th birthdays this year.

title: Fans Jam Exacta Windows and See Dead Heat as Aqueduct Opens
description: The debut of the Exacta, a bomb scare and a dead heal for first in the $36,700 Tremont Stakes turned racing's switch from Belmont to Aqueduct into a waiting game yesterday for 37,792 horseplayers and one detective.

title: Noncoal Mine Checks Slated
description: WELLS, Me., June 29 (UPI) Interior Secretary Walter J. Hickel said today that the na tion's underground noncoal mines will be inspected for health and safety hazards within the next 13 months. Federal inspectors will check 3,000 metal and nonmetal mines beginning July 31, Mr. Nickel said in a statement delivered here.

title: Samour Wins Over Hurdles In $88,000 French Event
description: PARIS, June 29  Mrs. Henri Seutet's gelding, Samour, won the $88,000 Grande Course de Haies d'Auteuil hurdles race today.

title: 2 Wounded in Gun Battle
description: CLEVELAND, June 29 (UPI) A police officer and a youth reportedly wearing a black na tionalist uniform were wounded today when a gunbattle broke out at what the authorities called a black nationalist re cruiting headquarters on the city's East Side.

title: Indications of Atomic Blast In Soviet Reported by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Indications of a new and fairly powerful Soviet under ground nuclear explosion bringing to 39 the possible num ber of such tests since the lim ited testban agreement in 1963 was announced today by the Atomic Energy Commission, two days after the test was presumed to have occurred.

title: Advertising: Bankers Rue the GiveAway
description: The current heavily adver tised premium war involving savings banks is making comparison shoppers out of depositors.

title: Screen: Draskovic's 'Horoscope' Bows at the Paris:First Feature Film by Yugoslav Director Boredom of Idle Young Provides Focal Point
description: "Horoscope" at the Paris Theater is the first feature film of Boro Draskovic, one of the young Yugoslav directors whose work was introduced here in screenings at the Museum of Modern Art last fall. Among recent Yugoslav film makers, Draskovic would seem to favor a relatively conservative, intellectually inclusive approach to filmsin the manner, say, of "Cahiers du Cinma" five years ago rather than in the manner of "Cahiers du Cinma" today. Because I share many of Draskovic's prejudices, and because he is a director of genuine ambition and considerable competence, I wish "Horoscope" were a better movie.Set in a minor rail-junction town near Yugoslavia's Adriatic-coast resorts, "Horoscope" concerns a group of aimless young men who mostly lie around in the hot sun all day at the railroad station restaurant. They relieve their boredom with acts of petty bravado and aimless horseplay, and by conning the holiday crowds of passengers making connections between trains.When a pretty blonde (Milean Dravic) arrives to operate the station's brand new kioskan unlikely concession specializing in newspapers, knives, Miss Dravic, and no visible customersone of the young men (Dragan Nikolic) swears, on a dare, that he will make her within a week. The manner and shifting motives of his assault provide the fiction upon which the film bases its preoccupations.Nothing about the story is dramatically necessary or thematically interesting. But at the same time, al the peripheral elements  the cruel games, the extensive anecdotes (particularly, a local wedding, full of folk custom and devoted to seven days of musical celebration and ritual blood-letting), compositional detail and visual symbolismreceive such elaborate and carefully programmatic treatment, that "Horoscope" suffers from a kind of gigantism of its rhetorical members.Some of those members, for example the wedding celebration, achieve a genuine intensity that from moment to moment almost carries the movie. Others at least excite admiration: among them, the ways in which Draskovic introduces the creatures and imitates the circular figure of the Zodiac to fulfill the suggestions of chance and repetition implicit in his title.But a world as patently constructed (half rock, half reptileaccording to several key images) as is the world of "Horoscope" provides too many clues and allows too little to the unaided imagination. It continually points toward significance but never really makes meaning, and its action ultimately fades into a violent melodrama of easy irony and pointless pathos.

title: CAMBODIAN CHIEF LAUDS U.S. ACTION
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 29Premier Lon Nol said today that he thought United States military intervention in his na tion had brought favorable re sults and also expressed opti mism about the development of the Cambodian Army.

title: WEST POINT CURATOR FOUND DEAD AT HOME
description: CORNWALL, N. Y., June 29 Gerald C. Stowe, the curator of the museum at the United States Military Academy at West Point and an authority on the American Revolution, was found dead outside his home here today. The coroner ruled Mr. Stowe's death a sui cide, according to the State Police.

title: Lawyer for Patrolman in Gambling Trial Says Police Gave Arrest Immunity to Witnesses
description: The lawyer for a Bronx po liceman charged with lying about his dealings with gam blers accused the police and prosecution yesterday of grant ing policy operators immunity from arrest in return for testi fying against his client.

title: British Tighten Security In Ulster Following Riots
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 29The British Army an nounced a stepup in security measures today as Roman Cath olicProtestant feelings in Bel fast became increasingly bitter.

title: San Francisco Now 194
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 (UPI)  The city of the cable car celebrated its 194th birth day today. Celebrations began yesterday and carried over into today when an anniversary mass was celebrated at Mis sion Dolores. During the ceremonies, a wreath was placed at the grave of Lieut. Jose Mo raga first commandant of the Presidio. Yesterday, a wreath was placed at the statue of Junipero Serra, whose repre sentative, Francisco Palou, cel ebrated the first mass at the mission 194 years ago.

title: JURY IMPANELED ON JACKSON STATE
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 29 A Federal judge impaneled a special grand jury today to in vestigate the shooting of Ne groes at Jackson State College last month by members of the State Highway Patrol.

title: Obituary for the Surtax
description: The surtax on personal and corporate income expires tonight. It deserves an obituary notice, since it will certainly be missedespecially when the Nixon Admin istration calculates the deficit that is looming for the fiscal year 1971, which starts tomorrow, and for fiscal 1972 as well.

title: U.S. SUPREME COURT CONTINUES PLOT CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Evidently divided, the Su preme Court called today for new round of argument on ef forts to prosecute 11 New York Negroes on charges of plotting to paralyze and overthrow the state government.

title: Alcoa Line Will Move
description: MOBILE, Ala., June 29 (UPI) the Alcoa Steamship Com pany will move its headquar ters from New York to Mobile, G. C. Halstead, president of the company, announced today. The line is a wholly owned sub sidiary of the Aluminum Com pany of America.

title: American Airlines Given Right To Apply for Australian Route
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 29  American Airlines has been awarded the right to apply for three flights a week to Australia under a new agreement be tween the Australian and United States Governments on air services across the south ern Pacific.

title: Koch Bids U.S. Act Against Polluters Here; Prosecutors and state Aides Cite Steps Taken
description: Representative Edward I. Koch, Democrat of Manhattan, asked Federal prosecutors here yesterday to bring charges against ten companies he de scribed as major polluters of New York City waterways.

title: Hoerner Rejoins Phillies
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 29 (UPI)  Joe Hoerner, relief pitcher for the Philadelphia Phillies, who suffered a spasm of the heart muscle yesterday, has rejoined the club and is ready for duty, the Phillies announced today. Hoerner suf fered the spasm while pitching to Richie Allen in the second game of a doubleheader with the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: Gleason to Wed Saturday
description: MIAMI, June 29 (AP)Jackie Gleason will marry Beverly McKittrick Saturday in Ash ford, England, a spokesman for the comedian said here today. Mr. Gleason received a New York State divorce last week from his wife of 34 years.

title: Rent Control Recast
description: The one thing that can be said with assurance about the revisions in rent control voted by the City Council is that they will make only a modest con tribution to ending building abandonment and decay. But, viewed in the light of more than two decades of official timidity and evasiveness on this emotion laden issue, the willingness of 27 Councilmen authorize any basic relaxation in the overtight rent curbs carried over from World War II represents substantial advance toward equity and civic respon sibility.

title: RAIL STOCKS LEAD DROP ON BIG BOARD
description: Stock prices observed a bear market tradition yesterday. They sagged on Blue Monday. Glamour and rail issues were hit hardest.

title: PANEL PROPOSES BROAD REVISIONS IN MEDICAL CARE
description: WASHINGTON, June 29A highlevel study group, ap pointed a year ago to advise the Secretary of Health, Edu cation and Welfare on what to do about the Medicaid pro gram, has concluded there must be sweeping changes in the entire American health care system.

title: Moiseyev Dancers Open At the Met Next Tuesday
description: The Moiseyev Dance Com pany will present three new numbers during its engage ment at the Metropolitan Opera House from next Tues day through July 25. They are Sicilian Tarantella, Dance of the Buffoons to music by RimskyKorsakov and an Ar gentine Gaucho dance.

title: Air Force Offer to Split C5A Claim Is Reported
description: A House committee released testimony yesterday in which the Air Force suggested that the best solution to its $600 million dispute with the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation over the C5A cargo jet might be for the Government to pay up to half the company's claim.

title: 6 North Koreans Are Killed After Their Boat Is Seized
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 29  The Defense Ministry said North Korean agents who re portedly jumped overboard from a highspeed espionage vessel captured by South Korean coast guard units early today were killed in a gunfight on a nearby island this afternoon.

title: Deepening Crisis in Ulster
description: The situation in Northern Ireland is more dangerous now than it was last August, even if the violence between Catholic and Protestant has not yet claimed quite so many lives. In this crisis it must be a prime objective of Major ChichesterClark's Government to dispense justice evenhandedly.

title: Australia Accepts 2 Czechs
description: BRISBANE, Australia, June 29 (Reuters)Two young Czech refugees have found a home in Brisbane. Karel Cerny, 24 years old, and Miroslav Hanvi, 23, escaped across the Austrian border last September.

title: Sweden Plans to Establish Permanent Hanoi Mission
description: STOCKHOLM, June 29 (UPI) Sweden will open a perma nent diplomatic mission in Hanoi next month to handle in creased relations with North Vietnam, the Government an nounced today.

title: Iranian Expatriates Urged to Return
description: TEHERAN, Iran, June 29  The Iranian Government is In the midst of a campaign to attract back home intellectuals and other highly qualified Iranians who are abroad for political reasons.

title: DuPre, Reiner Advance In Junior Tennis Here
description: Eight topseeded players, in cluding Pat DuPre of Birming ham, Ala., No. 1, advanced yes terday as play becan in the 16 yearsandunder division of the annual North Atlantic junior tennis championships at Colum bia's Baker Field courts.

title: Con Ed Shutdown Attributable to Defective Pipe
description: The trouble at Consolidated Edison's Indian Point nuclear generating plant stems from a defect in a stainless steel pipe used to help keep the reactor cool.

title: A LongTime Champion of the Consumer
description: Before Ralph Nader, there was Colston Estey Warne.

title: May Join Moore & Schley
description: Merger discussions are under way between Moore & Schley, Inc., and Dreyfus & Co., spokesmen for both New York Stock Exchange firms con firmed yesterday.

title: Bridge:
description: STOCKHOLM, June 29 European pairs dominated the standings after the first day play in the world pair championship here. With 48 deals completed of a sched uled 288, the leaders were Arne Persson and Einar Pyk of Stockholm, 4,568, a 61 per cent score; Niels Henriksen and Peter Lund of Arhus, Denmark, 4,450; Giuseppe Saulino and Mario Zanasi of La Spezia, Italy, 4,391, and Jean Besse and John Collings of Geneva, 4,357.

title: Vacancy at Allied Stores
description: The Allied Stores Corporation has announced the resignation of Robert Macht, as executive vice president for merchandis ing and as a director, for per sonal reasons related to a de sire to remain in Florida where he has resided since 1955.

title: N.L.R.B. Counsel Appointed
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The chairman of the National Labor Relations Board, Edward B. Miller, announced today the appointment of Patrick Henry Hardin, 29 years old, as his chief counsel. Mr. Hardin, Birmingham, Ala., native, has been attorney in charge for the New Orleans office of the Jus tice Department's civil rights division.

title: SPECIALISTS ADDED TO ATHENS CABINET
description: ATHENS, June 29Premier George Papadopottlos today en larged and shuffled the Cabinet of his armyhacked regime in a move that was viewed here as technical rather than political, as the appointees have predom inantly nonmilitary back grounds.

title: Talks May Be Decisive
description: CAIRO, June 29  President Nasser's talks in Moscow are expected to be decisive to the course of the ArabIsraeli con flict, either to pursue efforts for a political settlement or to increase military steps to com pel the Israelis to withdraw.

title: RARDIN REFUSES TO BAR DDT NOW
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Secretary of Agriculture Clif ford M. Hardin told the United States Court of Appeals today that he did not intend to suspend sales of DDT until he had decided whether to can cel various uses of the pesti cide.

title: Artful Lace For Shawls And Bikinis
description: Because Ernie Austin, a movie actor about to become a stage manager, has a brotherinlaw who is a Co lombian there is a new shop on Ninth Avenue between 57th and 58th Streets called Macramania.

title: Birth Control Curb Upheld
description: BOSTON, June 29 (AP)The Massachusetts Supreme Court unanimously upheld today the constitutionality of a state law making it a crime for doctors or druggists to furnish birth control drugs or devices to un married persons.

title: Mrs. King, Mrs. Court and Misses Casals and Durr Gain Wimbledon Semifinal
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 29The stands were buzzing in expectancy. It was hard to believe.

title: Electronics Show Tunes In to TV Tape
description: There's more them enough noise to cause headaches in the lower floors of the Amer icana and Statler Hilton Hotels. And the flashing and blinking psychedelic lights can castly create dizziness.

title: Senate Approves Increase Of $12Billion in Debt Ceiling
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate approved tonight a bill raising the temporary national debt ceiling to $395 billion, opening the way for the Government to borrow money it said it needed to pay its bills.

title: Excerpts From Speech by N.A.A.C.P. Head Calling Administration AntiNegro
description: CINCINNATI, June 29  Following are excerpts from the keynote address of Bishop Stephen G. Spottswood, chair man of the board of directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Col ored People, at the associa tion's annual convention here today:

title: Thousands of Italians Here Rally Against Ethnic Slurs
description: Tens of thousands of Italian Americans filled Columbus Cir cle yesterday afternoon for a communal outpouring of pride in the land of their forebears and outrage at the practice of equating Italians with criminals.

title: P.E.N. Session Opens in Seoul
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 29 Nearly 200 writers from 33 countries opened the 37th Inter national P.E.N. Congress here today to discuss Humor in LiteratureEast and West, as a factor in promoting interna tional understanding and co operation. The sixday meeting is the second P.E.N. Club Con gress held in Asia. The organi ?? met in Tokyo in 1957.

title: PRICES ADVANCE IN BOND MARKETS
description: Bond prices climbed again yesterday, nudging interest rates down still further from the peaks reached two weeks ago.

title: Shorter, Twice A.A.U. Victor, Is Rid of RunnerUp Complex
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 29  The loneliness of the longdistance runner is no more for Frank Short er, whose only record at Yale, he says, was for sec ondplace finishes.

title: A Correction
description: In yesterday's New York Times, an article inadvertently referred to the Horace E. Dodge Memorial race in Detroit for unlimited hydroplanes as the Gold Cup race. The Gold Cup rare will he held in San Diego on Sept. 26.

title: Fanny May Results for the Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 29Mortgage prices continued to drift lower at this week's auction, the Federal National Mort gage Association announced today.

title: Theater: The Devil's Disciple Given at Stratford
description: STRATFORD, Conn., June 29We all make mistakes, errors of judgment, failures in perception. Yesterday after noon in a bus on the way to the first performance of The Devil's Disciple given by the American Shakespeare Festi val Theater, I fell into a very natural error.

title: Mets Top Pirates, 32, as Clendenon's Sacrifice Fly Caps 2Run Rally in 9th
Diana Sands Is Arrested
description: ROCKFORD, Ill., June 29 (UPI)Diana Sands, the actress was arrested yesterday on charges of disorderly conduct and intoxication. The police said that Miss Sands, who is 35 years old and is playing the lead role in the Rockford College Summer Theater production of The Owl and The Pussycat, was arrested at the Sweden House Motel where she was staying. She remained in jail for three hours before posting $25 bond.

title: Diamond Crystal Salt Elects
description: Edward M. Dodd has been elected president and chief op erating officer of the Diamond Crystal Salt Company, St. Clair, Mich. He had been execu tive vice president since 1969 and before that was a corpo rate vice president and general manager of the packet products division.

title: New Commission Rates Are Sought by Big Board
description: The New York Stock Ex change has abandoned plans for any further volume dis counts on commission rates and would restrict the rate in creases on most small trans actions to 50 per cent under a plan to be submitted today to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: American Heritage's Head
description: Paul Gottlieb is the new president of the American Heritage Publishing Company, succeeding James Parton, who resigned early this month to join Encyclopaedia Britannica. Mr. Gottlieb, who is 35 years old, joined the company in 1962 and was named publisher of American Heritage, the hard cover magazine, last year.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
Military Court to Try Sihanouk in Absentia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, June 30 (AP) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, deposed Cambodian Chief of State, will be tried in absen tia July 3 before a military tribunal, a Cambodian Army spokesman said today. He declined to say what charges had been placed against Sihanouk, who has set up an exile regime in Peking. It was believed, however, that the charges would include treason.

title: TV Review
description: Liza Minnelli, who starred in her first television special last night, on the National Broadcasting Company, is so engaging and willing a per former that one feels posi tively caddish in finding her program less than memo rable. Rarely have more en ergy, enthusiasm and produc tion skill gone into a TV spe cial with such meager re sults.

title: LAST COMBAT UNIT OUT OF CAMBODIA AFTER 2 MONTHS
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 29  The last United States ground combat troops in Cam bodia scrambled back into the Central Highlands of South Vietnam this evening, ending two months of operations in Cambodia that, at the peak, had seen 18,000 American troops attacking Communist base and supply areas across the border.

title: Freedom: It Comes in All Sizes
description: What freedom means de pends a lot on who you are.

title: ROGERS SEES END OF ENEMY HAVEN
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 Secretary of State William P. Rogers warned North Vietnam today that it could not again count on a safe haven in Cam bodia despite the withdrawal of United States ground com bat forces from that country.

title: Public Offer Sought For Bob Foster Stock
description: A group of business men from Philadelphia and Wash ington, incorporated under the name of Bob Foster, Inc., and representing the light heavyweight boxing cham pion, announced yesterday they had filed a statement with the Securities and Ex change Commission seeking registration of 100,000 shares of common stock to be off ered for public sale at $4 a share.

title: Kitty Susan Stark Is Wed on Coast
description: SARATOGA, Calif., June 29 Miss Kitty Susan Stark, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Stark of New York, was mar ried here this evening to Lee Nicholas Price, son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Price of Bangkok, Thailand. The cere mony was performed by Rabbi Roger Herst at the Villa Montalvo.

title: Use of Child Behavior Drugs Studied
description: WASHINGTON, June 29A Federal agency and the chair man of a Congressional study of alleged invasions of privacy ordered separate investigations today into reports that perhaps as many as 10 per cent of the school children of Omaha, Neb., are taking prescribed behavior modification drugs.

title: TUGBOAT OPERATORS FORM ASSOCIATION
description: The formation of a new trade association for the port's tug and barge industry has been an nounced by Thomas E. Moran, chairman of the new group.

title: Kaman and Lockheed Agree
description: BLOOMFIELD, Conn., June 29 (UPI)The Kaman Corpora tion has completed an agree ment with the LockheedGeorgia Corporation amending its con tract to make flaps and spoil ers for the C5A cargo plane. Consequently, Kaman is with drawing its lawsuit against Lockheed that had been pend ing in the Federal Court in New Haven.

title: CON ED PLANT OUT REST OF SUMMER; POWER TO BE LOW
description: Consolidated Edison's nuclear power generating plant at In dian Point, which is capable of meeting the electrical needs of 260,000 families, will be out of service for the rest of the sum mer, the utility company an nounced yesterday.

title: LOSS IS REPORTED BY DEAN WITTER
description: Dean Witter & Co., the big investment banking and broker age firm, announced yesterday a loss for its third fiscal quar ter ended May 31 and a profit for the ninemonth period.

title: PARENTS GROUP ASKS SWIFT END OF WAR
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  Parents for Peace urged Presi dent Nixon today to end the war in Southeast Asia swiftly or, the group warned, the na tion will face irreparable harm to society.

title: In Accord With RCA
description: It took Cushman & Wake field, Inc., just one week to find a new merger partner. A week ago, it was announced that the Allied Maintenance Corporation and Cushman &I Wakefield had ended merger, talks because of tax consid erations that appear insoluble.

title: Welfare Chiefs Tell Critics: City's Relief Roll Increase Is Matched Elsewhere
description: The city's two top public welfare chiefs have declared that the rise in New York City's relief rolls during the nineteensixties had been par alleled by similar rises in Los Angeles and some other urban centers. They sought to rebut crisicism of administration here.

title: ERIC KAHLER, 84, HISTORIAN, DEAD
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 29 Eric Kahler, a cultural historian who had taught at universities here and abroad, died yester day at Princeton Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 1 Evelyn Place.

title: Griffith, Tiger Begin Drills For Garden Bout July 15
description: Emile Grifith, former middle weight and welterweight cham pion, started two weeks of training at Madison Square Garden's Felt Forum yesterday. He sparred two rounds apiece with Henry Castro, a middle weight, and Miguel Barreto, a welterweight, in preparation for his July 15 Garden bout with Dick Tiger.

title: Bergdorf Goodman Names 3 to Executive Positions
description: Three executive appoint ments have been announced by Bergdorf Goodman. Sigmund Waldman, assistant controller, has also been named budget di rector. Wilbert Shore, formerly with Abraham & Straus, has been named director of control operations for Bergdorf. Nelson Kaye, formerly vice president of Datapax Corporation, has been appointed Bergdorf's di rector of information systems.

title: BLACK CONTRACTORS OPPOSE LABOR AIDE
description: WASHINGTON, June 29An organization of black contrac tors announced today that would oppose the choice of Malcolm R. Lovell Jr., the De partment of Labor's manpower administrator, to replace Arnold R. Weber as Assistant Secretary of Labor when Mr. Weber joins the staff of the Office of Man agement and Budget.

title: Mayor Meets Kosygin
description: MOSCOW, June 29 (Reuters) Walter Washington, the may or of Washington, D. C., today met Soviet Premier Alexsei N. Kosygin The meeting came as a surprise. No details of the dis cussion were disclosed.

title: Iakovos Seeking to Americanize His Orthodox Church
description: Archbishop Iakovos, the Greek Orthodox Primate of North and South America, de clared yesterday that his church must be granted more autonomy by the Ecumenical Patriarchate in Istanbul if it is to thrive in an American con text.

title: Williamsburg Violence Reflects Tension in Area
description: Penn Street in the Williams burg section of Brooklyn was the scene of street fighting on Sunday night as Hasidic Jews and blacks threw bottles and insults at one another until the police took control.

title: New York World's Fair Hit Turns Into St. Louis Fiasco
description: ST. LOUISAfter the Car dinals won a recent game with a timely hit by their Spanish  speaking second baseman, Julian Javier, sev eral jubilant fans were walk ing past a vacant building near the stadium.

title: Saigon's Loss Put at 866
description: SAIGON, June 29 (UPI) South Vietnam's losses in the Cambodian operation were placed today at 866 killed and 3,724 wounded. The Vietnamese Communist losses were put at 14,488 killed and 1,427 captured.

title: Books of The Times
description: Daniel Callahan  director of the Insti tute of Society, Ethics and the Life Sciences, former executive editor of Com monweal magazine, and a Doctor of Phi losophy from Harvardbegan this book four years ago with the intention of de fending, with some modifications, the tra ditional Western prohibition against abor tion. His formidable researches caused to change his mind. He now believes that the State has no right to re fuse an abortion to a woman who wants one, and he proposes permissive legislation to that effect.

title: Major League Baseball
description: Tuesday, June 30, 1970

title: BASEBALL SIGNIUGS
description: NATIONAL LEAGUE

title: U.S. College Track Victor
description: MEXICO CITY, June 29 (AP) Mount San Antonio College of Walnut, Calif., took first place among 18 tears competing in the fifth international track and field meet sponsored by the Na tional Mexican Youth Institute. The junior college was the only United States entry in the event that ended yesterday.

title: Conforte and Eyler Share Qualifying Lead With 76's
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., June 29 Robert Conforte of Massape qua High School scored a 38, 3876 and Chris Eyler of Lindenhurst High School carded a 37, 39,76 to share the lead in the sectional qualifying round of the Metropolitan Golf Asso ciation's junior and boys cham pionships.
